('76', 0, 4, 6, 245) 2. SPEECH AT KATHIAWAR POLITICAL CONFERENCE, RAJKOT 1
('76', 0, 5, 7, 299) May 31, 1939 It is growing upon me every day that we shall have to lower our key, our demand for full responsible government will have to remain in abeyance for some time.
('76', 0, 5, 8, 471) Not that we are not entitled to it, but it is clear to me that we have not the will for it, we are not ready to pay the price.
('76', 0, 5, 9, 598) There is an awakening, but it is not the awakening of active non violence of the brave.
('76', 0, 5, 10, 686) Not that I have suddenly realized this point.
('76', 0, 5, 11, 732) The realization was there, the will to face the conclusion was not there, and I am reaping the fruit of that weakness of the will.
('76', 0, 5, 12, 863) I have been weak willed ever since Bardoli onwards, but my co workers deluded themselves into the belief that we had attained the requisite non violence and I shared their delusion.
('76', 0, 5, 13, 1045) I do not repent of this.
('76', 0, 5, 14, 1070) It is likely that if we had acted otherwise there would not have been the awakening we see today.
('76', 0, 5, 15, 1168) But that seems to lead one to a rather dreadful conclusion, viz., that compromise with non violence was necessary for a widespread awakening !
('76', 0, 5, 16, 1311) But that is not the conclusion.
('76', 0, 5, 17, 1343) The conclusion is that God chooses as his instruments the humblest and weakest of His creatures to fulfil Him self.
('76', 0, 5, 18, 1459) Today with [this] great realization I would not lead another Dandi March.
('76', 0, 5, 19, 1533) The breach of the salt laws was a perfect proposition, but violence of the mind had crept in almost from the beginning.
('76', 0, 5, 20, 1653) All that we had learnt then was that it was expedient to refrain from the

('76', 1, 0, 1, 1857) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 1, 1, 2, 1897) use of physical violence.
('76', 1, 1, 3, 1923) This was the non violence of the calculating Bania, not of the brave Kshatriya.
('76', 1, 1, 4, 2003) This non violence of the calculating Bania has not, could not have, carried us far.
('76', 1, 1, 5, 2087) It could not possibly avail to win and retain swaraj, to win over our opponent who believed in the use of arms.
('76', 1, 1, 6, 2199) Today I sense violence everywhere, smell it inside and outside Congress ranks.
('76', 1, 1, 7, 2278) In 1921 even goonda element outside the Congress was more or less under our control.
('76', 1, 1, 8, 2363) Perfect non violence is difficult.
('76', 1, 1, 9, 2398) It admits no weakness.
('76', 1, 1, 10, 2421) It made me take the false step of approaching the Viceroy in order to end my fast.
('76', 1, 1, 11, 2504) It was unpardonable on the part of a general who claims to derive his whole strength from God.
('76', 1, 1, 12, 2599) But God gave me that courage to retrieve the blunder, and we are all the stronger and purer for it.
('76', 1, 1, 13, 2699) I am not tired of repeating again and again that we should be non violent in thought and word and deed.
('76', 1, 1, 14, 2803) We had been saying so, but there was no emphasis on the first of these.
('76', 1, 1, 15, 2875) A dissolute character is more dissolute in thought than in deed.
('76', 1, 1, 16, 2940) And the same is true of vio lence.
('76', 1, 1, 17, 2975) Our violence in word and deed is but a feeble echo of the surging violence of thought in us.
('76', 1, 1, 18, 3068) Are you prepared to go with me so far?
('76', 1, 1, 19, 3107) Does all that I say carry conviction?
('76', 1, 1, 20, 3145) If so, violence should be eschewed from the innermost of our thoughts.
('76', 1, 1, 21, 3216) But if you cannot go with me, do go your own way.
('76', 1, 1, 22, 3266) If you can reach your goal in any other way, do so by all means.
('76', 1, 1, 23, 3331) You will deserve my congratulations.
('76', 1, 1, 24, 3368) For I cannot in any case stand cowar dice.
('76', 1, 1, 25, 3411) Let no one say when I am gone that I taught the people to be cowards.
('76', 1, 1, 26, 3481) If you think my ahimsa amounts to that, or leads you to that, you should reject it without hesitation.
('76', 1, 1, 27, 3584) I would far rather that you died bravely dealing a blow and receiving a blow than died in abject terror.
('76', 1, 1, 28, 3689) If the ahimsa of my dream is impossible, you can reject the creed rather than carry on the pretence of non violence.
('76', 1, 1, 29, 3806) Fleeing from battle—palayanam—is cowardice, and unworthy of a warrior.
('76', 1, 1, 30, 3877) An armed fighter is known to have sought fresh arms as soon as he loses those in his possession or they lose their efficacy.
('76', 1, 1, 31, 4002) He leaves the battle to get them.
('76', 1, 1, 32, 4036) A non violent warrior knows no leaving the battle.
('76', 1, 1, 33, 4087) He rushes into the mouth of himsa, never even once har bouring an evil thought.
('76', 1, 1, 34, 4167) If this ahimsa seems to you to be impossible, let us be honest with ourselves and say so, and give it up.
('76', 1, 1, 35, 4273) For me there is no laying down arms.
('76', 1, 1, 36, 4310) I cannot do so.
('76', 1, 1, 37, 4326) I am trying to be the warrior of my description and, if God wills, I may be that during this life.
('76', 1, 1, 38, 4425) Such a warrior can fight single handed.
('76', 2, 0, 1, 4465) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 3
('76', 2, 1, 2, 4507) Let me give a bit of my own experience in South Africa.
('76', 2, 1, 3, 4563) When thousands joined the movements, I had not spoken to them, not even seen them.
('76', 2, 1, 4, 4646) Papers they could not read.
('76', 2, 1, 5, 4674) My heart was working in unison with them.
('76', 2, 1, 6, 4716) Living faith is all that is necessary.
('76', 2, 1, 7, 4755) It is evident that I have not the capacity today to inspire faith in the millions.
('76', 2, 1, 8, 4838) This needs superior living faith in non violence and in God.
('76', 2, 1, 9, 4899) This faith is self acting, and illumines man’s life more and more every day.
('76', 2, 1, 10, 4976) In the pursuit of my earnest research I may seem to act strangely.
('76', 2, 1, 11, 5043) I should not grumble if everyone left me in the honesty of his conviction.
('76', 2, 1, 12, 5118) Let no one stick to me in the blind faith that something will happen.
('76', 2, 1, 13, 5188) Such [faith] will hinder rather than help the cause.
('76', 2, 1, 14, 5241) Harijan, 17 6 1939
('76', 2, 2, 15, 5260) 3. TALK WITH A MUSLIM FRIEND 1
('76', 2, 3, 16, 5291) [May 31, 1939] 2
('76', 2, 4, 17, 5308) I have been talking of non violence these 20 years but I have made unlawful compromises with myself.
('76', 2, 4, 18, 5409) My mind goes back to the days of Khilafat agitation.
('76', 2, 4, 19, 5462) I had the friendship of thousands of Mus lims then.
('76', 2, 4, 20, 5514) When at a meeting of the Muslim League before 1920 I asked for the supreme sacrifice, two or three names were given by Khwaja Saheb Abdul Majid, but I believed that many would come forward at the right time.
('76', 2, 4, 21, 5722) And they did.
('76', 2, 4, 22, 5736) But looking back upon those times I see that I compromised non violence.
('76', 2, 4, 23, 5809) I was satisfied with mere abstention from physical violence.
('76', 2, 5, 24, 5870) The fact is I have never placed unadulterated ahimsa before the country.
('76', 2, 5, 25, 5943) If I had done so, there would have been complete Hindu Muslim unity.
('76', 2, 5, 26, 6012) No doubt I kept on saying there would be no swaraj without Hindu Muslim unity, but I should have seen that there was no Hindu Muslim unity because there was not that insistence on unadul terated ahimsa on the part of all, whether Hindu or Muslim.
('76', 2, 5, 27, 6259) No wonder my new technique puzzles many.
('76', 2, 5, 28, 6300) But I must go on.
('76', 2, 5, 29, 6318) If I am right, the puzzles will be solved.
('76', 2, 5, 30, 6361) Harijan, 17 6 1939

('76', 3, 10, 10, 7209) 6. LETTER TO NRISINHPRASAD K. BHATT
('76', 3, 11, 11, 7245) ON THE TRAIN, June 1, 1939
('76', 3, 12, 12, 7272) BHAI NANABHAI, I wanted to write to you as soon as I got your wire, but could not do so.
('76', 3, 12, 13, 7361) Now I am writing this in the train.
('76', 3, 12, 14, 7397) The path of those who worship ahimsa under all circumstances is straight.
('76', 3, 12, 15, 7471) Such a person will not indulge in fighting even in self defence.
('76', 3, 12, 16, 7536) But he who does not have that strength has but to run away—that is, play the coward—if he does not attack the attacker.
('76', 3, 12, 17, 7656) Cowardice is worse than violence because cowards can never be non violent.
('76', 3, 12, 18, 7731) So such people should learn to
('76', 3, 13, 19, 7762) 1 According to the source, the third session of the Conference was held some time in “May, 1939”.
('76', 3, 13, 20, 7860) 2 By which Gandhiji travelled to Bombay.
('76', 4, 0, 1, 7901) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 5
('76', 4, 1, 2, 7943) defend themselves.
('76', 4, 1, 3, 7962) Under its constitution members of the Parishad 1
('76', 4, 2, 4, 8011) can be said to be wedded to non violence.
('76', 4, 2, 5, 8053) But here such ahimsa is of no use.
('76', 4, 2, 6, 8088) A person who has full faith in non violence should be a thousand times more fearless than an armed man.
('76', 4, 2, 7, 8192) Such fearlessness is not gained by joining some organization.
('76', 4, 2, 8, 8254) Hence every member of the Parishad should find an independent way for himself.
('76', 4, 2, 9, 8333) It is the duty of every believer in ahimsa to see that cowardice is not propagated in the name of non violence.
('76', 4, 2, 10, 8445) So we must frankly tell the common people that we are unable to guide them.
('76', 4, 2, 11, 8521) It is not proper that they should look to us.
('76', 4, 2, 12, 8567) If they can independently think of non violent ways they will not ask us and if they do ask us we should give them only one guidance that they should not be weak under any circumstances.
('76', 4, 2, 13, 8754) They should learn to deal with the attacker.
('76', 4, 2, 14, 8799) It is possible that if they observe restraint and if a handful of us can manifest true ahimsa, the attacker too may turn to ahimsa.
('76', 4, 2, 15, 8931) Please explain all this to all our workers there.
('76', 4, 2, 16, 8981) The talk of secret settlement that is going on in Bhavnagar is harmful.
('76', 4, 2, 17, 9053) Settlement can be with straightforward people.
('76', 4, 2, 18, 9100) Here there is nothing of the sort.

('76', 4, 3, 21, 9220) 7. DISCUSSION WITH TRAVANCORE STATE CONGRESS DEPUTATION 1
('76', 4, 4, 22, 9278) ON THE TRAIN, [June 1, 1993] 2
('76', 4, 5, 23, 9309) QUESTION: What about swaraj that we have been fighting for?
('76', 4, 5, 24, 9369) How does Gandhiji’s faith in non violence burning brighter than ever help those who want swaraj here and now?
('76', 4, 5, 25, 9479) Does not the emphasis on non violence of his conception make of swaraj a very remote vision hardly to be fulfilled?
('76', 4, 6, 26, 9595) GANDHIJI: For me, it is true, as I have often declared, ahimsa comes before swaraj.
('76', 4, 6, 27, 9679) I would not care to get power through anarchy and red ruin, among other things, because I want freedom and power even for the least among the people.
('76', 4, 6, 28, 9829) This can only be when freedom is won

('76', 5, 1, 2, 10221) through non violence.
('76', 5, 1, 3, 10243) In the other case the weak must go to the wall, only the physically strong and fit will remain to seize and enjoy power.
('76', 5, 1, 4, 10364) But you too cannot help putting ahimsa before everything else if you really mean business.
('76', 5, 1, 5, 10455) Ahimsa must be placed before everything else while it is professed.
('76', 5, 1, 6, 10523) Then alone it becomes irresistible.
('76', 5, 1, 7, 10559) Otherwise it will only be an empty hulk, a thing without potency or power.
('76', 5, 1, 8, 10634) A soldier fights with an irresistible strength when he has blown up his bridges, burnt his boats.
('76', 5, 1, 9, 10732) Even so it is with a soldier of ahimsa.
('76', 5, 2, 10, 10772) Q. But how will this lowering of the pitch work out in action?
('76', 5, 2, 11, 10835) How will it help us in attaining our goal of responsible government?
('76', 5, 3, 12, 10904) G. Today when we talk of responsible government, it frightens the States authorities.
('76', 5, 3, 13, 10990) The Paramount Power too do not like it.
('76', 5, 3, 14, 11030) They think it will result in red ruin and anarchy.
('76', 5, 3, 15, 11081) The argument is unsound but let us give them credit for honesty.
('76', 5, 3, 16, 11146) If you follow my advice, therefore, you will say, ‘We, for the time being, forget swaraj.
('76', 5, 3, 17, 11236) We shall fight to vindicate the elementary rights of the people, to remove corruption.’ In short, you will concentrate your attention on details of administration.
('76', 5, 3, 18, 11400) The auth orities won’t be frightened, and it will give you the substance of responsible government.
('76', 5, 3, 19, 11500) That has been the history of all my work in India.
('76', 5, 3, 20, 11551) If I had only talked of swaraj, I would have come a cropper.
('76', 5, 3, 21, 11612) By attacking details we have advanced from strength to strength.
('76', 5, 3, 22, 11677) What did I do at the time of the Dandi March?
('76', 5, 3, 23, 11723) I reduced our demand for complete independence to my eleven points.
('76', 5, 3, 24, 11791) 1 Motilalji was at first angry with me.“What do you mean by lowering the flag like this?” he said.
('76', 5, 3, 25, 11890) But he soon saw that if those points were con ceded, indepen dence would stand knocking at our door.
('76', 5, 3, 26, 11991) Let me explain to you the working of my mind.
('76', 5, 3, 27, 12037) As I have already told you, I had thought that responsible government in the States was within easy reach.
('76', 5, 3, 28, 12144) We have now found that we can’t at once take the masses with us along non violent lines.
('76', 5, 3, 29, 12233) You say that violence is committed by a few hooligans only; but capacity to obtain non violent swaraj presupposes capacity on our part to control the hooli gans too as we temporarily did during the non co operation days.
('76', 5, 3, 30, 12454) If you had complete control over the forces of violence and were ready to carry on the fight with your back to the wall in defiance of the Paramount Power, looking neither to me nor to the Congress outside

('76', 6, 1, 5, 12924) Nor, so far as I know, is it the case anywhere else in India.

('76', 6, 2, 8, 13105) 8. INTERVIEW TO DEPUTATION OF VICTUALLERS ’ ASSOCIATION 1
('76', 6, 3, 9, 13163) BOMBAY [June 2, 1939] 2
('76', 6, 4, 10, 13187) Gandhiji congratulated them on the restrained language of their represen tation.
('76', 6, 4, 11, 13268) They had every right to go to him, as he was specially attached to the Parsis [He said:] What I gather from your representation is that far from being opposed in principle to prohibition, you have pointed out the difficulties and hardships involved.
('76', 6, 4, 12, 13518) But I am afraid you have come to the wrong man.
('76', 6, 4, 13, 13566) I never interfere with the work of the Ministries.
('76', 6, 4, 14, 13617) But on prohibition I am keener even than the Ministers.
('76', 6, 4, 15, 13673) I confess I have not studied the economic aspect of the question.
('76', 6, 4, 16, 13739) With me it is a creed and I would, if I could, fulfil it at any cost.
('76', 6, 4, 17, 13809) If I had the administration in my own hands, I should study all the figures you have given.
('76', 6, 4, 18, 13901) I am sure the Ministers have studied them, and you should approach them.
('76', 6, 4, 19, 13974) They would gladly discuss the whole question with you and try to show the way out the difficulties you have pointed out.
('76', 6, 5, 20, 14095) 1 This and the following item are extracted from “The Anti Prohibition Deputations” by Mahadev Desai, who explains that “the first deputation consisted of representatives of toddy, country liquor and foreign liquor dealers”.
('76', 6, 5, 21, 14320) Their representation addressed itself mainly to the hardships and sufferings that would be the result of several thousand Parsi families being thrown out of employment; their being reduced to poverty and even bankruptcy; illicit sales and clandestine breaches of the law; impossibility of disposing of 50 to 60 lakhs of rupees worth of material by August 1; the loss on having to dispose of costly furniture.
('76', 6, 5, 22, 14729) The Bombay chronicle, 3 6 1939, reports that the deputation, which met Gandhiji in the afternoon, was led by M. B. Baria.
('76', 6, 5, 23, 14851) It included R. R. Patel, R. D. Shroff, Phirozeshaw Shroff, J. D. Crawford and M. M. Surve.
('76', 6, 5, 24, 14942) 2 From The Bombay Chronicle, 3 6 1939; also Gandhi—1915–1948
('76', 7, 0, 1, 15003) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 7, 1, 2, 15043) They also raised the question of short notice.
('76', 7, 1, 3, 15090) The Congress Election Mani festo, 1 they said, did not contain this programme, and the decision to introduce it in August had come upon them as a bolt from the blue.
('76', 7, 1, 4, 15256) In reply to this Gandhiji said: The Congress Election Manifesto is principally a political docu ment and naturally does not contain the prohibition programme.
('76', 7, 1, 5, 15415) But prohibition has been in the forefront of the Congress programme since 1920. With me it has been a passion ever since my close contact with the Indian immigrants in South Africa and also with the South Africans.
('76', 7, 1, 6, 15630) I have seen with my own eyes the terrible scourge drink can be.
('76', 7, 1, 7, 15694) It has ruined people morally, physically, economically and it has destroyed the sanctity and happiness of the home.
('76', 7, 1, 8, 15810) My heart bleeds as I think of the disaster that comes in its wake and I have really pined for the immediate introduction of prohibition.
('76', 7, 1, 9, 15947) When the Congress decided to accept offices, I thought it had a golden opportunity to introduce it at once, but it was the Ministers who pleaded for fixing the time limit at three years.
('76', 7, 1, 10, 16134) To my mind, therefore, there is no question of short notice.
('76', 7, 1, 11, 16195) It is coming several years too late.
('76', 7, 1, 12, 16232) Hundreds and thousands of women have in the past picketed liquor shops, suffered insults and assaults.
('76', 7, 1, 13, 16335) In one case a woman volunteer was so hit on the forehead that the evil effect still persists.
('76', 7, 1, 14, 16429) There was no com pulsion.
('76', 7, 1, 15, 16455) It was all peaceful persuasion, and it had succeeded so remar kably that in some provinces the excise revenue was almost reduced to zero.
('76', 7, 1, 16, 16593) As for its effects here in India I would like you to study the condition of workmen in factories, and I would like to tell you also the boon prohibition has been to them in Ahmedabad.
('76', 7, 2, 17, 16777) One of the gentlemen in the deputation said that 12 to 15 thousand tappers would be adversely affected and that fresh toddy had great medicinal value.
('76', 7, 2, 18, 16928) It is nira you are referring to.
('76', 7, 2, 19, 16961) For I agree it is a refreshing drink, and we make gur out of it.
('76', 7, 3, 20, 17026) If the tappers took to tapping the juice for gur making, there was no question of their unemployment.
('76', 7, 3, 21, 17128) In Bengal tons of gur was prepared from nira and in South India arrack was prepared from gur made out of fresh juice.
('76', 7, 4, 22, 17246) But the gentleman maintained that it was impossible to draw fresh nira from a tree more than ten times during a season and that gur was not a feasible proposition.
('76', 7, 4, 23, 17410) Gandhiji said that the evidence in his possession was to the contrary.
('76', 7, 4, 24, 17481) He would, however, inquire.
('76', 7, 4, 25, 17509) Harijan, 10 6 1939

('76', 8, 1, 2, 17718) 9. INTERVIEW TO PARSI DEPUTATION 1
('76', 8, 2, 3, 17753) [June 2, 1939] 2
('76', 8, 3, 4, 17770) The gravamen of their charge was that the prohibition policy was tantamount to coercion as the community had for centuries indulged in drink without being any the worse for it.
('76', 8, 3, 5, 17947) There was the argument of dislocation of trade and financial and economic structure of the province, of the hardships it would cause to traders and tappers, and the interference with the religious rites of the people.
('76', 8, 3, 6, 18165) They said they also resented the distinction between Asiatics and non Asiatics, and even suggested that not only the Parsis but Mussalmans and Hindus were also opposed to the policy!
('76', 8, 4, 7, 18348) Some of the gentlemen have been friends of Gandhiji for years, especially Sir Cowasji.
('76', 8, 4, 8, 18435) And so he was the most vehement in his attack, but the utmost friendliness prevailed during the discussion.
('76', 8, 5, 9, 18543) COWASJI: Drunkenness is bad, not drink.
('76', 8, 5, 10, 18583) And for the sake of a few who drink, why penalize the whole community?
('76', 8, 5, 11, 18654) I take two or three glasses of sherry every day and I know hundreds of others who talk of prohibition but who do drink and will do so in spite of prohibition.
('76', 8, 6, 12, 18813) There was obvious defiance in his voice, but Gandhiji disarmed it by ultimately reminding Sir Cowasji how he had helped him (Gandhiji) in the past at various junctures, and how he expected him to stand by him at this!
('76', 8, 7, 13, 19031) Sir Cowasji had a hearty laugh.
('76', 8, 8, 14, 19063) Mr. Khareghat, the veteran temperance reformer who, said Gandhiji, reminded him of Dadabhai by his silvery beard, entered a curiuos plea :
('76', 8, 9, 15, 19202) I do not drink, nor am I dealer in drinks.
('76', 8, 9, 16, 19245) But this policy will ruin thousands, and I want you to realize your error and do as you did in Rajkot.
('76', 8, 9, 17, 19348) I would then honour you with all my heart.
('76', 8, 9, 18, 19391) According to our religion it is the duty of the host to offer the guest good bread and good wine.
('76', 8, 10, 19, 19489) GANDHIJI: But it must be unfermented wine.
('76', 8, 10, 20, 19532) Whatever it may be, one wonders how this can be a religious duty at all!
('76', 8, 10, 21, 19605) What would a poor man do?
('76', 8, 10, 22, 19631) SAKLATWALA: I do not drink, and thank God I have enough property to enable me to pay the property tax.
('76', 8, 10, 23, 19734) But why should others regulate my life?

('76', 10, 7, 17, 23703) 11. STATEMENT ON TRAVANCORE 2
('76', 10, 8, 18, 23733) BOMBAY June 4, 1939 I have had prolonged conversations 3 with Shri Pattom Thanu Pillai, Shri Verghese and Shri J. Philipose over the situation in Travan core.
('76', 10, 8, 19, 23892) My rich experiences in Rajkot show me that civil disobedience in Travancore was suspended at the right time.
('76', 10, 8, 20, 24001) The Rajkot recantation teaches me that it is not enough to have with drawn the charges
('76', 10, 9, 21, 24088) 1 This was in response to a telegram from Sir Sayed Raza Ali, received on June 3, 1939, which read: “Indians meeting Johannesburg tomorrow to consider civil resistance.
('76', 10, 9, 22, 24257) Am advising them against it as premature India too weak to help them.
('76', 10, 9, 23, 24327) Please cable your advice Congress care Gabaco Johannesburg.” 2 In Harijan, this appeared under the title “New Technique in Action”.

('76', 11, 0, 1, 24629) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 11, 1, 2, 24670) against Sir C. P. Ramaswami Iyer.
('76', 11, 1, 3, 24704) But it is necessary to recognize that Travancoreans have not only to reckon with the Maharaja, but also with his Dewan.
('76', 11, 1, 4, 24824) I also observe that several Travan corean critics have asserted that suspension has led to greater repression.
('76', 11, 1, 5, 24935) These critics do not know that suspension was not advised in order to avoid repression, nor even in expectation of its being stopped.
('76', 11, 1, 6, 25069) It was advised in order to avoid popular violence, no matter how caused or by whom instigated, if it was instigated.
('76', 11, 1, 7, 25186) It was also advised in order to avoid brutalization of human nature.
('76', 11, 1, 8, 25255) These two objects may be said to have been attained in a fair measure.
('76', 11, 1, 9, 25326) It was also advised in order to pave the way for an honourable understanding with the authorities and to educate the people in the true way of ahimsa.
('76', 11, 1, 10, 25477) These objects have still to be worked for.
('76', 11, 1, 11, 25520) Here my new light, which I seem to see dimly, enables me to tender advice which, but for the light, I would perhaps not have been able to give with as much confidence as now.
('76', 11, 1, 12, 25695) I am convinced that direct negotiations should be opened with the authorities.
('76', 11, 1, 13, 25774) Hitherto the State Congress people have talked at the authorities and the latter at them.
('76', 11, 1, 14, 25864) The result has been a widening of the gulf between the two.
('76', 11, 1, 15, 25924) It would not do for a satyagrahi to argue that the approach must be mutual.
('76', 11, 1, 16, 26000) That assumes the existence of the spirit of satyagraha in the authorities, whereas satyagrahia is offered in respect of those who make no claim to be satyagrahis.
('76', 11, 1, 17, 26163) Hence the first and the last work of a satyagrahi is ever to seek an opportunity for an honourable approach.
('76', 11, 1, 18, 26272) Now this is impossible so long as the heart is steeled against a belief even in the possibility, let alone advisability, of such approach.
('76', 11, 1, 19, 26411) And hitherto the impossibility has been unquestion ably assumed.
('76', 11, 1, 20, 26476) I have been a tacit party to it.
('76', 11, 1, 21, 26509) I now know better.
('76', 11, 1, 22, 26528) If the leaders have active ahimsa in them, they must cultivate a belief in the perfect possibility and necessity of such approach.
('76', 11, 1, 23, 26659) And if they have that belief, the way will surely be open to them.
('76', 11, 1, 24, 26726) In my own person, it is well known, I have always acted on that principle.
('76', 11, 1, 25, 26801) In making such an approach it would be necessary to lower the key of our note.
('76', 11, 1, 26, 26880) Our aim must remain what it is, but we must be prepared to negotiate for less than the whole so long as it is unmistakably of the same kind and has in it inherent possibility of expansion.
('76', 11, 1, 27, 27069) I have found that nowhere, with the only exception of Aundh 1, are the Princes ready to part with
('76', 11, 2, 28, 27167) 1 The reformed Aundh constitution became law on January 21. It aimed at total transfer of power to the people.
('76', 12, 0, 1, 27278) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 13
('76', 12, 1, 2, 27321) all the power in favour of the people.
('76', 12, 1, 3, 27360) Nor is the Paramount Power anxious for the people in the States to receive full responsible govern ment.
('76', 12, 1, 4, 27465) If I interpret its mind correctly, assuming that an institution can have a mind, it would be sorry if any State of importance copied the example of Aundh.
('76', 12, 1, 5, 27620) But, what is most important of all, the States people themselves, as a mass, are nowhere prepared to pay the price.
('76', 12, 1, 6, 27736) There is no mistaking the awakening that has taken place in the States.
('76', 12, 1, 7, 27808) But it is not enough for the great purpose to be attained.
('76', 12, 1, 8, 27867) It will be well to recognize this fact.
('76', 12, 1, 9, 27907) In aiming beyond our capacity we are likely to lose all.
('76', 12, 1, 10, 27964) I would give much to have in all the States a reign of law instead of the reign of a person or persons, however well meaning they may be.
('76', 12, 1, 11, 28102) I can then see my way to build up responsible govern ment on the solid foundation.
('76', 12, 1, 12, 28185) But responsible government, which is only a gift without the will and the power of the people behind it, will be a mere paper responsibility, hardly worth the paper on which it may be printed.
('76', 12, 1, 13, 28378) The second object of suspension is closely related to the foregoing.
('76', 12, 1, 14, 28447) If it is a fact that the atmosphere for immediate responsible government among the States is not propitious and that the people are not ready to pay the price, it follows that they should have the proper training for it.
('76', 12, 1, 15, 28668) I am not likely, lightly and in the near future, to advise mass satyagraha anywhere.
('76', 12, 1, 16, 28753) There is neither adequate training nor discipline among the people.
('76', 12, 1, 17, 28821) I have not the shadow of a doubt that the people at large should pass one or more positive tests.
('76', 12, 1, 18, 28919) Mere abstention from physical violence will not answer our purpose.
('76', 12, 1, 19, 28987) In the centre of this programme of positive tests I unhesitatingly put the spinning wheel and all it means.
('76', 12, 1, 20, 29095) If there is quick response, this can be a short course.
('76', 12, 1, 21, 29151) But it may well be a long course if the people do not make an enthusiastic response.
('76', 12, 1, 22, 29236) I know no other programme than the fourfold constructive programme of 1920. If the people do not take it up whole heartedly, it is proof enough for me that they have no ahimsa in them, or not the ahimsa of my conception, or, say, they have no confidence in the present leadership.
('76', 12, 1, 23, 29517) For me there is no other test but what I have ever put before the nation since 1920. The new light tells me that I must not weaken as I have done before in exacting the disci pline I have mentioned.
('76', 12, 1, 24, 29716) I can quite clearly see my way to advise civil disobedience wherever the conditions mentioned are amply ful filled.
('76', 12, 1, 25, 29832) That civil disobedience will be individual but in terms of ahimsa far more effective than any mass civil disobedience of the past.
('76', 12, 1, 26, 29963) I must own that the past movements have been more or less tainted.
('76', 12, 1, 27, 30030) I have no
('76', 13, 0, 1, 30040) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 13, 1, 2, 30081) regret for them.
('76', 13, 1, 3, 30098) For I knew no better then.
('76', 13, 1, 4, 30125) I had the sense and humi lity to retrace my steps whenever I discovered blunders.
('76', 13, 1, 5, 30207) Hence the nation has gone forward from step to step.
('76', 13, 1, 6, 30260) But the time has come for a radical change in the direction indicated.
('76', 13, 1, 7, 30331) Thus my opinion on Travancore has resolved itself in the enun ciation of my present mental condition and its reaction on the Travancore situation.
('76', 13, 1, 8, 30478) To sum up: (1) suspension of mass civil disobedience should be indefinite; (2) there should be the will among the State Congress people to open a way to honourable negotiation with the authorities; (3) there should be no anxiety about those satyagrahis who are in prison or new ones.
('76', 13, 1, 9, 30762) If the spirit of satyagraha is rightly assimilated, these imprisonments and disabilities should hearten the people; (4) the pitch of the immediate demands should be lowered if necessary, in order to quicken the progress towards the final goal; (5) the condition precedent to any civil disobedience is the fulfilment by the general mass of the constructive programme as a test, if nothing more, of their coming under the discipline of the State Congress.
('76', 13, 1, 10, 31216) It is hardly necessary for me to say that it is open to the workers to reject my advice.
('76', 13, 1, 11, 31305) They should adopt it only if it appeals to their heads and their hearts and tallies with their own reading of the local situation of which I own they must be better judges.

('76', 17, 5, 7, 35440) 22. INTERVIEW TO KOLHAPUR STATE PRAJA PARISHAD DEPUTATION BOMBAY, June 6, 1939
('76', 17, 6, 8, 35519) That he would not object to any State, which is really ready for it, resorting to the direct step of civil resistance towards achieving responsible government and that he always recommended it to such States but that he would not be willing to allow any State to launch satyagraha unless he was satisfied that the State was fully prepared for it, was the view expressed by Gandhiji.
('76', 17, 6, 9, 35902) The deputation asked Gandhiji several questions to which he gave answers.
('76', 17, 6, 10, 35976) The following are some of the questions and answers :
('76', 17, 7, 11, 36030) Q. Even in spite of the fact that at present the Kolhapur State authorities are not in a mood to negotiate with the Parishad workers, in view of your latest statement 2 on the Travancore State should negotiations be started with the State authorities?
('76', 17, 8, 12, 36282) A. My statement is meant only for the Travancore State.
('76', 17, 8, 13, 36338) I know more than anyone that the State authorities in any state are never willing to have negotiations with their people.
('76', 17, 8, 14, 36460) This I have realized from the talks I had with Mr. Virawala in Rajkot.
('76', 17, 8, 15, 36531) Negotiations should always be started in an honourable way and for such negotiations there should be a suitable and proper atmosphere.
('76', 17, 8, 16, 36666) If that is not possi ble in your State, it is far better for you not to start negotiations at an immature time.
('76', 17, 8, 17, 36778) I found that opportunity and I have issued that statement concerning Travancore only.
('76', 17, 9, 18, 36864) 1 The reference is to the postponement of visit to the Frontier Province; vide the preceding item.
('76', 17, 9, 19, 36963) 2 Vide “Statement on Travancore”, 4 6 1939.
('76', 18, 0, 1, 37007) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 19
('76', 18, 1, 2, 37050) Q. What should the workers do on whom notices have been served by the Durbar to be present before the court failing which their properties will be confiscated?
('76', 18, 2, 3, 37210) A. There is no objection in being present before a court.
('76', 18, 2, 4, 37268) But it would be noble to lose the properties remaining outside the State and to work for ideals, like Garibaldi, Mazzini, etc.
('76', 18, 2, 5, 37395) It is a sin even to hold properties in a State where no law prevails.
('76', 18, 2, 6, 37465) Here you may think that the people will think in a different way about your staying outside the State and they will get demoralized.
('76', 18, 2, 7, 37598) But if you really lose your property and if the people are convinced that you work sincerely for them, you need not fear demoralization of any kind in them.
('76', 18, 2, 8, 37755) You should always be sure that self sacrifice carries public support.
('76', 18, 2, 9, 37825) The Hindu, 10 6 1939
('76', 18, 3, 10, 37846) 23. NOTES
('76', 18, 4, 11, 37856) LEADERS MUST LEAD A Cutch worker came in yesterday and said :
('76', 18, 5, 12, 37918) Some leaders in Cutch are telling the people there that but for your stopping civil disobedience they would today be enjoying responsible government or something near it.
('76', 18, 5, 13, 38089) I must deny having stopped civil disobedience in Cutch or for the matter elsewhere.
('76', 18, 5, 14, 38173) All I gave was my opinion.

('76', 18, 5, 16, 38408) I should be noted that my opinion was not given publicly.

('76', 18, 5, 20, 38836) Here there would be no question of indiscipline, for I am not in active command anywhere.

('76', 23, 3, 10, 47609) 30. MEANING OF PROHIBITION
('76', 23, 4, 11, 47636) His Grace the Archbishop of Bombay has been kind enough to send me letter 1 and a copy of his address to the Rotary Club against prohibition.
('76', 23, 4, 12, 47778) I have read both with the respect and attention their author deserves.
('76', 23, 4, 13, 47849) My study of His Grace’s letter and address at once revealed a serious flaw for which I must be held primarily responsible.
('76', 23, 4, 14, 47972) The word prohibition is a misnomer for what the Bombay Government and the other Provincial Governments where the Congress controls the Minis tries are doing regarding the liquor trade.
('76', 23, 4, 15, 48157) What the Governments are in reality doing is not prohibiting drink but they are closing liquor shops which are absolutely under Government control.
('76', 23, 4, 16, 48305) The shop owners have no statutory protection save what they get from year to year.
('76', 23, 4, 17, 48388) Every owner of a liquor shop knows that his licence may not be renewed next year.
('76', 23, 4, 18, 48470) He may be even outbidden if he possesses a country liquor or toddy licence as these are auctioned every year.
('76', 23, 4, 19, 48580) Therefore the licensees have no vested interest in their licences beyond the year for which they are held and then too subject to the observance of the stringent conditions laid down for them.
('76', 23, 4, 20, 48773) Therefore I claim that the law for the abolition of liquor licences “is an ordi nance of reason for the common good made and promulgated for the community by the competent authority.” All that the State is doing is to remove from the drinker the temptation or the facility which the State considers is harmful to him except for medicinal purposes.
('76', 23, 4, 21, 49121) The Archbishop says: “To win the allegiance of body, of mind
('76', 23, 5, 22, 49182) 1 The letter dated June 1, from T. D. Roberts, the Archbishop, was published separately in the same issue of Harijan.
('76', 24, 0, 1, 49300) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 25
('76', 24, 1, 2, 49343) and of heart needed by any law .
('76', 24, 1, 3, 49376) that law must be just”, that is to say,“the conscience of millions must say this is just.” I have no difficulty in endorsing the proposition.
('76', 24, 1, 4, 49518) Viewed in the manner indicated by me the State does not need to carry with it the conscience of millions.
('76', 24, 1, 5, 49624) But I hold that India is the one place in the world where the conscience of the millions would justify the law of abolition of the State trade in intoxicating liquors and drugs.
('76', 24, 1, 6, 49802) There is no need to take any referendum.
('76', 24, 1, 7, 49843) It consists in the overwhelming number of legislators approving of the law.
('76', 24, 1, 8, 49919) Let me remind His Grace of the past history of this great reform movement.
('76', 24, 1, 9, 49994) It began with the grand old man, Dada bhai Naoroji.
('76', 24, 1, 10, 50046) In 1920 it became an integral part of the Congress cons tructive programme.
('76', 24, 1, 11, 50122) In the absence of political power the Con gress arranged an elaborate programme of picketing liquor and opium shops.
('76', 24, 1, 12, 50239) In this programme thousands of men and women took part all over India.
('76', 24, 1, 13, 50310) All communities including Parsis took part in the picke ting programme.
('76', 24, 1, 14, 50382) Attempts were made even in the days of Non co operation to induce the authorities to undertake the abolition legis lation.
('76', 24, 1, 15, 50505) Without exception they pleaded financial inability, never the impropriety of so called interference with the right of the people to be supplied with liquor by the State.
('76', 24, 1, 16, 50675) Indeed one Minister told me that If I would help him to raise the revenue needed to make up for the loss caused by the drop in the drink revenue, he would introduce prohi bition at once.
('76', 24, 1, 17, 50862) It is an open secret that the reform has been delayed simply for the sake of the revenue.
('76', 24, 1, 18, 50952) In other words, the people have been tempted to drink for the sake of raising the revenue.
('76', 24, 1, 19, 51043) The black history of the opium trade bears out the truth of this statement.
('76', 24, 1, 20, 51119) Those who speak in the name of individual freedom do not know their India.
('76', 24, 1, 21, 51194) There is as much right of a person to demand drink ing facilities from the State as there is to demand facilities for the supply of public women for the satisfaction of his animal passion.
('76', 24, 1, 22, 51383) I hope that those who pride themselves on their moderation in drinking will not feel hurt by the illustration I have taken.
('76', 24, 1, 23, 51507) In this country we are not used to legislation for the regulation of vice.
('76', 24, 1, 24, 51582) But in countries like Germany the houses of women who sell their virtue are licensed.
('76', 24, 1, 25, 51668) I do not know what will be more resented in those countries, the stopping of the licences for the houses of ill fame or the houses of drink.
('76', 24, 1, 26, 51809) When woman realizes her dignity she will refuse to sell her virtue and those members of the sex who are jealous of its honour will move heaven and earth to have legalized prostitution abolished.
('76', 24, 1, 27, 52004) Will it be then contended that such abolition will go hard with the prostitutes
('76', 25, 0, 1, 52084) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 25, 1, 2, 52125) and their dependants whose only means of livelihood depended upon this calling?
('76', 25, 1, 3, 52205) I plead that social workers cannot work effectively so long as licensed liquor dens continue to lure the drinkers to enter them.
('76', 25, 1, 4, 52334) It is curious that in all India any opposition to prohibiton comes from the Parsis.
('76', 25, 1, 5, 52418) They pride themselves on their temperance and resent what they call encroachment upon their personal liberty.
('76', 25, 1, 6, 52528) They also make it a grievance that the Europeans have been given facilities, thus cons tituting a bar sinister against Asiatics.
('76', 25, 1, 7, 52657) I have already pleaded 1 with the Parsis that they should rise superior to their habit and allow the great reform to proceed with their active co operation.
('76', 25, 1, 8, 52814) As to the alleged bar sinister let me point out that a bar sinister is imposed from without.
('76', 25, 1, 9, 52907) In the case in point we the Asiatics voluntarily recognize the limitations of the Euro peans.
('76', 25, 1, 10, 53001) But even they have to secure exemption and submit to regulations.
('76', 25, 1, 11, 53067) The proper course for the Parsi friends would be to agitate, if they wish, for the removal of the discrimination, not use it for securing similar exemption for themselves.
('76', 25, 1, 12, 53239) His Grace has further argued that if the price to be paid for removing the temptation of drink from the drunkard “is out of all proportion to the good attempted”, the reform is harmful.The pro position is well stated, but it is a matter of opinion whether the price to be paid is out of all proportion to the good attempted.
('76', 25, 1, 13, 53564) I have endea voured to show that the whole of the excise policy has been not to supply any felt want but to increase the revenue.
('76', 25, 1, 14, 53694) I would invite the Archbishop to study the history of the excise administrtion.
('76', 25, 1, 15, 53774) He will find that all the advanced legislators have condemned the policy in unmeasured terms.
('76', 25, 1, 16, 53868) The price that is being paid for the attempted reform is insignificant if the history is borne in mind.
('76', 25, 1, 17, 53972) And even the insignificant price will not have to be paid, if the Archbishop and the influential Parsi friends will lead an agitation for the reduction in the wholly indefensible army expenditure and free the money thus saved for the purpose of bringing about all India abolition of the liquor traffic.
('76', 25, 1, 18, 54275) It is an overdue reform.
('76', 25, 1, 19, 54300) They should congratulate the Bombay Ministers on their courage in levying a tax which was the easiest to be borne.
('76', 25, 1, 20, 54415) But I have no doubt that the Ministry will gladly remit the tax, if they are helped by the Central Government.
('76', 25, 1, 21, 54526) Only they could not delay the reform whilst they were fighting the Central Government single handed.
('76', 25, 1, 22, 54627) Let all the parties recognize the necessity of the reform
('76', 25, 2, 23, 54685) 1Vide”Interview to Parsi Deputation”, 2 6 1939.
('76', 26, 0, 1, 54733) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 27
('76', 26, 1, 2, 54776) and demand justice from the Central Government and the hardship referred to by the Archbishop will be reduced almost to a nullity.
('76', 26, 1, 3, 54907) There is a curious question asked of Dr. Gilder 1. To do the Archbishop justice I must copy the question in his own words:
('76', 26, 2, 4, 55030) Does he admit that there are several kinds of intoxication which have nothing at all to do with drink?
('76', 26, 2, 5, 55133) Drunkenness paralyses the reason and wrecks homes.
('76', 26, 2, 6, 55184) But the intoxication of false ideals is now wrecking whole nations and the world itself.
('76', 26, 2, 7, 55273) Moreover, does Dr. Gilder admit that such intoxication is highly infectious?
('76', 26, 2, 8, 55350) He will hardly deny it, knowing as he does the recent history of the nations.
('76', 26, 2, 9, 55428) Then will he tell us, ‘Is India necessarily immune from the infection of false ideals which intoxicate?’ This suggests that the exercise by the State of the undoubted discretion to stop the issue of drink shop licences is a false ideal which intoxicates and which has infected Dr. Glider.
('76', 26, 2, 10, 55717) Of course everything is possible in this world.
('76', 26, 2, 11, 55765) But I venture to suggest that this abolition being a half century old national cry is not likely to be a false, intoxicating and infectious ideal.
('76', 26, 2, 12, 55912) An ideal that is false and intoxicating and highly infectious must in its nature be temporary.
('76', 26, 2, 13, 56007) The last paragraph of the address is a question addressed to me.
('76', 26, 2, 14, 56072) The half dozen lines are packed with suggestions which hardly answer known facts.
('76', 26, 2, 15, 56154) Thus His Grace suggests, among other things :
('76', 26, 3, 16, 56200) Prohibition tends to be regarded by its advocates not as one possible course but as the only possible religion.
('76', 26, 3, 17, 56312) Nobody has called it a religion.
('76', 26, 3, 18, 56345) After having stated the pro position His Grace ends:
('76', 26, 4, 19, 56398) The author of the creed of truth and non violence will not resent this last question: ‘Is he still quite certain that all religions are true?’ In any other mouth I would consider the question to be unpar donable.
('76', 26, 4, 20, 56611) But I do not expect a busy administrator like the Archbi shop of Bombay to study all a man like me may say or to verify his quotations.
('76', 26, 4, 21, 56747) His question to tally with what I have said should have been: ‘Is he still quite certain that all the known great religions of the earth are equally true?’ My answer to this revised question would be, ‘Emph atically yes.’ Only the revised question is obviously irrelevant to the Archbishop’s thesis.
('76', 26, 4, 22, 57047) His Grace has propounded a conundrum in his letter which now hardly needs a separate answer.
('76', 26, 4, 23, 57140) So far as I know the Ministers have no qualms of conscience.
('76', 26, 4, 24, 57201) They are robbing no one.
('76', 26, 4, 25, 57226) All trade is pre

('76', 29, 4, 14, 61367) SEGAON, June 13, 1939 If the proposed reforms are unacceptable as your fear they are likely to be, you may take no part in working them.
('76', 29, 4, 15, 61504) But regarding offering any opposition to them you must be the best judges.
('76', 29, 4, 16, 61579) What I have said in my statement 2 on Travancore does not apply wholly to any single State.
('76', 29, 4, 17, 61671) You must study the general principles laid down in it and do what you think fit.
('76', 29, 4, 18, 61752) Do not ask me to judge whether Mysore is well organized or ill organized.
('76', 29, 4, 19, 61826) You are the best judges.
('76', 29, 4, 20, 61851) Facts them selves are opinions.
('76', 29, 4, 21, 61883) If you are ready, you are ready, irrespective of what I may say.

('76', 30, 0, 1, 62873) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 31
('76', 30, 1, 2, 62916) The readiness may be of two kinds.
('76', 30, 1, 3, 62951) You may be able to em barrass Government sufficiently by making a big enough demons tration which invites shooting or compels them to yield.
('76', 30, 1, 4, 63092) But the demonstration may not be non violent as I am defining it.
('76', 30, 1, 5, 63158) Not that my definition has changed.
('76', 30, 1, 6, 63194) There is only a difference of emphasis.
('76', 30, 1, 7, 63234) I formerly compromised non violence in the belief that thereby India would progress further on the path of non violence, but that belief was not fulfilled.
('76', 30, 1, 8, 63390) So the non violence that you display may appear to be effective but it may not be unadulterated non violence in thought, word and deed.
('76', 30, 1, 9, 63526) If it is not, I should rule it out.
('76', 30, 1, 10, 63562) What I would not rule out today I cannot say.
('76', 30, 1, 11, 63608) I have come up to the point of saying, in the language of the Vedic seer, ‘neti’, ‘neti’ (‘not this’, ‘not this’), but I have not yet been able to say, ‘it is this’, ‘it is this’.
('76', 30, 1, 12, 63788) That is because I have not seen the full light yet.
('76', 30, 2, 13, 63840) That school says, ‘We believe both in violence and non violence, for sometimes non violence answers, and we resort to non violence because it appears to be best under the circumstances.’ But for me means and ends are convertible terms, and non violence and truth are therefore the end, so long as the end conceived has not been attained.
('76', 30, 2, 14, 64178) But in Rajkot I compromised the means; I was weighed in my own scales and found wanting.
('76', 30, 2, 15, 64267) But no harm has been done because I retrieved my error immediately I saw it.
('76', 30, 2, 16, 64344) My surrender was not due to weakness, it was a surrender out of the fullness of strength.
('76', 30, 2, 17, 64434) It came out of non violence which for me is the weapon of the bravest and not of the weak.
('76', 30, 2, 18, 64525) I will not be guilty of encouraging cowards amongst us, or of allowing people to hide their weakness under cover of non violence.
('76', 30, 2, 19, 64655) You will say that you will not make a declaration about non violence or satyagraha or civil disobedience.
('76', 30, 2, 20, 64761) It need not on that account be the reverse of any of these.
('76', 30, 2, 21, 64821) But you will say, ‘After having read all that Gandhiji has written, or has been written about in Harijan, we have come to the conclusion that we must not bandy about these technical expressions.

('76', 32, 8, 17, 68599) 37. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('76', 32, 9, 18, 68628) SEGAON, June 14, 1939 It is a pity that Shri Sarat Chandra Bose and Lalit Chandra Das had to resign from the Prisoners’ Release Advisory Committee 2 when they found that they could not make further headway and that their views differed from those of their colleagues and of the Government.
('76', 32, 10, 19, 68918) 1 This is extracted from “Bengal Political Prisoners”.
('76', 32, 10, 20, 68973) According to the source the statement was given “in releasing the letter” dated May 31, 1939, from Sarat Chandra Bose, Leader of the Opposition, Bengal Legislative Assembly; vide Appendix “Letter from Sarat Chandra Bose”, 31 5 1939. 2 Appointed by the Bengal Government; it started working from December 1938.
('76', 33, 0, 1, 69283) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 33, 1, 2, 69324) They had no option.
('76', 33, 1, 3, 69344) I had hoped, when the Committee was formed, that they would evolve a joint scheme whereby the question of poli tical prisoners would be solved on an all India basis and on non party lines.
('76', 33, 1, 4, 69533) Provincial autonomy should have meant at least the release of all political prisoners throughout India especially when they declared their faith in non violence as the vast majority, if not all, have done.
('76', 33, 1, 5, 69739) The releases already effected have shown that there is no dan ger of revival of terrorism such as the country has known.
('76', 33, 1, 6, 69860) Therefore I would suggest that Shri Sarat Chandra Bose and Lalit Chandra Das be reinvited to serve on the Committee and a formula be found so as to satisfy their viewpoint.
('76', 33, 1, 7, 70033) It would be unfortunate if a hurricane agitation were to be restarted on an issue which does not warrant any such agitation and which is capable of being decided by mutual accommo dation.
('76', 33, 1, 8, 70221) I hope that my appeal 1 to the Government of Bengal not to abandon the policy of conciliation they had adopted on this very important question of the release of political prisoners will not go in vain.
('76', 33, 1, 9, 70423) It ought to be enough for them that the prisoners have declared their faith in non violence.
('76', 33, 1, 10, 70516) I hope that the prisoners will not be restless but will allow friendly effort to take its course without the interruption of a hunger strike or the like.
('76', 33, 1, 11, 70670) I would ask them to continue the dignified restraint they have so wisely observed.
('76', 33, 1, 12, 70753) Harijan, 24 6 1939

('76', 36, 6, 20, 74611) 43. A LETTER
('76', 36, 7, 21, 74624) June 16, 1939 For me if ahimsa is not applicable to all walks of life, it is no use.
('76', 36, 7, 22, 74709) My experiments therefore must have that end in view.
('76', 36, 7, 23, 74762) I may correct myself a thousand times but I am not likely to give up an experiment in which visible results have been attained.
('76', 36, 7, 24, 74890) This earthly life is a blend of the soul and the body, spirit and matter.
('76', 36, 7, 25, 74964) We know the soul only through the body and so shall we know true ahimsa through its action in the daily life.

('76', 42, 8, 27, 82915) 55. HOW FAR ?
('76', 42, 9, 28, 82929) With reference to my advice 3 to the States people to lower their demands if necessary, a correspondent asks :
('76', 42, 10, 29, 83040) How far are the people to go and what reduction if any is suggested or contemplated, for instance, in the Jaipur demand which has been practically
('76', 42, 11, 30, 83187) 1 Congress worker of Saurashtra and editor of Gujarati daily, Prabhat, published from Ahmedabad 2 Vide also “Notes”, subtitle,“Leaders Must Lead”, 7 6 1939
('76', 42, 12, 31, 83343) 3 Vide “Statement on Travancore”, 4 6 1939.
('76', 43, 0, 1, 83387) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 43, 1, 2, 83428) framed by you?
('76', 43, 1, 3, 83443) This question would never have arisen if my language had been properly attended to.
('76', 43, 1, 4, 83527) In the first place, I have added the proviso ‘if necessary’.
('76', 43, 1, 5, 83588) This must be clearly proved and each committee should judge the necessity and the extent of the reduction.
('76', 43, 1, 6, 83695) In the second, there can be no question of reduction where the people are ready for the sacrifice involved in the development and the consolidation of the strength to enforce the demand.
('76', 43, 1, 7, 83882) Take the case of Rajkot itself.
('76', 43, 1, 8, 83914) Award or no award, if the people in general had the capacity for the required measure of sacrifice and if they had been ready for swaraj, nothing would have kept them from their prize.
('76', 43, 1, 9, 84099) It would be wrong to say or believe that but for my mistake the people of Rajkot would have got what they wanted.
('76', 43, 1, 10, 84213) My mistake has been admitted.
('76', 43, 1, 11, 84243) But it must not be held responsible for the failure of the famous Notification.
('76', 43, 1, 12, 84323) The talk of demoralization resulting from my ‘bad handling’ of the situation is nonsensical.
('76', 43, 1, 13, 84416) In satyagraha there is no such thing as demoralization.
('76', 43, 1, 14, 84472) Those who are truthful, non vio lent and brave do not cease to be so because of the stupidity of their leader.
('76', 43, 1, 15, 84583) Of course there would be demoralization or rather ex posure, if the three virtues were put on for the occasion and were to fail on the real test being applied.
('76', 43, 1, 16, 84743) People who are strong by nature displace weak leaders and go about their business as if they never needed a leader.
('76', 43, 1, 17, 84859) If they needed one, they would soon elect a better one.
('76', 43, 1, 18, 84915) Workers in the States should try to understand the Rajkot case, if they will profit by it.
('76', 43, 1, 19, 85006) If it is too compli cated for them, they should leave it alone and go forward as if it had not happened.
('76', 43, 1, 20, 85111) Nothing will be more misleading than to think that before my so called mishandling of the Rajkot case the Princes were so trembling in their shoes that they were about to abdicate their powers in favour of their people.
('76', 43, 1, 21, 85331) What they were doing before I even went to Rajkot was to confer among themselves as to the ways and means of meeting the menace, as they thought it to be, to their very existence.
('76', 43, 1, 22, 85511) We know what Limbdi did.
('76', 43, 1, 23, 85536) 1 The talk of com bining with the Muslims, the Garasias and even the Depressed Classes against the Congress workers was in the air.
('76', 43, 1, 24, 85668) My action has resulted in the discovery of the unholy combination.
('76', 43, 1, 25, 85735) A true diagnosis is three fourths the remedy.
('76', 43, 1, 26, 85781) The workers are today in a position to devise remedies to combat the combination.
('76', 43, 1, 27, 85863) It simply resolves itself into the
('76', 43, 2, 28, 85898) 1 Vide “Lawless Limbdi”, 20 2 1939.
('76', 44, 0, 1, 85934) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 45
('76', 44, 1, 2, 85977) necessity of Congressmen or satyagrahis gaining control over the forces arrayed against them.
('76', 44, 1, 3, 86071) They are as much out to gain liberty for the Muslims, Garasias, Depressed Classes and even the Princes as for themselves.
('76', 44, 1, 4, 86193) The satyagrahis have to show by cold reasoning and their conduct that the Princes cannot remain autocrats for all times, and that it is to their interest to become trustees of their people instead of remaining their masters.
('76', 44, 1, 5, 86418) In other words, what I have done by correcting myself in Rajkot is to show the true way to the satyagrahis.
('76', 44, 1, 6, 86526) In following it, they may find it necessary to lower their immediate demands but only so as to really hasten their progress to their goal.
('76', 44, 1, 7, 86665) Therefore there can be no lowering out of weakness.
('76', 44, 1, 8, 86717) Every lowering must be out of due appreciation of the local situation and the capacity of the workers to cope with it.
('76', 44, 1, 9, 86836) Here there is no room for demoralization and rout.
('76', 44, 1, 10, 86887) In cases like Jaipur of course there can [be] no question of lowering.
('76', 44, 1, 11, 86958) The demand itself is in the lowest pitch.
('76', 44, 1, 12, 87000) There is no room in it for lowering anything.
('76', 44, 1, 13, 87046) In essence it is one for civil liberty.
('76', 44, 1, 14, 87086) Civil liberty consistent with the observance of non violence is the first step towards swaraj.
('76', 44, 1, 15, 87181) It is the breath of political and social life.
('76', 44, 1, 16, 87228) It is the foundation of freedom.
('76', 44, 1, 17, 87261) There is no room there for dilution or compromise.
('76', 44, 1, 18, 87312) It is the water of life.
('76', 44, 1, 19, 87337) I have never heard of water being diluted.
('76', 44, 1, 20, 87380) Another question has been raised by another correspondent.
('76', 44, 1, 21, 87439) He says :
('76', 44, 2, 22, 87449) You expect us to work by negotiation.
('76', 44, 2, 23, 87487) But if there is no wish on the other side and the only wish is to humiliate the party of freedom, what is to be done?
('76', 44, 2, 24, 87605) Of course nothing is to be done except waiting and preparing for suffering and promotion of constructive work.
('76', 44, 2, 25, 87716) Absence of wish for negotiation by authority may mean despise or distrust of the party of freedom.
('76', 44, 2, 26, 87815) In either case silent work is the remedy.
('76', 44, 2, 27, 87857) Negotiation has been mentioned as a substitute for the ignoring of, i.e.
('76', 44, 2, 28, 87930) the despise of, the constituted authority whether it is the Dewan or any other.
('76', 44, 2, 29, 88010) And what I have pleaded for is desire and readiness for negotiation.
('76', 44, 2, 30, 88079) It is not inconceivable that the stage of negotiation may never be reached.
('76', 44, 2, 31, 88155) If it is not, it must not be for the fault of the satyagrahis.
('76', 44, 2, 32, 88218) SEGAON, June 19, 1939
('76', 44, 3, 33, 88240) Harijan, 24 6 1939
('76', 45, 0, 1, 88259) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 45, 1, 2, 88300) 56. WILL KHADI KILL KHADI ?
('76', 45, 2, 3, 88328) When the increase in the spinners’ wages was decided upon by the A. I. S. A., the Maharashtra Branch was the foremost in giving enthusiastic support to the proposal.
('76', 45, 2, 4, 88494) It has the direct guidance of Shri Vinoba.
('76', 45, 2, 5, 88537) It has worked out the increase programme with a precision not approached by the other provinces.
('76', 45, 2, 6, 88634) The result is that the other provinces not having increased the wages to the same extent as the Maharashtra Branch are able to undersell the latter’s khadi and do not hesitate to send their stock to the areas covered by the Maharashtra Branch.
('76', 45, 2, 7, 88878) Unscrupulous merchants are not slow to take advantage of the situation.
('76', 45, 2, 8, 88950) Thus uncertified stores have sprung up in Nagpur, Wardha and elsewhere.
('76', 45, 2, 9, 89022) The unwary public, not knowing the new arrangements and eager to buy cheap khadi, prefer to patronize uncertified stores, thus doing great damage to the Maharashtra Branch stores.
('76', 45, 2, 10, 89202) The result is that the Maharashtra Branch has either to reduce wages or to close down its business.
('76', 45, 2, 11, 89302) This would amount to khadi killing khadi.
('76', 45, 2, 12, 89344) Khadi lovers should know that the economics of khadi are different from and often contrary to the ordinary economics of the competitive system which is not governed by the principle of the greatest good of all, i.
('76', 45, 2, 13, 89558) e., of the least among the downtrodden.
('76', 45, 2, 14, 89598) Thus I have endea voured to show in these columns that if khadi is to fulfil its mission, 1. There must be progressive increase in the rise of the wages of the spinners till the minimum of one anna per hour is reached.
('76', 45, 2, 15, 89817) 2. The ideal is that each village should produce and use its own khadi.
('76', 45, 2, 16, 89889) From this it is clear that the least that should be done at present is that each province should produce enough and no more for its own requirements, permission being given for the sale outside its limits of such khadi as can only be produced by that province.
('76', 45, 2, 17, 90150) For instance, Andhra can export, say, 80 counts khadi outside its limits but not coarse khadi no matter how cheap it is.
('76', 45, 2, 18, 90271) 3. No profits can be made for the sake of profits.
('76', 45, 2, 19, 90322) The wage earners are the shareholders and the proprietors in this the greatest co operative organization in the world.
('76', 45, 2, 20, 90441) If, therefore, there happen to be profits made in any single year, the proper use to make of them is to devote them to increase the number of spinners so long as there are any to be provided for, otherwise to increase the wages of the existing spinners.
('76', 45, 2, 21, 90695) 4. Any province that makes an attempt to increase the wages of spinners to the desired level should be encouraged by the other branches and khadi lovers.
('76', 46, 0, 1, 90849) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 47
('76', 46, 1, 2, 90892) 5. The general public should restrict their use of khadi to the khadi produced in their own provinces although it is dearer than in the other provinces.
('76', 46, 1, 3, 91045) They must trust the A. I. S. A. to do its best for every province.
('76', 46, 1, 4, 91112) 6. The policy of the A. I. S. A. no doubt should be to reach uniformity of wages and prices throughout India.
('76', 46, 1, 5, 91222) But till that ideal condition is reached the public should have humanitarianism enough to know that they have a duty by the wage earners of their own province.
('76', 46, 1, 6, 91382) It is almost as bad to have inter provincial competition as it is to have competition with the outside world.
('76', 46, 1, 7, 91492) The immediate thing to be wished for is that all uncertified stores should be closed.
('76', 46, 1, 8, 91578) Congressmen and others should warn the public against buying from such stores, and provincial branches should resolutely refuse to sell their stock outside except at the ins tance of the provincial agencies concerned of the A. I. S. A. SEGAON, June 19, 1939 Harijan, 24 6 1939

('76', 47, 5, 16, 93595) 59. ITS IMPLICATIONS
('76', 47, 6, 17, 93616) I am sorry that my recent statements about States have per plexed even those who have hitherto had no difficulty in under stan ding my writings or my actions.
('76', 47, 6, 18, 93775) But the Rajkot statements, my actions in Rajkot, and the statement on Travancore have made ‘con fusion worse con founded’.
('76', 47, 6, 19, 93898) Pyarelal and latterly Mahadev have been man fully trying to interpret for the readers of Harijan, both my writings and doings.
('76', 47, 6, 20, 94025) I know that they have somewhat helped to clear misun derstandings.
('76', 47, 6, 21, 94092) But I observe that something is required from me directly.
('76', 47, 6, 22, 94151) I must therefore try to give the implications as I understand them of my recent writings and actions.
('76', 47, 6, 23, 94253) I had better first say what they do not imply.
('76', 47, 6, 24, 94300) Thus my ideas on civil disobedience—individual, group or mass—have not changed, nor have my views about the relations between the Congress and the Princes and the people changed.
('76', 47, 6, 25, 94479) Nor has my view undergone any change that it is essential for the Paramount Power to do its duty towards the people of the States—a duty which it has woefully neglected all these years.
('76', 47, 6, 26, 94665) My recantation had reference only to my distrust in God, in whose name the fast was undertaken, and my seeking to supplement His work by Viceregal intervention.
('76', 47, 6, 27, 94826) For me to rely upon the Viceroy, instead of God or in addition to God, to act upon the Thakore Saheb, was an act of pure violence which the fast was never conceived to imply or use in the remotest degree.
('76', 48, 0, 1, 95031) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 49
('76', 48, 1, 2, 95074) The positive implication of the Rajkot chapter in my life is the discovery that the non violence claimed for the movement since 1920, marvellous though it was, was not unadulterated.
('76', 48, 1, 3, 95257) The results though brilliant would have been far richer if our non violence had been complete.
('76', 48, 1, 4, 95352) A non violent action accompanied by non violence in thought and word should never produce enduring violent reaction upon the opponent.
('76', 48, 1, 5, 95487) But I have observed that the movement in the States has produced violent reaction on the Princes and their advisers.
('76', 48, 1, 6, 95604) They are filled with distrust of the Congress.
('76', 48, 1, 7, 95651) They do not want what they call interference from it.
('76', 48, 1, 8, 95705) In some cases the very name ‘Congress’ is anathema.
('76', 48, 1, 9, 95757) This should not have been the case.
('76', 48, 1, 10, 95793) The value of the discovery lies in its reaction upon me.
('76', 48, 1, 11, 95850) I have definitely stiffened in my demands upon would be satyagrahis.
('76', 48, 1, 12, 95919) If my stiffness reduces the number to an insignificant figure, I should not mind.
('76', 48, 1, 13, 96001) If satyagraha is a universal principle of universal application, I must find an effective method of action even through a handful.
('76', 48, 1, 14, 96132) And when I say I see the new light only dimly, I mean that I have not yet found with certainty how a handful can act effectively.
('76', 48, 1, 15, 96262) It may be, as has happened throughout my life, that I shall know the next step only after the first has been taken.
('76', 48, 1, 16, 96378) I have faith that when the time for action has arrived, the plan will be found ready.
('76', 48, 1, 17, 96464) But the impatient critic will say, ‘The time has always been there for action; only you have been found unready!’ I cannot plead guilty.
('76', 48, 1, 18, 96601) I know to the contrary.
('76', 48, 1, 19, 96625) I have been for some years saying that there is no warrant for resumption of satyagraha.
('76', 48, 1, 20, 96714) The reasons are plain.
('76', 48, 1, 21, 96737) The Congress has ceased to be an effective vehicle for launching nation wide satyagraha.
('76', 48, 1, 22, 96826) It has become unwieldy, it has corruption in it, there is indiscipline among Congressmen, and rival groups have come into being which would radically change the Congress pro gramme if they could secure a majority.
('76', 48, 1, 23, 97040) That they have failed hitherto to secure it is no comfort to me.
('76', 48, 1, 24, 97105) The majority has no living faith in its own programme.
('76', 48, 1, 25, 97160) In any case satyagraha through a majority is not a feasible proposition.
('76', 48, 1, 26, 97233) The whole weight of the Congress should be behind any nation wide satyagraha.
('76', 48, 1, 27, 97311) Then there is the ever growing communal tension.
('76', 48, 1, 28, 97360) Final satya graha is inconceivable without an honourable peace between the seve ral communities composing the Indian nation.
('76', 48, 1, 29, 97485) Lastly, there is the provincial autonomy.
('76', 48, 1, 30, 97527) I adhere to my belief
('76', 49, 0, 1, 97549) 50 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 49, 1, 2, 97590) that we have not done anything like justice to the task undertaken by the Congress in connection with it.
('76', 49, 1, 3, 97696) It must be confessed that the Governors have on the whole played the game.
('76', 49, 1, 4, 97771) There has been very little interference on their part with the ministerial actions.
('76', 49, 1, 5, 97855) But the interference, sometimes irritating, has come from Congressmen and Congress organizations.
('76', 49, 1, 6, 97953) Popular violence there should not have been whilst the Congressmen were in office.
('76', 49, 1, 7, 98036) Much of the ministerial energy has been devoted to dealing with the demands and opposition of Con gressmen.
('76', 49, 1, 8, 98144) If the Ministers are unpopular, they can and should be dis missed.
('76', 49, 1, 9, 98211) Instead they have been allowed to function without the active co operation of many Congressmen.
('76', 49, 1, 10, 98307) It will be contrary to every canon of satyagraha to launch upon the extreme step till every other is exhausted.
('76', 49, 1, 11, 98419) Such haste will itself constitute violence.
('76', 49, 1, 12, 98463) It may be said in reply with some justification that if all the conditions I have mentioned are insisted upon, civil disobedience may be well nigh impossible.
('76', 49, 1, 13, 98622) Is that a valid objection?
('76', 49, 1, 14, 98649) Every measure carries with it conditions for its adoption.
('76', 49, 1, 15, 98708) Satyagraha is no exception.
('76', 49, 1, 16, 98736) But I feel within me that some active form of satyagraha, not nece ssarily civil disobedience, must be available in order to end an im possible situation.
('76', 49, 1, 17, 98891) There must be either effective non violent action or violence and anarchy within a measurable distance of time.
('76', 49, 1, 18, 99003) I must examine this position on a future occasion.
('76', 49, 2, 19, 99054) SEGAON, June 20, 1939
('76', 49, 3, 20, 99076) Harijan, 24 6 1939

('76', 51, 4, 14, 101594) You should forget that woman.

('76', 51, 4, 17, 101751) Why should you be unhappy because of her shortcomings?
('76', 51, 4, 18, 101806) We believe that a wife is our property.
('76', 51, 4, 19, 101846) But in fact she is not.
('76', 51, 4, 20, 101870) What difference does it make even if she is married to you?
('76', 51, 4, 21, 101930) If you wish to divorce her and if that is possible, you may do so.
('76', 51, 4, 22, 101997) Do not be deterred through any false regard for society.
('76', 51, 4, 23, 102054) Even the parents’ authority will be of little use in this matter.
('76', 51, 4, 24, 102120) You should, therefore, stop being unhappy.
('76', 51, 4, 25, 102163) Cast off the load from your mind.

('76', 52, 4, 9, 102730) 66. LETTER TO LORD LINLITHGOW
('76', 52, 5, 10, 102760) BIRLA HOUSE, MALABAR HILL, BOMBAY, June 22, 1939
('76', 52, 6, 11, 102809) DEAR LORD LINLITHGOW, I thank you for your letter of 16th instant.
('76', 52, 6, 12, 102876) Though it is a pity that prisoner Prithvi Singh cannot be dis charged, I have no difficulty in understanding your decision.
('76', 52, 6, 13, 103000) I must await another opportunity.
('76', 52, 6, 14, 103034) The case of Jaipur is hanging fire.
('76', 52, 6, 15, 103070) I wonder if a solution may be expected.
('76', 52, 6, 16, 103110) As far as I know the Maharaja himself was quite willing to set free Sheth Jamnalalji and the other prisoners, to recognize the People’s Association and to respect full civil liberty so long as it did not cross the bounds of non violence.
('76', 52, 6, 17, 103348) There is one other matter which I had better mention in this letter.
('76', 52, 6, 18, 103417) I understand there are Princes who are desirous of seeing me but they have hesitation in doing so for fear of the disapproval of the Political Department.
('76', 52, 6, 19, 103572) As I had said during our talks 1 in New Delhi, I am of opinion that they should be free to meet any person so long as they do so openly.
('76', 52, 6, 20, 103709) It would be a good thing if a declaration of your policy on this subject were made either openly or privately as may be thought advisable.
('76', 52, 6, 21, 103848) I feel that it would not be enough if the permission is given in individual cases like mine.
('76', 52, 6, 22, 103941) Seeing that the people of the States have intimate connection—political and social—with Congress men and others all over India, is it not wise and proper to encourage the practice of Princes establishing friendly relation with those who have influence over their people?
('76', 52, 6, 23, 104212) To treat Congressmen and others as outsiders seems to be so unnatural that the barrier cannot last long.
('76', 52, 6, 24, 104317) It would be a pity if it is broken after a clash and creation of bad blood.
('76', 52, 7, 25, 104393) 1 On April 4, 1939
('76', 53, 0, 1, 104412) 54 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('76', 53, 1, 3, 104564) I do not complain of this but it is in striking contrast to the opposition fostered often by the Political Department to the visits of Congressmen.
