('76', 54, 1, 2, 105734) 69. ADVICE TO CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE June 22, 1939
('76', 54, 2, 3, 105789) It is understood that Gandhiji suggested that any amendment to the Cons titution which was being given effect to should find favour with the general body of Congressmen in the country.
('76', 54, 2, 4, 105974) His opinion seems to have been that such changes of far reaching importance should not be decided by a mere majority vote.
('76', 54, 2, 5, 106097) This suggestion of Gandhiji is regarded in responsible Congress circles as a hint particularly to drop the Clause 1 for the present.
('76', 54, 2, 6, 106230) The Bombay Chronicle, 23 6 1939
('76', 54, 3, 7, 106262) 70. A. I. C. C. RESOLUTIONS [June 23, 1939] 2
('76', 54, 4, 8, 106308) 1. The All India Congress Committee views with grave concern the measures proposed by the Ceylon Government with reference to their Indian employees and hopes that it may be possible to find a way to avoid the most undesirable and grave conflict that, as a result of these measures, is threatened between such near and ancient neigh bours as India and Ceylon.
('76', 54, 5, 9, 106668) 1 The reference is to the proposed amendment to Article V (c) of the Congress Constitution.
('76', 54, 5, 10, 106760) In his Presidential Address at the A. I. C. C. meeting on June 24, Rajendra Prasad said: “With the object of tightening up the Congress organization, attempts have
('76', 54, 6, 11, 106924) .been made to amend the Constitution.
('76', 54, 6, 12, 106962) The Tripuri Congress gave special authority to the A. I. C. C. for this purpose.
('76', 54, 6, 13, 107043) Among the recommendations made by the Constitution Sub committee was the addition of some words to Article V(c) of the Constitution so that the rule applying to communal organization might also be applied to other anti national organizations.
('76', 54, 6, 14, 107286) The Working Committee agreed with this recommendation.
('76', 54, 6, 15, 107341) It appeared to the Working Committee that there was a fear in the minds of some Congressmen that the proposed change in Article V(c) was intended to be used to penalize opinion or to suppress organizations.
('76', 54, 6, 16, 107548) This fear was entirely unjustified.
('76', 54, 6, 17, 107584) When, however, any organization is continually being attacked and run down by another organization, it is improper for the same person to be a member of the executives of both organizations.
('76', 54, 6, 18, 107775) This produces not only conflict between the organizations but continuous internal conflict within them.
('76', 54, 6, 19, 107879) It was with a view to avoid this and thus to have greater harmony even between the organizations that the amendment to Article V(c) was suggested.
('76', 54, 6, 20, 108026) But in view of the suspicions some members have, the Working Committee have decided not to press for the change .
('76', 54, 6, 21, 108140) .” (The Indian Annual Register, 1939, Vol. I, pp.
('76', 54, 6, 22, 108190) 355 6).
('76', 54, 7, 23, 108198) 2 The resolutions were drafted by Gandhiji on this date; vide the following item.
('76', 54, 7, 24, 108280) These were passed by the A. I. C. C. at its session held in Bombay from June 24 to 27.
('76', 55, 0, 1, 108367) 56 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 55, 1, 2, 108408) The Committee cannot contemplate without much concern a quarrel between the two countries which are separated only by a strip of water but which have a common culture and which have been inti mately connected from times immemorial.
('76', 55, 1, 3, 108640) The Committee desires to explore every means of avoiding conflict and, therefore, appoints Pan dit Jawaharlal Nehru to go to Ceylon and confer with the autho rities and representative associations and individuals on behalf of the Working Committee and do all that may be possible to effect a just and honourable settlement.
('76', 55, 1, 4, 108964) 2. The A. I. C. C. regrets the attitude of the Union Government towards Indian settlers.
('76', 55, 1, 5, 109053) It betrays utter disregard of the obligations undertaken by the predecessors of the present Government.
('76', 55, 1, 6, 109157) The policy 1 just initiated by them is in direct breach of the Smuts Gandhi Agreement of 1914, 2 the Cape Town Agreement of 1927, 3 the Feetham Commission of 1932 4 and the subsequent undertakings on behalf of the Union Government.
('76', 55, 1, 7, 109389) The A. I. C. C. notes with pride and satisfaction the firm stand taken up by the Indians of South Africa.
('76', 55, 1, 8, 109495) They will have the sympathy of the whole Indian nation behind them in their fight for self respect and honourable existence.
('76', 55, 1, 9, 109620) The A. I. C. C. trusts that there will be no dissensions among them and that they will present a united front.
('76', 55, 1, 10, 109731) The A. I. C. C. appeals to the Union Government to retrace their steps and carry out the promises of their predecessors to adopt a policy of progressive amelioration in the status of the Indian nationals in South Africa, 80 percent of whom are born and bred in that sub continent and to whom South Africa is their only home.
('76', 55, 1, 11, 110056) 3. This meeting of the A. I. C. C. resolves that no Congressman may offer or organize any form of satyagraha in the Administrative
('76', 55, 2, 12, 110187) 1 Vide 2nd footnote of “A Letter”, 7 4 1939.
('76', 55, 3, 13, 110232) 2 Vide Appendix “The Indians Relief Act, 1914”, .
('76', 55, 4, 14, 110282) 3 Vide “Sir Habibullah Deputation”, 10 2 1927 and “Honourable Com promise”, 24 2 1927. 4 Also called the Transvaal Asiatic Land Tenure Act Commission under the Chairmanship of justice Feetham, appointed by the Union Government of South Africa, “to enquire into the occupation by Coloured persons of proclaimed land in the Transvaal.” As the Commission “was unable to finish its work before April 30, 1935, as had been hoped, the Union Government of South Africa took steps early in the year to amend the Transvaal Asiatic Land Tenure Act of 1932, so as to extend the protection provided by it to April 30, 1937” (India in 1931 32, p.
('76', 55, 4, 15, 110916) 85 and India in 1934 35, pp.
('76', 56, 0, 1, 110945) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 57
('76', 56, 1, 2, 110988) Provinces of India without the previous sanction of the Provincial Congress Committee concerned.
('76', 56, 1, 3, 111085) 4. The Working Committee has repeatedly laid stress on the desirability of co operation between the Congress Ministry, the Con gress party and the Provincial Congress Committee.
('76', 56, 1, 4, 111263) Without such co operation misunderstandings are likely to arise with the result that the influence of the Congress will suffer.
('76', 56, 1, 5, 111391) In administrative matters the Provincial Congress Committee should not interfere with the dis cretion of the Congress Ministry, but it is always open to the executive of the Provincial Congress Committee to draw the attention of the Government privately to any particular abuse or difficulty.
('76', 56, 1, 6, 111684) In matters of policy if there is a difference between the Ministry and the pro vincial Congress Committee, reference should be made to the Parlia mentary Sub committee.
('76', 56, 1, 7, 111853) Public discussion in such matters should be avoided.
('76', 56, 1, 8, 111906) 5. This Committee views with grave concern the prolonged strike at Digboi and expresses its sympathy with the strikers in their distress.
('76', 56, 1, 9, 112044) 1 The Committee regrets that the Assam Oil Company has not seen its way to accept the modest suggestion of referring the question of the method and time of re employment of the strikers to a Con ciliation Board to be appointed by the Government of Assam.
('76', 56, 1, 10, 112299) In the opinion of this Committee no Corporation, however big and influential it may be, can be above public criticism or Govern ment supervision and legitimate control.
('76', 56, 1, 11, 112468) Moreover as was declared at the Karachi session the Congress policy is that there should be State ownership or control of key industries.
('76', 56, 1, 12, 112606) The oil industry is undou btedly a vital key industry.
('76', 56, 1, 13, 112661) This Committee therefore hopes that better counsels will prevail with the Company and that its directors will accept the modest suggestion made on behalf of the Committee by the President of the Congress.
('76', 56, 1, 14, 112866) If, however, the directors do not see their way to do so, the Committee advises the Assam Government forthwith to undertake legislation for making the acceptance of the decisions of Conciliation Boards obligatory and further give notice to the Company that the Committee may reluctantly be obliged to take such steps as may be necessary to stop renewal of the lease to the Company on its termination.
('76', 56, 1, 15, 113267) At the same time that this Committee urges the Company to fall in with the just suggestion made by the Committee, it

('76', 62, 2, 16, 122358) 80. NOTES
('76', 62, 3, 17, 122368) INDIA’S AMBASSADOR OF PEACE TO CEYLON
('76', 62, 4, 18, 122406) The A. I. C. C. has done well in choosing its best man 1 to pro ceed to Ceylon as the nation’s Ambassador of peace.
('76', 62, 4, 19, 122522) It is, at least it should be, impossible for India and Ceylon to quarrel.
('76', 62, 4, 20, 122596) We are the nearest neighbours.
('76', 62, 4, 21, 122627) We are inheritors of a common culture.
('76', 62, 4, 22, 122666) There is daily contact between the two countries.
('76', 62, 4, 23, 122716) From Rameshwar one almost steps on to Ceylon and finds that one is on no foreign land.
('76', 62, 4, 24, 122803) But even as blood brothers sometimes differ, so do next door neighbours.
('76', 62, 4, 25, 122876) And like brothers, they usually adjust their differences and are often more closely knit together after the clearance.
('76', 62, 4, 26, 122995) So may it be between Ceylon and India through the efforts of Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru.
('76', 62, 4, 27, 123081) No better man could have been chosen for the task.
('76', 62, 4, 28, 123132) The Indian side is clear.
('76', 62, 4, 29, 123158) Several thousand men who have been in Government service for years, whether as day workers or other it does not matter, are being dismissed for no fault save that they are Indians.
('76', 62, 4, 30, 123339) Private firms have been, it is said, told to copy the Government.
('76', 62, 4, 31, 123405) Now this pro cedure seems to be extraordinary, arbitrary and unjust.
('76', 62, 4, 32, 123474) But we do not clearly know the other side.
('76', 62, 4, 33, 123517) It will be for the Pandit to study the Ceylon Government case and make due allowance for everything that might be justly pleaded on their behalf.
('76', 62, 4, 34, 123663) Let us hope that both the Ceylon Government and the Indians in Ceylon will make the way smooth for an honourable settlement.
('76', 62, 5, 35, 123788) 1 Jawaharlal Nehru; vide “A.I.C.C. Resolutions”, 23 6 1939.
('76', 63, 0, 1, 123848) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 63, 1, 2, 123889) I must confess that these acute differences come upon me as a revelation.
('76', 63, 1, 3, 123963) I have a vivid recollection of my visit 1 to Ceylon.
('76', 63, 1, 4, 124016) There seemed to be most cordial relations between the Indians and the Cey lonese.
('76', 63, 1, 5, 124098) The monks and the laymen of Ceylon vied with the Indians in lavishing their affection on me.

('76', 63, 1, 7, 124282) Why has the partial responsible government that Ceylon enjoys made all the difference that we witness today?
('76', 63, 1, 8, 124391) It will be for the Pandit to unravel the mystery.
('76', 63, 1, 9, 124441) RAJKOT—WAS IT A BETRAYAL?
('76', 63, 2, 10, 124467) I have always felt that whatever Gandhiji done at any time from his spiritual standpoint, has been proved to be correct from the practical point.
('76', 63, 2, 11, 124613) He is not great for his enunciation of spiritual theories which are to be found in the scriptures of all countries.
('76', 63, 2, 12, 124729) His contribution to the world is his showing the way to put into practice, in the ordinary day to day life, those great spiritual theories.
('76', 63, 2, 13, 124869) For me, if any of Gandhiji’s actions done from a spiritual point of view failed to prove that it was the correct thing to be done from a practical
('76', 63, 3, 14, 125016) standpoint, then he would be considered to have failed to that extent.
('76', 63, 3, 15, 125087) Let me apply that test to what he did in Rajkot.
('76', 63, 4, 16, 125136) When he discovered that his fast became vitiated by his having requested H. E. the Viceroy to intervene, he renounced the Gwyer Award.
('76', 63, 4, 17, 125271) The practical effect was to free him from Rajkot.
('76', 63, 4, 18, 125321) But did his renunciation free the Viceroy from the obligation of seeing that the Rajkot Notification was acted upon according to the Chief Justice’s interpretation?
('76', 63, 4, 19, 125486) In my opinion Gandhiji’s renunciation casts a double duty on the Viceroy.
('76', 63, 4, 20, 125560) And if the Viceroy does not perform his duty, the people of Rajkot are free to act as they choose, and the Congress will have a powerful case against the Viceroy if the Notification proved abortive.
('76', 63, 4, 21, 125759) This is an abridgement of an article sent by a noted Con gressman for publication in Harijan.
('76', 63, 4, 22, 125853) He has built up an elaborate case in defence of my action regarding Rajkot, in reply to the criticism that I had betrayed the cause of the Rajkot people.
('76', 63, 4, 23, 126007) The heading of this note is the correspondent’s.
('76', 63, 4, 24, 126056) I need not weary the reader with the whole of his argument.
('76', 63, 4, 25, 126116) After all, time alone is the true test.
('76', 63, 4, 26, 126156) It will finally show whether my action was right or wrong.
('76', 63, 4, 27, 126215) But the abridge ment is given for the novelty of the thought about the Viceroy’s duty.
('76', 63, 4, 28, 126302) I had no thought of the consequence of the renunciation.
('76', 63, 4, 29, 126359) As soon as I
('76', 63, 5, 30, 126372) 1 In November 1927.
('76', 64, 0, 1, 126392) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 65
('76', 64, 1, 2, 126435) saw that my fast had become tainted for my seeking Viceregal intervention, I renounced the Award.
('76', 64, 1, 3, 126533) But now that my correspondent mentions it, I must admit the force of his reasoning.
('76', 64, 1, 4, 126617) My renunciation should act as a double spur to the Viceregal duty of seeing that the Rajkot Notification No.
('76', 64, 1, 5, 126726) 50 is carried out according to the inter pretation put upon it by the Chief Justice.
('76', 64, 1, 6, 126811) So far as I am concerned my renunciation debars me, in this instance, from invoking Viceregal intervention.

('76', 64, 2, 10, 127211) 81. SOUTH AFRICA RESOLUTION
('76', 64, 3, 11, 127239) It is a matter of congratulation that the South Africa Resolution 1
('76', 64, 4, 12, 127307) of the A. I. C. C. escaped complete disfigurement which the learned Dr. Lohia’s amendment would have caused.
('76', 64, 4, 13, 127416) I tender him my thanks for having listened to Pandit Jawaharlal’s advice to respect the opinion of an expert like me who had passed the best part of his life in South Africa and who had not lost touch with that great country after retiring from it.
('76', 64, 4, 14, 127665) This incident is an illustration showing that mere learning, mere humanitarianism divorced from actual experience may spell disaster to the cause sought to be espoused.
('76', 64, 4, 15, 127834) Dr. Lohia’s amend ment had as much place in the resolution as mine would have in a resolution framed by him as an authority on socialism to meet a socialist difficulty.
('76', 64, 4, 16, 128003) If I made any such attempt, he would very pro perly say, ‘Don’t pass the resolution if you don’t like it, but don’t disfigure it.
('76', 64, 4, 17, 128133) It would defeat the purpose for which it is framed.’ What I have said about the South Africa resolution applies more or less to the Working Committee’s resolutions.
('76', 64, 4, 18, 128298) That Committee is the expert body on matters relating to the Congress.
('76', 64, 4, 19, 128369) It is dangerous to tamper with its resolutions unless reason convinces the Cabinet of the sound ness of alterations suggested by members of the A. I. C. C. Accep tance of this practical advice, which I tendered more than once when I was a member of the Working Committee, would facilitate the despatch of national business.
('76', 64, 5, 20, 128693) 1 Vide “A.I.C.C. Resolutions”, 1 7 1939.
('76', 65, 0, 1, 128734) 66 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 65, 1, 2, 128775) Having said this let me say for the information of Dr. Lohia and his fellow humanitarians that I yield to no one in my regard for the Zulus, the Bantus and the other races of South Africa.
('76', 65, 1, 3, 128964) I used to enjoy intimate relations with many of them.
('76', 65, 1, 4, 129018) I had the privilege of often advising them.
('76', 65, 1, 5, 129062) It used to be my constant advice to our countrymen in South Africa, never to exploit or deceive these simple folk.
('76', 65, 1, 6, 129177) But it was not possible to amalgamate the two causes.
('76', 65, 1, 7, 129231) The rights and privileges (if any could be so called) of the indigenous inhabitants are different from those of the Indians.
('76', 65, 1, 8, 129356) So are their disabilities and their causes.
('76', 65, 1, 9, 129400) But if I discovered that our rights conflicted with their vital interests, I would advise the forgoing of those rights.
('76', 65, 1, 10, 129520) They are the inhabitants of South Africa as we are of India.
('76', 65, 1, 11, 129581) The Europeans are undoubtedly usurpers, exploiters or conquerors or all these rolled into one.
('76', 65, 1, 12, 129676) And so the Africans have a whole code of laws specially governing them.
('76', 65, 1, 13, 129748) The Indian segregation policy of the Union Government has nothing in common with the policy governing the African races.
('76', 65, 1, 14, 129869) It is unnecessary for me to go into details.
('76', 65, 1, 15, 129914) Suffice it to say that ours is a tiny problem compared to the vast problem that faces the African races and that affects their progress.
('76', 65, 1, 16, 130051) Hence it is not possible to speak of the two in the same breath.
('76', 65, 1, 17, 130116) The A. I. C. C. resolution concerns itself with the civil resistance struggle of our countrymen on a specific issue applicable solely to them.
('76', 65, 1, 18, 130259) It is now easy to see that Dr. Lohia’s amendment, if it had remained, would have been fatal to the resolution which would have become perfectly meaningless.
('76', 65, 1, 19, 130416) The appeal to the Union Government would have lost all its point.
('76', 65, 1, 20, 130482) But good often comes out of evil.
('76', 65, 1, 21, 130516) The amendment, wisely withdrawn, shows to the Africans and to the world in general that India has great regard and sympathy for all the exploited races of the earth and that she would not have a single benefit at the expense of the vital interest of any of them.
('76', 65, 1, 22, 130779) Indeed the war against imperialism cannot wholly succeed unless all exploitation ceases.
('76', 65, 1, 23, 130868) The only way it can cease is for every exploited race or nation to secure freedom without injuring any other.
('76', 65, 1, 24, 130978) My examination of the South Africa resolution would be incomplete if I did not warn the Indians in South Africa against build ing much on the resolution itself.
('76', 65, 1, 25, 131139) It is a potent resolution only if the Indians take the contemplated action.
('76', 65, 1, 26, 131215) The motherland will not be able to protect their self respect, if they are not prepared to protect it them selves.
('76', 65, 1, 27, 131330) They must therefore be ready to suffer for it.
('76', 65, 1, 28, 131377) The struggle may be prolonged, suffering great.
('76', 65, 1, 29, 131425) But they will have the moral backing of
('76', 66, 0, 1, 131465) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 67
('76', 66, 1, 2, 131508) the whole nation.
('76', 66, 1, 3, 131526) In this Hindus, Muslims, and all political parties including Europeans are united.
('76', 66, 1, 4, 131609) The Government of India may feel powerless.
('76', 66, 1, 5, 131653) I fancy they are not so powerless as they imagine.
('76', 66, 1, 6, 131704) I am reminded of the ‘Thought for the Day’ in The Times of India of the 24th instant.
('76', 66, 1, 7, 131790) It begins, ‘We have more power than will.’ I know their sympathy is with the Indians.
('76', 66, 1, 8, 131876) If they have the strength of will, they have the power.
('76', 66, 1, 9, 131932) Our countrymen in South Africa know the conditions of satyagraha.
('76', 66, 1, 10, 131998) The foremost condition is unity among themselves.
('76', 66, 1, 11, 132048) To the Union Government I would say, “You have never proved your case.
('76', 66, 1, 12, 132119) Your best men have admitted that there is no difficulty in your absorbing the two hundred thousand Indians in your continent.
('76', 66, 1, 13, 132245) They are but a drop in the ocean.
('76', 66, 1, 14, 132279) Remember that 80 percent of them are born in South Africa.
('76', 66, 1, 15, 132338) They have adopted your manners, customs and costume.
('76', 66, 1, 16, 132391) They are intelligent.
('76', 66, 1, 17, 132413) They have the same feelings and emotions that you have.
('76', 66, 1, 18, 132469) They deserve better treatment than to be regarded untouchables fit only to be relegated to ghettos.
('76', 66, 1, 19, 132569) This is not playing the game.
('76', 66, 1, 20, 132599) And you should not wonder if, at last, Indians say, ‘We shall rather die in your jails than live in your segregation camps.’ I am sure you do not want to go to all that length.
('76', 66, 1, 21, 132776) Let it not be said of you that you had no respect for your promises.” BOMBAY, June 26, 1939 Harijan, 1 7 1939

('76', 67, 3, 16, 133901) 84. THE NATIONAL FLAG The question of the use of the national flag still continues to agitate the public mind.
('76', 67, 3, 17, 134012) It was designed when non co operation was at its height.
('76', 67, 3, 18, 134069) 1 It was accepted without reserve, without opposition, by all communities.
('76', 67, 3, 19, 134144) The Muslims and others vied with the Hindus in hoist ing, carrying and honouring it.
('76', 67, 3, 20, 134229) I recall having listened to the Ali Brothers enthusing over its praises from many a platform.
('76', 67, 3, 21, 134323) It was conceived as a symbol of the peaceful revolt against imperialistic exploitation of a nation pledged to non violence through a mighty, constructive and united effort through the spinning wheel and khadi signifying out and out swadeshi and identity with the poorest in the land.
('76', 67, 3, 22, 134607) It also symbolized unbreakable communal unity, the colours being specially and deliberately designed and chosen.
('76', 67, 3, 23, 134720) That flag can admit of no competition as national flag.
('76', 67, 3, 24, 134776) At national gatherings it should command unquestioned and universal respect.
('76', 67, 3, 25, 134853) But it has to be admitted that it does not command that respect today.
('76', 67, 3, 26, 134924) Instead of being a symbol of simplicity, purity, unity, and through these a determined revolt against exploitation, moral, material and political, it nowadays often becomes a signal for communal quarrels.
('76', 67, 3, 27, 135129) Even among Congressmen attempt is sometimes made to prefer the red flag
('76', 67, 4, 28, 135201) 1 Vide “The National Flag”, 13 4 1921; also “My Notes”, 13 1 1929.
('76', 68, 0, 1, 135268) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 69
('76', 68, 1, 2, 135311) to the tricolour.
('76', 68, 1, 3, 135329) Some Congressmen do not even hesitate to run it down.
('76', 68, 1, 4, 135383) In these circumstances I personally would like to remove it from public gatherings and not unfurl it till the public feel the want and impatiently demand to see it restored to its original and unique place.
('76', 68, 1, 5, 135590) But the vast majority of Congressmen who have suffered under this well tried banner and drawn inspiration and strength from it will not go the length I would like them to.
('76', 68, 1, 6, 135762) I therefore suggest that where there is any opposition in a mixed gathering, the flag should not be hoisted.
('76', 68, 1, 7, 135871) This can happen in schools, colleges, local boards, municipal councils and the like.
('76', 68, 1, 8, 135956) The flag should not be insisted on when there is opposition even from one member.
('76', 68, 1, 9, 136038) Let it not be called the tyranny of one person.
('76', 68, 1, 10, 136086) When one person among many offers opposition and if he is allowed to have his way, it is proof of magnanimity or farsightedness on the part of the overwhelming majority.
('76', 68, 1, 11, 136256) I have no doubt that this is the most effective non violent way of dealing with the question.
('76', 68, 1, 12, 136350) My advice applies even to those places where the flag is already flying.
('76', 68, 1, 13, 136423) It was triumphantly flown in many places when the nation was offering non co operation on a scale perhaps hitherto un known in history.
('76', 68, 1, 14, 136559) Times are changed.
('76', 68, 1, 15, 136578) Opposition wherever it is offered is fomenting communal dissensions.
('76', 68, 1, 16, 136647) Surely it is wisdom on the part of those who treasure the flag and unity to submit to the opposition of a minority be it ever so small.
('76', 68, 1, 17, 136783) What I have said about the flag applies mutatis mutandis to the singing of the Vandemataram 1. No matter what its source was and how and when it was composed, it had become a most powerful battle cry among Hindus and Mussalmans of Bengal during the partition days.
('76', 68, 1, 18, 137048) it was an anti imperialist cry.
('76', 68, 1, 19, 137080) As a lad, when I knew nothing of Anand math or even Bankim, its immortal author, Vandemataram had gripped me, and when I first heard it sung, it had enthralled me.
('76', 68, 1, 20, 137244) I associated the purest national spirit with it.
('76', 68, 1, 21, 137293) It never occurred to me that it was a Hindu song or meant only for Hindus.
('76', 68, 1, 22, 137368) Unfortunately now we have fallen on evil days.
('76', 68, 1, 23, 137415) All that was pure gold before has become base metal today.
('76', 68, 1, 24, 137474) In such times it is wisdom not to market pure gold
('76', 68, 2, 25, 137525) 1 The song occurs in Anandmath by Bankim Chandra Chatterjee.
('76', 68, 2, 26, 137586) In 1937, the Congress Working Committee meeting in Calcutta passed a resolution that “Whenever and wherever Vandemataram is sung only the first two stanzas should be sung, with perfect freedom to the organizers to sing any other song of unobjectionable character in addition to, or in the place of, Vandemataram song.”
('76', 69, 0, 1, 137905) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 69, 1, 2, 137946) and let it be sold as base metal.
('76', 69, 1, 3, 137980) I would not risk a single quarrel over singing Vandemataram at a mixed gathering.
('76', 69, 1, 4, 138062) It will never suffer from disuse.
('76', 69, 1, 5, 138096) It is enthroned in the hearts of millions.
('76', 69, 1, 6, 138139) It stirs to its depth the patriotism of millions in and outside Bengal.
('76', 69, 1, 7, 138211) Its chosen stanzas are Bengal’s gift among many others to the whole nation.
('76', 69, 1, 8, 138287) The flag and the song will live as long as the nation lives.

('76', 75, 1, 3, 147870) The deputation of licensees and tappers took up no such attitude.

('76', 75, 1, 5, 148044) They are chiefly about : (a) the right to use wines for religious purposes.
('76', 75, 1, 6, 148120) (b) the right to have liquor on medical, i.
('76', 75, 1, 7, 148164) e., health grounds, (c) racial discrimination, (d) compensation to those who will be thrown out of employ ment, i.
('76', 75, 1, 8, 148279) e., tappers, contractors and liquor dealers, etc., (e) the effect of the property tax on charities.
('76', 75, 1, 9, 148379) All these are pertinent questions demanding clear answers.
('76', 75, 1, 10, 148438) Ministers are bound to remove every valid objection that can be advanced against the working out of the policy.
('76', 75, 1, 11, 148550) The right to use wines on religious or health grounds has always been recognized by Dr. Gilder.
('76', 75, 1, 12, 148646) I understand that in law there will be no racial discrimination.
('76', 75, 1, 13, 148711) It may appear to be in the administration of the law.
('76', 75, 1, 14, 148765) No one will be entitled to have the permit for the asking, not even the Europeans, if only so that the law might not be evaded.
('76', 75, 1, 15, 148893) Every case will be examined on merits.
('76', 75, 1, 16, 148932) Even Europeans will be expected to respect the liquor policy of the country and, wherever they can, to refrain from asking for permits.
('76', 75, 1, 17, 149068) The Archbishop of Bombay, in spite of his unconvincing opposition 1
('76', 75, 2, 18, 149136) to the closing of liquor shops, has gracefully announced that he and many under him are not going to ask for permits for their personal use.
('76', 75, 2, 19, 149277) Many Protestant divines, I understand, have already announced similar self denial.
('76', 75, 2, 20, 149360) I should not be surprised if many European laymen copy the estimable example of the European divines.
('76', 75, 2, 21, 149462) Never theless there is no doubt that in the administration of the law there will be more indulgence to Europeans than to those like Parsis for whom India has been their home for centuries.
('76', 75, 2, 22, 149651) But I have not the shadow of a doubt that every genuine case will be considered with sympathy.
('76', 75, 2, 23, 149746) May not the Parsis be expected to fall in with the general sentiment, especially when it conduces to the conservation of the social and economic welfare of the labouring classes?
('76', 75, 2, 24, 149925) Enlightened Parsis must surely recognize the necessity of checking the drink evil while there is still time.
('76', 75, 3, 25, 150034) 1 Vide “Meaning of Prohibition”, 11 6 1939.
('76', 76, 0, 1, 150078) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 77
('76', 76, 1, 2, 150121) The points (d) and (e) cannot be dealt with at all satisfactorily without the hearty co operation of the parties concerned.
('76', 76, 1, 3, 150245) Thus, so far as the charities are concerned, it is surely up to the trustees of these charities to support their case with facts and figures.
('76', 76, 1, 4, 150387) Some hardship no doubt there will be.
('76', 76, 1, 5, 150425) Every tax is a hardship.
('76', 76, 1, 6, 150450) But I should be surprised if any single charity is seriously affected.
('76', 76, 1, 7, 150521) After all, the tax calculated to bring in from the city of Bombay about Rs. one crore is so widely distributed that no individual or corporation will be hit beyond endurance.
('76', 76, 1, 8, 150696) But it is for those who contend otherwise to prove their case.
('76', 76, 1, 9, 150759) Liquor dealers have to present their case with full detail so as to enable the Government to deal with it.
('76', 76, 1, 10, 150866) I understand that most owners of stocks of wine have not even furnished the information asked for by the Government.
('76', 76, 1, 11, 150983) How is the Government to deal with them, if they will sullenly refuse to help the Government to help them?
('76', 76, 1, 12, 151090) I know that the Government are taxing themselves to meet every case of proved and avoidable hardship.
('76', 76, 1, 13, 151192) I use the word ‘avoidable’ purposely.
('76', 76, 1, 14, 151230) The ‘Taj’ will certainly be affected, but that is as much as saying that the liquor shopkeepers will be affected.
('76', 76, 1, 15, 151344) The ‘Taj’ is a mighty liquor dealer.

('76', 76, 2, 21, 151988) VIOLENCE
('76', 76, 3, 22, 151997) I must resume the argument about the implications of the Rajkot step, where I left it the week before.
('76', 76, 4, 23, 152100) In theory, if there is sufficient non violence developed in any single person, he should be able to discover the means of combating violence, no matter how widespread or severe, within his jurisdiction.
('76', 76, 4, 24, 152303) I have repeatedly admitted my imperfections.
('76', 76, 4, 25, 152348) I am no example of per

('76', 77, 0, 1, 152409) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 77, 1, 2, 152450) fect ahimsa.
('76', 77, 1, 3, 152463) I am evolving.
('76', 77, 1, 4, 152478) Such ahimsa as has been developed in me has been found enough to cope with situations that have hitherto arisen.
('76', 77, 1, 5, 152591) But today I feel helpless in the face of the surrounding vio lence.
('76', 77, 1, 6, 152659) There was a penetrating article in The statesman on my Rajkot statement.
('76', 77, 1, 7, 152732) The editor had therein contended that the English had never taken our movement to be true satyagraha, but being practical people they had allowed the myth to continue though they had known it to be a violent revolt.
('76', 77, 1, 8, 152948) It was none the less so because the rebels had no arms.
('76', 77, 1, 9, 153004) I have quoted the substance from memory.
('76', 77, 1, 10, 153045) When I read the article, I felt the force of the argument.
('76', 77, 1, 11, 153104) Though I had intended the movement to be pure non violent resistance, as I look back upon the happenings of those days, there was undoubtedly violence among the resisters.
('76', 77, 1, 12, 153276) I must own that had I been perfectly tuned to the music of ahimsa, I would have sensed the slightest departure from it and my sensitiveness would have rebelled against any discord in it.
('76', 77, 1, 13, 153463) It seems to me that the united action of the Hindus and the Muslims blinded me to the violence that was lurking in the breasts of many.
('76', 77, 1, 14, 153599) The English who are trained diplomats and administrators are accustomed to the line of least resistance, and when they found that it was more profitable to conciliate a big organization than to crush it by extensive frightfulness, they yielded to the extent that they thought was necessary.
('76', 77, 1, 15, 153890) It is, however, my conviction that our resistance was predominantly non violent in action and will be accepted as such by the future historian.
('76', 77, 1, 16, 154034) As a seeker of truth and non violence, however, I must not be satisfied with mere action if it is not from the heart.
('76', 77, 1, 17, 154152) I must declare from the house tops that the non violence of those days fell far short of the non violence as I have so often defined.
('76', 77, 1, 18, 154286) Non violent action without the co operation of the heart and the head cannot produce the intended result.
('76', 77, 1, 19, 154392) The failure of our imperfect ahimsa is visible to the naked eye.
('76', 77, 1, 20, 154457) Look at the feud that is going on between Hindus and Muslims.
('76', 77, 1, 21, 154519) Each is arming for the fight with the other.
('76', 77, 1, 22, 154564) The violence that we had harboured in our breasts during the non co operation days is now recoiling upon ourselves.
('76', 77, 1, 23, 154680) The violent energy that was generated among the masses, but was kept under check in the pursuit of a common objective, has now been let loose and is being used among and against ourselves.
('76', 77, 1, 24, 154869) The same phenomenon is discernible, though in a less crude manner, in the dissension among Congressmen themselves and the use of forcible methods that the Congress Ministers are obliged to adopt
('76', 78, 0, 1, 155064) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 79
('76', 78, 1, 2, 155107) in running the administrations under their charge.
('76', 78, 1, 3, 155158) This narrative clearly shows that the atmosphere is surcharged with violence.
('76', 78, 1, 4, 155236) I hope it also shows that non violent mass movement is an impossibility unless the atmosphere is radically changed.
('76', 78, 1, 5, 155352) To blind one’s eyes to the events happening around us is to court disaster.
('76', 78, 1, 6, 155428) It has been suggested to me that I should declare mass civil disobedience and all internal strife will cease, Hindus and Muslims will compose their differences, Congressmen will forget mutual jealousies and fights for power.
('76', 78, 1, 7, 155653) My reading of the situation is wholly different.
('76', 78, 1, 8, 155702) If any mass movement is undertaken at the present moment in the name of non violence, it will resolve itself into violence largely unorganized and organized in some cases.
('76', 78, 1, 9, 155874) It will bring discredit on the Congress, spell disaster for the Congress struggle for independence and bring ruin to many a home.
('76', 78, 1, 10, 156004) This may be a wholly untrue picture born of my weakness.
('76', 78, 1, 11, 156061) If so, unless I shed that weakness, I cannot lead a movement which requires great strength and resolution.
('76', 78, 1, 12, 156168) But if I cannot find an effective, purely non violent method, outbreak of violence seems to be a certainty.
('76', 78, 1, 13, 156276) The people demand self expression.
('76', 78, 1, 14, 156311) They are not satisfied with the constructive programme prescribed by me and accepted almost unanimously by the Congress.
('76', 78, 1, 15, 156432) As I have said before, the imperfect response to the constructive programme is itself proof positive of the skin deep nature of the non violence of Congressmen.
('76', 78, 1, 16, 156593) But if there is an outbreak of violence, it would not be without cause.
('76', 78, 1, 17, 156665) We are yet far from the independence of our dream.
('76', 78, 1, 18, 156716) The irresponsibility of the Centre, which eats up 80 percent of the revenue, grinds down the people and thwarts their aspirations, is daily proving more and more intolerable.
('76', 78, 1, 19, 156891) There is a growing consciousness of the terrible autocracy of the majority of the States.
('76', 78, 1, 20, 156981) I admit my responsibility for the suspension of civil resistance in several States.
('76', 78, 1, 21, 157065) This has resulted in demoralization both among the people and the Princes.
('76', 78, 1, 22, 157140) The people have lost nerve and feel that all is lost.
('76', 78, 1, 23, 157194) The demoralization among the Princes consists in their thinking that now they have nothing to fear from their people, nothing substantial to grant.
('76', 78, 1, 24, 157342) Both are wrong.
('76', 78, 1, 25, 157358) The result does not dismay me.
('76', 78, 1, 26, 157389) In fact I had foretold the possibility of these results when I was discussing with the Jaipur workers the advisability of suspending the movement, even though it was well circumscribed with rules and restrictions.
('76', 78, 1, 27, 157603) The demoralization among the people shows that there was not non violence in thought and word, and therefore when the
('76', 79, 0, 1, 157721) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 79, 1, 2, 157762) intoxication and excitement of jail going and the accompanying demonstrations ceased they thought that the struggle was over.
('76', 79, 1, 3, 157888) The Princes came to the hasty conclusion that they could safely consoli date their autocracy by adopting summary measures against the resis ters and placating the docile element by granting eye wash reforms.
('76', 79, 1, 4, 158096) Both the people and the Princes might have reacted in the right manner—the people by recognizing the correctness of my advice and calmly generating strength and energy by quiet and determined cons tructive effort, and the Princes by seizing the opportunity afforded by suspension, of doing justice for the sake of justice and granting reforms that would satisfy the reasonable but advanced section among their people.
('76', 79, 1, 5, 158514) This could only happen, if they recognized the time spirit.
('76', 79, 1, 6, 158574) It is neither too late for the people nor the Princes.
('76', 79, 1, 7, 158629) In this connection I may not omit the Paramount Power.
('76', 79, 1, 8, 158684) There are signs of the Paramount Power repenting of the recent declarations about the freedom to the Princes to grant such reforms to their people as they chose.
('76', 79, 1, 9, 158846) There are audible whispers that the Princes may not take those declarations literally.
('76', 79, 1, 10, 158933) It is an open secret that the Princes dare not do anything that they guess is likely to displease the Para mount Power.
('76', 79, 1, 11, 159053) They may not even meet persons whom the Paramount Power may not like them to meet.
('76', 79, 1, 12, 159136) When there is this tremendous influence exercised over the Princes, it is but natural to hold the Para mount Power responsible for the unadulterated autocracy that reigns supreme in many States.
('76', 79, 1, 13, 159331) So if violence breaks out in this unfortunate land, the respon sibility will have to be shared by the Paramount Power, the Princes, and above all by Congressmen.
('76', 79, 1, 14, 159493) The first two have never claimed to be non violent.
('76', 79, 1, 15, 159545) Their power is frankly derived from and based on the use of violence.
('76', 79, 1, 16, 159615) But the Congress has since 1920 adopted non violence as its settled policy and has undoubtedly striven to act up to it.
('76', 79, 1, 17, 159735) But as Congressmen never had non violence in their hearts, they must reap the fruit of the defect, however unintentional it was.
('76', 79, 1, 18, 159864) At the crucial moment the defect has come to the surface and the defective method does not seem to meet the situation.
('76', 79, 1, 19, 159983) Non violence is never a method of coercion, it is one of conversion.
('76', 79, 1, 20, 160052) We have failed to convert the Princes, we have failed to convert the English administrators.
('76', 79, 1, 21, 160145) It is no use saying that it is impossible to persuade persons willingly to part with their power.
('76', 79, 1, 22, 160243) I have claimed that satyagraha is a new experiment.
('76', 79, 1, 23, 160295) It will be time to pronounce it a failure when Congressmen have given it a genuine trial.
('76', 79, 1, 24, 160385) Even a policy, if it is honestly pursued, has to be
('76', 80, 0, 1, 160437) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 81
('76', 80, 1, 2, 160480) pursued with all one’s heart.
('76', 80, 1, 3, 160510) We have not done so.
('76', 80, 1, 4, 160531) Hence Con gressmen have to convert themselves before the Paramount Power and the Princes can be expected to act justly.
('76', 80, 1, 5, 160651) But if the Congressmen can or will go no further than they have done in the direction of non violence, and if the Paramount Power and the Princes do not voluntarily and selfishly do the right thing, the country must be prepared for violence, unless the new technique yields a new mode of non violent action which will become an effective substitute for violence as a way of securing redress of wrongs.
('76', 80, 1, 6, 161053) The fact that violence must fail will not prevent its outbreak.
('76', 80, 1, 7, 161117) Mere constitutional agitation will not do.

('76', 86, 7, 27, 171125) 110. BHANDARIS AND PROHIBITION
('76', 86, 8, 28, 171156) As the train taking me to the Frontier Province was steaming out of the station, Rao Bahadur Bole handed me a copy of the petition of the Bhandaris of Bombay addressed to the Prime Minister.
('76', 86, 8, 29, 171347) He pressed me to read it and send him my reply.
('76', 86, 8, 30, 171395) I read the petition after resting my tired limbs and sent him my reply.
('76', 86, 9, 31, 171467) The petition is an interesting document and deserves public notice.
('76', 86, 9, 32, 171535) According to it the Bhandaris got the concession to tap trees as early as 1672 as a mark of favour for military services rendered to the then British Power.
('76', 86, 9, 33, 171692) Then they lost the concession.
('76', 86, 9, 34, 171723) But they were able to continue their occupation, and to the present that is the occupation of about 8,000 people.
('76', 86, 9, 35, 171837) The petitioners say they are not against prohibition but they plead for gradualness extending to a few years.
('76', 86, 10, 36, 171947) 1 The date has been inferred from the sentence “I shall send you a telegram from Abbottabad”.
('76', 86, 10, 37, 172041) Gandhiji was in Abbottabad from July 7 to 26, 1939. 2Vide “Letter to S. K. Bole”, 6 7 1939.
('76', 87, 0, 1, 172133) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 87, 1, 2, 172174) Then comes the sting at the very tail end.
('76', 87, 1, 3, 172217) It runs :
('76', 87, 2, 4, 172227) If the Government fail to pay heed to all these entreaties and leave the
('76', 87, 3, 5, 172300) Bhandaris to their fate as it falls upon them, we do not know what course these
('76', 87, 4, 6, 172380) poorly educated and uneducated people may follow in their sheer
('76', 87, 5, 7, 172444) disappointment.
('76', 87, 5, 8, 172460) We are afraid they may even go to the length of adopting
('76', 87, 6, 9, 172517) not only Congress methods of seeking relief but adopting more drastic
('76', 87, 7, 10, 172587) measures in their frenzy.
('76', 87, 7, 11, 172613) The threat, in my opinion, vitiates a good case and raises grave doubts about the bona fides of the signatories.
('76', 87, 7, 12, 172726) Are the Government to yield to cold reason or to the cold steel?
('76', 87, 7, 13, 172791) If the Bhandaris have a good case, why do they not rely upon its commanding public sympathy?
('76', 87, 7, 14, 172884) Let me inform the public that the Ministers are trying their best, in spite of threats, to remove every kind of injustice.
('76', 87, 7, 15, 173007) In these days of the growing violence of the mind, threats must be regarded as the ordinary lot of Ministers elected under the extensive democratic franchise.
('76', 87, 7, 16, 173166) They may not be deterred even at the cost of their offices or lives from doing what they hold to be their duty, nor can they afford to be angry and refuse to do justice because as in the case under consideration, the petition for justice ends by issuing an ugly threat.
('76', 87, 7, 17, 173436) I have, therefore, pleasure in informing the public that the Ministers are applying themselves to the task of keeping every tapper employed at the very work to which he has been used.
('76', 87, 7, 18, 173620) Only the tappers have got to help the Ministers to apply the remedy.
('76', 87, 7, 19, 173689) It consists in the tappers tapping nira during the nira season and turning it into gur.
('76', 87, 7, 20, 173777) This requires honest care and attention.
('76', 87, 7, 21, 173818) The pots have to be treated as has been pointed out in these columns.
('76', 87, 7, 22, 173888) The nira need not be drunk.
('76', 87, 7, 23, 173916) Pure nira cannot take the place of toddy which contains a certain percentage of alcohol and which therefore changes in quality.
('76', 87, 7, 24, 174044) Pure nira is food even as sugar is.
('76', 87, 7, 25, 174080) Toddy, even sweet, is not in the same sense and to the same extent as nira.
('76', 87, 7, 26, 174156) Hence nira will be turned into gur which can compete with the ordinary gur which is often dirty, adulterated, full of grit.
('76', 87, 7, 27, 174280) Palm gur is any day more tasty than sugarcane gur.
('76', 87, 7, 28, 174331) It can be eaten raw whereas sugarcane gur being much sweeter does not admit of being eaten raw.
('76', 87, 7, 29, 174427) And palm gur, when it is manufactured under State supervision, will always carry with it the guarantee of being pure.
('76', 87, 7, 30, 174545) Many sweets can be manufactured out of palm gur.
('76', 87, 7, 31, 174594) But in order to accomplish this great task wholehearted co operation of the Bhandaris is necessary.
('76', 87, 7, 32, 174694) If they are in earnest, they will help the Government and help themselves.
('76', 87, 7, 33, 174769) What to do during the
('76', 88, 0, 1, 174791) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 89
('76', 88, 1, 2, 174834) off season will be a question.
('76', 88, 1, 3, 174865) I have not been able to study the condition under which toddy is drawn.
('76', 88, 1, 4, 174937) But this is a matter of detail and adjustment.
('76', 88, 1, 5, 174984) ON THE WAY TO PESHAWAR, July 7, 1939 Harijan, 15 7 1939

('76', 88, 6, 12, 175286) 112. WAR SPURS INVENTION OF NEW MACHINE
('76', 88, 7, 13, 175326) The invention of a revolutionary type of spinning machine that will raise the daily output of the individual Chinese spinner from its present standard of one pound of yarn a day to an average of between twenty and thirty pounds, by Mr. Kanya Nieh, of the Ministry of Economic Affairs and a graduate of Cornell University and the Massachussetts Institute of Techno logy, was announced in Chingkiang on May 26. The invention, stimulated and hastened by the demands of China’s war time economy, represents the fruit of six years of research and experimentation, during the last twenty two months of which the inventor was constantly moving about the country as he followed the National Government in its transfer to the interior of the province.
('76', 88, 8, 14, 176069) Mr. Nieh’s new frames are based somewhat remotely on the old native spinning methods of China.
('76', 88, 8, 15, 176164) He studied and analysed according to modern principles all the motions that go into the process of spinning until he had reduced each one to its essential scientific function—then he constructed a machine which utilized and intensified all the useful motions in the old process of spinning, and which discarded the useless motions which serve
('76', 88, 9, 16, 176507) 1 Jan Christiaan Smuts (1870 1950); South African soldier and statesman; Prime Minister, 1919 24 and 1939 48 2 Gandhiji reached Abbottabad on July 7, 1939. 3 Vide also “A Letter”, 7 4 1939, “Message to Indians in South Africa”, 23 5 1939 and “A.I.C.C. Resolutions”, 23 6 1939.
('76', 89, 0, 1, 176784) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 89, 1, 2, 176825) only to waste the individual’s energy and time.
('76', 89, 1, 3, 176873) The machines that Mr. Nieh has built according to these principles of scientific analysis are strong, sturdy machines that are at the same time extremely cheap.
('76', 89, 1, 4, 177034) They are built basically of wood, with copper used as the chief metal.
('76', 89, 1, 5, 177105) Iron and steel are used only at a few key parts, while the cogs are made of hard wood.
('76', 89, 1, 6, 177192) The new machine is so made that it works almost automatically with a minimum of exertion on the part of the operator.
('76', 89, 1, 7, 177310) The energy to operate the machine is supplied by a foot treadle which the operator keeps in motion.
('76', 89, 2, 8, 177410) The actual introduction of the new machine to the people will fall to the lot of the Chinese Industrial Co operatives and several private concerns.
('76', 89, 2, 9, 177558) The Chinese Industrial Co operatives plan to establish in the coming year over 10,000 co operatives, of which at least thirty percent will be textile co operatives.
('76', 89, 2, 10, 177723) It is the belief of the Co operatives that of the normal consuming capacity of Free China of 10,000,000 bolts of cloth a year, at least, 3,000,000 will be produced by its co operatives within the next twelve months.
('76', 89, 2, 11, 177939) In the production of these textiles, the new spinning frames will play an important part.
('76', 89, 2, 12, 178029) It is planned to introduce the new machine to its users at the rate of two machines per family.
('76', 89, 2, 13, 178125) Cotton yarn, now selling in the interior at 2.30 dollars per pound, will be reduced to a fraction of its former cost.
('76', 89, 2, 14, 178243) The foregoing 1 was received by Shri Aryanayakam 2 from a friend in China.
('76', 89, 2, 15, 178318) I wish I could give more details about this invention.
('76', 89, 2, 16, 178373) For me its merit lies in China finding it necessary to introduce village, in the place of town, production.
('76', 89, 2, 17, 178481) Harijan, 8 7 1939

('76', 91, 2, 9, 182206) 114. TO THE PRINCES
('76', 91, 3, 10, 182226) Several persons interested in the States have asked me what in my opinion is the minimum that all States should guarantee in order to come in line with the enlightened opinion in what is called British India.
('76', 91, 3, 11, 182435) I cannot vouch for what the Congress would say if it had to give any such opinion.
('76', 91, 3, 12, 182518) Perhaps it would be wrong for the Congress to have or to give such opinion.
('76', 91, 3, 13, 182594) A democratic body can only pronounce opinion on events as they happen.
('76', 91, 3, 14, 182665) Be that as it may, the opinion I am about to give is only my own and binds no one but me.
('76', 91, 3, 15, 182755) The minimum then that all States great and small can give is : 1. Full civil liberty, so long as it is not used to promote violence directly or indirectly.
('76', 91, 3, 16, 182911) This includes freedom of the Press and freedom to receive newspapers which do not promote violence.
('76', 91, 3, 17, 183011) 2. Freedom to the people of the States to form associations and educate public opinion in favour of establishing responsible government in their own States.
('76', 91, 3, 18, 183168) 3. Freedom for Indians outside particular States to enter them without let or hindrance so long as their activities are not directed towards the destruction of the States in question.
('76', 91, 3, 19, 183352) 4. The privy purse should be limited so as not to exceed one tenth of the income where it ranges between Rs. 10 to 15 lakhs per year, and in no case should the purse exceed Rs. 3 lakhs per year, and should include all the private expenses of the Ruler (e.
('76', 91, 3, 20, 183608) g., palace expenses, cars, stables, the Ruler’s guests) except those which have reference to performance of public duty which should be clearly defined.
('76', 92, 0, 1, 183761) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 93
('76', 92, 1, 2, 183804) 5. Judiciary to be independent and permanent and free of all interference.
('76', 92, 1, 3, 183879) In order to ensure uniformity of practice and strict im partiality, there should be an appeal to the High Court of the Pro vince within which the State in question is situated.
('76', 92, 1, 4, 184056) This may not be possible without a change in the law governing the High Courts.
('76', 92, 1, 5, 184136) It can, I imagine, be easily altered if the States agree.
('76', 92, 1, 6, 184194) I have purposely avoided reference to constitutional reform.
('76', 92, 1, 7, 184255) This will depend upon the situation as it exists in every State.
('76', 92, 1, 8, 184320) I should assume that where local public opinion demands it, the Ruler is bound to respond.
('76', 92, 1, 9, 184411) The most contentious part of my minimum is perhaps the right of appeal to the High Courts.
('76', 92, 1, 10, 184502) And yet unless some such arrangement is made, pure justice cannot be guaranteed in the States whatever may be said to the contrary.
('76', 92, 1, 11, 184634) This is one institution which the British have built up with patient care.
('76', 92, 1, 12, 184709) No doubt the High Court procedure is expensive and far from expeditious.
('76', 92, 1, 13, 184782) The poor of the land cannot reach it.
('76', 92, 1, 14, 184820) The processes are cumbersome.
('76', 92, 1, 15, 184850) Often the unscrupulous win.
('76', 92, 1, 16, 184878) With all their faults, however, and except where high politics have come in, the decisions of High Courts have been just and fearless.
('76', 92, 1, 17, 185013) I can think of no easy and ready made check save that of the High Courts on the vagaries, and sometimes subservience to the executive, of the judiciary in the States.
('76', 92, 1, 18, 185180) But I am not wedded to my solution.
('76', 92, 1, 19, 185216) If something else equally effective can be devised, I should have no objection.
('76', 92, 1, 20, 185296) One thing seems to me to be clear.
('76', 92, 1, 21, 185331) If the transfer of power from the Princes to the people is to take place without violence, and if the Princes are to live as such, they will have to adapt themselves to the changed circumstances.
('76', 92, 1, 22, 185527) Very few people have faith in my plan, viz., the plan of Princes voluntarily parting with power and becoming real trustees.The critics say it is Utopian and against human nature.
('76', 92, 1, 23, 185706) I must advocate it so long as I believe in its practical possibility.
('76', 92, 1, 24, 185776) The world is inevitably moving to self destruction or to a non violent solution of all its ailments, moral, social, economic and political.
('76', 92, 1, 25, 185916) The threatened world war will bring us nearer the desirable solution if a respectable part of it survives the impending catastrophe.
('76', 92, 1, 26, 186049) Whoever recognizes that the only escape from the impending fate is a non violent solution will, therefore, apply it to his own problems, whether they are domestic, communal or any other.
('76', 92, 1, 27, 186236) Non violence is a universal law acting under
('76', 93, 0, 1, 186281) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 93, 1, 2, 186322) all circumstances.
('76', 93, 1, 3, 186341) Disregard of it is the surest way to des truction.
('76', 93, 1, 4, 186392) It is only a question of time.
('76', 93, 1, 5, 186423) The Princes would not solve the riddle by the proposed combi nation with Garasias, Muslims, Scheduled Classes, and their own sub jects who are too cowed down to resist.
('76', 93, 1, 6, 186592) It is a combination that is bound to break under its own weight.
('76', 93, 1, 7, 186657) It is itself an inflammable mix ture.
('76', 93, 1, 8, 186695) And a combination against whom?
('76', 93, 1, 9, 186727) The Congress which seeks to represent all these not excluding the Princes themselves?
('76', 93, 1, 10, 186813) The Con gress will die a natural death when it ceases to be national in every sense of the term.
('76', 93, 1, 11, 186910) It has that unbroken tradi tion for the past fifty years.
('76', 93, 1, 12, 186968) Whatever transformation it under goes, it is the only institution 1
('76', 93, 2, 13, 187036) that will succeed British Imperialism whose days as imperialism are numbered.
('76', 93, 2, 14, 187114) British politicians realize this.
('76', 93, 2, 15, 187148) They would not resist, do not want to resist, its transformation or destruction.
('76', 93, 2, 16, 187229) The imperialism is increasingly becoming a dead weight if only because it is based on highly organized violence.
('76', 93, 2, 17, 187342) The Princes may ignore the Congress for a time.
('76', 93, 2, 18, 187390) But they cannot for all time.
('76', 93, 2, 19, 187420) Some are reported to have said that after all it was composed of Banias who would show the white feather on a few knock out blows on the head by the strong combination pictured above.
('76', 93, 2, 20, 187604) I would like respectfully to point out that the Con gress is not composed of Banias who can be counted on one’s finger tips.
('76', 93, 2, 21, 187729) The millions who took part in the civil disobedience fights were not Banias.
('76', 93, 2, 22, 187806) I do not thereby mean to imply that they were desirous of giving blow for a blow.
('76', 93, 2, 23, 187888) Many could.
('76', 93, 2, 24, 187900) But they had forsworn violence.
('76', 93, 2, 25, 187932) Many Congress heads were broken by something severer than knock out blows.
('76', 93, 2, 26, 188007) All I wish to imply is that the Congress is not composed of mere cowards.
('76', 93, 2, 27, 188081) Non violence and cowardice go ill together.
('76', 93, 2, 28, 188125) I can imagine a fully armed man to be at heart a coward.
('76', 93, 2, 29, 188182) Possession of arms implies an element of fear, if not cowardice.
('76', 93, 2, 30, 188247) But true non violence is an impossibility without the possession of unadulterated fearlessness.
('76', 93, 2, 31, 188343) I beseech the Princes not to underrate the Congress as a force in the country.
('76', 93, 2, 32, 188422) Its policy still remains non violent.
('76', 93, 2, 33, 188460) I admit it is fast tending towards violence.
('76', 93, 2, 34, 188505) I and a few of my companions are putting forth every effort in favour of non violence.
('76', 93, 2, 35, 188592) I ask the Princes,for their own sakes and for the sake of the country that has given them birth, to throw in their weight in favour of non violence.
('76', 93, 2, 36, 188741) It seems to be touch and go with the Congress.
('76', 93, 2, 37, 188788) It will either become growingly non violent or will presently become a violent organization, not necessarily doing
('76', 93, 3, 38, 188903) 1 The source, however, has “constitution”.
('76', 94, 0, 1, 188946) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 95
('76', 94, 1, 2, 188989) immediate deeds of violence but preparing itself for ultimate violence.
('76', 94, 1, 3, 189061) It would not harbour cowards.
('76', 94, 1, 4, 189091) If it does, it will cease to be the power it has become.
('76', 94, 1, 5, 189148) Every Indian, high or low, (there is no high and no low for the Congress) has to make his choice.

('76', 101, 0, 1, 199746) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 101, 1, 2, 199788) 128. INTERVIEW TO L. W. JARDINE 1
('76', 101, 2, 3, 199822) ABBOTTABAD, [July 9, 1939] 2
('76', 101, 3, 4, 199851) GANDHIJI: That is the only correct position, and no other is possi ble.
('76', 101, 3, 5, 199923) If you have followed my writings, you know that I have declared that no one is competent to offer satyagraha unless he has a living faith in God.
('76', 101, 3, 6, 200069) I had formerly not the courage to say so bluntly to my co workers.
('76', 101, 3, 7, 200136) I knew it was difficult to get a heart response to this thing.
('76', 101, 3, 8, 200199) For there are many who say they have living faith and yet are not godfearing, and others who scoff at the idea of believing in God and yet are at heart godfearing.
('76', 101, 3, 9, 200363) But I said it did not matter how difficult it was, I must put it forward as I know it.
('76', 101, 4, 10, 200450) [JARDINE: ] You came only recently to the conclusion that you must insist on
('76', 101, 5, 11, 200527) the condition?
('76', 101, 5, 12, 200542) G. Yes.
('76', 101, 5, 13, 200550) I felt I must make it an indispensable condition.
('76', 101, 5, 14, 200600) I knew it, I practised it, but had not declared it for acceptance by all.
('76', 101, 5, 15, 200674) I knew some resented this and even imputed to me motives of excluding them from the chosen circle.
('76', 101, 5, 16, 200773) But I said I must take even the risk of being misunderstood, but must declare the truth at all cost.
('76', 101, 5, 17, 200874) How to reduce the whole thing to practice I do not know.
('76', 101, 6, 18, 200931) J. That is simply terrific.
('76', 101, 6, 19, 200959) To hear you say that it is difficult is tremendous, for
('76', 101, 7, 20, 201015) it is an encouragement to me.
('76', 101, 7, 21, 201045) There is a kind of hero worship that attributes to you
('76', 101, 8, 22, 201100) superhuman powers.
('76', 101, 8, 23, 201119) It is something to hear that you have difficulties and are human,
('76', 101, 9, 24, 201185) and thus to feel kinship with you.
('76', 101, 10, 25, 201220) Then there is another thing that has come home to me.
('76', 101, 10, 26, 201274) You must not think of
('76', 101, 11, 27, 201296) taking but always of giving something.
('76', 101, 12, 28, 201335) G. That is right in a sense, but you can’t give without taking, and to go on saying that you will always give would be humbug.
('76', 101, 13, 29, 201462) 1 Revenue Commissioner, Frontier Province; President, Oxford Movement.
('76', 101, 13, 30, 201533) The interview is extracted from “The Oxford Group and Moral Rearmament” by Mahadev Desai, who explains : “We have found them refreshingly frank .
('76', 101, 13, 31, 201679) On some of the basic principles we found ourselves in complete agreement .
('76', 101, 13, 32, 201754) The friend who met Gandhiji described the object of the movement as the ‘eradication of fear by bringing people under the guidance of God’.” 2 Vide the following item.
('76', 102, 0, 1, 201922) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 103
('76', 102, 1, 2, 201966) Honesty, purity, unselfishness and love are their fourfold principles, and the
('76', 102, 2, 3, 202045) friend said that whilst the first two would come under the heading ‘truth’, the other
('76', 102, 3, 4, 202131) two would come under the heading ‘non violence or bravery’.
('76', 102, 3, 5, 202191) Gandhiji asked: How is a civilian who is trained not to establish any human con tact with the ruled to fare under this rule?
('76', 102, 3, 6, 202316) Perhaps you will not admit that they are so trained ?
('76', 102, 5, 7, 202370) G. Well, you will by and by.
('76', 102, 5, 8, 202399) I do not make a charge of it.
('76', 102, 5, 9, 202429) It was worldly wisdom that dictated the course to those who organized the Service.
('76', 102, 5, 10, 202512) How could they allow them to live on terms of familiarity with those over whom they had to rule, especially when the rulers were only a handful?And yet if you accept the creed of the Oxford Group, you have to establish human contact with me.
('76', 102, 5, 11, 202754) And if you do it with me, you must do it with others.
('76', 102, 5, 12, 202808) You will have to contact the whole of India through me, and I with all Englishmen through you.
('76', 102, 5, 13, 202903) That at any rate is what the Oxford Group must stand for, otherwise it would be like many other similar movements.
('76', 102, 6, 14, 203018) J. You are right, and that is why I kept out of freemasonry.
('76', 102, 6, 15, 203079) We have to meet
('76', 102, 7, 16, 203095) under God, and we shall not make demands from another which are inconsistent with
('76', 102, 8, 17, 203177) the guidance of God.
('76', 102, 9, 18, 203198) G. Anyway, I have expressed my difficulty.
('76', 102, 10, 19, 203241) J. A programme of moral rearmament for the world cannot fail to lessen the
('76', 102, 11, 20, 203316) dangers of armed conflict.
('76', 102, 11, 21, 203343) Such moral rearmament must receive support on a world 
('76', 102, 12, 22, 203398) wide basis.
('76', 102, 13, 23, 203410) Gandhiji was invited to put his signature to a “response” to President
('76', 102, 14, 24, 203481) Roosevelt’s message.
('76', 102, 15, 25, 203502) 1 Mahadev Desai explains: “.
('76', 102, 15, 26, 203531) President Roosevelt advocated, before four thousand persons assembled in Constitution Hall in America, moral rearmament as a means of maintaining world peace.
('76', 102, 15, 27, 203690) Two of the paragraphs in it read thus: ‘MRA means first of all a change of heart.
('76', 102, 15, 28, 203772) It means admission of our responsibility for the past, a frank acceptance by nations as by individuals of the standards of honesty, purity, unselfishness and love daily listening and daily obedience to God’s direction.
('76', 102, 15, 29, 203991) ‘At this fateful hour we pledge ourselves to give the last full measure of our devotion—the service of heart, mind, will—to the Moral and Spiritual Rearmament of our nation—to building the world of tomorrow, the world of new men, new nations, where every resource of human genius is liberated under God’s leadership to enrich the heritage of all mankind.’ ”
('76', 103, 0, 1, 204349) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 103, 1, 2, 204391) With all deference to those in India who had signed this “response” Gandhiji
('76', 103, 2, 3, 204468) said he could not in all conscience sign this.
('76', 103, 2, 4, 204515) He could not endorse a falsehood.
('76', 103, 3, 5, 204549) can India accept responsibility for the past?
('76', 103, 3, 6, 204595) All this has no application to me.
('76', 103, 3, 7, 204630) The whole paragraph applies to exploiting nations, whereas India is an exploited nation.
('76', 103, 3, 8, 204719) The second paragraph too applies to nations of the West and not to us.
('76', 103, 3, 9, 204790) The whole appeal is so unreal.
('76', 103, 3, 10, 204821) I can think of moral rearmament, but that would be in a different setting.
('76', 103, 3, 11, 204896) I can think of communal unity through moral rearmament.
('76', 103, 3, 12, 204952) As a member of an exploited nation I can have a different moral rearmament programme, and I may invite China to it, but how can I invite the West or Japan?
('76', 103, 3, 13, 205108) And just as it would be unreal for me to invite the West, it would to that extent be unreal for the West to invite India.
('76', 103, 3, 14, 205230) Let them shed their exploitation policy and their immoral gains first.

('76', 104, 1, 2, 205876) 130. LETTER TO MAURICE FRYDMAN
('76', 104, 2, 3, 205907) ABBOTTABAD, July 10, 1939 MY DEAR FRYDMAN, I am only today able to deal with your letter of 18th May.
('76', 104, 2, 4, 206009) You say there should be no self torture, self compulsion, self violence in the practice of non violence.
('76', 104, 2, 5, 206114) This is a profound error.
('76', 104, 2, 6, 206140) There is no salvation without the cross.
('76', 104, 2, 7, 206181) Self torture is only so called.
('76', 104, 2, 8, 206213) The right word is self purification.
('76', 104, 2, 9, 206250) The flesh must be subdued.
('76', 104, 2, 10, 206277) The flesh has gained such mastery over us that it has to be dislodged.
('76', 104, 2, 11, 206348) We are born slaves of the flesh.
('76', 104, 2, 12, 206381) Freedom from that bondage is mastery over the flesh, the self.
('76', 104, 2, 13, 206444) All tapasya is self torture.
('76', 104, 2, 14, 206473) All restraint is self tourture.
('76', 104, 2, 15, 206505) It is a surgical operation which has got to be performed.
('76', 104, 2, 16, 206563) The fleshly mantle divides you from me.
('76', 104, 2, 17, 206603) I must destroy it if I love you, i.
('76', 104, 2, 18, 206639) e., if I want to be one with you.
('76', 104, 2, 19, 206673) Its destruction in this life means its complete subjection.
('76', 104, 2, 20, 206733) Is this not quite clear?
('76', 104, 2, 21, 206758) Love to you and Appu.

('76', 109, 1, 2, 212337) 139. NOTES
('76', 109, 2, 3, 212348) A REPUDIATION Janab Yusuf Meherally, President, Cutch Prajakiya Parishad, writes:
('76', 109, 3, 4, 212430) In a recent issue of the Harijan, under the caption “Leaders Must
('76', 109, 4, 5, 212496) Lead” 1, you have made reference to Cutch which raises one or two points that
('76', 109, 5, 6, 212574) need to be cleared up.
('76', 109, 5, 7, 212597) The note has it that a Cutch worker informed you that
('76', 109, 6, 8, 212651) “some leaders in Cutch are telling the people there that but for your stopping
('76', 109, 7, 9, 212730) civil disobedience they would today be enjoying responsible government or
('76', 109, 8, 10, 212804) something near it.”
('76', 109, 9, 11, 212824) We were not a little surprised to read this, for to the best of my knowledge none of our responsible workers in Cutch has said this.
('76', 109, 9, 12, 212957) Since the suspension of the satyagraha by us under your advice on April 1, I alone must have addressed over 200 meetings all over Cutch.
('76', 109, 9, 13, 213094) My other colleagues in Cutch have similarly done a great deal of touring.
('76', 109, 9, 14, 213168) But nowhere have our leading workers given expression to such sentiments.
('76', 109, 9, 15, 213242) In fact, at a public meeting in the capital town of Bhuj, which is our headquarters, I asked the large gathering present if any among them had heard these or similar words.
('76', 109, 9, 16, 213415) The unanimous reply was in the negative.
('76', 109, 9, 17, 213456) I asked again if there were any person in the audience who had recollection of hearing anything that even resembled this.
('76', 109, 9, 18, 213578) Not one such person was there.
('76', 109, 9, 19, 213609) I do not wish to labour the point any further.
('76', 109, 9, 20, 213656) But we could not help feeling hurt that you should have lent the weight of your name to a statement which on further enquiry you would have found to be incorrect.
('76', 109, 9, 21, 213819) I gladly publish this repudiation.
('76', 109, 9, 22, 213854) But I must say that there was no occasion for the President to feel hurt.
('76', 109, 9, 23, 213928) Had I mentioned names, I would certainly have referred to him before writing the note.
('76', 109, 9, 24, 214015) But when a responsible worker asked me if I had stopped civil disobe dience in Cutch and wanted a public declaration from me, I could not wait for confirmation before giving my answer.
('76', 109, 9, 25, 214200) Nor does the present repudiation take the matter any further than where it was left by my note except that Janab Meherally and those whom he asked did not make the statement alluded to.
('76', 109, 9, 26, 214386) The proper procedure is to challenge my informant to produce the names of those whom he knew had made the statement imputed to them or unreservedly to withdraw his
('76', 109, 10, 27, 214550) 1 Vide “Notes”, 7 6 1939.
('76', 110, 0, 1, 214576) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 111
('76', 110, 1, 2, 214620) allegation.

('76', 110, 1, 4, 214772) Meanwhile my note has served a very useful purpose in the other States if not in Cutch.
('76', 110, 1, 5, 214860) The leaders have a greater sense of responsibility and realize that my opinion should have no weight with them except to the extent that it appeals to their heads and hearts.
('76', 110, 1, 6, 215035) They are solely responsible for any action they take.
('76', 110, 1, 7, 215089) And naturally.

('76', 110, 1, 9, 215184) THE WAY TO DO IT Narandas Gandhi is khadi mad.
('76', 110, 1, 10, 215231) He is a good teacher after my style and an able accountant, but has been for years a staunch believer in the gospel of khadi.
('76', 110, 1, 11, 215357) He devotes about four hours daily to spinning.
('76', 110, 1, 12, 215404) His output gives him khadi enough for his house hold.
('76', 110, 1, 13, 215458) Five years ago he conceived the idea of popularizing khadi and raising funds for public services by dedicating as many days as my years at the time of my birthday.
('76', 110, 1, 14, 215622) He began with my 66th year.
('76', 110, 1, 15, 215650) I attach the greatest impor tance to my service of the poor through khadi.
('76', 110, 1, 16, 215725) I do not regard it as a mad man’s mad idea.
('76', 110, 1, 17, 215769) It cannot be so mad when it is remembered that it has put into the pockets of Hindu and Muslim spinners and weavers nearly five crores of rupees.
('76', 110, 1, 18, 215915) Though, therefore, Narandas Gandhi’s enterprise is connected with my name, I do not hesitate to advertise it year after year.
('76', 110, 1, 19, 216041) His ambition rises as years roll by.
('76', 110, 1, 20, 216078) And it has been always hitherto more than fulfilled.
('76', 110, 1, 21, 216131) He began by asking co workers to contribute in all 66,000 yards of yarn and collecting 66 coins from those who would care to give them.
('76', 110, 1, 22, 216267) Collection of yarn was made from all over India.
('76', 110, 1, 23, 216316) Collection of coin was naturally confined to Rajkot for it was matter of door to door begging.
('76', 110, 1, 24, 216411) This time Narandas Gandhi hopes to receive, instead of seventy thousand, 70 lakhs of yards of yarn.
('76', 110, 1, 25, 216511) Is there anything which the determination of the good cannot achieve?
('76', 110, 1, 26, 216581) 1 It should not be difficult of fulfilment if 100 2 volunteers spin 1,000 yards of yarn daily from 2nd August for seventy days.
('76', 110, 1, 27, 216709) The programme commences on 2nd August and finishes on 10th October.
('76', 110, 1, 28, 216777) A fast spinner would do 1,000 yards in three hours.
('76', 110, 1, 29, 216829) But an average spinner would easily do it in four hours.
('76', 110, 1, 30, 216886) If Narandas secures the co 
('76', 110, 2, 31, 216914) 1 This sentence is from the Gujarati leaflet, “Note on Rentia Baras”, written by Narandas Gandhi (C. W. 8566).

('76', 111, 1, 2, 217143) operation of 1,000 1 volunteers, the output need not be more than 100 yards per day.
('76', 111, 1, 3, 217228) That means giving less than thirty minutes daily.
('76', 111, 1, 4, 217278) And of course merit lies in an increasing number of volunteers responding every year.
('76', 111, 1, 5, 217364) The virtue of khadi lies in bringing the distribution of the work of spinning as near the individual use of khadi as possible.
('76', 111, 1, 6, 217491) The spinning provides the best and the easiest method of voluntary and useful co operation.
('76', 111, 1, 7, 217583) India has man power in crores and that is why it does not require giant soul less machines.
('76', 111, 1, 8, 217675) 2 Given the co operation of crores of people, it would be child’s play for them to produce cloth for their own use.
('76', 111, 1, 9, 217791) That would save the drain of crores of rupees to foreign countries and the wealth would automatically be distributed among crores of people.
('76', 111, 1, 10, 217932) Let me hope Narandas Gandhi will secure the association of many volunteers in his enterprise.
