('76', 111, 3, 20, 218956) It is a great event in the campaign against untouchability and the movement for the opening of temples to Harijan.
('76', 111, 3, 21, 219071) The Proclamation opening the State temples of Travancore was no doubt a very big step.
('76', 111, 3, 22, 219158) But it was the prerogative of the Maharaja.
('76', 111, 3, 23, 219202) He had in his Dewan a wise adviser.
('76', 111, 3, 24, 219238) The Maharaja, the Maharani and the Dewan brought about
('76', 111, 4, 25, 219293) 1 The source has “700” and “7,000” a misprint; vide also “Notes”, 6 8 1939.
('76', 111, 5, 26, 219369) 2 This and the following two sentences are from the Gujarati.
('76', 112, 0, 1, 219431) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 113
('76', 112, 1, 2, 219475) the transformation.
('76', 112, 1, 3, 219495) But the opening of the celebrated temple of Madura is a greater event in that it is the popular will that has brought about the happy consummation.
('76', 112, 1, 4, 219643) It reflects a decided conversion of the temple goers of the Meenakshi temple.
('76', 112, 1, 5, 219721) Shri Vaidyanatha Aiyar and his co workers deserve all the praise for the ceaseless effort that they have put forth in educating public opinion.
('76', 112, 1, 6, 219865) Let us hope that this opening will be followed up by the opening of the other great temples of the South.
('76', 112, 1, 7, 219971) There should be no hurry, no hustling of the public.
('76', 112, 1, 8, 220024) The opinion of the temple goers is of the greatest value.
('76', 112, 1, 9, 220082) Theirs should be the deciding voice.
('76', 112, 1, 10, 220119) The workers will consolidate every gain so as to prevent any set back.
('76', 112, 1, 11, 220190) Every open ing of a temple to Harijans should mark greater purification inside and outside the temple opened.
('76', 112, 1, 12, 220300) The sanctity of such temples should on no account be marred.
('76', 112, 1, 13, 220361) No political capital should be made out of what is, and is intended to be, a purely religious act.
('76', 112, 1, 14, 220460) Harijans too should be taught to understand the religious signi ficance of the opening of temples for them.
('76', 112, 1, 15, 220568) There were fifteen useful resolutions taken at the Conference.
('76', 112, 1, 16, 220631) Of these the following three attract special attention:
('76', 112, 2, 17, 220687) 1. This Conference notes with deep regret the recent action of the Mysore Government in having withdrawn their order permitting Harijans into the Sravana Belagola temple even up to the limits where non Hindus are allowed.
('76', 112, 3, 18, 220909) 2. This Conference resolves that the Provincial Boards of the Harijan Sevak Sangh should take up the organization of a Provincial Sevak Service with the following objects:
('76', 112, 4, 19, 221081) (a) There should be a whole time worker in charge of every institution run by the Harijan Sevak Sangh, as schools, hostels, etc.
('76', 112, 5, 20, 221210) (b) The sevaks should undertake to serve for at least five years.
('76', 112, 6, 21, 221276) (c) They should be paid an allowance ranging from Rs. 15 to Rs. 30 according to the needs of the individual and the circumstances of the locality.
('76', 112, 7, 22, 221423) (d) The sevak shall be attached to any one of the centres allotted to him by the Provincial Board.
('76', 112, 8, 23, 221522) (e) The qualifications of the sevak and the pledge to be given by him shall be
('76', 112, 9, 24, 221601) the same as that of the Central Board sevaks, with this additional qualification that he should have passed at least the third form and must have been for at least three years in Harijan work, and should possess full faith and confidence in th ideals set forth by Mahatmaji and the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('76', 112, 10, 25, 221904) (f) The Provincial Board, though solely responsible for the salary of the sevaks, the institution to which he is attached will also undertake to pay at least half his allowance.
('76', 113, 0, 1, 222082) 114 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 113, 1, 2, 222124) (g) The Provincial Board in consulation with the district or local committees shall select the sevaks under the scheme who will abide by the conditions laid down by the Provincial Board from time to time.
('76', 113, 2, 3, 222329) (h) The sevaks attached to each Provincial Board shall meet at least once a year.
('76', 113, 3, 4, 222411) 3. Resolved that a short workers’ training camp extending about a month be organized by the respective Provincial Boards in any of the following centres, viz., the Ramakrishna Vidyalaya of Coimbatore, the Vinayashram in Guntur and the Kengeri Gurukul in Mysore.
('76', 113, 3, 5, 222673) Shri Avinasilingam, Ramachandran, Bapineedu and Gopalaswamy be requested to draft a scheme for their training and circulate the same to all the Provincial Boards.
('76', 113, 3, 6, 222836) The first is surprising and demands an answer from the Mysore authorities.
('76', 113, 3, 7, 222911) I hope that there is some misunderstanding somewhere.
('76', 113, 3, 8, 222965) A concession once given is not withdrawn lightly.
('76', 113, 3, 9, 223015) The second resolution is very important.
('76', 113, 3, 10, 223056) The Conference has thereby taken a big step.
('76', 113, 3, 11, 223101) The third is also a substantial resolution.
('76', 113, 3, 12, 223145) Let us hope that whatever has been undertaken by the Conference will be duly carried out.
('76', 113, 3, 13, 223235) Our resolutions often begin and end with being printed and advertised in the Press.
('76', 113, 3, 14, 223319) They have value only if they are reduced to practice.

('76', 118, 6, 7, 228590) 150. A GOOD SAMARITAN
('76', 118, 7, 8, 228612) As will appear from the following letter received by me from Shri A.S. Wadia of Poona, he has been truly a good samaritan to the poor people who eke out a bare living by heaving up to the Maha baleshwar Hill loads of wood from the plains below for the use of the summer visitors.
('76', 118, 7, 9, 228892) Here is the extract from Shri Wadia’s letter: 1
('76', 118, 8, 10, 228940) I went to Mahabaleshwar to get that isolation and quiet I wanted to write my new book on Southern Rhodesia.
('76', 118, 8, 11, 229048) But while there my mind and energies were unexpectedly diverted to looking into a grievance of the village people who came up to Mahabaleshwar from the valleys below with heavy loads of hay and firewood and sold them for a mere pittance in our bazaar.
('76', 118, 8, 12, 229300) Whenever I happened to talk to them, they invariably complained of the awful condition of the tracks by which they came up, as the pointed stones cut their toes and blistered their feet.
('76', 118, 8, 13, 229487) On inquiry I found that the tracks came to be made by constant use and were never touched by the hand of man ever since Mahabaleshwar was discovered by General Lodnick a hundred years ago.
('76', 118, 9, 14, 229676) Realizing that the grievance of the village people was just and needed immediate attention, I put away the writing of my Rhodesia and engaged a gang of coolies and systematically took to the smoothening and broadening of the tracks, breaking up obstructive stones and lopping off branches which came in the way of their long loads of firewood.
('76', 118, 9, 15, 230020) Off and on the work was continued for eight weeks, during the course of which I must have employed altogether about a thousand coolies.
('76', 118, 9, 16, 230156) Counting small and big, a dozen tracks must have been made, re made and in some cases re aligned.
('76', 118, 10, 17, 230254) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('76', 119, 0, 1, 230291) 120 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 119, 1, 2, 230333) Now I come to the main purpose of my writing you these notes.
('76', 119, 1, 3, 230395) It is to ask you if Government is not bound to keep in good condition these tracks that I have made for the use of the villagers just as much as they are bound to maintain in good condition the roads for vehicular traffic.
('76', 119, 2, 4, 230618) While conversing with the villagers I gathered a few more facts which might interest you:
('76', 119, 3, 5, 230708) 1. They all complained that the soil of their cultivated fields was deteriorating year after year so that their crops came to about half of what they used to have ten years ago.
('76', 119, 4, 6, 230886) 2. The Congress Government, they said, had again imposed on them a tax of four annas on each head of cattle after exempting them from the tax for the last two years.
('76', 119, 5, 7, 231052) 3. The waste lands round the villages should be given them for cultivation and small areas of forest reserve should be opened for grazing their cattle.
('76', 119, 6, 8, 231204) I wish you, Mahatmaji, would do something to help the ‘Adijans’, as I call these poor villagers of the valleys round Mahabaleshwar, in whose welfare and well being I am personally interested.
('76', 119, 6, 9, 231396) I forwarded the letter to the Bombay Ministers, and I am happy to be able to inform the reader that the matter has been taken up by them.
('76', 119, 6, 10, 231534) The Bombay Government will keep in good repair the foot paths so considerately smoothed down and made safer than they were before by Shri Wadia.
('76', 119, 6, 11, 231679) They will also attend to the other matters referred to by my correspondent.
('76', 119, 6, 12, 231755) I wrote to him asking for further particulars of his enterprise.
('76', 119, 6, 13, 231820) It appears that he laboured with the labourers himself and constituted himself their road engineer.
('76', 119, 6, 14, 231920) He paid from his own pocket over Rs. 200 which were supplemented by two friends to the extent of Rs. 125. I am quite sure that Shri Wadia has lost nothing by suspending the writing of his book which it is highly probable will now bear the impress of his very practical philanthropy.
('76', 119, 6, 15, 232203) It is fashionable to give something to charities out of one’s super fluous cash.
('76', 119, 6, 16, 232284) But not many give their labour as well as money.
('76', 119, 6, 17, 232333) Those who do, ensure the best use possible of their donations.
('76', 119, 6, 18, 232396) It is to be hoped that the other hill goers will copy Shri Wadia’s good example by studying and ameliorating the condition of the poor who uncom plainingly labour for them often on starvation wages.
('76', 119, 6, 19, 232595) ABBOTTABAD, July 13, 1939. Harijan, 22 7 1939

('76', 120, 1, 2, 232685) 151. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS1
('76', 120, 2, 3, 232714) ABBOTTABAD, July 13, 1939 I have read Subhas Babu’s statement 2 on the Bombay prohi bition with pain and sorrow.
('76', 120, 2, 4, 232827) He had discussed the question with me when I was in Bombay.
('76', 120, 2, 5, 232887) I had told him to confer with the Bombay Ministers.
('76', 120, 2, 6, 232939) I do not know whether he did so.
('76', 120, 2, 7, 232972) But I was unprepared for his public statement.
('76', 120, 2, 8, 233019) He has used the arguments of the opponents of prohibition.
('76', 120, 2, 9, 233078) He was President of the Congress last year, and having been duly elected for the second year he chose to resign 3 owing to differences with his colleagues.
('76', 120, 2, 10, 233234) He is still head of the Bengal Congress Executive.
('76', 120, 2, 11, 233285) He is identified with the prohibition policy of the Con gress.
('76', 120, 2, 12, 233348) His responsibility has not ceased because he is no longer in the Working Committee.
('76', 120, 2, 13, 233432) Had he been a member, he could not have spoken as he has done.
('76', 120, 2, 14, 233495) His statement because of his position is calcu lated to discredit the Bombay Ministry in a manner the avowed oppo nents of prohibition could never hope to do.
('76', 120, 2, 15, 233654) I can only hope that in this matter Subhas Babu does not reflect the opinion of any other responsible Congressman, and that the general public will con tinue to support the Bombay ministerial policy with as much enthusiasm as hitherto.
('76', 120, 2, 16, 233890) The Ministers’ duty is plain.
('76', 120, 2, 17, 233920) They have to pursue their pro gramme undeterred by any opposition, if they have faith in it.
('76', 120, 2, 18, 234013) Prohi bition is the greatest moral reform in the Congress programme.
('76', 120, 2, 19, 234082) Pre vious Governments too had given their lip assent to it, but having been irresponsible they had neither the courage nor the will to carry it out.
('76', 120, 2, 20, 234231) They were not willing to forgo revenue which they could get without effort.
('76', 120, 2, 21, 234307) They did not stay to examine its tainted source.
('76', 120, 2, 22, 234356) The Congress Governments have the backing of public opinion.
('76', 120, 2, 23, 234417) The Working Com mittee after very careful deliberation issued its mandate on prohi bition.
('76', 120, 2, 24, 234508) The Ministers have all over taken it up to the best of their abil ity.
('76', 120, 2, 25, 234579) The manner of execution was naturally left to the respective

('76', 121, 0, 1, 234895) 122 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 121, 1, 2, 234937) Ministries.
('76', 121, 1, 3, 234949) The Bombay Ministers have been courageously pursuing their programme with every prospect of success.
('76', 121, 1, 4, 235050) Theirs is a difficult position.
('76', 121, 1, 5, 235082) They were bound to tackle Bombay some day or other.
('76', 121, 1, 6, 235134) They would be faced with the same opposition as today from the inte rests directly affected by the prohibition policy.
('76', 121, 1, 7, 235253) It is not open to any Congressman to embarrass the Ministers as Subhas Babu has done.
('76', 121, 1, 8, 235339) The communal question does not arise at all.
('76', 121, 1, 9, 235384) Subhas Babu has rendered a great disservice to the Congress by raising the communal cry and the cry of minorities.
('76', 121, 1, 10, 235499) Independence of India is impossible if causes great or small are to be discredited and ruined on the altar of the minority cry.
('76', 121, 1, 11, 235627) Subhas Babu has played a most dangerous game by mixing up the communal question with such a purely moral reform as prohibition.
('76', 121, 1, 12, 235755) It is as much the concern of a Muslim or a Parsi or a Christian as of a Hindu to look after his less fortunate countryman who happens to be a labourer and falls a victim to drink.
('76', 121, 1, 13, 235935) The Bom bay property owners will pay one crore rupees as additional tax not because they are Parsis or Muslims but because they are property owners.
('76', 121, 1, 14, 236084) It is altogether misleading to suggest that the tax payer, him self a non drinker, will pay the tax for saving the drunkard.
('76', 121, 1, 15, 236209) He will pay the tax for the education of his children whereas hitherto the drinker has been made by him to pay for that education.
('76', 121, 1, 16, 236340) The addi tional tax will be a tardy but very small reparation for the wrong done by monied men to the poor.
('76', 121, 1, 17, 236448) And the poor have no class.
('76', 121, 1, 18, 236476) They irrespective of their caste and creed make by themselves a down trodden class.
('76', 121, 1, 19, 236560) Their enforced creed is wretched poverty.
('76', 121, 1, 20, 236602) Parsis are philanthropists of the world.
('76', 121, 1, 21, 236643) Why should they be behindh and in this the greatest philanthropy?
('76', 121, 1, 22, 236709) And if theirs is the greatest contribution, it is but in accordance with their best tradition.
('76', 121, 1, 23, 236804) And they will be thrice blessed.
('76', 121, 1, 24, 236837) Many of them will be weaned from a trade which corrupts the morals of their countrymen less fortunately placed than they.
('76', 121, 1, 25, 236959) They will themselves be weaned from the drink habit.
('76', 121, 1, 26, 237012) However mild it may be for them, I know, from having lived in intimate contact with them, that the drink does leave an indelible mark on them.
('76', 121, 1, 27, 237155) Thirdly, monied men amongst them will have paid for the long delayed reform.
('76', 121, 1, 28, 237232) The cry of minorities is a calumny.
('76', 121, 1, 29, 237268) It is a Parsi Minister to whose lot has fallen the privilege of introducing prohi bition.
('76', 121, 1, 30, 237358) Dr. Gilder’s is a job which brings him no money and it brings him drudgery and loss of a princely medical practice.
('76', 121, 1, 31, 237474) Another
('76', 122, 0, 1, 237482) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 123
('76', 122, 1, 2, 237526) equally disinterested physician 1 is the Sheriff of Bombay.
('76', 122, 1, 3, 237586) A third learned Parsi is Vice Chancellor 2 of the University, and a fourth businesman is the Mayor 3 of Bombay.
('76', 122, 1, 4, 237698) I do not know that there has been such a happy conjunction before in the history of Bombay.
('76', 122, 1, 5, 237790) If the Congressmen and the Congress Ministry of Bombay were commu nally minded and were indifferent to the minorities, this unique event would not have taken place.
('76', 122, 1, 6, 237955) And I suggest that without the willing co operation of the Mus lim population of Bombay the movement in Bombay could not have been introduced.
('76', 122, 1, 7, 238098) I am quite sure that the best Muslim mind in all India is with the Congress in this Bombay project.
('76', 122, 1, 8, 238198) The piecemeal solution flung by Subhas Babu would not work.
('76', 122, 1, 9, 238258) For one thing it would lack the psychological background.
('76', 122, 1, 10, 238316) I therefore invite Subhas Babu to retrace his steps and join me in making an appeal to the great Parsi community and those others who may oppose the reform to help it to become the success which it deserves to be.
('76', 122, 1, 11, 238530) It is his duty as Rajen Babu’s immediate predecessor to help the Bombay Ministry which is bravely pursuing the policy laid down for it by the Congress.
('76', 122, 1, 12, 238682) Harijan, 22 7 1939.

('76', 125, 4, 5, 242715) 156. NOTES
('76', 125, 5, 6, 242726) VANDEMATARAM
('76', 125, 6, 7, 242739) Some students in Hyderabad complain that my note 1 on Vande mataram has created confusion in their minds.
('76', 125, 6, 8, 242845) They read an extract from it in some local papers from which the words “at a mixed gathering” were omitted so as to leave the impression that it was not to be sung even in gatherings of their own, though such an inter pretation was absurd.
('76', 125, 6, 9, 243085) I was being quoted in support of the con tention that the students should not be allowed to sing Vandemataram in their own rooms or the prayer hall set apart for their section who had not only no objection but who regarded it as part of their prayer to sing it.
('76', 125, 6, 10, 243347) My note is quite plain.
('76', 125, 6, 11, 243371) If at any mixed gathering any person objected to the singing of Vandemataram even with the Congress expurgations, the singing should be dropped.
('76', 125, 6, 12, 243516) But it was never intended to apply to gatherings in which there was no objection raised.
('76', 125, 6, 13, 243605) Such an objection would amount to interference, unlawful and intolerant.
('76', 125, 6, 14, 243678) If objections could be carried to such lengths, even the performance of religious worship would become impossible.
('76', 125, 6, 15, 243793) And I know that for many patriots the singing of Vandemataram amounts to a religious duty.
('76', 125, 7, 16, 243884) THAT OBSTINATE DISEASE
('76', 125, 8, 17, 243907) Thus writes Shri Tatachar who is an ardent lover of Harijans:
('76', 125, 9, 18, 243969) Some time ago there was a riot at Nallathur Cheri.
('76', 125, 9, 19, 244020) Caste men attacked the Adi dravida bhajanai and inflicted injuries on several members of the party.
('76', 125, 10, 20, 244120) this riot caste men received a few injuries.
('76', 125, 10, 21, 244165) Adi dravidas complained of the riot to the police.
('76', 125, 10, 22, 244216) The police took no notice of their complaint.
('76', 125, 10, 23, 244262) Caste men filed private complaints in court against five Adi dravidas.
('76', 125, 10, 24, 244333) These five Adi dravidas
('76', 125, 11, 25, 244357) 1 Vide “The National Flag”, 27 6 1939.
('76', 126, 0, 1, 244396) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 127
('76', 126, 1, 2, 244440) were convicted and fined Rs. 25 each and one month’s rigorous imprisonment in default.
('76', 126, 1, 3, 244527) Appeals were filed and heard on May 26, 1939. Judgment was reserved and was pronounced today in favour of the appellant accused.
('76', 126, 1, 4, 244656) In accordance with the directions of the appellate court, the appellants asked the trying court on May 27, 1939, to postpone the recovery of the fines, until judgments were pronounced in the appeals.
('76', 126, 1, 5, 244856) The lower court refused to grant them time and sent them to jail.
('76', 126, 1, 6, 244922) This grave act of injustice must satisfy you that the problem of the removal of untouchability is not going to solve itself.
('76', 126, 1, 7, 245047) He has sent me also copious notes which I have read with pain ful interest.
('76', 126, 1, 8, 245123) The letter from which I have quoted bare facts is filled with biting strictures of the police and the first court which is reported to have refused to stay execution although appeal was admitted and the appellate court is said to have recommended stay of execution.
('76', 126, 1, 9, 245389) I have asked Shri Tatachar for further particulars.
('76', 126, 1, 10, 245441) Allegations that the police refused to register the complaints of the Harijans while private complaints against them were readily entertained and that the trying magistrate refused to suspend execution of sentences, are serious enough to warrant a departmental enquiry.
('76', 126, 1, 11, 245711) There is no doubt that if the virus of untouchability is to be eradicated, ceaseless vigi lance by the central authority is necessary.
('76', 126, 1, 12, 245846) ABBOTTABAD, July 14, 1939. Harijan, 22 7 1939
('76', 126, 2, 13, 245892) 157. PROVINCIAL AUTONOMY OR PROVINCIAL JEALOUSY
('76', 126, 3, 14, 245940) Shri Jamshedji Mehta writes: After the introduction of provincial autonomy one is pained to observe the growth of provincial exclusiveness and jealousies in matters big or trivial.
('76', 126, 3, 15, 246121) I often wonder if provincial autonomy has not come upon us as a curse rather than a bless ing.
('76', 126, 3, 16, 246216) Instead of the nationalistic spirit having increased, provin cial exclusiveness seems to have flourished.
('76', 126, 3, 17, 246322) Before autonomy ‘my country’ used to mean India.
('76', 126, 3, 18, 246371) Now it means ‘my province’.
('76', 126, 3, 19, 246399) Will you not warn the country against the danger before it becomes too deep rooted to be dealt with?
('76', 126, 3, 20, 246500) The letter is naturally in Gujarati.
('76', 126, 3, 21, 246537) I have given a very free ren dering of the thought and the grief running through the original.
('76', 127, 0, 1, 246632) 128 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 127, 1, 2, 246674) Shri Jamshedji’s complaint has justification for it.
('76', 127, 1, 3, 246727) Provincialism of a healthy type there is, and always will be.
('76', 127, 1, 4, 246789) There is no meaning in having separate provinces, if there were no differences, though healthy, between them.
('76', 127, 1, 5, 246899) But our provincialism must never be narrow or exclusive.
('76', 127, 1, 6, 246956) It should be conducive to the interest of the whole country of which the provinces are but parts.
('76', 127, 1, 7, 247054) They may be likened to tribu taries of a mighty river.
('76', 127, 1, 8, 247109) The tributaries promote its mightiness.
('76', 127, 1, 9, 247149) Their strength and purity will be reflected in the majestic stream.
('76', 127, 1, 10, 247217) It must be thus with the provinces.
('76', 127, 1, 11, 247253) Everything that the provinces do must be for the glory of the whole.
('76', 127, 1, 12, 247322) If the great contribution of Rabindranath glorifies Bengal, it glorifies also India.
('76', 127, 1, 13, 247407) Does not his influence pervade the whole of India?
('76', 127, 1, 14, 247458) Dadabhai lived not merely for the Parsis, not merely for Bombay, but for the whole of India.
('76', 127, 1, 15, 247551) There is no room for exclusiveness or jealousy between province and province, unless India is to be dismembered into warring countries each living for itself and if possible at the expense of the rest.
('76', 127, 1, 16, 247753) The Congress will have lived in vain if such a calamity descends upon the country.
('76', 127, 1, 17, 247836) Every attempt at dividing India into watertight compartments must be resisted.
('76', 127, 1, 18, 247915) India’s destiny is to become a strong, independent nation making her unique contribution to the world’s progress.
('76', 127, 1, 19, 248029) Our patriotism is at no stage exclusive.
('76', 127, 1, 20, 248070) We do not desire prosperity at the expense of the other nations of the earth.
('76', 127, 1, 21, 248148) A time must come when we will be able to say, ‘We are no less citizens of the world than we are citizens of India’.
('76', 127, 1, 22, 248264) But the time will never come unless we know the art of being citizens of an independent India.
('76', 127, 1, 23, 248359) We cannot learn the art if we develop poisonous provincialisms.
('76', 127, 1, 24, 248423) The right national life has to begin with the individual.
('76', 127, 1, 25, 248481) I wish to be strong and free so that not only I but my neighbour also may benefit by my strength and freedom.
('76', 127, 1, 26, 248591) We as individuals or provinces must bring our best fruit to the altar of the motherland.
('76', 127, 1, 27, 248680) ABBOTTABAD, July 14, 1939. Harijan, 22 7 1939

('76', 131, 10, 23, 252706) 165. NOTES ON NIRA
('76', 131, 11, 24, 252725) Shri I. S. Amin, Chief Chemist and Technical Superintendent of the Alembic Chemical Works of Baroda, has made important obser vations during the past two years and arrived at certain conclusions in the experiments on the collection and preservation of nira.
('76', 132, 0, 1, 252983) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 133
('76', 132, 1, 2, 253027) now furnished me with the results which are too technical for the reader.
('76', 132, 1, 3, 253101) He has appended useful notes to the results which are given below.
('76', 132, 2, 4, 253168) Harijan, 15 7 1939.
('76', 132, 3, 5, 253188) 166. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 2
('76', 132, 4, 6, 253218) ABBOTTABAD, July 15, 1939 Some women are inundating me with wires and letters about the hunger striking prisoners in Bengal.
('76', 132, 4, 7, 253343) One telegram peremptorily asks me to discharge my responsibility by myself joining the hunger strike.
('76', 132, 4, 8, 253445) Another lays the whole burden on my shoulders of leading the agitation on the ground that the prisoners had suspended their hun ger strike on my assurance.
('76', 132, 4, 9, 253601) I have returned suitable replies where necessary, but the matter is too important to be disposed of by per sonal replies.
('76', 132, 4, 10, 253723) I fear my fair correspondents are damaging the cause they represent by expecting me to do what I cannot do.
('76', 132, 4, 11, 253831) They are damaging it also by encouraging hunger strikers.
('76', 132, 4, 12, 253889) I have no doubt that the hunger strike is wrong.
('76', 132, 4, 13, 253938) No person should free himself from prison by refusing to take food.
('76', 132, 4, 14, 254006) The women who are corresponding with me, and others who are agitating for their release, should per suade the hunger strikers to give up their fast.
('76', 132, 4, 15, 254155) The exercise of pressure of public opinion is a legitimate method and if it is wisely applied, it will become quite effective.
('76', 132, 4, 16, 254282) No government nowadays can afford to be indifferent to popular opinion.
('76', 132, 4, 17, 254354) Therefore, I implore those who are organizing public opinion to persuade the hunger strikers to give up the hunger strike, and not to mislead the public by expecting me to do the impossible.
('76', 132, 4, 18, 254545) At the same time I would urge the Bengal Government to put an end to this particular agitation by releasing the prisoners although, as I have admitted, the prisoners have put themselves in the wrong by resorting to hunger strike.
('76', 132, 4, 19, 254775) The release is long overdue.
('76', 132, 4, 20, 254804) Rightly or wrongly, and I think rightly, the public had expected their release on the transfer of power to a responsible legislature.
('76', 132, 4, 21, 254938) That expectation should have been fulfilled long ago.

('76', 137, 4, 7, 260810) 177. LETTER TO SIKANDAR HYAT KHAN
('76', 137, 5, 8, 260844) ABBOTTABAD, July 17, 1939
('76', 137, 6, 9, 260870) DEAR SIR SIKANDAR, Many thanks for your letter of 12th instant.
('76', 137, 6, 10, 260934) You have forgotten to answer my question about separate electorates 2 for Harijans.
('76', 137, 6, 11, 261018) I have now carefully gone through your scheme and your remarks upon my draft 3 about Hindu Muslim unity.
('76', 137, 6, 12, 261123) The scheme is too complicated for me to form an opinion.
('76', 137, 6, 13, 261180) I must own to you that I never studied the Government of India Act in the manner required for a proper evaluation of your scheme which I see is designed, so far as the Federal structure is concerned, to replace the Act.
('76', 137, 6, 14, 261400) I see that you contemplate zonal legislatures in between the provincial ones and the Federal legislature.
('76', 137, 6, 15, 261506) The Government of India scheme itself is much too expensive and complicated for me.
('76', 137, 6, 16, 261590) Yours seems to add to the expense and the complication.
('76', 137, 6, 17, 261646) Then you suggest that the composition of the army should not be disturbed except under the contingency mentioned therein.
('76', 137, 7, 18, 261768) 1 Who cabled his reply on July 19 thus: “.
('76', 137, 7, 19, 261811) .situation is being carefully examined and there is no intention to violate 1914 agreement.
('76', 137, 7, 20, 261903) .” 2 This and other points raised by Gandhiji were met by the addressee in his letter dated July 20; vide Appendix “Letter from Sikandar Hyat Khan”, 20 7 1939.
('76', 137, 8, 21, 262063) 3 The Congress Working Committee which met at Bardoli on January 11, 1939, had discussed Gandhiji’s new draft on the minorities question.
('76', 138, 0, 1, 262201) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 139
('76', 138, 1, 2, 262245) out and out believer in non violence like me, I would disband the army altogether.
('76', 138, 1, 3, 262328) An army and non violence go ill together.
('76', 138, 1, 4, 262370) But I am painfully conscious that in this extreme view of non violence I have no partner.
('76', 138, 1, 5, 262460) How far those who believe in the necessity of the country having an army even after it has come to its own will accept your proposition is more than I can say.
('76', 138, 1, 6, 262620) Then you have enunciated Dominion Status as an accepted fact.
('76', 138, 1, 7, 262682) It is a bitter pill for Congressmen to swallow.
('76', 138, 1, 8, 262730) But I see that your solution of the communal tangle is your scheme including the proposal about the army.
('76', 138, 1, 9, 262836) Yours is the only proposal of a constructive character on behalf of the league.
('76', 138, 1, 10, 262916) I con gratulate you on the great pains you have bestowed upon it.
('76', 138, 1, 11, 262982) I am glad that you have decided to publish it in full.
('76', 138, 1, 12, 263037) 1 I must thank you for having taken me into your confidence and asked me to give you my opinion upon it.
('76', 138, 1, 13, 263142) As to my draft solution, as I have already told you, it is in no sense adopted by the Working Committee.
('76', 138, 1, 14, 263247) But it does still represent my views.
('76', 138, 1, 15, 263285) I prize your criticism upon it.
('76', 138, 1, 16, 263317) And if it ever formed a basis for the solution of our difficulties, I should adopt many of your suggestions.
('76', 138, 1, 17, 263426) Your solution for representation of minorities on services causes difficulty.
('76', 138, 1, 18, 263504) What are the minorities?
('76', 138, 1, 19, 263529) Is there a final list?
('76', 138, 1, 20, 263552) I am therefore very uneasy about communal representation in the services.
('76', 138, 1, 21, 263626) If we make much of the minorities question in the services, we shall not only endanger efficiency but we shall endanger purity and impar tiality in the administration of affairs of the country.
('76', 138, 1, 22, 263820) But I heartily en dorse your suggestion that all the backward members of the nation should be levelled up to the forward ones.
('76', 138, 1, 23, 263947) I do not want to burden this letter with the other points arising out of your criticism.
('76', 138, 1, 24, 264036) They are easy of adjustment, If we all make up our minds to meet with the determination not to part without reaching a settlement.
('76', 138, 2, 25, 264167) Yours sincerely, SIR SIKANDAR HYAT KHAN PRIME MINISTER LAHORE

('76', 143, 7, 12, 270720) 186. NOT GUILTY
('76', 143, 8, 13, 270736) Dr. Lohia has sent me a long, well reasoned letter on the current controversy on the Congress resolution 4 on Satyagraha.
('76', 143, 8, 14, 270858) There is a portion in it which demands public discussion.
('76', 143, 8, 15, 270916) Here it is:
('76', 143, 9, 16, 270928) You will not permit the slightest separation of the principle of Satyagraha from your own specific programme.
('76', 143, 9, 17, 271038) Is it not possible to universalize the principles of Satyagraha, to make it the bed rock of programmes other than your own?
('76', 143, 9, 18, 271162) Perhaps, it is not; but I have this argument against you that you have not permitted and encouraged any such experiment.
('76', 143, 9, 19, 271283) The people today do not regard your own programme of ministerial action and constructive activities as wholly adequate; they are experimenting with such programmes as those of peasant action.
('76', 143, 9, 20, 271475) These newer programmes entail an amount of local and isolated action even during such times when there is no general satyagraha.
('76', 143, 9, 21, 271604) Will you stop these little satyagrahas till you have found the formula for a general satyagraha?
('76', 143, 9, 22, 271701) In such a course of action there is the danger of anarchy that arises out of suppression.
('76', 143, 9, 23, 271791) Non violent collective action is among the rarest and most precious gifts received by mankind in all history; we may not, however, know how to treasure it and continue it.
('76', 143, 9, 24, 271963) Not only have I not prohibited separation of the principle of Satyagraha from my own specific programme, I have often invited new programmes.
('76', 143, 9, 25, 272105) But hitherto I have not known a single case of any new programme.
('76', 143, 9, 26, 272171) I have never suggested that there can never be any departure from or addition to my programme.
('76', 143, 9, 27, 272266) What, however, I have
('76', 143, 10, 28, 272288) 1 The source has these in Gujarati.
('76', 143, 11, 29, 272324) 3 The source has this in English.
('76', 143, 11, 30, 272358) 4 Vide “A.I.C.C. Resolutions”, 23 6 1939.
('76', 144, 0, 1, 272400) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 145
('76', 144, 1, 2, 272444) said and would like to repeat here is that I cannot bless or encourage a new programme that makes no appeal to me.
('76', 144, 1, 3, 272559) My programme, I claim, is a deduction from the satyagraha of my conception.
('76', 144, 1, 4, 272635) It is, therefore, likely that if there was any such vital activity favouring the growth of satyagraha, it would not escape me.
('76', 144, 1, 5, 272762) I am painfully conscious of the fact that my programme has not made a general appeal to the Congress intelligentsia.
('76', 144, 1, 6, 272879) I have already pointed out that the reason for the apathy of Congressmen is not to be sought in any inherent defect in the programme, but that it is due to the want of a living faith in ahimsa.
('76', 144, 1, 7, 273073) What can be more patent than that we should have complete communal harmony, eradication of untou chability, sacrifice of the drink revenue by the closing of liquor shops and the replacement of mill cloth by khadi?
('76', 144, 1, 8, 273287) I suggest that non vio lent Swaraj is impossible if Hindus, Muslims and others do not shed their mutual distrust and do not live as blood brothers, if Hindus do not purify themselves by removing the curse of untouchability and thus establish intimate contact with those whom they have for ages put beyond the pale of society, if the wealthy men and women of India will not tax themselves so that the poor who are helpless victims of the drink and drug habit may have the temptation removed from them by the closing of drink and drug shops, and, lastly, if we all will not identify ourselves with the semi starved millions by giving up the taste for mill cloth and revert to khadi produced by the many million hands in the cottages of India.
('76', 144, 1, 9, 274028) In all that has been written against the constructive programme, I have not come across a single convincing argument against either its intrinsic merit or its merit in terms of non violent Swaraj.
('76', 144, 1, 10, 274225) I make bold to say that if all Congressmen concentrate themselves on this constructive programme, we shall soon have the requisite non violent atmosphere throughout the length and breadth of the land for cent per cent satyagraha.
('76', 144, 1, 11, 274455) Take the peasant action suggested by Dr. Lohia as a possible new programme.
('76', 144, 1, 12, 274531) I regret to have to say that in most cases the pea sants are not being educated for non violent action.
('76', 144, 1, 13, 274635) They are being kept in a state of perpetual excitement and made to entertain hopes which can never be fulfilled without a violent conflict.
('76', 144, 1, 14, 274775) The same may safely be said about labour.
('76', 144, 1, 15, 274817) My own experience tells me that both the peasantry and labour can be organized for effective non violent action, if Congressmen honestly work for it.
('76', 144, 1, 16, 274967) But they cannot, if they have no faith in the ultimate success of non violent action.
('76', 144, 1, 17, 275053) All that is required is the proper education of the peasantry and labour.
('76', 145, 0, 1, 275127) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 145, 1, 2, 275169) need to be informed that if they are properly organized they have more wealth and resources through their labour than the capitalists through their money.
('76', 145, 1, 3, 275324) Only capitalists have control over the money market, labour has not over its labour market, although if labour had been well served by its chosen leaders it would have become conscious of the irresistible power that comes from proper instruction in non violence.
('76', 145, 1, 4, 275587) Instead, labour in many cases is being taught to rely on coercive methods to compel compliance with its demands.
('76', 145, 1, 5, 275700) The kind of training that labour generally receives today leaves it in ignorance, and relies upon violence as the ultimate sanction.
('76', 145, 1, 6, 275833) Thus it is not possible for me to regard the present peasant or labour activity as a new programme for the preparation of Satyagraha.
('76', 145, 1, 7, 275967) Indeed what I see around me is not preparation for a non vio lent campaign but for an outbreak of violence, however unconscious or unintended it may be.
('76', 145, 1, 8, 276120) If I was invited to hold myself responsible for this ending to the past twenty years’ effort, I should have no hesitation in pleading guilty.
('76', 145, 1, 9, 276262) Have I not said as much already in these columns?
('76', 145, 1, 10, 276312) But my admission will not take us anywhere, unless it results in the retracing of our steps, the undoing of the wrong already done.
('76', 145, 1, 11, 276444) This means having a reasoned faith in the non violent method as the only means of gaining complete independence.
('76', 145, 1, 12, 276557) When we have that faith, all bickerings within the Congress will cease, there will be no longer an ungainly scramble for power, and there will be mutual help instead of mutual mud flinging.
('76', 145, 1, 13, 276747) But it may be that Congressmen have come to believe that non violence of my definition is played out or is not possible of attainment.
('76', 145, 1, 14, 276882) In that case there should be a conference, formal or informal between all Congress groups or a special meeting of the A. I. C. C. to consider the question whether time has not come to revise the policy of non violence and the consequent constructive programme, and to find out and frame a programme in consonance with and answering the present temper of Congressmen.
('76', 145, 1, 15, 277249) It is up to every Congressman to carry on a fierce search inward and deal with this central problem.
('76', 145, 1, 16, 277350) It is not safe or dignified for the Congress to follow the policy of drift.
('76', 145, 1, 17, 277426) I would like such a meeting to forget that the members belong to different groups and to remember that they are first and last servants of the nation pledged to fight the nation’s battle of freedom with one mind.
('76', 145, 1, 18, 277639) The Congress today is a house divided against itself.
('76', 145, 1, 19, 277693) It must not be.
('76', 145, 1, 20, 277709) ABBOTTABAD, July 19, 1939 Harijan, 29 7 1939

('76', 149, 1, 2, 281906) 193. MINORITY ADMINISTRATION
('76', 149, 2, 3, 281935) The Chief of Chamba is a minor.
('76', 149, 2, 4, 281967) The State is therefore under direct British administration.
('76', 149, 2, 5, 282027) And the administrator acts virtually as the Chief and exercises all his powers.
('76', 149, 2, 6, 282107) A correspondent from Chamba writes :
('76', 149, 3, 7, 282144) Ours is a minority administered State being directly under the control of
('76', 149, 5, 8, 282218) Paramount Power.
('76', 149, 5, 9, 282235) We have been pressing for the repeal of the liberty penalizing laws which have been enforced during the minority administration, and we do wish that popular element be introduced in the temporary administrative council at least during the minority of the Raja .
('76', 149, 5, 10, 282497) 1 In a case like ours the Paramount Power cannot say that it can’t intervene.
('76', 149, 5, 11, 282575) If it has to safeguard the rights of the Ruler, has it not any liability towards the people ?.
('76', 149, 5, 12, 282670) 2Will you throw some light on the question?
('76', 149, 5, 13, 282714) The question is pertinent.
('76', 149, 5, 14, 282741) There is no reason whatsoever why the people of administered States should not enjoy all the liberty that those in British India enjoy.
('76', 149, 5, 15, 282877) Indeed a wise and liberal minded administrator of a State has within his jurisdiction greater opportunity for doing good than one in British India proper.
('76', 149, 5, 16, 283032) A State administrator has much greater latitude than an official working under the routine of a Province.
('76', 149, 5, 17, 283138) The latter is subject to a series of superiors and has only limited powers.
('76', 149, 5, 18, 283214) An administrator of a State is much more than a Governor in his own little State.
('76', 149, 5, 19, 283296) He is subject only to general super vision of the Resident of the Agency to which his State belongs.
('76', 149, 5, 20, 283397) Therefore there is no excuse whatsoever for any misrule or failure of justice in administered States, if the Paramount Power’s policy is declared in unambiguous terms and followed in its entirety.
('76', 149, 5, 21, 283594) But if the administration is not all it should be, it shows that there is no well defined policy of the Paramount Power so far as the people of the States are concerned.
('76', 149, 5, 22, 283764) There is no insistence on the right being done by the States towards their people.
('76', 149, 5, 23, 283847) There should be no such thing as policy of non interference by the Paramount Power in so far as the elementary rights of the people are concerned.
('76', 149, 5, 24, 283994) The policy of non interference can remain unchallenged only so long as the States people are ignorant of their strength.
('76', 149, 5, 25, 284115) But there is nowadays too much consciousness among the people of the States to permit of the policy
('76', 149, 6, 26, 284215) 1 Omissions as in the source 2 Ibdi
('76', 150, 0, 1, 284251) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 151
('76', 150, 1, 2, 284295) of non interference being successful any longer.
('76', 150, 1, 3, 284344) Denial of justice in administered States should be unthinkable.
('76', 150, 1, 4, 284408) Let the people of Chamba publish unvarnished facts about the state of things there.
('76', 150, 1, 5, 284492) I have little doubt that if there is any unjustice done there, force of public opinion will secure the needed redress.
('76', 150, 1, 6, 284611) Absence of declared policy by the Paramount Power about the rights of the people of the States is perhaps glaringly demonstrated by the happenings in the little hill State of Dhami.
('76', 150, 1, 7, 284793) The shooting that took place there would have been impossible if the policy of the Paramount Power was known.
('76', 150, 1, 8, 284903) The communique issued by the Political Agent should not be the last word on the tragedy.
('76', 150, 1, 9, 284992) He had no material before him to enable him to form a correct judgment.
('76', 150, 1, 10, 285064) Every such firing should be followed up by an open, quick, judicial inquiry.
('76', 150, 1, 11, 285141) The Chiefs who get easily frightened and resort to firing ought not to possess the power they have today over the lives of their subjects.
('76', 150, 1, 12, 285280) But the public who have to form an opinion do not have a fair chance of doing so.
('76', 150, 1, 13, 285362) They cannot set up an authoritative inquiry.
('76', 150, 1, 14, 285407) And a Political Agent’s communique is no true guide.
('76', 150, 1, 15, 285460) Take the Dhami communique.
('76', 150, 1, 16, 285487) I need not challenge the statements made in it.
('76', 150, 1, 17, 285535) For aught I know every word in it may be true.
('76', 150, 1, 18, 285582) But it cannot command implicit confidence.
('76', 150, 1, 19, 285625) In its very nature, it is a one sided document.
('76', 150, 1, 20, 285673) The Political Agent can produce no legal proof in support of his statements.
('76', 150, 1, 21, 285750) He does not give the sources of his information.
('76', 150, 1, 22, 285799) To inspire confidence there should be a judicial enquiry carrying necessary consequences for the wrongdoer or doers whether the wrong done is on the part of the State or the people.
('76', 150, 1, 23, 285981) Thus, if the people sought to overwhelm the Rana, it was undoubtedly wrong as it was if there was defiance of the order against Shri Bhagmal.
('76', 150, 1, 24, 286123) It was wrong too if outsiders joined the alleged demonstration.
('76', 150, 1, 25, 286187) The lightning ultimatum, if it was that, was a prepost erous thing deserving severe condemnation.
('76', 150, 1, 26, 286285) Responsible government is made of sterner stuff.
('76', 150, 1, 27, 286334) If the principality consists of only 5,000 persons and the revenue is Rs. 30,000, responsible government is a meaningless term.
('76', 150, 1, 28, 286462) If people in every principality will take the law into their own hands, they will do irreparable damage to the cause.
('76', 150, 1, 29, 286580) The All India States Conference is there to guide them.
('76', 150, 1, 30, 286636) Every Praja Mandal should put itself under its guidance in order to enable it to frame its case for freedom.
('76', 150, 1, 31, 286745) There seems to be little doubt that there has been undue haste on the people’s side.
('76', 150, 1, 32, 286830) But what about the Rana?
('76', 150, 1, 33, 286855) Has he been dealing justly by his people?
('76', 150, 1, 34, 286897) Was he really in danger of his life to warrant firing in self 
('76', 151, 0, 1, 286960) 152 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 151, 1, 2, 287002) defence?
('76', 151, 1, 3, 287011) Every crowd is not necessarily a hostile crowd.
('76', 151, 1, 4, 287059) Firing ought not to be treated lightly.
('76', 151, 1, 5, 287099) Human life should have the same value in a State as in British India.
('76', 151, 1, 6, 287169) Every firing should be followed by the closest scrutiny and by suitable action both of a punitive and of a preventive character.
('76', 151, 1, 7, 287298) It is the duty of the Paramount Power to deprive Chiefs of powers of which they do not know judicious use.
('76', 151, 1, 8, 287405) The whole question regarding the place of the States in Greater India requires over hauling.
('76', 151, 1, 9, 287498) A new epoch has come replacing the old.
('76', 151, 1, 10, 287538) With the change of the times there must be a change in the manners of all parties—the Paramount Power, the Princes, their people, and last but not least the Congress if it survives the internal crisis that has overtaken it.
('76', 151, 1, 11, 287762) It will be a mistake for the Paramount Power or the Princes to ignore the Congress, a body under whose shadow the people of the States from the commencement have been accustomed to grow and flourish.
('76', 151, 1, 12, 287962) The Congress must guide them.
('76', 151, 1, 13, 287992) Any resenting by the Princes or the Paramount Power of guidance of the people by the Congress must result in an inevitable but wholly unnecessary clash.
('76', 151, 1, 14, 288145) How can people who are one in blood and bound together by the closest social and economic ties be artificially kept apart for any length of time?
('76', 151, 1, 15, 288291) Instead of suspecting or fearing the Congress, surely the proper thing for all concerned is to welcome the Congress aid whenever it is available for the common good of both the Princes and the people.
('76', 151, 1, 16, 288492) No doubt the Congress will have to recognize its own limita tions.
('76', 151, 1, 17, 288559) It can hope to work with effect only if its work is of a friendly and peaceful nature.
('76', 151, 1, 18, 288646) It has to hold the scales evenly between parties.
('76', 151, 1, 19, 288696) It must avoid all show of force or coercion.
('76', 151, 1, 20, 288741) Thus the reported participation by non Dhami ites in the demonstration should have been impossible under the Congress aegis.
('76', 151, 1, 21, 288866) The Congress influence can be effectively exercised only if it retains its non violence.
('76', 151, 1, 22, 288955) Its only capital is its moral authority.
('76', 151, 1, 23, 288996) Any other position must lead to inter necine feud and bloodshed.
('76', 151, 1, 24, 289061) Dhami has a lesson which Congressmen have to take to heart.
('76', 151, 1, 25, 289121) This I say quite apart from the admitted fact that we do not yet know exactly what happened and where the blame actually lay.
('76', 151, 1, 26, 289247) In the absence of a proper judicial inquiry, right action becomes impossible.
('76', 151, 1, 27, 289325) ABBOTTABAD, July 20, 1939 Harijan, 29 7 1939

('76', 152, 4, 6, 289662) 195. LETTER TO PRABHAVATI
('76', 152, 5, 7, 289688) ABBOTTABAD, July 22, 1939
('76', 152, 6, 8, 289714) PRABHA, Your letter arrived here yesterday via Peshawar.
('76', 152, 6, 9, 289771) It is all right that you wrote to Rajen Babu, but you must improve your health.
('76', 152, 6, 10, 289851) Other wise you will not be of any use at all.
('76', 152, 6, 11, 289897) Why do you keep worrying?

('76', 153, 1, 2, 290794) 196. MY NOTES
('76', 153, 2, 3, 290808) HOW TO ATTAIN TRUTH
('76', 153, 3, 4, 290828) Lab Bibando, Chashma Bando, Gosh Band
('76', 153, 4, 5, 290866) Gar Nabini Sirre Haq, Bar Ma Bikhand
('76', 153, 5, 6, 290903) Keep your lips, eyes and ears closed and laugh at me then if you do not
('76', 153, 6, 7, 290975) reach the heart of Truth.
('76', 153, 6, 8, 291001) This is a couplet by Maulana Rumi.
('76', 153, 6, 9, 291036) Off and on Chaman Kavi of Kutch sends me such valuable verses.
('76', 153, 6, 10, 291099) When I was at Rajkot, he sent me the above verse along with its meaning.
('76', 153, 6, 11, 291172) I liked it so much that I wanted to place it before the readers of Harijanbandhu.
('76', 153, 6, 12, 291254) At times when we talk nonsense, listen to falsehood or filth and look at objec tionable things, this couplet ought to pierce our heart like a pointed arrow.
('76', 153, 6, 13, 291411) The quest for Truth demands a heavy price.
('76', 153, 6, 14, 291454) We may not actually close our lips, ears and eyes although we would lose nothing by closing them.
('76', 153, 6, 15, 291552) We can, however, certainly do this much.
('76', 153, 6, 16, 291593) Instead of uttering false or bitter words or hearing defamatory or useless things or watching lustful scenes, we may speak the truth at all costs, chant the name of God, hear His songs, observe the magic of His creation, have darshan of the saints and hear only such things as will help our progress.
('76', 153, 6, 17, 291894) It is only he who does this that will attain the Truth.
('76', 153, 6, 18, 291950) He alone can be a true satyagrahi and through his tapascharya we can get a glimpse of peaceful Swaraj.
('76', 153, 6, 19, 292053) The rest is all in vain.
('76', 153, 6, 20, 292078) [From Gujarati]
('76', 153, 7, 21, 292094) Harijanbandhu, 23 7 1939

('76', 155, 5, 13, 293857) 200. LETTER TO ADOLF HITLER 3
('76', 155, 6, 14, 293887) AS AT WARDHA, C. P., INDIA, July 23, 1939
('76', 155, 7, 15, 293929) DEAR FRIEND, Friends have been urging me to write to you for the sake of humanity.
('76', 155, 7, 16, 294012) But I have resisted their request, because of the feeling that any letter from me would be an impertinence.
('76', 155, 7, 17, 294120) Something tells me that I must not calculate and that I must make my appeal for whatever it may be worth.
('76', 155, 7, 18, 294226) It is quite clear that you are today the one person in the world who can prevent a war which may reduce humanity to the savage state.
('76', 155, 8, 19, 294360) 1 Of the Hindu Maha Sabha 2 Dated July 20, which read: “.
('76', 155, 8, 20, 294418) owing to corruption and rise of violence in the Congress and the country generally and particularly owing to non achievement of Hindu Muslim unity, you do not feel justified in advising the Congress to start mass civil disobedience for exercising pressure on the Government to modify the present Federation according to your wishes .
('76', 155, 8, 21, 294752) and yet the Congress is not prepared to accept this Federation.
('76', 155, 8, 22, 294816) The Government on the other hand not being pressed or coerced to modify the Federation according to your wishes will remain indifferent in the matter, though it may be tempted to modify it to suit the conveniences of the Muslim League.
('76', 155, 8, 23, 295052) The result will be that the Muslim communalism will be still further strengthened and the hope for Hindu Muslim unity will disappear for ever .
('76', 155, 8, 24, 295196) Will it not be wise to accept the present Federation in spite of all its defects and use it as a jumping ground for further quarrels and gains ?.
('76', 155, 8, 25, 295342) ” 3 The Government did not permit this letter to go.
('76', 156, 0, 1, 295395) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 157
('76', 156, 1, 2, 295439) Must you pay that price for an object however worthy it may appear to you to be?
('76', 156, 1, 3, 295520) Will you listen to the appeal of one who has deliberately shunned the method of war not without considerable success?
('76', 156, 1, 4, 295638) Anyway I anticipate your forgiveness, if I have erred in writing to you.
('76', 156, 2, 5, 295711) I remain, Your sincere friend, HERR HITLER BERLIN GERMANY

('76', 157, 4, 16, 297504) 203. SPEECH AT ABBOTTABAD
('76', 157, 5, 17, 297530) [July 23, 1939] 1
('76', 157, 6, 18, 297548) I hardly thought, when I came here, that you would present me with an address even this time too, on my third 2 visit to your province.
('76', 157, 6, 19, 297684) I had thought I had sufficiently identified myself with your province to be entitled to be regarded as one of you and therefore above the need of such formalities as the presentation of an address.
('76', 157, 6, 20, 297882) Should I suppose that I have still to win my spurs?
('76', 157, 6, 21, 297934) Last time you gave me an address and a purse.
('76', 157, 6, 22, 297980) But this time you have given me only an address and no purse.
('76', 157, 6, 23, 298042) May I inquire how I have merited this ‘fall from grace’?
('76', 157, 6, 24, 298099) I have more than once heard the complaint that the establish ment of Hindu Muslim unity is being delayed owing to lack of sufficient effort in its behalf on my part, that if only I would concentrate myself on it exclusively it could be realized today.
('76', 157, 6, 25, 298351) May I assure you that if I do not seem to be doing that today, it is not because my passion for Hindu Muslim unity has grown less.
('76', 157, 6, 26, 298482) But I have realized, as I had never done before, my own imperfection as an instrument for this high mission and the inadequacy of mere external means for the attainment of big objects.
('76', 157, 6, 27, 298667) I have learnt more and more to resign myself utterly to His grace.
('76', 157, 7, 28, 298734) 1 From The Hindustan Times.
('76', 157, 7, 29, 298762) Harijan, however, has July 24.
('76', 157, 8, 30, 298793) 2 The two earlier visits were in May and October November, 1938.
('76', 158, 0, 1, 298858) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 159
('76', 158, 1, 2, 298902) If you could dissect my heart, you would find that the prayer and spiritual striving for the attainment of Hindu Muslim unity goes on there unceasingly all the twenty four hours without even a moment’s interruption, whether I am awake or asleep.
('76', 158, 1, 3, 299148) I want Hindu Muslim unity if only because I know that without it there can be no Swaraj.
('76', 158, 1, 4, 299237) Let no one imagine that because the Hindus constitute the majority community they can win Swaraj for India or even for them selves by organizing civil disobedience without the backing or support of the other communities.
('76', 158, 1, 5, 299458) Civil disobedience of the purest type, as I have often repeated, can be effective even if it is confined to a few.
('76', 158, 1, 6, 299573) But then these few must represent in their persons the united will and strength of the whole nation.
('76', 158, 1, 7, 299674) Is it not the same in armed warfare?
('76', 158, 1, 8, 299711) The fighting forces need the backing and co operation of the entire civil population.
('76', 158, 1, 9, 299797) Without it they would be crippled.
('76', 158, 1, 10, 299832) I must be impatient for Hindu Muslim unity because I am impatient for Swaraj.
('76', 158, 1, 11, 299910) And I have full faith that true and lasting heart unity between the Hindus and Mussalmans, not a merely patched up political compromise, will come sooner or later, sooner perhaps than later.
('76', 158, 1, 12, 300101) That dream has filled my being since my earliest childhood.
('76', 158, 1, 13, 300161) I have the vividest recollection of my father’s days, how the Hindus and Mussalmans of Rajkot used to mix together and participate in one another’s domestic functions and ceremonies like blood brothers.
('76', 158, 1, 14, 300364) I believe that those days will dawn once again over this country.
('76', 158, 1, 15, 300430) The present bickerings and petty recriminations between the communities are an unnatural aberration.
('76', 158, 1, 16, 300531) They cannot last for ever.
('76', 158, 1, 17, 300558) The greatest of things in this world are accomplished not through unaided human effort.
('76', 158, 1, 18, 300646) They come in their own good time.
('76', 158, 1, 19, 300680) God has his own way of choosing his instruments.
('76', 158, 1, 20, 300729) Who knows, in spite of my incessant heart prayer I may not be found worthy for this great work.
('76', 158, 1, 21, 300825) We must all keep our loins girt and our lamps well trimmed; we do not know when or on whom his choice may fall.
('76', 158, 1, 22, 300937) You may not shirk your responsibility by shoving it all on me.
('76', 158, 1, 23, 301000) Pray for me that my dream may be fulfilled in my lifetime.
('76', 158, 1, 24, 301059) We must never give way to despair or pessimism.
('76', 158, 1, 25, 301107) God’s ways are more than man’s arithmetic.
('76', 158, 1, 26, 301150) It has grieved me to find that internal squabbles have begun to fill the Congress ranks in this province too.
('76', 158, 1, 27, 301260) Yesterday I was closeted for over an hour with the members of your Provincial Congress Committee.
('76', 158, 1, 28, 301358) They asked me to show them a way out.
('76', 158, 1, 29, 301396) I suggest to you that the solution lies in your own hands.
('76', 158, 1, 30, 301455) You have adopted Khan Saheb Abdul Ghaffar Khan as your uncrowned chieftain.
('76', 158, 1, 31, 301531) You have
('76', 159, 0, 1, 301540) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 159, 1, 2, 301582) given him the proud titles of ‘Badshah Khan’ and ‘Fakhr e Afghan’.
('76', 159, 1, 3, 301649) Let his word be law to you as it was before.
('76', 159, 1, 4, 301694) He does not believe in argument.
('76', 159, 1, 5, 301727) He speaks from his heart.
('76', 159, 1, 6, 301753) You must learn to sink your individual differences and work together like a team under him if the titles that you have bestowed upon him are to be vindicated, and not remain as mere lip compliments.
('76', 159, 1, 7, 301952) Then there is the question of poverty among the Frontier masses.
('76', 159, 1, 8, 302017) I am told that many of them hardly get enough to eat.
('76', 159, 1, 9, 302071) It is a humiliating reflection that a sturdy race like the Pathans should be in that plight.
('76', 159, 1, 10, 302164) But here again the remedy lies largely with you.
('76', 159, 1, 11, 302213) You must teach the people to work with their hands and realize the dignity of labour.
('76', 159, 1, 12, 302299) The Ministry can and will, of course, provide facilities.
('76', 159, 1, 13, 302357) But the spade work will have to be done by volunteers.
('76', 159, 1, 14, 302412) May God show you the right way.
('76', 159, 1, 15, 302444) I know that even when we quarrel amongst ourselves it is only to hasten the advent of indepen dence in the fond hope that independence will prove a solvent of all our ills.
('76', 159, 1, 16, 302617) May our passion for independence prove a uniting bond stronger than all the differences that divide us.
('76', 159, 2, 17, 302721) Harijan, 5 8 1939; also The Hindustan Times, 24 7 1939

('76', 161, 3, 4, 304476) MY DEAR HANNA, I was delighted to have your letter after so many months.

('76', 161, 3, 10, 304765) As in the body so in the spirit though the diseases are various the cause is one and so is the remedy one, so in the spirit world, the cause of distemper is one and therefore the remedy also is one.
('76', 161, 3, 11, 304964) Every spiritual distemper is a fleeing away from God.
('76', 161, 3, 12, 305018) The surest remedy therefore is to seek the presence of God so much so that we see Him face to face.
('76', 161, 3, 13, 305118) In the presence of God, there can be no sin, no sorrow, no anger, no malice, no falsehood.
('76', 161, 3, 14, 305209) In His presence there is no fear, no external affliction can put us out.
('76', 161, 3, 15, 305282) If this lesson of lessons is learnt there is no question, no doubt left.

('76', 164, 1, 2, 308765) 213. DISCUSSION WITH CHARLES FABRI 1
('76', 164, 2, 3, 308802) ABBOTTABAD, [On or before July 26, 1939] 2
('76', 164, 3, 4, 308845) GANDHIJI: It is a difficult thing to explain fully what I do when I pray.
('76', 164, 3, 5, 308919) But I must try to answer your question.
('76', 164, 3, 6, 308959) The Divine Mind is un changeable, but that Divinity is in everyone and everything— animate and inanimate.
('76', 164, 3, 7, 309065) The meaning of prayer is that I want to evoke that Divinity within me.
('76', 164, 3, 8, 309136) Now I may have that intellectual conviction, but not a living touch.
('76', 164, 3, 9, 309205) And so when I pray for Swaraj or indepen dence for India I pray or wish for adequate power to gain that Swaraj or to make the largest contribution I can towards winning it, and I maintain that I can get that power in answer to prayer.
('76', 164, 4, 10, 309440) FABRI: Then you are not justified in calling it prayer.
('76', 164, 4, 11, 309496) To pray means to beg or demand.
('76', 164, 4, 12, 309528) Yes, indeed.
('76', 164, 4, 13, 309541) You may say I beg it of myself, of my Higher Self, the Real Self with which I have not yet achieved complete identifi cation.
('76', 164, 4, 14, 309667) You may therefore describe it as a continual longing to lose oneself in the Divinity which comprises all.
('76', 164, 5, 15, 309773) And you use an old form to evoke this?
('76', 164, 5, 16, 309812) The habit of a lifetime persists, and I would allow it to be said that I pray to an outside Power.
('76', 164, 5, 17, 309911) I am part of that Infinite, and yet such an infinitesimal part that I feel outside it.
('76', 164, 5, 18, 309998) Though I give you the intellectual explanation, I feel, without identification with the Divinity, so small that I am nothing.
('76', 164, 5, 19, 310124) Immediately I begin to say I do this thing and that thing, I begin to feel my unworthiness and nothingness, and feel that someone else, some Higher Power, has to help me.
('76', 164, 6, 20, 310295) Tolstoy says the same thing.
('76', 164, 6, 21, 310324) Prayer really is complete meditation and melting into the Higher Self, though one occasionally does lapse in imploration like that of a child to his father.
('76', 164, 7, 22, 310481) 1 This appeared under the title “A Dialogue with a Buddhist” by Mahadev Desai, who explains: “.
('76', 164, 7, 23, 310577) .an archaeologist.
('76', 164, 7, 24, 310596) Dr. Fabri .
('76', 164, 7, 25, 310608) has been in India for many years.
('76', 164, 7, 26, 310642) He was a pupil of Prof.
('76', 164, 7, 27, 310666) Sylvain Levi and came out as assistant to the famous archaeologist, Sir Aurel Stein .
('76', 164, 7, 28, 310752) He is a Hungarian and had in the past corresponded with Gandhiji and even sympathetically fasted with him.
('76', 164, 7, 29, 310859) He had come to Abbottabad specially to see Gandhiji .
('76', 164, 7, 30, 310913) He was particulary exercised about the form and content of prayer and would very much like to know what kind of prayer Gandhiji said.
('76', 164, 7, 31, 311047) Could the Divine Mind be changed by prayer?
('76', 164, 7, 32, 311091) Could one find it out by prayer?” 2 Gandhiji left Abbottabad on July 26, 1939.
('76', 165, 0, 1, 311170) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 165, 1, 2, 311212) Pardon me, I would not call it a lapse.
('76', 165, 1, 3, 311252) It is more in the fitness of things to say that I pray to God who exists somewhere up in the clouds, and the more distant He is, the greater is my longing for Him and [I] find myself in His presence in thought.
('76', 165, 1, 4, 311463) And thought as you know has a greater velocity than light.
('76', 165, 1, 5, 311522) Therefore the distance between me and Him, though so incalculably great, is obliterated.
('76', 165, 1, 6, 311611) He is so far and yet so near.
('76', 165, 2, 7, 311641) It becomes a matter of belief, but some people like me are cursed with an acute
('76', 165, 3, 8, 311721) critical faculty.
('76', 165, 3, 9, 311739) For me there is nothing higher than what Buddha taught, and no great
('76', 165, 4, 10, 311808) master.
('76', 165, 4, 11, 311816) For Buddha alone among the teachers of the world said: ‘Don’t believe
('76', 165, 5, 12, 311886) implicitly what I say.
('76', 165, 5, 13, 311909) Don’t accept any dogma or any book as infallible.’ There is for
('76', 165, 6, 14, 311973) me no infallible book in the world, inasmuch as all were made by men, however
('76', 165, 7, 15, 312051) inspired they may have been.
('76', 165, 7, 16, 312080) I cannot hence believe in a personal idea of God, a
('76', 165, 8, 17, 312132) Maharaja sitting on the Great White Throne listening to our prayers.
('76', 165, 8, 18, 312201) I am glad that
('76', 165, 9, 19, 312216) your prayer is on different level.
('76', 165, 10, 20, 312251) Let me remind you that you are again only partially true when you say my prayer is on a different level.
('76', 165, 10, 21, 312356) I told you that the intellec tual conviction that I gave you is not eternally present with me.
('76', 165, 10, 22, 312451) What is present is the intensity of faith whereby I lose myself in an Invisible Power.
('76', 165, 10, 23, 312538) And so it is far truer to say that God has done a thing for me than that I did it.
('76', 165, 10, 24, 312621) So many things have happened in my life for which I had intense longing, but which I could never have achieved myself.
('76', 165, 10, 25, 312740) And I have always said to my co workers it was in answer to my prayer.
('76', 165, 10, 26, 312811) I did not say to them it was in answer to my intellectual effort to lose myself in the Divinity in me!
('76', 165, 10, 27, 312914) The easiest and the correct thing for me was to say, ‘God has seen me through my difficulty.’
('76', 165, 11, 28, 313008) But that you deserved by your karma.
('76', 165, 11, 29, 313045) God is Justice and not Mercy.
('76', 165, 11, 30, 313075) You are a good man and good things happen to you.
('76', 165, 11, 31, 313125) No fear.
('76', 165, 11, 32, 313134) I am not good enough for things to happen like that.
('76', 165, 11, 33, 313187) If I went about with that philosophical conception of karma, I should often come a cropper.
('76', 165, 11, 34, 313279) My karma would not come to my help.
('76', 165, 11, 35, 313315) Although I believe in the inexorable law of karma I am striving to do so many things; every moment of my life is a strenuous endeavour which is an attempt to build up more karma, to undo the past and add to the present.
('76', 165, 11, 36, 313535) It is therefore wrong to say that because my past is good, good is happening at present.
('76', 165, 11, 37, 313624) The past would be soon ex hausted, and I have to build up the future with prayer.
('76', 165, 11, 38, 313706) I tell you karma alone is powerless.
('76', 165, 11, 39, 313743) ‘Ignite this match,’ I say to myself, and yet I cannot if there is no co operation from without.
('76', 165, 11, 40, 313840) Before I strike the
('76', 166, 0, 1, 313860) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 167
('76', 166, 1, 2, 313904) match my hand is paralysed or I have only one match and the wind blows it off.
('76', 166, 1, 3, 313983) Is it an accident or God or Higher Power?
('76', 166, 1, 4, 314025) Well, I prefer to use the language of my ancestors or of children.
('76', 166, 1, 5, 314092) I am no better than a child.
('76', 166, 1, 6, 314121) We may try to talk learnedly and of books, but when it comes to brass tacks—when we are face to face with a calamity—we behave like children and begin to cry and pray and our intellectual belief gives no satisfaction!
('76', 166, 2, 7, 314339) I know, very highly developed men to whom belief in God gives incredible comfort and help in the building of character.
('76', 166, 2, 8, 314459) But there, are some great spirits that can do without it.
('76', 166, 2, 9, 314517) That is what Buddhism has taught me.
('76', 166, 2, 10, 314554) But Buddhism is one long prayer.
('76', 166, 3, 11, 314587) Buddha asked everyone to find salvation from himself.
('76', 166, 3, 12, 314641) He never prayed, he meditated.
('76', 166, 3, 13, 314672) Call it by whatever name you like, it is the same thing.
('76', 166, 3, 14, 314729) Look at his statues.
('76', 166, 4, 15, 314750) But they are not true to life.
('76', 166, 4, 16, 314781) They are 400 years later than his death.
('76', 166, 4, 17, 314822) Well, give me your own history of Buddha as you may have discovered it.
('76', 166, 4, 18, 314894) I will prove that he was a praying Buddha.
('76', 166, 4, 19, 314937) The intellectual conception does not satisfy me.
('76', 166, 4, 20, 314986) I have not given you a perfect and full definition as you cannot describe your own thought.
('76', 166, 4, 21, 315078) The very effort to describe is a limitation.
('76', 166, 4, 22, 315123) It defies analysis and you have nothing but scepticism as the residue.
('76', 166, 5, 23, 315194) What about the people who cannot pray?
('76', 166, 5, 24, 315233) ‘Be humble,’ I would say to them,‘and do not limit even the real Buddha by your own conception of Buddha.’ He could not have ruled the lives of millions of men that he did and does today if he was not humble enough to pray.
('76', 166, 5, 25, 315457) There is something infinitely higher than intellect that rules us and even the sceptics.
('76', 166, 5, 26, 315546) Their scepticism and philosophy does not help them in critical periods of their lives.
('76', 166, 5, 27, 315633) They need something better, something outside them that can sustain them.
('76', 166, 5, 28, 315707) And so if someone puts a conundrum before me, I say to him,‘You are not going to know the meaning of God or prayer unless you reduce yourself to a cipher.
('76', 166, 5, 29, 315862) You must be humble enough to see that in spite of your greatness and gigantic intellect you are but a speck in the universe.
('76', 166, 5, 30, 315987) A merely intellectual conception of the things of life is not enough.
('76', 166, 5, 31, 316057) It is the spiritual conception which eludes the intellect, and which alone can give one satisfaction.
('76', 166, 5, 32, 316159) Even monied men have critical periods in their lives; though they are surrounded by every thing that money can buy and affection can give, they find at certain
('76', 167, 0, 1, 316319) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 167, 1, 2, 316361) moments in their lives utterly distracted.
('76', 167, 1, 3, 316404) It is in these moments that we have a glimpse of God, a vision of Him who is guiding every one of our steps in life.
('76', 167, 1, 4, 316521) It is prayer.’
('76', 167, 2, 5, 316536) You mean what we might call a true religious experience which is stronger than intellectual conception.
('76', 167, 2, 6, 316640) Twice in life I had that experience, but I have since lost it.
('76', 167, 2, 7, 316703) But I now find great comfort in one or two sayings of Buddha: ‘Selfishness is the cause of sorrow.’ ‘Remember, monks, everything is fleeting.’ To think of these takes almost the place of belief.
('76', 167, 2, 8, 316898) That is prayer.
('76', 167, 3, 9, 316914) What would you say to the right of man to dispose of his life?
('76', 167, 3, 10, 316977) Life as life I hold of very little importance.
('76', 167, 3, 11, 317024) I think that man has a perfect right to dispose of his life under certain circumstances.
('76', 167, 3, 12, 317113) A co worker 1, suffering from leprosy, knowing that his life was as much an agony for those who had to serve him as it was for him, recently decided to end his life abstaining from food and water.
('76', 167, 3, 13, 317310) I blessed the idea.
('76', 167, 3, 14, 317330) I said to him: ‘If you really think you can stand the trial you may do so.’ I said this to him for I knew how different it is to die by inches from, say, suddenly killing oneself by drowning or poisoning.
('76', 167, 3, 15, 317535) And my warning was fully justified, for some one tempted him with the hope that there was one who could cure leprosy, and I now hear that he has resumed eating and put himself under his treatment!
('76', 167, 4, 16, 317732) The criticism seems to me to be that if one’s mind is completely obscured by pain, the best thing for him would be to seek nirvana.
('76', 167, 4, 17, 317864) A man may not be ill but he
('76', 167, 5, 18, 317892) may be tired of the struggle.
('76', 167, 5, 19, 317922) No, no.
('76', 167, 5, 20, 317930) My mind rejects this suicide.
('76', 167, 5, 21, 317960) The criterion is not that one is tired of life, but that one feels that one has become a burden on others and therefore wants to leave the world.
('76', 167, 5, 22, 318106) One does not want to fly from pain but from having to become an utter burden on others.
('76', 167, 5, 23, 318194) Otherwise one suffers greater pain in a violent effort to end one’s agony.
('76', 167, 5, 24, 318269) But supposing I have a cancer, and it is only a question of time for me to pass away, I would even ask my doctor to give me a sleeping draught and thereby have the sleep that knows no waking .
('76', 167, 6, 25, 318462) Now according to you I should have no business to stay if I feel I have finished my task.
('76', 167, 6, 26, 318552) And I do think I have finished mine!
('76', 167, 7, 27, 318589) 1 Parachure Shastri 2 Here, Mahadev Desai explains: “Dr. Fabri got up to go with the parting wish that there may be many more years of helpful activity left for Gandhiji.”
('76', 168, 0, 1, 318761) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 169
('76', 168, 1, 2, 318805) I am convinced that you can serve humanity for many years.
('76', 168, 1, 3, 318864) Millions are praying for your life.
('76', 168, 1, 4, 318900) And though I can neither pray nor desire anything— Yes, the English language is so elastic that you can find another word to say the same thing.
('76', 168, 2, 5, 319045) Yes, I can unselfishly opine that you have many years before you.
('76', 168, 2, 6, 319111) Well, that’s it.
('76', 168, 2, 7, 319128) You have found the word!
('76', 168, 2, 8, 319153) Here too let me tell you there is the purely intellectual conception of a man being unable to live.
('76', 168, 2, 9, 319253) If he has not the desire to live, the body will perish for the mere absence of the desire to live.
