('76', 169, 4, 20, 320819) 217. SPEECH AT HARIJAN INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL, DELHI 1
('76', 169, 5, 21, 320869) July 27, 1939 I congratulate myself that I am here to give away the certificates to the first batch of students leaving the school which was established in 1936. But the fact that they have won the certificates throws a good deal of responsibility on their as well as my shoulders—mine because my blessings, which are being given from the depth of my heart, must bear fruit.
('76', 169, 5, 22, 321244) That only time can show.
('76', 169, 5, 23, 321269) Shri Viyogi Hari will have to maintain contact with the boys who are going out today.
('76', 169, 5, 24, 321355) It will have to be a contact as close as that between parents and children.
('76', 169, 5, 25, 321431) The parents’ interest in the children is all the more when the children go away from them for work in distant places.
('76', 169, 5, 26, 321549) He will keep me informed of your progress.
('76', 169, 6, 27, 321592) 1 This appeared under the title “Among Harijan Boys” by Mahadev Desai, who explains that Gandhiji presided over the first convocation of the school which imparted a system of education cum manual training comprising carpentry, tailoring, leather work and paper making.
('76', 169, 6, 28, 321861) The Hindustan Times, 28 7 1939, reported that Viyogi Hari, Superintendent of the school, read out the report, and that Gandhiji, before his speech, gave away certificates to all the 21 students and then presented some spinning wheels made by the institution to those who had distinguished themselves in spinning.
('76', 170, 0, 1, 322174) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 171
('76', 170, 1, 2, 322218) The responsibility will be no less yours to be worthy of the training you have received, of the clean life you have lived, and of the uplifting contacts you have formed here.
('76', 170, 1, 3, 322393) My blessings will be no use if you will not fulfil your trust.
('76', 170, 1, 4, 322456) Your responsibility is enhanced by the fact that you will go out as representatives of Harijans and you will have to reflect in your life there the life you have lived here.
('76', 170, 1, 5, 322630) Your contribution to the destruction of untouchability will be in proportion to the cleanness and purity of the life you live and the service you will render to your community.
('76', 170, 1, 6, 322807) Hinduism, you will remember, cannot live if untouchability remains, and you will have to make yourselves volunteer workers in the sacred cause.
('76', 170, 1, 7, 322951) Shri Viyogi Hari said that it was difficult to make the tailoring department self supporting.
('76', 170, 1, 8, 323045) There must then be something wrong with the training given.
('76', 170, 1, 9, 323105) Every craft is being taught, or ought to be taught, on a self supporting basis.
('76', 170, 1, 10, 323185) You students ought to ascertain from time to time from Viyogiji whether the work you turn out is paying enough and if not where in lies the defect.
('76', 170, 1, 11, 323333) Only then will you be able to make your school an ideal industrial school.
('76', 170, 1, 12, 323408) If you pay for your training through your work, you will never have difficulty in after life in earning your bread.
('76', 170, 1, 13, 323524) Those who leave the institution ought to get work wherever they go; and if those who are fully qualified fail to get work, it is the duty of the industrial school to find work for them.
('76', 170, 1, 14, 323710) Let no one think that they get here an inferior kind of training fit only for the poorest people.
('76', 170, 1, 15, 323808) The training they receive is in my opinion superior to what the most well to do boys receive elsewhere.
('76', 170, 1, 16, 323912) It will depend on you to show by the work you do that it is in no way inferior to similar training imparted by any other institution.
('76', 170, 1, 17, 324046) It is my firm opinion that useful as the other activities of the Harijan Sevak Sangh are, its educational activity in a home like this is the most useful.
('76', 170, 1, 18, 324201) For if this institution throws up even a few boys of sterling worth who would give themselves to the service of the Harijans, they will solve the pro blem of untouchability in a most substantial manner.
('76', 170, 1, 19, 324404) May you live straight and clean lives, and thus be the representa tives not only of the Harijans but of the millions of non Harijans who want to serve the Harijans.
('76', 170, 1, 20, 324569) Harijan, 5 8 1939

('76', 172, 1, 2, 325620) 220. SUMMARY OF INDUSTRIAL SURVEY COMMITTEE REPORT 1
('76', 172, 2, 3, 325673) An Industrial Survey Committee was appointed by the Central Provinces Government on 15th December last on the following terms :
('76', 172, 3, 4, 325801) 1. To review the work done in the province by the Department of Industries
('76', 172, 4, 5, 325876) since its establishment.
('76', 172, 5, 6, 325901) 2. To supervise the collection of data relating to large, small and especially cottage industries from previous publications and reports by an officer appointed for the purpose.
('76', 172, 6, 7, 326079) 3. To advise the officer in charge as regards the lines on which the
('76', 172, 7, 8, 326148) industrial survey of the province should be undertaken and to review its progress from time to time.
('76', 172, 8, 9, 326249) 4. To visit typical villages, study their economic condition and examine the possibility of reviving cottage industries, and in doing so to take the advice and guidance of the All India Spinners’ Association and the All India Village Industries Association.
('76', 172, 9, 10, 326507) 5. To report on the industrial possibilities of the raw materials available in the province, with special reference to the forest and mineral resources.
('76', 172, 10, 11, 326660) 6. To report on the measures which Government can undertake to pro mote industrial development within the province, especially of cottage indus tries in the villages, and to suggest methods for financing the same or other wise promoting them.
('76', 172, 11, 12, 326903) The Committee consists of the following ten members :
('76', 172, 12, 13, 326957) Chairman: Shri J. C. Kumarappa, Wardha.
('76', 172, 13, 14, 326997) Members: Shri Chaturbhujbhai Jasani, M. L. A, Gondia; Shri V. V. Subhedar,
('76', 172, 14, 15, 327072) M. L. A., Saugar; Shri K. P. Ghaira, General Manager, Central Provinces Syndicate, Limited, Nagpur; Shri R. N. Jha, Secretary, Berar Chamber of Commerce, Akola; Shri K. P. Sagreiya, I. F. S., Sylviculturist, Central Provinces and Berar; Dr. A. N. Kapanna, Demonstrator of Chemistry, College of Science, Nagpur; Shri Walter Dutt, Bar at Law, Nagpur; the Director of Industries, Central Provinces and Berar; Dr. R. S. Thakur, Officer on Special Duty in connectio with Laxminarayan Institute of Technology, Nagpur University, Nagpur.
('76', 172, 14, 16, 327603) He will also act as Secretary to the Committee.
('76', 172, 15, 17, 327651) The Committee is empowered to appoint sub committees and to co opt
('76', 172, 16, 18, 327718) 1 This appeared under the title “An Original Report” in six instalments.
('76', 172, 16, 19, 327791) The item is placed here under the date of publication of the last instalment in the series.
('76', 172, 16, 20, 327883) Only relevant portions from the extracts summarizing the report are reproduced here.
('76', 173, 0, 1, 327968) 174 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 173, 1, 2, 328010) members for specific purposes.
('76', 173, 1, 3, 328041) To this number the following two more were added under the Gazette Notification of Resolution No.
('76', 173, 1, 4, 328139) 175 89 A VII, dated the 12th January, 1939:
('76', 173, 2, 5, 328183) Shrimati Sarahamma Ittyerah, M. A. Wardha (late Professor of Economics, Lahore); Shri E. R. Mahajani, Managing Director, Shri Laxmi Oil Mills Company, Limited, Akola.
('76', 173, 2, 6, 328350) The Proceedings of the Committee were inaugurated on 15th January last.
('76', 173, 2, 7, 328422) The survey began on 21st January and was finished on 6th February.
('76', 173, 2, 8, 328489) 207 students including eight women volunteered their services.
('76', 173, 2, 9, 328552) 14 persons were co opted to lead the survey party.
('76', 173, 2, 10, 328603) The party was divided into groups of 10 students each.
('76', 173, 2, 11, 328658) It surveyed 606 villages covering a population of 15 lakhs paying an annual revenue of over 11 lakhs.
('76', 173, 2, 12, 328760) The survey cost was Rs. 3,000 in round numbers, i.e., Rs. 5 per village.
('76', 173, 2, 13, 328833) The whole expense amounted to one tenth of the esti mates.
('76', 173, 2, 14, 328892) The report covers 46 pages of hand made paper, foolscap size.
('76', 173, 2, 15, 328954) The party travelled third class, but when some members saw dur ing their survey that old women were picking grass seeds for food they declined to draw even the third class fare.
('76', 173, 2, 16, 329132) The party satisfied it self with such lodgings and food as the villagers had.
('76', 173, 2, 17, 329210) Nothing was specially prepared for them.
('76', 173, 2, 18, 329251) Kumarappa says to me in a covering note :
('76', 173, 3, 19, 329293) 1. Ours is not an academic survey where mathematical accuracy is the one goal.
('76', 173, 4, 20, 329372) 2. Neither is it a propagandic survey to gather ‘evidence’ to prove pre conceived theories.
('76', 173, 5, 21, 329464) 3. Nor is it a clinical survey to further the knowledge of the science of economics.
('76', 173, 6, 22, 329549) 4. It is a diagnostic survey done in a short time with the set purpose of saving the patient’s life by a suitable prescription, and this is national plan ning—not planning for a whole country as such, but planning the economic activity of each individual in relation to the raw material available within the field of our operations.
('76', 173, 7, 23, 329882) One member of the staff, an M. A. in economics, argued that without detailed statistics it would be impossible to prove whether the villagers are poor and are getting poorer.
('76', 173, 7, 24, 330057) I took him with me into the villages, showed him the houses in disrepair and one three storeyed house, half fallen down, and the goldsmiths sitting idle.
('76', 174, 0, 1, 330211) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 175
('76', 174, 1, 2, 330255) This is no doubt a rough and ready argument.
('76', 174, 1, 3, 330300) But if most of our villages contain ruins of well built houses and artisans without occupation, surely the evidence of poverty is more complete and con vincing than cold statistics which may prove everything or nothing.
('76', 174, 1, 4, 330520) The report which is Part I of Vol. 1 (Vol. 2 and Part II are to follow) contains six chapters and three short dissenting notes by Drs.
('76', 174, 1, 5, 330655) Thakur and Kapanna and Shri Sagreiya.
('76', 174, 1, 6, 330693) The dissenters chiefly emphasize the necessity of industrialization though they acknowledge that village industries need the help recommended by the main report.
('76', 174, 1, 7, 330855) Chapter two dealing with “General Considerations” stamps the report as an original document and shows that it is not to be pigeon holed as most such reports are but should be given effect to without delay.
('76', 174, 1, 8, 331061) The only way to do so is, as pointed out in the report, to invite the A. I. S. A. and the A. I. V. I. A. to help the Government to carry out the recommendations.
('76', 174, 1, 9, 331223) I give below a full summary 1 of the chapter on “General Considerations”.
('76', 174, 1, 10, 331297) The reader might have thought that my examination of the Kumarappa Committee’s report on the Industrial Survey of the Cen tral provinces was concluded.
('76', 174, 1, 11, 331449) The fact is that constant travelling and preoccupations disabled me from pursuing the examination with the regularity I had intended.
('76', 174, 1, 12, 331583) The long journey to the Frontier Province has provided the opportunity to continue and finish the examination.
('76', 174, 1, 13, 331694) The last instalment brought up the examination to the chap ter two.
('76', 174, 1, 14, 331762) The third is no less important.
('76', 174, 1, 15, 331794) The survey of 606 villages revealed to the Committee the painful fact that the average income of the villager per head was no more than Rs. 12. This need not startle the arm chair scientist who relies for his figures on books, and who has been taught to believe that it is anything between Rs. 60 to Rs. 80. Both are right from their own standpoints and data.
('76', 174, 1, 16, 332154) The figure of 65 to 80 is an all India average which includes the income of million aires, middlemen and zamindars.
('76', 174, 1, 17, 332270) The figure has a purpose of its own.
('76', 174, 1, 18, 332307) But for the Kumarappa Committee the figure 65 would be wholly
('76', 174, 2, 19, 332369) 1 This appeared under eight sub headings: “Functions of the State”, “Taxes and Expenditure”, “Capital and Labour Wealth”, “Mercy and Barter Economics”, “Barter and Government Funds”, “Raw Materials, Production and Profit”, “Administrative or Creative Efficiency” and “Impediment to Production”.
('76', 175, 0, 1, 332664) 176 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 175, 1, 2, 332706) The figure 12 is accurate and truly scientific.
('76', 175, 1, 3, 332754) That Committee was concerned with the average income of the villagers only.
('76', 175, 1, 4, 332830) The Committee says :
('76', 175, 2, 5, 332851) Our survey showed that most of the industries are tottering.
('76', 175, 2, 6, 332912) There are hardly any which can be said to be even in a normal state.
('76', 175, 2, 7, 332981) The taxable capacity of the people is rapidly going down and if the matter is not taken in hand immediately, the time is fast approaching when the Government will get nothing from the people .
('76', 175, 2, 8, 333174) The meagreness of the income shows itself in the diet of the people.
('76', 175, 2, 9, 333243) Thus the report says.
('76', 175, 2, 10, 333265) Their food is largely rice or some other grain, sometimes taken as gruel to
('76', 175, 3, 11, 333341) fill themselves up with water, but the tragedy of the situation is that even this little amount of rice that is available to them is polished rice making their diet even worse.
('76', 175, 3, 12, 333518) They hardly get the chaff.
('76', 175, 3, 13, 333545) This makes its incumbent on the Government to see that at least the rice is given to the poor people has all its nutritive elements left in it.
('76', 175, 3, 14, 333689) There are other valuable hints on the subject of diet for which I must refer the reader to the original.
('76', 175, 3, 15, 333794) There is a brief reference to agriculture.
('76', 175, 3, 16, 333837) Here is an excerpt from it : .
('76', 175, 3, 17, 333868) We have, in a way, already touched upon the question of payment of
('76', 175, 4, 18, 333935) revenues.
('76', 175, 4, 19, 333945) In addition to this, the land tenure appears to us to require careful examination.
('76', 175, 4, 20, 334028) A great deal of harm has been done and is being done because of the unscientific dues taken without careful planning.
('76', 175, 4, 21, 334146) During our survey we found that very little attention is being paid to renew the fertility of the soil.
('76', 175, 4, 22, 334250) It is time that the Agricultural Department took this function of re fertilizing the soil on its own shoulders and supplied to the farmers manure from various depots in the villages at the proper season, getting back their return at the time of their harvest.
('76', 175, 4, 23, 334510) Manufacture of artificial fertilizers should form a key industry.
('76', 175, 4, 24, 334576) Seeds also may be given out .
('76', 175, 4, 25, 334606) On the methods of production the Committee says: .
('76', 175, 4, 26, 334657) large scale organized industries are rendered various services and are
('76', 175, 5, 27, 334728) granted concessions by the Government which enable them to produce cheaply, while village and cottage units hardly get even the recognition of their existence, not to mention services and concessions.
('76', 175, 5, 28, 334929) Cottage and village industries, as long as their natural tendency is to distribute wealth, have a definite unchallengeable place in the economy of a nation and more especially in that of our country.
('76', 175, 5, 29, 335129) A careful examination will reveal that any cheapness in production in large scale industries or any economies that may be effected are not necessarily inherent in the method of production.
('76', 176, 0, 1, 335318) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 177
('76', 176, 1, 2, 335362) largely due to expenditure which should be debited to this method of production being spread over the whole country.
('76', 176, 1, 3, 335479) Chapter four deals with the Department of Industries.
('76', 176, 1, 4, 335533) The report has some trenchant remarks on it.
('76', 176, 1, 5, 335578) Here is a summary : .
('76', 176, 1, 6, 335600) As it is organized today, the department is not equipped to direct industries, it is nothing but a glorified inspectorate.
('76', 176, 1, 7, 335723) The organization of a department of this kind should be such that every villager will turn to it naturally for help and advice.
('76', 176, 1, 8, 335851) This department should be the pivot round which the production of the masses should revolve.
('76', 176, 1, 9, 335944) It should provide direct help in every way—scientific, financial and technical .
('76', 176, 2, 10, 336025) The suggestion that has been made here is on the lines on which the All India Village Industries Association and the All India Spinners’ Asso ciation are already working successfully.
('76', 176, 2, 11, 336209) At the headquarters of the All India Village Industries Association at Maganwadi, Wardha, various types of village industries are being carried on.
('76', 176, 2, 12, 336357) Students are trained in the industries and for village work.
('76', 176, 2, 13, 336418) A certain amount of scientific research is made.
('76', 176, 2, 14, 336467) The goods produced are marketed in a shop organized by the Association.
('76', 176, 2, 15, 336539) There is attached to it the Magan Sangrahalaya which is a museum of the type that is described herein after.
('76', 176, 2, 16, 336648) The Spinners’ Association has emphasized all these points and, in addition, has organized the village producers, and built up a network of shops all over the country to find outlets for the products of the organization in the villages .
('76', 176, 2, 17, 336885) It is worthy of note that the Director of Industries who is a mem ber of the Committee, has endorsed these remarks about his depart ment.
('76', 176, 2, 18, 337023) He deserves congratulation for his detached and impartial out look.
('76', 176, 2, 19, 337091) The following instructive analysis of the distribution of expen diture deserves more than a passing attention :
('76', 176, 3, 20, 337203) Education 0 3 5 1 2
('76', 176, 4, 21, 337223) General Administration 0 3 0
('76', 176, 5, 22, 337252) Collection of Revenues 0 3 0 Police and Jails 0 3 0 Justice 0 1 3 Medical and Public Health 0 1 0 Agriculture, Veterinary, Civil Works 0 1 1 Co operative Credit 0 0 1
('76', 176, 6, 23, 337419) Industries 0 0 1 1 2 ______
('76', 176, 7, 24, 337447) Re 1 0 0
('76', 177, 0, 1, 337456) 178 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 177, 1, 2, 337498) Where industries, i.
('76', 177, 1, 3, 337519) e., village economy takes only 11 2 pies there is
('76', 177, 2, 4, 337569) surely something rotten in the State of Denmark.
('76', 177, 2, 5, 337618) And, as the Committee has truly observed, this money is spent largely on mere administrative work.
('76', 177, 2, 6, 337717) If this department was run as it should be, the villages will be prosperous, and to that extent they would add to the prosperity of the State.
('76', 177, 2, 7, 337860) It is wrong for the State to absorb three annas out of 16 for general administration and police and jails respectively.
('76', 177, 2, 8, 337980) The fifth chapter which deals with the survey is really intro ductory to the sixth and last which describes the village industries in detail.
('76', 177, 2, 9, 338122) The condition of the villages is thus described : .
('76', 177, 2, 10, 338174) The primary needs of the people suggest that sanitary surroundings and fresh and wholesome water supply must form a first charge on the revenues of the villages as it affects the health of the people.
('76', 177, 2, 11, 338375) Unfortunately, water supply has been neglected, especially the supply of water to the Harijan families.
('76', 177, 2, 12, 338479) Whatever may be said against social customs, we cannot wait until these have been reformed to enable these downtrodden communities to get water.
('76', 177, 2, 13, 338624) The report has the following remarks on the condition of the industries in the villages : .
('76', 177, 2, 14, 338716) In our survey we noticed everywhere all manner of industries interposed
('76', 177, 3, 15, 338788) without any policy or plan.
('76', 177, 3, 16, 338816) The result of it all is that today we find the villages disintegrating .
('76', 177, 3, 17, 338889) This shows that the villages have been criminally neglected in the past.
('76', 177, 3, 18, 338962) If the Congress Governments will carry out the professed intention of the Congress, they will reconstruct the lives of the villagers and make them utilize their time so as to supply most of their own wants.
('76', 177, 3, 19, 339169) As the report points out, the Governments have to do two things: (1) to prevent interference with the village economy by preventing foreign goods from entering the villages, and by preventing our own merchants from introducing milled flour, rice, oil, etc.
('76', 177, 3, 20, 339426) These impose idleness on the villagers, and the polished, devita lized food products undermine their health.
('76', 177, 3, 21, 339535) Secondly and side by side with these preventive measures must go improvement in the methods of conducting the existing industries so as to make them more paying, and introduction of new industries in accordance with the condition of particular villages in regard to raw material.
('76', 177, 3, 22, 339815) And if the venture is to succeed, the planning will have to include the taking up by the State of the goods produced by the villagers not for self consumption but for sale outside the villages of production.
('76', 178, 0, 1, 340023) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 179
('76', 178, 1, 2, 340067) Among the village industries noted by the Committee are paddy husking, flour grinding, oil pressing, gur making, sugar manu facture, bee keeping, pottery, glass work, soap making, cotton pro cesses (i.e., picking, ginning, carding, spinning, weaving), washing, dyeing, wool spinning, weaving, sheep breeding, carpentry, smithy, sericulture, mat weaving, rope making, tanning, disposal of carcasses, pisciculture, poultry breeding, dairy farming, shoe making, brass and metal wares, toy making, goldsmithy, paper making, transport, lac industry, bamboo, match manufacture, etc.
('76', 178, 1, 3, 340644) Among the industries is bidi making.
('76', 178, 1, 4, 340681) This is what the Committee has to say on this industry :
('76', 178, 2, 5, 340738) Bidi manufacture is a very lucrative but a harmful industry in this province .
('76', 178, 3, 6, 340817) Naturally, as other industries are not available to those who are willing to work this industry attracts labour at very low rates considering the subsistence level of wages.
('76', 178, 3, 7, 340991) At all events they are able to make two and a half annas to three annas a day which, as wages go in the villages today, is high.
('76', 178, 3, 8, 341120) The Committee has made practical suggestions on all the indus tries.
('76', 178, 3, 9, 341189) No summary can do justice to the hints given under each head ing.
('76', 178, 3, 10, 341255) The curious must procure the report and study it.
('76', 178, 3, 11, 341305) The Govern ment should issue a cheap and handy edition, and have a translation in Hindustani at least.
('76', 178, 3, 12, 341408) The report is useful for other pro vinces also.
('76', 178, 3, 13, 341456) The Government in the other provinces should therefore procure copies and instruct their Directors to study and act in the spirit of the report.
('76', 178, 3, 14, 341601) I hope that the Central Provinces Government will carry out in full the recommendations made by the Committee.

('76', 178, 6, 17, 341775) 221. NOTES
('76', 178, 7, 18, 341786) MORE TEMPLES THROWN OPEN Raja Shri Rajaram Raja Saheb is the senior Prince and hereditary trustee of Tanjore Palace Devasthanams.
('76', 178, 7, 19, 341916) He has 90 temples under his charge including the famous temple called Shri Brihadishwara.
('76', 178, 7, 20, 342006) He has thrown open all these temples to Harijans as a purely voluntary act of reparation to Harijans and thus hastened the process of purification that Hinduism is going through.
('76', 178, 7, 21, 342185) It is a great and good thing that the Raja Saheb has done.
('76', 178, 7, 22, 342244) He deserves the congratulations of all those who believe that untouchability is a blot on Hinduism.
('76', 178, 7, 23, 342344) The accounts I have received from Shrimati Rameshwari Nehru of the enthusiasm she has
('76', 179, 0, 1, 342430) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 179, 1, 2, 342472) witnessed in the South in favour of opening temples to Harijans, show that the reform is genuine and is going to be lasting.
('76', 179, 1, 3, 342597) She is a very careful observer.
('76', 179, 1, 4, 342629) She says her meetings are attended by thousands of persons who follow every word of what she has to say.
('76', 179, 1, 5, 342734) This is done through able interpretation.
('76', 179, 1, 6, 342776) And she says that her listeners gladly endorse her sentiments.
('76', 179, 1, 7, 342839) All this is a distinct improvement upon the past.
('76', 179, 1, 8, 342889) Thus, though much has been done, much more remains to be done before Hindu reformers can rest on their oars.
('76', 179, 1, 9, 342998) Temple reform has to go side by side with temple entry.
('76', 179, 1, 10, 343054) If the reform is not super ficial but is an index of the desire for purification of Hinduism and Hindus, it must be accompanied by purification of the temples in every respect.
('76', 179, 1, 11, 343231) Their sanctity and popularity should increase.
('76', 179, 1, 12, 343278) The admission of Harijans to the temples should mean an automatic uplift in their lives.
('76', 179, 1, 13, 343367) These things will not happen unless Harijan sevaks in crease their vigilance, redouble their zeal and feel themselves uplifted by the reform they have helped to bring about.
('76', 179, 1, 14, 343541) Reforms like the throwing open of temples to Harijans should bring with them a general levelling up in the lives of those who are engaged in and affected by them.
('76', 179, 2, 15, 343704) SEGAON, July 29, 1939 Harijan, 5 8 1939

('76', 180, 2, 3, 344211) SEGAON, WARDHA July 29, 1939
('76', 180, 3, 4, 344240) MY DEAR JAWAHARLAL, Instead of guiding the Dhami people I have passed them on to you.
('76', 180, 3, 5, 344326) 1 I feel that you should discharge this burden without any interference from me.
('76', 180, 3, 6, 344407) The idea in the States seems to be to isolate and ignore the Congress and hence the States Conference.
('76', 180, 3, 7, 344510) I have already suggested 2 in Harijan that no State Association or Mandal should act on its own without reference to your committee 3. I should act, if at all, through you; i.e., when you refer to me, I should give my opinion as I do in respect of the Working Committee.
('76', 180, 3, 8, 344781) I told the Gwalior people also likewise yesterday.
('76', 180, 3, 9, 344832) You will have to reorganize your committee a bit, if it is to function properly.
('76', 180, 3, 10, 344913) After all I could not go to Kashmir.
('76', 180, 3, 11, 344950) Sheikh Abdullah and his friends won’t tolerate the idea of my being State guest.
('76', 180, 3, 12, 345031) Banking on my past experience, I had accepted State offer in anticipation of Sheikh Abdullah’s approval.
('76', 180, 3, 13, 345136) But I saw that I was mistaken.
('76', 180, 3, 14, 345167) I there fore cancelled the acceptance of the State hospitality and accepted the Sheikh’s.
('76', 180, 3, 15, 345257) This embarrassed the State.
('76', 180, 3, 16, 345285) So I cancelled the visit alto gether.
('76', 180, 3, 17, 345323) I was guilty of double stupidity—in daring to think of going there without you and in not getting Sheikh’s permission before accepting the State offer.
('76', 180, 3, 18, 345475) I had thought that I would serve the people by accepting the State offer.
('76', 180, 3, 19, 345549) I must confess that I was not pleased with my contact [with] the Sheikh and his friends.
('76', 180, 3, 20, 345638) They seemed to all of us to be most unreasonable.
('76', 180, 3, 21, 345688) Khan Saheb reasoned with them.
('76', 180, 3, 22, 345719) But it was to no purpose.
('76', 180, 3, 23, 345745) Your visit to Ceylon was glorious.
('76', 180, 3, 24, 345780) I don’t mind what the imme diate outcome is.
('76', 180, 3, 25, 345825) Saleh Tyabji asks me to send you to Burma and Andrews thinks of you in connection with South Africa.
('76', 180, 3, 26, 345926) For Ceylon the idea of a Congress deputation came to me spontaneously, not so

('76', 182, 2, 8, 348031) 226. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('76', 182, 3, 9, 348061) SEGAON, July 29, 1939 I have been in telegraphic correspondence with Dr. Dadoo, leader of the Passive Resistance Committee in South Africa.
('76', 182, 3, 10, 348201) I have no hesitation in asking the Passive Resistance Committee to postpone, for a time, the proposed launching of the struggle 2 on 1st August.
('76', 182, 3, 11, 348346) I do so because I have some hope of an honourable settlement.
('76', 182, 3, 12, 348408) I know that the Government of India as well as the British Government are trying to obtain relief.
('76', 182, 3, 13, 348507) I have put myself in touch with the Ministers.
('76', 182, 3, 14, 348554) In the circumstances I think a brief postponement of the struggle to be necessary.
('76', 182, 3, 15, 348637) I am fully aware of the enthusiasm of the resisters.
('76', 182, 3, 16, 348690) They have proved their mettle before, and they will do so again if it becomes necessary.
('76', 182, 3, 17, 348779) But it is a code with passive resisters to seize every opportunity of avoiding resistance, if it can be done honourably.
('76', 182, 3, 18, 348900) Every cessation in search of peace adds strength to real fighters.
('76', 182, 3, 19, 348967) Let them remember that the Cape Town Settlement of 1914 was the outcome of a cessation of struggle for the sake of peace.
('76', 182, 3, 20, 349089) I hope that the proposed cessation will lead to a similar result.
('76', 182, 3, 21, 349155) Should it unfor tunately prove otherwise and should the struggle begin, let Dr. Dadoo and his fellow resisters know that the whole of India will be at their back.
('76', 182, 3, 22, 349318) Harijan, 5 8 1939
('76', 182, 4, 23, 349336) 1 This appeared under “Notes”, sub title, “Postpone the Struggle”.
('76', 182, 4, 24, 349403) The statement was also published in The Hindustan Times, 30 7 1939.
('76', 182, 5, 25, 349471) 2 The movement was proposed as a protest against the Asiatic (Transvaal) Land and Trading Act, 1939, which aimed at virtual economic extinction of the Indian community in the Transvaal.
('76', 182, 5, 26, 349657) Vide also Vol. “A Letter”, 7 4 1939. According to The Bombay Chronicle, 31 7 1939, Dadoo had issued a statement acceding to Gandhiji’s appeal to postpone the Passive Resistance movement, pending further advice from him.
('76', 183, 0, 1, 349877) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 183, 1, 2, 349919) 227. LESSON OF DHAMI
('76', 183, 2, 3, 349940) We have not heard the last of Dhami.
('76', 183, 2, 4, 349977) The truth is not yet out.
('76', 183, 2, 5, 350003) The necessarily one sided version of the Political Agent has been challenged by the Himalayan States Praja Mandal.
('76', 183, 2, 6, 350118) Their statement shows how absolutely necessary it is to have an open judicial inquiry into the events that led to firing by the Rana of Dhami.
('76', 183, 2, 7, 350261) Some members of the Himalayan Mandal came to see me during my brief stay in Delhi.
('76', 183, 2, 8, 350344) Dhami had made me think furiously.
('76', 183, 2, 9, 350379) Was nothing possible to prevent such tragedy?
('76', 183, 2, 10, 350425) I had much to say about it to the deputation, but I felt it would be wrong on my part to shoulder the burden of guiding the Himalayan States Praja Mandal.
('76', 183, 2, 11, 350580) The responsibility was great.
('76', 183, 2, 12, 350610) The issues at stake were equally great.
('76', 183, 2, 13, 350650) I therefore felt that the matter should be handled not by me but by the Standing Committee of the All India States People’s Conference.
('76', 183, 2, 14, 350786) The question of the States is daily assuming bigger and bigger propor tions.
('76', 183, 2, 15, 350863) The ruling Chiefs are becoming free with their rifles.
('76', 183, 2, 16, 350918) They feel that they are safe so far as the Paramount Power is concerned.
('76', 183, 2, 17, 350991) The Congress has not much prestige with them.
('76', 183, 2, 18, 351037) Many of them are now evolving measures to crush the growing spirit of their people and make it impossible, if they can, for the Congress to give effective guidance to them, let alone to interfere.
('76', 183, 2, 19, 351234) Nevertheless the Congress has a duty to perform.
('76', 183, 2, 20, 351283) I do not exactly know the constitution of the Con ference, but I presume that in some shape or other it is connected with the Congress.
('76', 183, 2, 21, 351419) Anyway it is the only body which is specially designed for guiding the States people.
('76', 183, 2, 22, 351505) It would be wrong for the States to resent such guidance.
('76', 183, 2, 23, 351563) They should also realize that any resentment would be futile.
('76', 183, 2, 24, 351625) The Congress cannot give up its duty of guiding the States people in the hour of their need.
('76', 183, 2, 25, 351718) Time was when the Congress was guiding and protecting the rights of the States as against the Para mount Power.
('76', 183, 2, 26, 351830) If the Congress friendship was desired and welcomed by the States in need, it hardly becomes them to demur at their people seeking Congress advice, guidance and protection.
('76', 183, 2, 27, 352003) That the Congress may not always be able to give the people effective assistance is unfortunately too true.
('76', 183, 2, 28, 352111) The Congress has to forge the necessary sanc tion by putting the organization on a firmer footing and by wise restraint to acquire credit for impartiality and strictest justice.
('76', 183, 2, 29, 352289) If the Congress is to discharge its function in a becoming manner, it will
('76', 184, 0, 1, 352364) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 185
('76', 184, 1, 2, 352408) have to insist upon the workers learning to be more accurate than they have been hitherto in preparing their cases.
('76', 184, 1, 3, 352524) In order to ensure accu racy, the Standing Committee will have to subject to strict scrutiny everything coming to it.
('76', 184, 1, 4, 352642) If unchallengeable accounts of the doings in the States where even simple justice is denied are published, they will afford a foundation for action.
('76', 184, 1, 5, 352791) I have merely indicated a line of approach.
('76', 184, 1, 6, 352835) The Standing Committee will no doubt lay down its own policy and method of dealing with problems as they arise from time to time.
('76', 184, 1, 7, 352965) My object in writing these lines is to warn workers in the States against coming to me and expecting me to advise them.
('76', 184, 1, 8, 353085) They should approach the Standing Committee.
('76', 184, 1, 9, 353130) Even as I do not guide Congressmen on general matters falling within the function of the Working Committee but hold myself at the disposal of that body, so shall I henceforth act in respect of new State problems.
('76', 184, 1, 10, 353343) I may not give up guiding those with whom I am already directly concerned.
('76', 184, 1, 11, 353418) I need hardly add that I shall continue to do what my special aptitude in matters affecting States may enable me to do without being involved in the general direction of popular movements in them.
('76', 184, 1, 12, 353615) I would ask workers in the States not to take up any forward movement without previous reference to any sanction of the Standing Committee.
('76', 184, 1, 13, 353755) It must be the duty of the Congress acting through the States People’s Conference to avoid, if at all possible, a quarrel with the States.
('76', 184, 1, 14, 353894) SEGAON, July 30, 1939 Harijan, 5 8 1939
('76', 184, 2, 15, 353934) 228. NOTES
('76', 184, 3, 16, 353945) ONE SCRIPT FOR DAUGHTERS OF SANSKRIT The question of having one script for the Indian languages which are daughters of Sanskrit by birth or adoption has been before the public for a number of years.
('76', 184, 3, 17, 354144) Yet in these days of aggressive provincialism, perhaps, any plea for one script will be regarded as an impertinence.
('76', 184, 3, 18, 354261) But the literacy campaigns raging all over the country should compel a hearing for the advocates of one script.
('76', 184, 3, 19, 354373) I have been one such for years.
('76', 184, 3, 20, 354405) I remember having even adopted in South Africa Devanagari script for my Indian correspondence with Gujaratis in select cases.
('76', 184, 3, 21, 354531) Inter provincial intercourse will be much facilitated by such adoption, and the learning of the various provincial languages
('76', 185, 0, 1, 354656) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 185, 1, 2, 354698) will be made infinitely easier than it is today.
('76', 185, 1, 3, 354747) If the educated people of the land were to put their heads together and decide upon one script, its universal adoption should be an easy thing.
('76', 185, 1, 4, 354891) To the millions who are illiterate it is a matter of indifference what script is prescribed to them.
('76', 185, 1, 5, 354992) If the happy consummation comes to pass, there will be only two scripts in India—Devanagari and Urdu, and every nationalist will deem it his duty to master the two scripts.
('76', 185, 1, 6, 355165) I am a lover of all Indian languages.
('76', 185, 1, 7, 355203) I have tried to learn as many scripts as possible.
('76', 185, 1, 8, 355254) And if only I had the time, even at the age of seventy I have energy enough to learn more Indian languages.
('76', 185, 1, 9, 355362) That would be a recreation for me.
('76', 185, 1, 10, 355397) But in spite of all my love for the languages I must confess that I have not learnt all the scripts.
('76', 185, 1, 11, 355498) But if the sister languages were written in one script, I should pick up a workable knowledge of the principal languages of the provinces in very little time.
('76', 185, 1, 12, 355657) And Devanagari has nothing to be ashamed of in point of symmetry or beauty.
('76', 185, 1, 13, 355733) I hope that those who are engaged in the literacy campaigns will give a passing thought to my suggestion.
('76', 185, 1, 14, 355839) If they will adopt Devanagari script, they will save for the future generations tons of labour and time and earn their blessings.
('76', 185, 1, 15, 355969) SEGAON, July 30, 1939 Harijan, 5 8 1939

('76', 193, 1, 2, 367045) My third hope is that the Rulers will fulfil their duty by rendering the people as much help as possible, and the fourth hope is that the volunteers will rush out to offer help at various places.
('76', 193, 1, 3, 367241) The spinning yajna will be observed for seventy days with effect from 2nd August, under the auspices of the Rajkot Rashtriyashala.
('76', 193, 1, 4, 367372) It has been suggested that during the yajna workers should increase their speed of spinning and from the produce 70 percent should be used for helping the famine stricken people.

('76', 194, 6, 16, 369177) The hunger striking prisoners of Dum Dum Jail have sent me some questions through Shri Mahadev Desai.

('76', 194, 6, 21, 369529) But they give me no chance whatever by continuing their hunger strike.
('76', 194, 6, 22, 369600) In so far as it was intended to rouse public atten tion it has served its purpose.
('76', 194, 6, 23, 369683) Any prolongation of the fast will now defeat that purpose.
('76', 194, 6, 24, 369742) There are many who would work actively for their release if the strike is given up.
('76', 194, 6, 25, 369826) I do feel very strongly that this fast is not justified.
('76', 194, 6, 26, 369883) The strikers are giving a bad lead to those who are similarly situated.
('76', 194, 6, 27, 369955) Such hunger strikers, if they are largely copied, will break all discipline to pieces and make orderly government impossi ble.
('76', 194, 6, 28, 370082) The prisoners’ cause is essentially just, but they are weake ning it by their persistence.

('76', 194, 6, 30, 370335) Let them not hamper one whom they consider to be their best advocate.

('76', 194, 6, 32, 370539) But I do not propose to go into the past.
('76', 194, 6, 33, 370581) Suffice it to add that their refusal to give up the strike

('76', 198, 1, 2, 374563) 253. LETTER TO PRESIDENT, TANZEEM UL MOMININ 1
('76', 198, 2, 3, 374610) [Before August 4, 1939] 2
('76', 198, 3, 4, 374636) DEAR FRIEND, I have sufficient papers in front of me to enable me to formulate a tentative opinion upon the Shia and Sunni controversy.
('76', 198, 3, 5, 374772) I have a long letter from Pantji 3 and printed papers giving me what purports to be an unbiased version.
('76', 198, 3, 6, 374877) This much seems to stand out clearly.
('76', 198, 3, 7, 374915) Whereas the Madhe Saheba is to praise the elected Caliphs, the Tabarra is a curse pronounced upon the first three Caliphs.
('76', 198, 3, 8, 375038) Whilst one can understand the right of publicly praising people, is there such a thing as right of pronouncing a curse on dead men?
('76', 198, 3, 9, 375170) The right of Tabarra cannot be derived from the holy Koran for the simple reason that the Caliphate came into being only after the death of the holy Prophet.
('76', 198, 3, 10, 375328) I would like you, therefore, to enlighten me on the religious duty of saying the Tabarra.
('76', 198, 3, 11, 375418) I would also readily grant that there can be no religious duty in praising the Caliphs specially in public places and in the presence of those whom the recital is known to offend.
('76', 198, 3, 12, 375598) Therefore, subject to what you might say to the contrary, I would advise you, for the sake of peace, to withdraw the civil resistance 4 and stop the public recital of Tabarra unconditionally, leaving it to the good sense of the Sunnis so to act as not to wound the susceptibilities of their Shia brethren.
('76', 198, 3, 13, 375904) I have not written this letter for publication.
('76', 198, 3, 14, 375952) You have been good enough to ask me to give my candid opinion and I have given it tentatively.
('76', 198, 3, 15, 376047) If it helps you in announcing your decision in accor dance with my advice, you are at liberty to publish this letter.I am not sending a copy of this opinion to anyone.
('76', 198, 3, 16, 376215) It is simply meant for you and friends who accompanied you and on whose behalf you had come.
('76', 198, 3, 17, 376308) The Hindu, 5 8 1939
('76', 198, 4, 18, 376328) 1 The source reported that a deputation of Tanzeem ul Mominin “recently waited on Gandhiji to seek his advice regarding the Shia Sunni dispute” on the right to recite, in public, Madhe Saheba by Sunnis and Tabarra by Shias.
('76', 198, 4, 19, 376552) The agitation had started as early as March.
('76', 198, 4, 20, 376597) Vide “Telegram to Tanzeem Ul Mominin”, on or after 19 5 1939 and “A Letter”, 23 5 1939. 2 The letter was reported under the date line “Lucknow, August 4”.
('76', 198, 4, 21, 376752) 3 Govind Ballabh Pant, Premier and Minister of Home Affairs and Finance of the United Provinces 4 Started by the Shias in early June

('76', 199, 1, 2, 376927) 254. INTERVIEW TO GOVERDHANLAL SHUKLA
('76', 199, 2, 3, 376965) [On or before August 4, 1939] 1
('76', 199, 3, 4, 376997) Gandhiji told Mr. Shukla 2 that he was not treating the question of the release of political prisoners, both of the Punjab and Bengal, lightly.
('76', 199, 3, 5, 377141) He pointed out that the hunger strike by the political prisoners in Bengal jails had been causing difficulties in finding a solution.
('76', 199, 4, 6, 377275) Gandhiji declared that the problem of the political prisoners was coming up before the Congress Working Committee.
('76', 199, 5, 7, 377390) Gandhiji pointed out that, with a solution found for the problem of political prisoners in Bengal, the question relating to the Punjab prisoners would be solved immediately and automatically.
('76', 199, 6, 8, 377582) Gandhiji, it is stated, then asked Mr. Shukla to furnish him with particulars about the prisoners belonging to the Punjab, and the attempts made for their release, on receipt of which he would do what lay in his power.
('76', 199, 6, 9, 377801) The Hindu, 5 8 1939
('76', 199, 7, 10, 377821) 255. WELL DONE BOMBAY!
('76', 199, 8, 11, 377844) From all the accounts I have received it seems that Bombay surpassed itself on the 1st of August, the day of the inauguration of prohibition.
('76', 199, 8, 12, 377986) An eye witness of the demonstration tells me that the procession that took the mortal remains of the immortal Lokamanya to the Chowpaty sands, huge as it was, was far outdone by the crowds that gathered together on the Azad Maidan.
('76', 199, 8, 13, 378218) He tells me that all Bombay was present there.
('76', 199, 8, 14, 378265) The labourers, who were the chief persons to benefit by the measure and who were at the same time the most affected by prohibition, attended in their thousands with their wives.
('76', 199, 8, 15, 378443) They rejoiced in the deliverance from the devil from whose grip they could not disengage themselves without external assistance.
('76', 199, 8, 16, 378572) Had they gone to express their gratefulness to the Ministers for their courage in persisting in their benevolent measure in the teeth of the opposition of vested interests?
('76', 199, 8, 17, 378745) It was not a mere labour demonstration.
('76', 199, 8, 18, 378785) All classes took part in it.
('76', 199, 8, 19, 378814) At that huge meeting there was not a jarring note.
('76', 199, 8, 20, 378865) Men and women had turned up in their thousands to take part in thanks giving to God for the successful inauguration of prohibition.
('76', 199, 8, 21, 378997) The great Parsi community deserves congratulations for the
('76', 199, 9, 22, 379056) 1 The interview was reported under the date line “Wardha, August 4”.
('76', 199, 9, 23, 379125) 2 Of Kanpur
('76', 200, 0, 1, 379137) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 201
('76', 200, 1, 2, 379181) restraint it observed in spite of its bitter opposition to the measure.
('76', 200, 1, 3, 379253) Evidently wiser counsel prevailed and no hostile demonstration appe ars to have been staged by them.
('76', 200, 1, 4, 379354) My hope that Parsi philanthropy will get the better of the opposition, appears to have been justified.
('76', 200, 1, 5, 379457) Is it too much to expect whole hearted support from the Parsis in making the measure a complete success?
('76', 200, 1, 6, 379562) Let them remember, the glory of the effort in Bombay will be reflected not only throughout the province but it will be reflected all over India.
('76', 200, 1, 7, 379707) I make bold to say that although they feel that they have been unjustly dealt with, the future generation of Parsis will bless Dr. Gilder as their true represent ative and benefactor.
('76', 200, 1, 8, 379891) Surely Parsis should be proud, as India is proud, that they have produced in Dr. Gilder a man who has stood firm as a rock in the midst of fiercest opposition including threats of boycott and worse.
('76', 200, 1, 9, 380090) Indeed the whole of the Ministry deserves hearty congratula tions on the steadfastness with which they have pursued this great moral reform.
('76', 200, 1, 10, 380231) The demonstration of 1st August shows that they had and have practically the whole of Bombay behind them.
('76', 200, 1, 11, 380337) No construc tive measure promoted by the Congress has had such enthusiastic support as this great moral reform.
('76', 200, 1, 12, 380449) It is a matter of regret that a Muslim procession of protest, not against the measure but against the property tax, was organized the same day and resulted in a clash with the police.
('76', 200, 1, 13, 380633) But it only enhanced the value of the public meeting, for the procession had no effect whatsoever on the great and irresistible demonstration.
('76', 200, 1, 14, 380776) Bombay had one mind at the Azad Maidan.
('76', 200, 1, 15, 380816) Let us hope the brilliant beginning has momentum enough in it to lead to a brilliant end.
('76', 200, 1, 16, 380906) Much constructive effort will be required in order to consolidate the advantage gained by the closing of liquor shops.
('76', 200, 1, 17, 381025) It removes the temptation from the drinker but not the craving for drink.
('76', 200, 1, 18, 381099) His mind has to be directed into the right channel.
('76', 200, 1, 19, 381151) He must have healthy refreshment at a place where he can rest his tired mind and limbs.

('76', 202, 1, 2, 383287) 258. DISCUSSION WITH V. V. SATHE 1
('76', 202, 2, 3, 383322) SEGAON, August 5, 1939
('76', 202, 3, 4, 383345) GANDHIJI : If you are a satyagrahi, I too am a satyagrahi, and as I have been told by many friends that you are a reasonable man and a man of restraint, I shall show you that you are wrong.
('76', 202, 3, 5, 383535) Well then, you ought to have exhausted all the constitutional means.
('76', 202, 3, 6, 383604) You must remember that the Bombay Congress Ministry is under four Congress Committees—Gujarat, Maharashtra, Karnataka and Bombay.
('76', 202, 3, 7, 383734) You should have lodged your complaint before them.
('76', 202, 3, 8, 383785) Failing satisfaction you should have gone to the Working Committee, failing there to the A.I.C.C., and then to the open session of the Congress.
('76', 202, 3, 9, 383930) And if you accept my authority as an expert in satyagraha, then you should have come to me, but not with a decision to fast.
('76', 202, 4, 10, 384055) SATHE: I do not accept you as the final authority, but I would certainly take your advice.
('76', 202, 4, 11, 384146) But let me ask you one question.
('76', 202, 4, 12, 384179) Whether all these Congress Committees give an opinion in my favour or not, what if the Ministers say they have violated the Congress principles?
('76', 202, 4, 13, 384324) Do they say so?
('76', 202, 5, 14, 384340) But they will not resign, they say, unless they are asked to resign.
('76', 202, 5, 15, 384409) But they have broken the promises given in election manifestos.
('76', 202, 5, 16, 384473) There is no rigidity about the manifestos.
('76', 202, 5, 17, 384516) You may say many things but you may not be able to carry them all out.
('76', 202, 6, 18, 384587) My own Sadashiv Peth, which is one of the constituencies, did resolve that the Ministry had not fulfilled the promises.
('76', 202, 6, 19, 384707) Well then, let that committee approach the A.I.C.C. But why this fast?
('76', 202, 6, 20, 384778) You must exhaust all the natural steps.
('76', 202, 7, 21, 384818) The natural steps take years.
('76', 202, 7, 22, 384848) It is a cumbersome machinery.
('76', 202, 7, 23, 384878) Not years, but it may take a year.
('76', 202, 7, 24, 384913) That should not matter.

('76', 205, 6, 10, 390416) 260. AM I ALL POWERFUL?
('76', 205, 7, 11, 390440) Two Congressmen came to me during the week.
('76', 205, 7, 12, 390484) One of them said :
('76', 205, 8, 13, 390503) We in the Central Provinces think that you can do everything you want.
('76', 205, 8, 14, 390574) You can remove the Ministry at will and you can make them do what you like.
('76', 205, 8, 15, 390650) The other said :
('76', 205, 9, 16, 390667) You are the Working Committee.
('76', 205, 9, 17, 390698) Every Congressman therefore blames you for the present corruption.
('76', 205, 9, 18, 390765) You showed us that moral authority was the supreme authority.
('76', 205, 9, 19, 390827) You taught us to think that the existing system was Satanic.
('76', 205, 9, 20, 390888) You taught us that when the Congress reigned there would be no devilry, there would be purity in every walk of life.
('76', 205, 9, 21, 391005) But we find today quite the reverse.
('76', 205, 9, 22, 391042) The Congress reigns in many provinces and yet corruption is rampant.
('76', 205, 9, 23, 391111) Congressmen quarrel among themselves.
('76', 205, 9, 24, 391149) There is marked deterioration.
('76', 205, 9, 25, 391180) Devilry is not gone.
('76', 205, 9, 26, 391201) You do not rely upon numbers.
('76', 205, 9, 27, 391231) You have often said that even a few true and good Congressman can, by their moral worth, represent the whole nation and real democracy can be evolved.
('76', 205, 9, 28, 391382) But instead of quality the cry everywhere is for quantity.
('76', 205, 9, 29, 391441) The amendments recently made are of no use.
('76', 205, 9, 30, 391485) They won’t remove the growing corruption nor reduce the unmanageable size of the Congress.
('76', 205, 9, 31, 391576) If you say that you cannot have your way with the Working Committee, let us know it.
('76', 205, 9, 32, 391661) As it is we believe you to be all powerful and are therefore filled with wonder that you allow things to go from bad to worse.
('76', 205, 9, 33, 391788) Look at your Khadi Clause.
('76', 205, 9, 34, 391815) It is responsible for extensive hypocrisy in the Congress.
('76', 205, 9, 35, 391874) Very few believe in Khadi and therefore use it only for show.
('76', 205, 9, 36, 391936) Khadi therefore stands for falsehood and worse.
('76', 205, 9, 37, 391984) You who brought the
('76', 206, 0, 1, 392004) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 207
('76', 206, 1, 2, 392048) country to a moral height are now bringing it down.
('76', 206, 1, 3, 392100) Presently the Congress will become the laughing stock of the country, if things go as they are doing.
('76', 206, 1, 4, 392202) If you cannot mend the Congress, why don’t you leave it alone?
('76', 206, 1, 5, 392265) This second critic is a well known Congressman and organizer.
('76', 206, 1, 6, 392327) He spoke feelingly.
('76', 206, 1, 7, 392347) I promised to reproduce in these columns the substance of the answer I gave him.
('76', 206, 1, 8, 392428) I am not all powerful whether with the Central Provinces Ministers or with the Working Committee.
('76', 206, 1, 9, 392526) I know very little of the doings of the Ministers.
('76', 206, 1, 10, 392577) I never interfere with their work.
('76', 206, 1, 11, 392612) I have never regarded that as my function.
('76', 206, 1, 12, 392655) Occasionally I have to correspond with them on matters such as the village industries, basic education or the like precisely as any citizen would do.
('76', 206, 1, 13, 392805) I have invariably refused to interfere with their work.
('76', 206, 1, 14, 392861) I would not have the time for it even if I had the wish.
('76', 206, 1, 15, 392918) It would mean usurpation of the function of the Parliamen tary Sub committee of the Working Committee.
('76', 206, 1, 16, 393021) So far as the Working Committee is concerned, I do attend its meetings whenever I am required to do so.
('76', 206, 1, 17, 393125) I do influence its decisions in the matters that may be referred to me and never in any others.
('76', 206, 1, 18, 393221) Many sittings of the Committee I do not attend at all.
('76', 206, 1, 19, 393276) Of many of its resolutions I have no knowledge except after they are passed and that through the Press.
('76', 206, 1, 20, 393380) This was the arrangement when I first severed 1 my legal connection with the Congress.
('76', 206, 1, 21, 393467) What hold I have on the Committee is purely moral.
('76', 206, 1, 22, 393518) My opinion prevails only to the extent that I carry conviction.
('76', 206, 1, 23, 393582) Let me give out the secret that often my advice makes no appeal to the members.
('76', 206, 1, 24, 393662) For instance, if I had my way, the Congress would be reduced to the smallest compass possible.

('76', 206, 1, 26, 393937) But this is too drastic and too undemo cratic for Congressmen.

('76', 207, 2, 22, 396335) 261. NOTES SHETH JAMNALALJI
('76', 207, 3, 23, 396363) Sheth Jamnalalji is an extraordinary prisoner.
('76', 207, 3, 24, 396410) He believes that as a prisoner he has not to care about his body beyond what the doctors provided for him do.
('76', 207, 3, 25, 396520) And so I have only now come to know the true state of his health.
('76', 207, 3, 26, 396586) Shri Shankerlal Banker, who happened to go to Jaipur to see Jamnalalji, got concerned about his health and told me how bad it was.
('76', 207, 4, 27, 396717) 1 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 17 9 1934
('76', 208, 0, 1, 396760) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 209
('76', 208, 1, 2, 396804) For the moment I refrain from publishing the correspondence which has come into my hands.
('76', 208, 1, 3, 396894) According to the Jaipur Civil Surgeon his is a case for special treatment.
('76', 208, 1, 4, 396969) If it is, the onus is on the State to release him unconditionally, leaving it to Jamnalalji whether he will take special treatment within the State or without.
('76', 208, 1, 5, 397129) It is futile to suggest to Jamnalalji that he should undertake to leave Jaipur if he is discharged.
('76', 208, 1, 6, 397229) He will rather die in prison than be free under the very condition for the breach of which he has courted imprisonment.
('76', 208, 1, 7, 397349) As I have already pointed out, 1 there is no fear of Jamnalalji promoting civil disobedience in the State.
('76', 208, 1, 8, 397456) For it stands indefinitely suspended.
('76', 208, 1, 9, 397494) The authorities know that Jamnalalji is essentially a non violent man.
('76', 208, 1, 10, 397565) They also know him to be a man of his word.
('76', 208, 1, 11, 397609) To me his detention is a mystery and, in the present state of his health, a crime.
('76', 208, 1, 12, 397692) The public generally do not know that though the place where he is detained is good and accessible, it is a haunt of ferocious animals.
('76', 208, 1, 13, 397828) Under what appear to me to be barbarous shikar laws of Jaipur State, these animals are protected under pain of heavy fines being inflicted on the persons killing them.
('76', 208, 1, 14, 397996) Tigers and their brood, it is said, eat men and animals with impunity.
('76', 208, 1, 15, 398067) My purpose here, however, is not to deal with these shikar laws, inhuman as they appear to me to be.
('76', 208, 1, 16, 398168) My purpose is to protest against Jamnalalji being kept in a tiger infested place.
('76', 208, 1, 17, 398250) I understand that even his keepers are not very happy over their job.
('76', 208, 1, 18, 398320) There is no fear of Jamnalalji running away.
('76', 208, 1, 19, 398365) If he must be kept in prison, why should he not be kept in an unobjectionable place where medical and other assistance is easily available?
('76', 208, 1, 20, 398505) There is also another point which calls for notice.
('76', 208, 1, 21, 398557) Though repeated requests have been made, he has not yet been permitted to keep a companion.
('76', 208, 1, 22, 398649) He has been given no nurse.
('76', 208, 1, 23, 398677) Instances are on record when he was badly in need of night attendance.
('76', 208, 1, 24, 398748) That he him self has made no complaint is no reason for the authorities’ negli gence in not providing necessary attendance.
('76', 208, 1, 25, 398872) Their attention has been drawn to the matter more than once by Shethji’s secretary.

('76', 213, 5, 16, 406254) I hope too that the Bengal Government will use the occasion for a generous gesture and end the agony.

('76', 214, 1, 2, 407102) 271. AN EXPLANATION
('76', 214, 2, 3, 407122) I gladly publish the foregoing letter 1 and accept the explan ation.
('76', 214, 2, 4, 407191) Without it the concluding paragraph of the petition could only be interpreted as a threat.
('76', 214, 2, 5, 407282) Better than the explanation, however, will be the help the Bhandaris could render in the prosecution of the prohibition programme.
('76', 214, 2, 6, 407413) Let them be true soldiers of the Congress Government and the nation as they were of the East India Company, who were foreigners come to exploit the country.
('76', 214, 2, 7, 407570) If they will heartily assist the Government in their arduous task, they will find that they will also assist themselves in a manner they never otherwise could have done.
('76', 214, 2, 8, 407740) SEGAON, August 7, 1939 Harijan, 12 8 1939
('76', 214, 3, 9, 407782) 272. MILLS V. CHARKHA
('76', 214, 4, 10, 407804) The A.I.V.I.A. has been issuing for some time a monthly bulle tin called Gram Udyog Patrika at Maganwadi, Wardha, for the annual subscription of 12 annas.
('76', 214, 4, 11, 407959) The July number contains an interesting article on national planning.
('76', 214, 4, 12, 408029) I must refer the curious to the Patrika.
('76', 214, 4, 13, 408070) I wish here only to draw attention to the following 2 striking figures: .
('76', 214, 4, 14, 408144) .we would need Rs. 300 crores of capital employing 33 lakhs of
('76', 214, 5, 15, 408207) people if we supplied all our requirements by mill production, while we would
('76', 214, 6, 16, 408285) require about Rs. 72 crores of investment employing 800 lakhs of people if
('76', 214, 7, 17, 408360) our supply were to come from cottage units.
('76', 214, 7, 18, 408404) The two methods have their
('76', 214, 8, 19, 408431) undoubted advantages.
('76', 214, 8, 20, 408453) We are poor but we have an ocean of labour wealth.
('76', 214, 9, 21, 408504) Therefore an intelligent plan will find the cottage method fit into the scheme
('76', 214, 10, 22, 408583) for our country.
('76', 214, 10, 23, 408600) Any planning in our country that ignores the absorption
('76', 214, 11, 24, 408656) of labour wealth will be misplaced.
('76', 214, 11, 25, 408692) Our analysis has shown that centralized
('76', 214, 12, 26, 408732) method of production, whatever may be its capacity to produce, is incapable of
('76', 214, 13, 27, 408811) 1 This was dated “Bombay, July 31, 1939” from S. K. Bole, who inter alia, said: “The signatories to that memorial acted bona fide and they never intended to offer any threat to the Bombay Ministry.

('76', 222, 1, 3, 418451) JIVRAJ N. MEHTA
('76', 222, 2, 4, 418467) SEGAON, WARDHA, August 9, 1939
('76', 222, 3, 5, 418498) BHAI JIVRAJ, I wanted to write to you just at the time when you had a talk with Sushila 1 at Bardoli but it could not materialize because of the con tinuous rush of work and then I allowed the matter to drop.
('76', 222, 3, 6, 418707) I am prompted to write this because of the criticism from you in Lilavati’s presence.
('76', 222, 3, 7, 418793) Your criticism has pained her.
('76', 222, 3, 8, 418824) She ought to have promptly expressed her feelings and asked for clarification.
('76', 222, 3, 9, 418903) 2 What is the use of fretting and fuming?
('76', 222, 3, 10, 418945) I do believe that you are the guardian of my right conduct as well as of my bodily health.
('76', 222, 3, 11, 419036) You would be pained if I were to commit something I ought not to.
('76', 222, 3, 12, 419102) Also it is your duty to bring it to my notice.
('76', 222, 3, 13, 419149) Hence if you have found anything in my conduct which deserves criticism or censure, please let me know, without hesi tation.
('76', 222, 3, 14, 419274) I will look upon it as true friendship.
('76', 222, 3, 15, 419314) I know, these days the newspapers carry a lot of abusive references to me.
('76', 222, 3, 16, 419389) I don’t read them; I come to hear about them.
('76', 222, 3, 17, 419435) All this abuse is not going to affect me in any way, although I should really want to know if anything weighs on the minds of friends like you.
('76', 222, 3, 18, 419579) My life is an open book.
('76', 222, 3, 19, 419604) I have never had any secrets, so you can ask me about anything you wish to.
('76', 222, 3, 20, 419680) I hope to take a lot of work from friends like you which I might not be able to do if my life were veiled in secrecy.

('76', 225, 4, 8, 423650) 292. CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE RESOLUTION 1
('76', 225, 5, 9, 423695) [August 11, 1939] 2
('76', 225, 6, 10, 423715) The Working Committee has given the most anxious conside ration to the action of Shri Subhas Chandra Bose 3 the erstwhile President of the National Congress, in connection with two resolutions 4
('76', 225, 7, 11, 423910) of the last meeting of the A. I. C. C. known as “Satyagraha in Pro vinces” and “Congress Ministries and the P. C. C.s”.
('76', 225, 7, 12, 424030) The Working Committee has also considered the long letter 5 of Shri Subhas Babu, appended hereto.
('76', 225, 7, 13, 424128) The Working Committee with great sorrow and reluctance has come to the conclusion that Subhas Babu has wholly missed the main point raised by the President of the even though he differed from the ruling of the President.
('76', 225, 7, 14, 424349) It was open to him, if he felt aggrieved by the ruling, to appeal to the Working Committee or the A. I. C. C. But he was bound, so long as the Presi dent’s instructions stood, to carry them out faithfully.
('76', 225, 7, 15, 424555) This is the first condition of the proper functioning of any organization, much more so of a vast organization like the National Congress which is engaged in a life and death struggle with the world.
('76', 225, 7, 16, 424755) If, what seems to be Subhas Babu’s contention in his letter, that every member is free to interpret the Con gress Constitution as he likes, prevails, there will be perfect anarchy in the Congress and it must break to pieces in no time.
('76', 225, 8, 17, 424991) 1 Drafted by Gandhiji; vide “Statement to the Press”, 23 8 1939. 2 From Gandhi—1915 1948: A Detailed Chronology
('76', 225, 9, 18, 425103) 3 He had asked the people to observe July 9, 1939, as ‘Protest Day’.
('76', 225, 9, 19, 425172) 4 Vide “A.I.C.C. Resolutions”, 23 6 1939. 5 Addressed to the Congress President; vide Appendix “Letter from Subhas Chandra Bose to Congress President”, 7 8 1939.
('76', 226, 0, 1, 425334) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 227
('76', 226, 1, 2, 425378) The Working Committee has come to the painful conclusion that it will fail in its duty if it condones the deliberate and flagrant breach of discipline by Subhas Babu.
('76', 226, 1, 3, 425545) The Working Committee there fore resolves that for his grave act of indiscipline Shri Subhas Babu is declared disqualified as President of the Bengal Provincial Congress Committee for three years as from August 1939. The Working Committee trusts that Shri Subhas Babu will see the error of his ways and loyally submit to this disciplinary action.
('76', 226, 1, 4, 425892) The Working Committee has taken note of the indiscipline of many other Congressmen including responsible officials.
('76', 226, 1, 5, 426008) But it has refrained from taking any action as the members acted under the inspiration of Shri Subhas Babu.
('76', 226, 1, 6, 426116) The Working Committee, however, leaves it open to Provincial Organizations to take action if they think it necessary for the proper observance of discipline and especially if the offending members do not express regret for their indiscipline.
('76', 226, 1, 7, 426359) The Committee further empowers the President to take discipli nary action against such members who, instead of expressing regret by their speech or conduct for the indiscipline, persist in it.
('76', 226, 2, 8, 426552) The Indian Annual Register, 1939, Vol. II, pp.

('76', 228, 7, 16, 429436) 297. HUNGER STRIKE
('76', 228, 8, 17, 429455) Hunger strike has positively become a plague.
('76', 228, 8, 18, 429501) On the slightest pretext some people want to resort to hunger strikes.
('76', 228, 8, 19, 429572) It is well, therefore, that the Working Committee 1 has condemned the practice in unequivocal terms, so far at least as hunger strike for discharge from imprisonment is concerned.
('76', 228, 8, 20, 429752) The Committee should have gone further and condemned also the practice of forcible feeding.
('76', 228, 8, 21, 429844) I regard forcible feeding as an undue liberty with the human body which is too sacred to be trifled with, even though it belongs to a prisoner.
('76', 228, 8, 22, 429988) No doubt the State has control over the bodies of its prisoners but never to the extent of killing their soul.
('76', 228, 8, 23, 430099) That control has well defined limits.
('76', 228, 8, 24, 430137) If a prisoner decides to starve himself to death, he should, in my opinion, be allowed to do so.
('76', 228, 8, 25, 430234) A hunger strike loses its force and dignity, when it has any, if the striker is forcibly fed.
('76', 228, 8, 26, 430328) It becomes a mockery if
('76', 228, 9, 27, 430352) 1 At its meeting held from August 9 to 12
('76', 229, 0, 1, 430394) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 229, 1, 2, 430436) somehow or other sufficient nourishment is poured down the throat, whether through the mouth or the nose.
('76', 229, 1, 3, 430542) Of course, the mind instinc tively revolts against feeding through the nose.
('76', 229, 1, 4, 430619) But I under stand that after a few day’s practice the process ceases to offend the subject himself.
('76', 229, 1, 5, 430719) Where a prisoner offers violent resistance, the matter becomes difficult.
('76', 229, 1, 6, 430793) But cases of such resistance are rare.
('76', 229, 1, 7, 430832) It is not possible to keep up effective resistance for any length of time.
('76', 229, 1, 8, 430907) A determined resister will of course die at the very first attempt and thus frustrate it.
('76', 229, 1, 9, 430997) But such resistance requires great daring and reckless defiance of death.
('76', 229, 1, 10, 431071) In any case it is my firm conviction that the method of forcible feeding should be abandoned as a relic of barbarism.
('76', 229, 1, 11, 431189) I know that some prisoners welcome forcible feeding for the empty glory of being regarded as hunger strikers.
('76', 229, 1, 12, 431299) Jailors have often told me that such prisoners would deplore stoppage of forcible feeding.
('76', 229, 1, 13, 431390) I am told that under the existing law jail authorities are bound to resort to forcible feeding if reasoning fails.
('76', 229, 1, 14, 431505) I would recommend amendment of such legislation if any.
('76', 229, 1, 15, 431561) It is also worthy of consideration whether a rule should not be passed by the Working Committee making a public and political hunger strike without permission a breach of discipline.
('76', 229, 1, 16, 431744) I do not like restraint on the liberty of the individual except for his own good and that of the society of which he is a member.
('76', 229, 1, 17, 431874) Hunger strike has, how ever, become such a nuisance that it will be as well for the Work ing Committee to adopt measures to check it before it assumes dangerous proportions.
('76', 229, 1, 18, 432048) A Working Committee resolution in such matters means expression of considered public opinion and is likely to prove a deter rent against an abuse of the practice.
('76', 229, 1, 19, 432211) It may never need to be en forced.
('76', 229, 1, 20, 432246) SEGAON, August 14, 1939 Harijan, 19 8 1939
('76', 229, 2, 21, 432289) 298. CONFEDERATION OF SMALL STATES
('76', 229, 3, 22, 432324) May I take the liberty of writing to you with a view to draw your attention to the problem of Kathiawar States?
('76', 229, 3, 23, 432436) A close study of the States comprising the Western India Agency will convince anyone that the real problem of Kathiawar is not that of responsible government in individual States.
('76', 229, 3, 24, 432616) That, in fact, is a demand very much beyond the ken of economic possibility.
('76', 229, 3, 25, 432693) None of these States, with the exception of five or six, can afford to be genuine, separate, self government units.
('76', 229, 3, 26, 432809) Economic considerations apart, their geographical contiguity, and cultural and linguistic unity posi tively point towards the desirability of grouping them all adminis tratively.
('76', 230, 0, 1, 432988) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 231
('76', 230, 1, 2, 433032) confederation of these States alone can bring their people on a par with the people of Bombay Province or, for that matter, any other province in British India.
('76', 230, 1, 3, 433193) As to the fear that the Princes might strongly dislike such a move, it might be said that one cannot hope to go through any scheme of reform em boding real transference of power to the people without being confronted by the most dogged opposition from those quarters.
('76', 230, 1, 4, 433461) And when at all events a fight (of course a non violent one) has got to be waged against that oppos ition, it is only prudent and politic on our part to fight on an issue which should be our main and ultimate demand.
('76', 230, 1, 5, 433678) Whatever our immediate and minimum demands, the final objective must not be lost sight of.
('76', 230, 1, 6, 433769) And may I suggest in the case of Kathiawar, as also some three fourths of the States in India, the final goal of all political reformers must be a confederation on the lines roughly foreshadowed in the appended printed articles?
('76', 230, 1, 7, 433998) I hope you will see that this idea, though by no means new or original, deserves to be popularized.
('76', 230, 1, 8, 434098) For, collective agitation by a group or cluster of States in favour of confederation has certain obvious advantages which agitation for reform in a single State cannot have.
('76', 230, 1, 9, 434272) How much I wish you had worked for the propagation of this idea while you were actively engaged in the Rajkot struggle.
('76', 230, 1, 10, 434392) Even now one word of support from you—of course, only if you generally agree with this view—will place this idea on a sound footing.
('76', 230, 1, 11, 434525) This important letter 1 was received by me in Abbottabad.
('76', 230, 1, 12, 434583) The articles 2 appended are cuttings from The Tribune of Lahore specially dealing with the problem.
('76', 230, 1, 13, 434683) The articles contain an interesting analysis of the Kathiawar States and corroborative quotations from the Butler Committee’s Report 3 and a recent pronouncement 4 by the Viceroy.
('76', 230, 1, 14, 434863) For the moment I must content myself with heartily supporting the proposal.
('76', 230, 1, 15, 434939) I do not share the fear of my correspondent about much opposition from the smaller States if they are sympathetically appro ached.
('76', 230, 1, 16, 435070) They will soon realize that their safety lies in some kind of confederation and sharing of power with the people.
('76', 230, 1, 17, 435184) The chief thing is a dispassionate representation of the problem and creation of public opinion that cannot be answered or opposed.
('76', 230, 1, 18, 435316) SEGAON, WARDHA, August 14, 1939 Harijan, 19 8 1939
('76', 230, 2, 19, 435367) 1 From R. L. Handa, vide “Letter from R. L. Handa”, 10 8 1939 2 For extracts, vide Appendix “Kathiawar States”, 30 9 1939. 3 According to India’s Struggle for Freedom, Vol. I, p.
