('76', 231, 1, 2, 435934) 299. NOTES
('76', 231, 2, 3, 435945) THE ARYA SAMAJ
('76', 231, 3, 4, 435960) It was a happy ending 1 to the Arya Satyagraha.
('76', 231, 3, 5, 436008) I have hitherto not written a word about this struggle.
('76', 231, 3, 6, 436064) The matter seemed too delicate for public treatment by me.
('76', 231, 3, 7, 436123) The country knows that I have a special way of dealing with things public or private.
('76', 231, 3, 8, 436209) Some even call it qui xotic.
('76', 231, 3, 9, 436238) Thus my public silence over the Arya Satyagraha did not mean that I was not deeply interested in the struggle.
('76', 231, 3, 10, 436349) I was keeping myself in touch 2 with both the Arya Samaj leaders and the Muslim friends who could have any thing to do with Hyderabad affairs.
('76', 231, 3, 11, 436492) Of course I was acting in concert with Maulana Abul Kalam Azad.
('76', 231, 3, 12, 436556) My sympathies were with the Aryas so far as their demands were con cerned.
('76', 231, 3, 13, 436631) They seemed to me to be so simple and so elementary.
('76', 231, 3, 14, 436684) But I was averse to their Satyagraha from my own standpoint which I had explained to them.
('76', 231, 3, 15, 436775) I was, however, nonplussed when they suggested that it was no worse if it was no better than the satyagraha I had led.
('76', 231, 3, 16, 436894) They must not be expected, they added, to appreciate and follow my new method or requirements.
('76', 231, 3, 17, 436989) I saw that I had no right to put any pressure upon them beyond that of reason.
('76', 231, 3, 18, 437068) Then I was anxious not to embarrass H. E. H. the Nizam’s Government as long as I could help it.
('76', 231, 3, 19, 437164) It is, therefore, a matter of great joy to me personally that the Arya struggle has ended in a friendly manner.
('76', 231, 3, 20, 437276) Both the Nizam Government and the Arya Samaj 3 deserve congratulations.
('76', 231, 3, 21, 437348) Let me hope that the dignified statement issued by Shri Ghanshyamsingh Gupta will receive from the Aryas the response it deserves.
('76', 231, 3, 22, 437479) There is no doubt that much bitterness has been engendered during the struggle.
('76', 231, 3, 23, 437559) If the Aryas act in the spirit of Shri Gupta’s appeal and the Nizam’s Government in the spirit of their own communique 4, the bitterness will die out and there never will be any occasion for resumption of the struggle so far as simple religious and cultural freedom is concerned.
('76', 231, 4, 24, 437839) 1 On August 8 2 Vide “Letter to Amrit Kaur”, 31 7 1939.
('76', 231, 5, 25, 437895) 3 “Sabha” in the source 4 According to The Indian Annual Register, 1939, Vol. II.
('76', 231, 5, 26, 437977) 14, the communique contained “clarification of certain points in the official communique of July 17, 1939, in which the Government’s attitude regarding the religious liberties in the State was set out as well as of the points raised by the, Government Gazette Extraordinary on July 19, 1939, announcing the reforms.”
('76', 232, 0, 1, 438294) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 233
('76', 232, 1, 2, 438338) THE PUNJAB CONGRESS Dr. Satyapal 1 has needlessly quoted me in order to go out of public life.
('76', 232, 1, 3, 438433) If it is an inner urge, the decision is sound.
('76', 232, 1, 4, 438480) If it is due to my innocent postcard 2 to Lala Dunichand, the doctor is hopelessly wrong.
('76', 232, 1, 5, 438570) In the first place the postcard has to do with the whole Congress atmosphere in the Punjab which has resulted in a distrust not of this or that individual but of myself.
('76', 232, 1, 6, 438740) A critic may call it cowardice if he likes.
('76', 232, 1, 7, 438784) But whether it is cowardice or want of self confidence, I am useless as a mediator so long as my malady persists.
('76', 232, 1, 8, 438898) So, when Sardar Mangal Singh and other friends from Ludhiana came to Wardha armed with authority from Dr. Satyapal, I told them that I was useless, but that Rajendra Babu as the head of the Congress organization was the proper person to go to the Punjab.
('76', 232, 1, 9, 439153) He has consented to go as soon as his health and other engagements permit.
('76', 232, 1, 10, 439228) But I have suggested to these friends that there is no help equal to self help.
('76', 232, 1, 11, 439308) They must, by their own exertion, put their house in order.
('76', 232, 1, 12, 439368) If Dr. Satyapal has not gone out in obedience to the inner urge, he will not be able to keep himself out for any length of time.
('76', 232, 1, 13, 439497) His nature will revolt against the artificial self suppression.
('76', 232, 1, 14, 439561) I therefore suggest a better course.
('76', 232, 1, 15, 439598) Let him cease to be a party man.
('76', 232, 1, 16, 439631) Let him forget old quarrels and let him be intent on producing real solidarity in the Punjab.
('76', 232, 1, 17, 439725) I cannot say how this can be done.
('76', 232, 1, 18, 439760) I have not even the data for laying down a plan of action.
('76', 232, 1, 19, 439819) He must devise it himself.
('76', 232, 1, 20, 439846) All I can say is that if he really wills it, he can do the thing.
('76', 232, 1, 21, 439912) Everybody knows that he has a following in the Punjab, that he is an indefatigable worker and has sacrifice to his credit.
('76', 232, 1, 22, 440035) If, therefore, anybody can bring about peace among Congress men in the Punjab, it is certainly Dr. Satyapal.
('76', 232, 1, 23, 440144) But whether it is he or anybody else, that one will have to efface himself and put the people’s cause, which is the Congress cause, before his own or his party’s.
('76', 232, 1, 24, 440307) Behind my diffidence must be read an intense wish that the Congress men in the Punjab should unite without mental reservations and act as one man.
('76', 232, 1, 25, 440454) INDIAN STRUGGLE IN SOUTH AFRICA Whether our countrymen in South Africa have to take up passive resistance or not, there is no doubt that they will not be able to vindicate their position if they cannot close their ranks and act as one man and act unselfishly.
('76', 232, 1, 26, 440714) Their corporate existence cannot be main 
('76', 232, 2, 27, 440756) 1 Member of the Punjab Legislative Assembly 2 Vide “Letter to Dunichand”, 20 7 1939.
('76', 233, 0, 1, 440841) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 233, 1, 2, 440883) tained with honour, if individuals in order to serve their selfish ends compromise the community’s interest and honour.
('76', 233, 1, 3, 441003) There is, at the time of writing these lines, a cleavage between the local Congress and the passive resisters.
('76', 233, 1, 4, 441114) The resisters seem to have the bulk of the Indian population with them.
('76', 233, 1, 5, 441186) But the name and prestige of the South African Congress is with the non resisters.
('76', 233, 1, 6, 441269) Now there is a prospect of a lawsuit over the possession of the Congress books, funds and offices.
('76', 233, 1, 7, 441368) I would warn the resisters against falling into the legal trap.
('76', 233, 1, 8, 441432) Let them follow my example.
('76', 233, 1, 9, 441460) The equivalent to the Congress in my days was the British Indian Association.
('76', 233, 1, 10, 441538) From the very commencement of passive resistance, I recognized that all Indians would not and could not join the struggle although all might be, as they actually were, in sympathy with it.
('76', 233, 1, 11, 441727) Although it was open to me, being secretary, to utilize the name and prestige of the Association, I founded a separate organi zation 1 leaving the British Indian Association free to act as it might within constitutional limits.
('76', 233, 1, 12, 441955) It was possible by this arrangement to protect the non resisters from harm, retain their sympathy and save the resisters from the embarrassment that would undoubtedly be caused by non resisters if they were members of the same body.
('76', 233, 1, 13, 442188) Let the present passive resisters work along their own lines and rely upon getting more than prestige by their strength, sacrifice and capacity for suffering.
('76', 233, 1, 14, 442347) A passive resister should have a generous heart and represent not only his own companions but even his opponents.
('76', 233, 1, 15, 442461) Whatever rights he secures, he will secure for all.
('76', 233, 1, 16, 442513) He is a friend of all and enemy of none.
('76', 233, 1, 17, 442554) That is the first condition of successful passive or civil resistance.
('76', 233, 1, 18, 442625) KHADI AS FAMINE INSURANCE AND MEDIUM OF INSTRUCTION
('76', 233, 2, 19, 442677) There has been a full discussion among the khadi workers at the meeting of the A. I. S. A. held at Wardha on the 12th instant and thereafter.
('76', 233, 2, 20, 442819) It has been claimed for khadi that it has at least three definite functions.
('76', 233, 2, 21, 442896) It provides a supplementary occupation to the semi starved and semi employed millions of India on a scale un equalled by any other occupation.
('76', 233, 2, 22, 443039) It provides, with the least possible loss, work in famine areas; and it is the best medium of instruction for the boys and girls of India in the primary stage.
('76', 233, 2, 23, 443199) But there is one definite condition for the success of khadi as famine insurance or medium of instruction in the primary stage.
('76', 233, 3, 24, 443327) 1 The Natal Indian Congress; vide Vol. I.
('76', 234, 0, 1, 443369) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 235
('76', 234, 1, 2, 443413) What is to be done with the khadi produced in famine areas and in the schools?
('76', 234, 1, 3, 443492) If khadi cannot be sold, it is as useless as the stones broken in many parts of India during famine time.
('76', 234, 1, 4, 443598) I have suggested often enough in these columns that all the khadi produced under the last two heads must be taken up by the State.
('76', 234, 1, 5, 443729) This can be most easily done through the A. I. S. A., if the State guarantees the losses as it guarantees today railway dividends and many other things.
('76', 234, 1, 6, 443882) Consi dering price, khadi is undoubtedly dearer than mill cloth.
('76', 234, 1, 7, 443947) Therefore it commands a market only among patriots and philanth ropists.
('76', 234, 1, 8, 444020) But those who have no spare cash will not be easily actuated by philanthropy or patriotism.
('76', 234, 1, 9, 444112) They will go to the cheapest market.
('76', 234, 1, 10, 444149) It is therefore the business of the State to shut out or tax heavily enough such goods as compete with those which, for the general good, should command a market.
('76', 234, 1, 11, 444312) I think it can be taken as proved that khadi comes under such goods.
('76', 234, 1, 12, 444381) The administration of eight provinces is virtually in Congress hands to an extent enough to protect khadi and the like.
('76', 234, 1, 13, 444501) There is no reason why the other provinces should not follow the Congress provinces in matters like protection of khadi on which there is no difference of opinion.
('76', 234, 1, 14, 444665) Hindu Muslim unity may not come as early as many of us wish.
('76', 234, 1, 15, 444726) But even as we breathe common air and drink the common water supplied by the rivers, wells or waterworks, surely we might agree on a common policy regarding other necessaries of life, without in any way interfering with our differences, if we must unfortunately hug these and use them for warring against one another.
('76', 234, 1, 16, 445044) But whether the other provinces fall in line or not, it is necessary for the Congress provinces to confer with the A. I. S. A. and the A. I. V. I. A. and evolve a line of action whereby the difficulty I have pointed out can be solved without delay.

('76', 243, 5, 12, 457778) 320. SPINNERS’ WAGES
('76', 243, 6, 13, 457799) The following is the translation of the resolution adopted by the A. I. S. A. at its meeting on the 15th instant at Wardha:
('76', 243, 7, 14, 457923) The A. I. S. A. has for the past four years recognized the duty of making a
('76', 243, 8, 15, 457999) progressive rise in the wages payable to the spinners.
('76', 243, 8, 16, 458054) In the performance of this
('76', 243, 9, 17, 458081) duty, the Maharashtra Branch of the Sangh has paid the highest rate of all the
('76', 243, 10, 18, 458160) branches.
('76', 243, 10, 19, 458170) But the result of this experiment of the Branch has been that khadi has
('76', 243, 11, 20, 458242) proved unable to bear the burden and the sales have considerably gone down.
('76', 243, 11, 21, 458318) The rise
('76', 243, 12, 22, 458327) in wages should not result in a diminution in the capacity of khadi to provide work for
('76', 243, 13, 23, 458415) the unemployed.
('76', 243, 13, 24, 458431) It seems that in view of the existing circumstances it is necessary to
('76', 243, 14, 25, 458502) postpone the insistence on giving the spinners more than three annas for eight
('76', 243, 15, 26, 458581) hours’ spinning.
('76', 243, 15, 27, 458598) There is much unemployment.
('76', 243, 15, 28, 458626) There is a sufficient number of
('76', 243, 16, 29, 458658) spinners eager to work for less than one anna for eight hours’ spinning.
('76', 243, 16, 30, 458731) Other people
('76', 243, 17, 31, 458744) are ready to give them work at such low wages to the detriment of the principle laid
('76', 243, 18, 32, 458829) down by the Sangh.
('76', 243, 18, 33, 458848) Apart from the Sangh providing them also with work, there
('76', 243, 19, 34, 458906) seems to be no other way of combating the evil.
('76', 243, 19, 35, 458954) Thus there are two duties before the
('76', 243, 20, 36, 458991) Sangh: one that of raising the spinners’ wages to eight annas for an eight hour day,
('76', 243, 21, 37, 459076) and the other of finding work for the unemployed sisters.
('76', 243, 21, 38, 459134) There comes an interim
('76', 243, 22, 39, 459157) period before reaching the simultaneous performance of the two duties.
('76', 243, 23, 40, 459228) Moreover there is a danger of famine overtaking some parts of the country.
('76', 243, 24, 41, 459303) The spinning wheel is being proved to be of the greatest help at such times.
('76', 244, 0, 1, 459380) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 245
('76', 244, 1, 2, 459424) question arises whether it is necessary to make the scale of wages lower than even three annas.
('76', 244, 1, 3, 459520) A third problem arises from the fact of the production of yarn in the schools conducted according to the Wardha scheme of education.
('76', 244, 2, 4, 459653) Taking all these things into consideration the Sangh has come to the following conclusion :
('76', 244, 3, 5, 459745) Generally the scale of three annas for eight hours’ work of the fixed standard be not touched for the time being.
('76', 244, 3, 6, 459859) But it should be open to any branch to rise higher than the scale, provided that it takes over the responsibility of sustaining its sales under the higher scale.
('76', 244, 3, 7, 460021) In the event of the necessity being felt of lowering the wages of artisans in the famine areas, the decrease may be made with the previous permission of the Secretary.
('76', 244, 3, 8, 460189) The Sangh should take over from the respective Governments the sales of khadi prepared in famine areas and in schools conducted under the Wardha scheme of education, provided that these Governments bear the losses sustained in the disposal of such khadi.
('76', 244, 4, 9, 460444) This is an important resolution.
('76', 244, 4, 10, 460477) It marks a slowing down of the speed with which I was goading the Sangh to rise to eight annas wages for an eight hour day for the spinners.
('76', 244, 4, 11, 460618) I knew that the goal was not to be reached in one jump.
('76', 244, 4, 12, 460674) I had, however, nursed the hope that every few months would show a progressive increase in the wages.
('76', 244, 4, 13, 460776) But reports from the different branches and the partial failure of the ex periment carried on under my nose by Shri Jajuji 1 under the guidance of Shri Vinoba with high hopes of going forward with the rise, have opened my eyes to the stern and grim reality that this country is so terribly poor that it cannot afford to pay a wage of eight annas per day of eight hours to millions of women.
('76', 244, 4, 14, 461167) Generally nowhere in rural areas do village labourers or artisans earn eight annas for eight hours’ work.
('76', 244, 4, 15, 461273) Spinners could not earn eight annas without all the other classes doing likewise.
('76', 244, 4, 16, 461355) And the purchasing classes simply have not the money to pay an all round wage of eight annas per day unless conditions are radically altered.
('76', 244, 4, 17, 461497) The crushing and unproductive military burden drains the country dry.
('76', 244, 4, 18, 461567) Add to this the inordinately high salaries and correspondingly high pensions paid, and spent abroad.
('76', 244, 4, 19, 461668) There are other internal causes also for this gnawing poverty.
('76', 244, 4, 20, 461731) But I must not stray from the purpose of this article.
('76', 244, 4, 21, 461786) Be the cause or causes what they may, the painful fact has been brought home by khadi workers that in spite of all the will in the world the middle class khadi buyer simply has not the money to buy khadi at the increased price necessitated by the rise in wages beyond the point
('76', 244, 5, 22, 462064) 1 Shri Krishnadas Jaju
('76', 245, 0, 1, 462087) 246 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 245, 1, 2, 462129) of three annas.
('76', 245, 1, 3, 462145) They report that for the time being at any rate that is the saturation point.
('76', 245, 1, 4, 462223) The resolution is a recognition of this painful fact.
('76', 245, 1, 5, 462277) But even the scale of three annas cannot be sustained if the Pro vincial Governments do not come to the rescue.
('76', 245, 1, 6, 462389) They can do so both through legislative and administrative effort.
('76', 245, 1, 7, 462456) This they will only do if they will use the A.I.S.A., the A.I.V.I.A. and the Hindustani Talimi Sangh as their own expert, voluntary and honorary agencies.
('76', 245, 1, 8, 462611) I present them with the prospect of putting several lakhs of rupees into the pockets of the famishing villagers by providing them with employ ment during leisure hours.
('76', 245, 1, 9, 462780) But no progress can be made if the manu factures of the villagers do not become current coin.
('76', 245, 1, 10, 462874) SEGAON, August 20, 1939 Harijan, 26 8 1939
('76', 245, 2, 11, 462917) 321. NOTES AMONG ‘CRIMINAL TRIBES’
('76', 245, 3, 12, 462952) Shri H. S. Kaujalgi of the Karnataka Branch of the A.I.S.A. sends me beautiful slivers and equally good yarn prepared and spun by the women in the‘criminal tribes’ settlement near Bijapur and writes :
('76', 245, 4, 13, 463153) The women are not criminals themselves, but they are the immediate dependants of the habitual criminals that are placed under certain restrictions in the settlement.
('76', 245, 4, 14, 463319) The manager of the settlement asked the A.I.S.A. Karnataka Branch to try to introduce spinning in the settlement.
('76', 245, 4, 15, 463433) As spinning was unknown to these women, they had no prejudices for any particular kind of spinning wheels or carding process.
('76', 245, 4, 16, 463559) So we thought it in the best interest of the spinners to introduce Andhra methods of spinning and carding.
('76', 245, 4, 17, 463666) We began on the 19th of July.
('76', 245, 4, 18, 463696) Five women are attending the class.
('76', 245, 4, 19, 463732) They belong to the Bhat, Corvi and Waders communities.
('76', 245, 4, 20, 463787) They are paid one anna and six pies per day as stipend during the course of spinning.
('76', 245, 4, 21, 463873) They can now spin 500 yards in three hours.
('76', 245, 4, 22, 463917) The cotton used is Jayawant and the yarn spun is between 30 and 40 counts.
('76', 245, 4, 23, 463992) We are continuing the class till the end of August, after which time we shall be providing them with cotton and purchasing yarn from them.
('76', 245, 4, 24, 464131) If the experiment succeeds, we are introducing spinning in other criminal settlements also.
('76', 245, 4, 25, 464223) Shri Dhruva, the Backward Class Officer, Poona, is enthusiastic about it.
('76', 245, 5, 26, 464297) Towards the end of August we are holding a competition in spinning.
('76', 245, 5, 27, 464365) We are giving a sari as a present to all those who spin more than three hundred yards of 30 counts yarn in one hour.
('76', 245, 5, 28, 464482) As the women are quick and intelligent it is possible that every one of the five spinners will get a sari.
('76', 246, 0, 1, 464589) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 247
('76', 246, 1, 2, 464633) This is a good beginning.
('76', 246, 1, 3, 464659) If the Provincial Governments will take the fullest advantage of the three expert constructive bodies, viz., A.I.S.A., A.I.V.I.A. and Hindustani Talimi Sangh, they will find the maximum amount of productive work with the minimum expen diture of money and energy.
('76', 246, 1, 4, 464922) But of course they have to face the problem of the sale of goods manufactured through the activities of these three bodies.
('76', 246, 1, 5, 465046) Such a question arises only in this unfortunate land.
('76', 246, 1, 6, 465100) In other countries the State sees to it that the people use the goods that are manufactured by or under State supervision.
('76', 246, 1, 7, 465223) The Pro vincial Governments have the opportunity, though to a limited extent, of putting things right.
('76', 246, 1, 8, 465326) SEGAON, August 20, 1939 Harijan, 26 8 1939

('76', 246, 8, 15, 465651) 323. WANTED PURCHASERS
('76', 246, 9, 16, 465674) The following is taken from a letter from the Gandhi Ashram, Meerut :
('76', 246, 10, 17, 465744) The A.I.S.A. is giving work today to more than three lakhs of people.
('76', 246, 10, 18, 465814) Its operations extend to 13,000 villages.
('76', 246, 10, 19, 465856) 2,571 workers are engaged in this great nation building activity.
('76', 246, 10, 20, 465922) The quota of the United Provinces is no mean one.
('76', 246, 10, 21, 465972) We have more than 40,000 spinners on our registers.
('76', 246, 10, 22, 466024) The number of other artisans, weavers, washermen, carders, etc., is 4,780. Nearly 3,043 villages are covered by our activities, and 600 workers carry the message of khadi to different parts of the province.
('76', 246, 10, 23, 466231) It brings all the creative forces of the nation into play.
('76', 246, 10, 24, 466290) We learn to combine, plan, co ordinate and build.
('76', 246, 10, 25, 466340) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru has been reported to have said in the Working Committee that the spinning wheel cannot fulfil all
('76', 247, 0, 1, 466462) 248 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 247, 1, 2, 466504) our needs of cloth today.
('76', 247, 1, 3, 466530) I feel this statement underrates the possibility of the spinning wheel.
('76', 247, 1, 4, 466602) I can say from our experience that we have not been able to touch even the fringe of the problem.
('76', 247, 1, 5, 466700) Production can be multiplied a thousand times within a very short period provided we have a ready market for the khadi we manufacture.
('76', 247, 1, 6, 466835) I have omitted the portion containing an appeal for sales.
('76', 247, 1, 7, 466894) I hope that their effort will meet with the success it deserves.
('76', 247, 1, 8, 466959) But what I wish to consider here is the reason for the sales not keeping pace with the production.
('76', 247, 1, 9, 467058) Propaganda undoubtedly has its place.
('76', 247, 1, 10, 467096) But more than propaganda is wanted scientific research.
('76', 247, 1, 11, 467152) There is no doubt that our people use on an average 15 yards of cloth per head per year.
('76', 247, 1, 12, 467241) There is is no doubt that this cloth costs the country a figure approaching 100 crores of rupees, meaning less than three rupees per head, coun ting India’s population at 35 crores.
('76', 247, 1, 13, 467423) It is easy enough to say that the sales can be effected if the State protects khadi.
('76', 247, 1, 14, 467508) That khadi deserves protection is in my opinion a self proved proposition.
('76', 247, 1, 15, 467583) 1 But have the khadi workers who have the qualifications found out whether we have done all we could to command sales even without protection?
('76', 247, 1, 16, 467726) There are two obstacles.
('76', 247, 1, 17, 467751) Mill made cloth is said to be much cheaper than khadi, and has a variety of colour, design and finish which khadi does not possess.
('76', 247, 1, 18, 467883) The second has been largely overcome, but more is perhaps required to be done.
('76', 247, 1, 19, 467962) There must be a limit beyond which probably khadi cannot go.
('76', 247, 1, 20, 468023) If there is, we must frankly confess it.
('76', 247, 1, 21, 468064) But my fear is that sufficient research has not been made as to the prices.
('76', 247, 1, 22, 468140) Professor Kumarappa has put forth a startling claim for the spinning wheel.
('76', 247, 1, 23, 468216) He has produced figures in support of it.
('76', 247, 1, 24, 468258) 2 But the man in the street asks the questions: ‘Then why is khadi dearer than mill cloth?’ This question has to be satisfactorily answered.
('76', 247, 1, 25, 468399) The obvious answers I would not consider to be satisfactory.
('76', 247, 1, 26, 468460) The answers themselves have to be thoroughly examined and the way to overcome the difficulties discovered and pursued till khadi comes to occupy its natural supremacy.
('76', 247, 1, 27, 468628) It is a shame that we who grow more cotton than we need should have to send it abroad for being turned into cloth for us.
('76', 247, 1, 28, 468750) It is equally a shame for us that we who have in our villages unlimited unused labour, and can easily supply ourselves with village instru ments of
('76', 247, 2, 29, 468898) 1 Vide also “Notes”, sub title, “Khadi as Famine Insurance and Medium of Instruction”, “Letter to Jivanji D. Desai”, 14 8 1939. 2 Vide “Mills v.
('76', 247, 2, 30, 469043) Charkha”, 7 8 1939.
('76', 248, 0, 1, 469063) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 249
('76', 248, 1, 2, 469107) manufacture, should send our cotton to the mills of our cities for it to be manufactured into cloth for our use.
('76', 248, 1, 3, 469220) We know the history of the shame.
('76', 248, 1, 4, 469254) But we have not yet discovered the sure way to deal with the double shame beyond a patriotic appeal to the public.
('76', 248, 1, 5, 469369) The latter have returned an encouraging response.
('76', 248, 1, 6, 469419) But the recent resolution seems to show that we have reached the limit of the patronage.
('76', 248, 1, 7, 469508) We may not be satisfied until khadi becomes an article of universal wear.
('76', 248, 1, 8, 469582) It may be that in the prosecution of our search we may find, as some suggest we shall, that khadi can never become an economic pro position.
('76', 248, 1, 9, 469723) We should then have no hesitation in making the admission, however it may hurt our pride and demolish the proposition we have hitherto advanced with so much confidence.
('76', 248, 1, 10, 469892) But the admission cannot be made till we have made every search that is possible for a human being to make so as to yield an unequivocal answer to the questions propounded by me.
('76', 248, 1, 11, 470071) SEGAON, August 21, 1939 Harijan, 26 8 1939
('76', 248, 2, 12, 470114) 324. NOTES
('76', 248, 3, 13, 470125) WHY ONLY PROHIBITION?
('76', 248, 3, 14, 470147) A correspondent thus twits me: It was all very well for you to have insisted on prohibition.
('76', 248, 3, 15, 470240) Do you suppose that the ‘satta’ in the share market, the ‘ank farak’, the dens of gambling, the races and the cinemas do less damage to the morals and the pockets of the people than the drink evil?
('76', 248, 3, 16, 470438) I hear you have never gone to the cinema.
('76', 248, 3, 17, 470480) Do go, if only once, and you will see things on the stage and among the spectators that will set you athinking.
('76', 248, 3, 18, 470592) I assure you that the institutions I have mentioned demand your attention as much as the drink monster.
('76', 248, 3, 19, 470696) This is the substance of a fairly long indictment in Gujarati.
('76', 248, 3, 20, 470759) There are other things packed into the letter.
('76', 248, 3, 21, 470806) But I have given in my own words the relevant portions.
('76', 248, 3, 22, 470862) I have no difficulty in agreeing with the correspondent that the evils named by him are serious and should be dealt with.
('76', 248, 3, 23, 470984) But who will bell the cat?
('76', 248, 3, 24, 471011) If I could have, I should have dealt with the lady long ago.
('76', 248, 3, 25, 471072) I have my limitations.
('76', 248, 3, 26, 471095) I have only recently shown 1 that I am not so
('76', 248, 4, 27, 471141) 1 Vide “Am I All Powerful”, 6 8 1939.
('76', 249, 0, 1, 471179) 250 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 249, 1, 2, 471221) powerful as some people imagine.
('76', 249, 1, 3, 471254) The drink evil has been recog nized as such by the people of this land.
('76', 249, 1, 4, 471326) But the other evils are more or less fashionable.
('76', 249, 1, 5, 471376) If I led an agitation against the share gambling, I should be in danger of losing some of my willing and regular donors.
('76', 249, 1, 6, 471497) If I incited people against the races and the infernal gamble that goes on there, all the high personages from the Viceroy downward would be up in arms against me.
('76', 249, 1, 7, 471661) And those who patronize the race specials?
('76', 249, 1, 8, 471704) If I led a raging compaign against the cinemas, I should lose caste among educationists and reformers.
('76', 249, 1, 9, 471807) They have often sought to con vert me by pleading that cinemas are a fine medium of education and that churches and reformers in the West give them their patronage in an ever increasing measure.
('76', 249, 1, 10, 472002) Therefore if I treated these evils as I have treated the drink evil and if I began to organize picketing in respect of them, I should lose caste, lose my mahatmaship, and even lose my head which of course has very little value at this time of my life.
('76', 249, 1, 11, 472254) But as I do not wish to suffer the triple loss, I must allow my corres pondent and others like him to think that I am shirking an obvious duty.
('76', 249, 1, 12, 472398) I know the evils.
('76', 249, 1, 13, 472416) I hope that greater reformers than I will deal with them.
('76', 249, 1, 14, 472474) For me one step is enough.
('76', 249, 2, 15, 472501) A FRAUD ON KHADI The Secretary, A.I.S.A., Punjab Branch, writes:
('76', 249, 3, 16, 472566) I am sending per separate parcel an advertisement of Butala khadi.
('76', 249, 3, 17, 472633) They were our certified centre till the end of 1937. Some suspicion then arose regarding the purity of yarn used by them.
('76', 249, 3, 18, 472755) The matter was investigated and the Ahmedabad Office decided that they must keep an A.I.S.A. inspector for their centre to watch that no mill yarn was used.
('76', 249, 3, 19, 472912) They refused to abide by that decision, on which their certificate was cancelled.
('76', 249, 3, 20, 472994) They are now exploiting our certificate that was given to them while they were working as a certified centre.
('76', 249, 3, 21, 473104) They do not say that their certificate has been cancelled since, but quote the old certificate giving a false impression to the public that they have still got the patronage of Mahatma Gandhi, Shri Jamnalal Bajaj and other leaders of esteem.
('76', 249, 3, 22, 473346) I feel something might be done to remove this impression.
('76', 249, 3, 23, 473404) I have omitted the advertisement.
('76', 249, 3, 24, 473438) The action complained of in the letter is obviously a fraud on khadi.
('76', 249, 3, 25, 473508) It is probably an actionable wrong.
('76', 249, 3, 26, 473544) Though the A.I.S.A. has followed the policy of relying upon public opinion to protect khadi against fraud, the wrong doers should know that the A.I.S.A. has taken no vow not to seek legal protection if it became necessary.
('76', 249, 3, 27, 473767) I hope that the party making use of a cancelled certificate will wisely give up the practice, return the certificate to the Association, and refrain from dealing in khadi in contravention of the
('76', 250, 0, 1, 473962) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 251
('76', 250, 1, 2, 474006) rules of the A.I.S.A. The Secretary of the Branch should warn the wrong doer against the wrongful use of the cancelled certificate and report the result to the Central Office.

('76', 257, 0, 1, 484174) 258 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 257, 1, 2, 484216) 337. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('76', 257, 2, 3, 484246) SEGAON, August 23, 1939 I continue to receive letters, mostly abusive, about what may be called the Subhas Babu resolution 2 of the Working Committee.
('76', 257, 2, 4, 484397) I also saw a letter addressed to Rajendra Babu, which can hardly be sur passed in the use of filthy language.
('76', 257, 2, 5, 484507) I have seen some criticisms about the war resolution 3. I owe it to the public to make my position clear about both these resolutions.
('76', 257, 2, 6, 484642) I must confess that the Subhas Babu resolution was drafted by me.
('76', 257, 2, 7, 484708) I can say that the members of the Working Committee would have shirked the duty of taking action if they could have.
('76', 257, 2, 8, 484825) They knew that there would be a storm of opposition against their action.
('76', 257, 2, 9, 484899) It was easier for them to have a colourless resolution than to have one which was no respecter of persons.
('76', 257, 2, 10, 485006) Not to take some action would have amounted to abdication of their primary function of preserving discipline among Congressmen.
('76', 257, 2, 11, 485134) Subhas Babu had invited action.
('76', 257, 2, 12, 485166) He had gallantly suggested that if any action was to be taken it should be taken against him as the prime mover.
('76', 257, 2, 13, 485279) In my opinion the action taken by the Working Committee was the mildest possible.
('76', 257, 2, 14, 485361) There was no desire to be vindictive.
('76', 257, 2, 15, 485399) Surely the word vindictiveness loses all force and meaning when the position of Subhas Babu is considered.
('76', 257, 2, 16, 485506) He knew that he could not be hurt by the Working Committee.
('76', 257, 2, 17, 485566) His popularity had put him above being affected by any action that the Working Committee might take.
('76', 257, 2, 18, 485667) He had pitted himself against the Working Committee, if not the Congress organization.
('76', 257, 2, 19, 485754) The members of the Working Committee, therefore, had to perform their duty and leave the Congressmen and the public to judge between themselves and Subhas Babu.
('76', 257, 2, 20, 485915) It has been suggested that Subhas Babu has done what I would have done under similar circumstances.
('76', 257, 2, 21, 486015) I cannot recall a single instance in my life of having done what Subhas Babu has done, i.e., defied an organization to which I owed allegiance.
('76', 257, 2, 22, 486159) I could understand rebellion after secession from such an organization.
('76', 257, 2, 23, 486231) That was the meaning and secret of the non 
('76', 257, 3, 24, 486275) 1 This appeared under the title “The Two Resolutions”.
('76', 257, 3, 25, 486330) The statement was also published in The Hindu, 23 8 1939, and The Hindustan Times, 24 8 1939. 2 Vide “Congress Working Committee Resolution”, 11 8 1939. 3 Vide Appendix “Congress Working Committee Resolution”, after 18 7 1939

('76', 262, 3, 4, 494117) 343. PLEA FOR VOLUNTARY FEDERATION
('76', 262, 4, 5, 494152) Imposed federation is likely to divide India more than it is today.
('76', 262, 4, 6, 494220) It would be a great step if the British Government were to declare that they would not impose their federal structure on India.
('76', 262, 4, 7, 494348) The Viceroy seems to be acting in that fashion if he is not saying so.
('76', 262, 4, 8, 494419) If my surmise is correct, I suggest that a clear declaration will add grace to his action and will probably pave the way for real federation and therefore real unity.
('76', 262, 4, 9, 494586) That federation can naturally never be of the Government of India Act brand.
('76', 262, 4, 10, 494663) Whatever it is, it must be a product of the free choice of all India.
('76', 262, 4, 11, 494733) But before that political and legalized federation of free choice comes, there should be voluntary federation of parts, to begin with, if not of the whole.
('76', 262, 4, 12, 494889) This reflection arises from famine conditions today in parts of lesser Gujarat and the whole of Kathiawar.
('76', 262, 4, 13, 494996) I have received angry protests from correspondents drawing my attention to what they have termed the heartless policy of the Bombay Government in prohibiting the movement of fodder and grain.
('76', 262, 4, 14, 495188) I could not believe my correspondents.
('76', 262, 4, 15, 495227) I knew that the Sardar was moving heaven and earth to cope with the distress both in Gujarat and Kathiawar.
('76', 262, 4, 16, 495335) But in order to make assurance doubly sure, I wired to the Prime Minister.
('76', 262, 4, 17, 495410) Immediately on the same day came the following answer :
('76', 262, 5, 18, 495466) Removal of fodder from six districts not permitted without the permision of Collector as the necessities of our Province must be first considered.
('76', 262, 5, 19, 495613) Excess will be permitted to be removed.
('76', 262, 5, 20, 495653) The wire was followed by a letter enclosing a copy of the Bill about to be introduced in the Bombay Assembly.
('76', 262, 5, 21, 495763) It simply controls the movement and prices of grain and fodder during times of famine or scarcity.
('76', 262, 5, 22, 495862) This is no policy of prohibition but it is one of control over and regulation of the movement of fodder and grain so as to prevent hoarding in speculators’ hands or disposal to the extent of starving the places where it is grown and stored.
('76', 262, 5, 23, 496103) The Premier’s letter contemplates collection of grain andfodderfrom available sources outside the Province and its distribution in famine areas including Kathiawar.
('76', 262, 5, 24, 496268) The Bombay measure I consider not only to be necessary but conducive to the interest as well of the whole of the States part of the Province as of
('76', 263, 0, 1, 496415) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 263, 1, 2, 496457) the British part.
('76', 263, 1, 3, 496475) I call it an act of voluntary fede ration.
('76', 263, 1, 4, 496518) The reader must not quarrel with the stretch of the mean ing of the word.
('76', 263, 1, 5, 496592) This little act introduces the reader to what can become a big act of voluntary federation.
('76', 263, 1, 6, 496684) I reproduced 1 the other day a letter from a correspondent suggesting a federation of the Kathiawar States in many matters of common interest.
('76', 263, 1, 7, 496827) The correspondent’s ultimate aim was political federation.
('76', 263, 1, 8, 496886) What I contemplate has nothing to do with politics.
('76', 263, 1, 9, 496938) My present and ultimate aim here is purely humanitarian.
('76', 263, 1, 10, 496995) If the Kathiawar States would voluntarily federate, say, for water, forests and roads, purely for saving life, there would be no danger of a water famine such as threatens the cluster of States.
('76', 263, 1, 11, 497190) There are States rich enough who can provide water for the whole of Kathiawar.
('76', 263, 1, 12, 497269) I know it cannot be done in a day.
('76', 263, 1, 13, 497304) But the dog in the manger policy followed in Kathiawar has made impossible any scheme of big waterworks.
('76', 263, 1, 14, 497409) Kathiwar has fairly good rivers and hills.
('76', 263, 1, 15, 497452) There is no limit to the possibility of artesian wells.
('76', 263, 1, 16, 497508) If only all the States will combine and the rich ones will use their riches for the common good, they will be saved the awful prospect of people and cattle having to die of thirst.
('76', 263, 1, 17, 497689) I have faith that it is possible for Kathiawar to ensure a proper supply of water even in dry years.
('76', 263, 1, 18, 497790) But no common waterworks will answer the purpose for all time unless there is a long view scheme of afforestation.
('76', 263, 1, 19, 497905) There are practically no forests in Kathiawar.
('76', 263, 1, 20, 497952) The Princes and the people have to combine to plant trees on an extensive scale.
('76', 263, 1, 21, 498033) This cannot be done unless the States and the people regard the whole of Kathiawar as their joint and common land and have wisdom enough to desire to live on their land without the perpetual dread of having to die of thirst when the god of rain stops supplies.
('76', 263, 1, 22, 498294) SEGAON, August 25, 1939 Harijan, 2 9 1939
('76', 263, 2, 23, 498336) 344. MOTOR V. CART
('76', 263, 3, 24, 498355) Gram Udyog Patrika for August examines the respective merits of motor vans and carts for village propaganda.
('76', 263, 3, 25, 498464) Those who will read the whole argument should send for the Patrika.
('76', 263, 3, 26, 498532) I give below the most
('76', 263, 4, 27, 498554) 1 Vide”Confederation of Small States”, 14 8 1939.
('76', 264, 0, 1, 498604) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 265
('76', 264, 1, 2, 498648) important part of the argument.
('76', 264, 2, 3, 498680) We have been asked whether District Boards and such other local bodies, who wish to set apart a certain amount of money for village work, will do well to invest in motor vans for propaganda work of various kinds in villages.
('76', 264, 2, 4, 498905) .The question is whether speeding up matters by the use of motor vans which can visit more than one village in a night will suit the purpose.
('76', 264, 3, 5, 499047) In all our expenditure, especially when that expenditure is undertaken expressly for the benefit of the village people, it is necessary to see that the money spent goes back to the villager.
('76', 264, 3, 6, 499238) District and local Boards obtain their money from the people, and their purchases must be such as will help to circulate money among the people.
('76', 264, 4, 7, 499383) What the villager needs above all is profitable employment.
('76', 264, 4, 8, 499443) We steadily deprive him of employment by buying imported articles, and by way of compensation give him lectures, magic lantern shows and tinned music all at his expense, and pat ourselves on the back that we are working for his welfare.
('76', 264, 4, 9, 499680) Can anything be more absurd?
('76', 264, 5, 10, 499709) Compare with this what happens if in the place of the motor van the much despised bullock cart were used.
('76', 264, 5, 11, 499815) It can reach the most remote villages which a motor lorry cannot do.
('76', 264, 5, 12, 499884) It costs only a fraction of the money required for a van, so that many bullock carts can be bought, if necessary, to serve groups of villages in the district.
('76', 264, 5, 13, 500043) The money spent on them goes to the village carpenter, blacksmith and cart driver.
('76', 264, 5, 14, 500126) Not a pie of it need go out of the district.
('76', 264, 6, 15, 500171) Rural work and motor vans appear, therefore, to go ill together.
('76', 264, 6, 16, 500236) What is required is steady, constructive effort, not lightning speed and empty show.
('76', 264, 6, 17, 500321) We would commend to local Boards and public institutions genuinely interested in village welfare to start by using only village made goods, to study the conditions which are steadily producing poverty in the villages, and concentrate on removing them one by one.
('76', 264, 6, 18, 500584) When every side of village life needs intensive, well considered effort, it seems a waste of public money to throw it away on methods which attempt to bring about village uplift overnight.
('76', 264, 6, 19, 500773) It is to be hoped that those who interest themselves in village welfare will take to heart the obvious argument advanced in favour of the cart.
('76', 264, 6, 20, 500917) It will be cruel to destroy the village economy through the very agency designed for village welfare.
('76', 264, 6, 21, 501019) SEGAON, August 25, 1939 Harijan, 16 9 1939

('76', 265, 13, 22, 502080) 347. MACHINE OIL AND “GHANI” OIL
('76', 265, 14, 23, 502113) The village ghani, the village chakki, the village loom and charkha, and the village sugar cane crusher were once inseparable parts of the village.
('76', 265, 14, 24, 502261) The A.I.S.A. and the A.I.V.I.A. are trying to
('76', 266, 0, 1, 502307) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 267
('76', 266, 1, 2, 502351) revive some of them.
('76', 266, 1, 3, 502372) We know fairly well how the loom and the charkha can be revived.
('76', 266, 1, 4, 502437) Khadi has become a science to be mastered in all its aspects.
('76', 266, 1, 5, 502499) Maganlal Gandhi laid the foundation of that science.
('76', 266, 1, 6, 502552) The village chakki and the village sugar cane crusher have yet to discover their science men.
('76', 266, 1, 7, 502646) But the ghani has.
('76', 266, 1, 8, 502665) Shri Jhaverbhai Patel of Maganwadi is studying the ghani in all its aspects with the zeal and precision of a scientist.
('76', 266, 1, 9, 502785) He has made improvements which he claims have lessened the labour of both men and animals who work at the ghani and have at the same time increased the output of oil.
('76', 266, 1, 10, 502952) He has studied the oil market and the movement of seeds.
('76', 266, 1, 11, 503009) The result is that he is today able to sell his oil at almost the bazaar rates and therefore commands a ready market.
('76', 266, 1, 12, 503127) His oil is superior to the machine product which is, as a rule, adulterated and never fresh.
('76', 266, 1, 13, 503220) But Shri Jhaverbhai is not satisfied merely because he competes successfuly with the local market in Wardha.
('76', 266, 1, 14, 503329) He has found out why the machine oil is at all cheaper than the ghani oil.
('76', 266, 1, 15, 503404) He gives three reasons, two of which are unavoidable.
('76', 266, 1, 16, 503458) They are capital and the ability of the machine to extract the last drop of oil and that too in a shorter time than the ghani.
('76', 266, 1, 17, 503585) These advantages are neutralized by the commission.
('76', 266, 1, 18, 503637) The owner of the mill has to pay to the middleman.
('76', 266, 1, 19, 503688) But Shri Jhaverbhai cannot cope with the third reason, adulteration, unless he also takes to it.
('76', 266, 1, 20, 503785) This naturally he will not do.
('76', 266, 1, 21, 503816) He therefore suggests that adulteration should be dealt with by law.
('76', 266, 1, 22, 503885) This can be done by enforcing the Anti adulteration Act if there is one or by enacting it and by licensing oil mills.
('76', 266, 1, 23, 504003) Shri Jhaverbhai has also examined the cause of the decline of the village ghani.
('76', 266, 1, 24, 504084) The most potent cause is the inability of the oilman to command a regular supply of seeds.
('76', 266, 1, 25, 504175) The villages are practically denuded of seeds after the season.
('76', 266, 1, 26, 504239) The oilman has no money to store the seeds, much less to buy them in the cities.
('76', 266, 1, 27, 504320) Therefore he has disappeared or is fast disappearing.
('76', 266, 1, 28, 504374) Lakhs of ghanis are today lying idle causing a tremendous waste of the country’s resources.
('76', 266, 1, 29, 504466) Surely it is the function of the State to resuscitate the existing ghanis by conserving seeds in the places of their origin and making them available to the village oilman at reasonable rates.
('76', 266, 1, 30, 504659) The Government loses nothing by giving this aid.
('76', 266, 1, 31, 504708) It can be given,so Shri Jhaverbhai contends, through co operative societies or panchayats.
('76', 266, 1, 32, 504799) If this is done, Shri Jhaverbhai is of opinion, based on research, that ghani oil can compete with the machine product and the villager can be spared the infliction of the adulterated oil he gets today.
('76', 266, 1, 33, 505002) It should be borne in
('76', 267, 0, 1, 505024) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 267, 1, 2, 505066) mind that the only fat the villager gets, when he gets any, is what the oil can give him.
('76', 267, 1, 3, 505156) To ghee he is generally a stranger.
('76', 267, 1, 4, 505192) SEGAON, August 26, 1939 Harijan, 2 9 1939
('76', 267, 2, 5, 505234) 348. A MAHARJA’S THREAT
('76', 267, 3, 6, 505258) I received some weeks ago an important letter from Patiala.
('76', 267, 3, 7, 505318) It contained such grave statements attributed to the Maharaja Saheb of Patiala that I referred them to him for confirmation or otherwise.
('76', 267, 3, 8, 505456) It is now more than three weeks since I wrote to him.
('76', 267, 3, 9, 505510) But I have no reply.
('76', 267, 3, 10, 505531) 1 I therefore presume that the statements reported by my correspondent are substantially true.
('76', 267, 3, 11, 505626) Here is the main part of the letter :
('76', 267, 4, 12, 505664) The Patiala State Praja Mandal launched satyagraha against the Hidayat of
('76', 267, 5, 13, 505738) 1988 2, a lawless law curtailing the civil liberties of the people.
('76', 267, 5, 14, 505806) On our advice the satyagraha was suspended unconditionally.
('76', 267, 5, 15, 505866) The Publicity Officer, Patiala, on behalf of H.H.’s Government, stated in a Press communique dated 15th April that the Government would repeal or withdraw the aforesaid Hidayat within three to
('76', 267, 6, 16, 506059) four weeks, and further stated that the Government had constituted a Committee to go into its provisions and submit an early report.
('76', 267, 6, 17, 506192) But the announcement has remained up till now a dead letter.
('76', 267, 6, 18, 506253) And instead, H.H. has by Ijlas khas orders dated 25th May ordered the strict enforcement of the Hidayat for a period of another
('76', 267, 7, 19, 506381) six months.
('76', 267, 7, 20, 506393) In view of this, no propaganda of any kind can be carried on by the Praja Mandal workers, the provisions of the Hidayat being very wide and
('76', 267, 8, 21, 506533) sweeping.
('76', 267, 8, 22, 506543) The workers arrested in connection with this agitation are still in jail and others are being tried.
('76', 267, 8, 23, 506644) Apart from this there is at present another movement going on within the State, i.e., between landlords and tenants.
('76', 267, 9, 24, 506761) Some of the Praja Mandal workers were allowed an interview with H. H.
('76', 267, 10, 25, 506831) on the 18th instant.
('76', 267, 10, 26, 506852) During the interview H. H. addressed them as follows :
('76', 267, 11, 27, 506907) “My ancestors have won the State by the sword and I mean to keep it by
('76', 267, 12, 28, 506978) the sword.
('76', 267, 12, 29, 506989) I do not recognize any organization to represent my people or to
('76', 267, 13, 30, 507054) speak on their behalf.
('76', 267, 13, 31, 507077) I am their sole and only representative.
('76', 267, 13, 32, 507118) No such
('76', 267, 14, 33, 507126) organization such as Praja Mandal can be allowed to exist within the State.
('76', 267, 15, 34, 507202) 1 For the Maharaja’s reply, which was received subsequently and which appeared along with this, vide Appendix “Letter from Yadavindra Singh”, 9 9 1939. Also for Gandhiji’s note appended to these, vide “Remarks on ‘A Maharaja’s Threat’”, 12 9 1939. 2 Of Vikram calendar, corresponding to 1932 A.D.
('76', 268, 0, 1, 507499) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 269
('76', 268, 1, 2, 507543) you want to do Congress work, get out of the State.
('76', 268, 1, 3, 507595) The Congress can terrify the
('76', 268, 2, 4, 507624) British Government, but if it ever tries to interfere in my State it will find me a
('76', 268, 3, 5, 507708) terrible resister.
('76', 268, 3, 6, 507727) I cannot tolerate any flag other than my own to be flown
('76', 268, 4, 7, 507784) within my boundaries.
('76', 268, 4, 8, 507806) You stop your Praja Mandal activities, otherwise I shall
('76', 268, 5, 9, 507863) resort to such repression that your generations to come will not forget it.
('76', 268, 6, 10, 507939) see some of my dear subjects drifting away into another fold, it touches the very
('76', 268, 7, 11, 508021) core of my heart.
('76', 268, 7, 12, 508039) I advise you to get out of the Mandal and stop all kind of
('76', 268, 8, 13, 508098) agitation; or else remember I am a military man; my talk is blunt and my bullet
('76', 268, 9, 14, 508178) straight.” It may be that my letter never reached the Maharaja Saheb, and that if it had, he would have disputed the correctness of my corres pondent’s letter.
('76', 268, 9, 15, 508338) If any repudiation is received by me, I shall gladly publish it.
('76', 268, 9, 16, 508403) But I must say that my correspondent is a respon sible person.
('76', 268, 9, 17, 508466) Assuming then that the Maharaja did make the remarks quoted, it is a serious thing for any Prince, no matter how powerful he is, to use the threats the Maharaja is reported to have done.
('76', 268, 9, 18, 508653) With due respect to him, I suggest that there is too much awakening among the people throughout India to be suppressed by threats and even corresponding action.
('76', 268, 9, 19, 508814) The days of unadulterated autocracy are gone for ever.
('76', 268, 9, 20, 508869) It is possible perhaps by intense frightfulness to suppress the rising spirit of the people for some time.
('76', 268, 9, 21, 508976) But I am quite sure that it cannot be suppressed for all time.
('76', 268, 9, 22, 509039) I have no desire to eliminate the Princes.
('76', 268, 9, 23, 509082) Friends have com plained to me that Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru has, however, made such a statement although the Congress has enunciated no such policy.
('76', 268, 9, 24, 509231) I have not had the opportunity of asking him about the alleged remark.
('76', 268, 9, 25, 509302) But assuming that he did make the statement, it can only mean that some Princes are so acting as to bring about their own elimination.
('76', 268, 9, 26, 509437) It is wrong to judge him by newspaper reports.
('76', 268, 9, 27, 509484) His considered opinion is to be gathered from his statement on behalf of the Standing Committee of the All India States People’s Conference.
('76', 268, 9, 28, 509625) Therein he has even warned people against hasty action.
('76', 268, 9, 29, 509681) He is much too loyal a Congressman to contemplate any action in advance of known Con gress policy.
('76', 268, 9, 30, 509780) Therefore the fear and hatred of the Congress on the part of some Princes are misplaced and are calculated to injure rath er than help them.
('76', 268, 9, 31, 509921) The Congress is not seeking to interfere directly in the affairs of any State.
('76', 268, 9, 32, 510000) But the Congress does guide the States people.
('76', 268, 9, 33, 510047) They are part of the Congress organization.
('76', 268, 9, 34, 510091) They derive strength and
('76', 269, 0, 1, 510116) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 269, 1, 2, 510158) inspiration from their connection with the Congress.
('76', 269, 1, 3, 510211) I do not know how this organic relationship can be avoided.
('76', 269, 1, 4, 510271) To wish its termination is like an attempt to make children disown their parents.
('76', 269, 1, 5, 510353) For better or for worse it is well to recognize the fact that just as the vast mass of people of British India look up more to the Congress than to the Government for the removal of their woes, even so do the people of the States look to the Congress for their delive rance.
('76', 269, 1, 6, 510628) It is under the Congress advice and inspiration that the people of the States say that they want to grow to their full height under the aegis of their respective Princes.
('76', 269, 1, 7, 510799) I hope, therefore, that the Maharaja Saheb of Patiala and those Princes who hold the opinion attributed to him will revise their views and welcome the movement of their people for liberty to grow to their full height and not regard the reformers in their States as their enemies.
('76', 269, 1, 8, 511079) It will be well if they will seek Congress aid in the settlement of their people’s demands.
('76', 269, 1, 9, 511171) But they need not do so, if they distrust Congress friendship.
('76', 269, 1, 10, 511234) It is enough if they will placate the advanced section of their people by granting substantial reforms.
('76', 269, 1, 11, 511338) What is worse in my opinion, however, than the alleged threat of the Maharaja is the breach of the promise referred to in my corres pondent’s letter.
('76', 269, 1, 12, 511488) There is no doubt so far as I can see that the promise of withdrawal of the Hidayat of 1988 was made; there is equally no doubt that the promise has been broken.
('76', 269, 1, 13, 511650) It is a dangerous thing even for a rich and powerful Prince to break his plighted word.
('76', 269, 1, 14, 511738) Breach of a promise is no less an act of insolvency than a refusal to pay one’s debt.
('76', 269, 1, 15, 511824) I plead with the Maharaja Saheb to redeem the promise and hope that his counsellors will advise him to do so.

('76', 271, 1, 2, 513537) 352. NOTES
('76', 271, 2, 3, 513548) BOMBAY CORPORATION AND HARIJANS The following important resolutions were carried by the Bom bay Municipal Corporation on 17th and 18th August respectively:
('76', 271, 3, 4, 513704) That the attention of the Commissioner be invited to the absence of bathing and washing facilities for the Municipal Labour Staff, particularly the Health Department sweepers and Drainage Department cleaners, after they finish their work on the streets, and he be requested to report as to whether it would not be desirable to construct a number of special bathrooms and washing places near their centre of work so that they can wash and clean themselves after finishing their day’s duties and return home tidy and refreshed.
('76', 271, 4, 5, 514230) That the attention of the Commissioner be invited to the fact that the dress used by the municipal sweepers and similar other menial staff gets extremely dirty as a result of their condition of work, and that the continuous use of such dress by this class of employees even during off duty hours presents a very shabby appearance and is harmful to their health, and he be requested to report whether it would not be desirable to provide these employees with working suits which they may put on just before starting their work and take out at the end of their duty.
('76', 271, 4, 6, 514795) The resolutions should have been carried long ago.
('76', 271, 4, 7, 514846) Both the points covered by the resolutions are important as well for the employees as the citizens.
('76', 271, 4, 8, 514946) Sanitation of a big city like Bombay is dependent largely upon the efficiency of the those who are employed to attend to it.
('76', 271, 4, 9, 515071) And yet all over India they are the least looked after.
('76', 271, 4, 10, 515127) I needed a Congress majority in the Corporation to pass these necessary resolutions.
('76', 271, 4, 11, 515212) Let us hope that the Commissioner will report favourably without delay.
('76', 271, 4, 12, 515284) There can be no objection to the reforms in principle.
('76', 271, 4, 13, 515339) The objection so as I can see can only be on the score of finance.
('76', 271, 4, 14, 515406) But in matters such as the sanitary welfare of the city, financial objection can have little weight.
('76', 271, 4, 15, 515507) Assuming that the report is favourable and not delayed, there will still be another stage to be gone through before the reforms become accomplished facts, for the necessary sanction of the Corporation will be required.
('76', 271, 4, 16, 515726) I hope the mover and the seconder of the resolutions will, therefore, not rest till they see washing places and working dresses provided for the sweepers, cleaners and the other members of the labour staff.
('76', 271, 4, 17, 515933) SEGAON, August 27, 1939 Harijan, 9 9 1939
('76', 272, 0, 1, 515975) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 273
('76', 272, 1, 2, 516019) 353. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('76', 272, 2, 3, 516049) SEGAON, [August 27, 1939] 2
('76', 272, 3, 4, 516077) A sister from London wired on the 24th instant :
('76', 272, 4, 5, 516126) Please act.
('76', 272, 4, 6, 516138) World awaiting lead.
('76', 272, 4, 7, 516159) Another wire from another sister in London received today says:
('76', 272, 5, 8, 516223) Urge you consider immediate expression of your unshakable faith in reason not force to rulers and all peoples.
('76', 272, 5, 9, 516334) I have been hesitating to say anything on the impending world crisis which affects the welfare not of a few nations but of the whole of mankind.
('76', 272, 5, 10, 516479) I have felt that my word can have no effect on those on whom depends the decision whether there is to be war or peace.
('76', 272, 5, 11, 516598) I know that many in the West believe that my word does carry weight.
('76', 272, 5, 12, 516667) I wish I shared their belief.
('76', 272, 5, 13, 516697) Not having such belief I have been praying in secret that God may spare us the calamity of war.
('76', 272, 5, 14, 516793) But I have no hesitation in redeclaring my faith in reason, which is another word for non violence, rather than the arbitrament of war for the settlement of disputes or redress of wrongs.
('76', 272, 5, 15, 516981) I cannot emphasize my belief more forcibly than by saying that I personally would not purchase my own country’s freedom by violence even if such a thing were a possibility.
('76', 272, 5, 16, 517154) My faith in the wise saying that what is gained by the sword will also be lost by the sword is imperishable.
('76', 272, 5, 17, 517263) How I wish Herr Hitler would respond to the appeal of the President of the United Sates and allow his claim to be investigated by arbitrators in whose choice he will have as effective a voice as the disputants.
('76', 272, 5, 18, 517474) Harijan, 2 9 1939

('76', 276, 1, 2, 522791) 359. KHADI IN TAMIL NADU
('76', 276, 2, 3, 522816) The extracts from the half yearly report of khadi work in Tamil Nadu ending 30th June, published elsewhere in this issue, should be read with interest.
('76', 276, 2, 4, 522968) The report was followed up by a personal letter from Shri Aiyamuthu, the indefatigable secretary of the Tamil Nadu Branch of the A.I.S.A. Relevant extracts from the letter being very instructive are given below:
('76', 276, 3, 5, 523180) Three years have passed since the first attempt was made for determining a
('76', 276, 4, 6, 523255) minimum living wage for the spinners.
('76', 276, 4, 7, 523293) The second step has also been taken
('76', 276, 5, 8, 523329) since the Ist of this month.
('76', 276, 5, 9, 523358) There has been a definite increase in the earnings of
('76', 276, 6, 10, 523412) spinners, though it is not exactly the same as we aim at.
('76', 276, 6, 11, 523470) A lot of spade work has
('76', 276, 7, 12, 523494) been done towards improving the spinning and carding efficiency of the spinner.
('76', 276, 7, 13, 523574) Use of machine ginned lint has been given up and kapas has been made the basis
('76', 276, 8, 14, 523653) of all spinning.
('76', 276, 8, 15, 523670) Improved implements have been distributed.
('76', 276, 8, 16, 523713) The age old village
('76', 276, 9, 17, 523733) charkha has been rejuvenated by the addition of a transformer.
('76', 276, 9, 18, 523796) The time has now
('76', 276, 10, 19, 523813) come to pause and consider all the changes that have resulted from this step.
('76', 276, 11, 20, 523891) You have always visualized khadi only as part of the home economics of the villager.
('76', 276, 11, 21, 523976) Our ancients gave us the small wheel and the spindle as their heritage for all posterity.
('76', 276, 11, 22, 524066) In this their idea was that each home should spin enough for its own immediate requirements.
('76', 276, 11, 23, 524159) They viewed production only from the viewpoint of the natural consumer, that is, the producer and his family or at the most the village.
('76', 276, 11, 24, 524296) May be the village weaver took a few cloths to the shandy 1. But the commercial aspect of utilizing the spinning wheel for catering
('76', 276, 12, 25, 524428) to the needs of distant consumers never occured to them.
('76', 276, 13, 26, 524485) Till 1935, when the first step towards increasing the wages of spinners
('76', 276, 14, 27, 524557) was taken, the Association had been looking more to the interest of the
('76', 276, 15, 28, 524629) consumer than to that of the spinner.
('76', 276, 15, 29, 524667) The Association always aimed at bringing
('76', 276, 16, 30, 524708) down the price of khadi, thereby enabling more and more people to purchase it.
('76', 276, 17, 31, 524787) It acted as a check against individuals entering the field and trying to exploit the
('76', 276, 18, 32, 524872) consumer.
('76', 276, 18, 33, 524882) Very few persons were willing to take to khadi business and the few
('76', 276, 19, 34, 524950) who entered the field fell back as soon as they found that khadi did not pay them
('76', 276, 20, 35, 525032) up to their expectations.
('76', 276, 21, 36, 525058) The spinner till 1935 was able to earn on an average only four annas per lb.
('76', 276, 21, 37, 525135) as spinning wages.
('76', 276, 21, 38, 525154) Spinners who spun yarn above the average quality
('76', 276, 22, 39, 525203) 1 Market

('76', 277, 1, 2, 525254) were paid a little more, the maximum being six annas per lb.
('76', 277, 1, 3, 525315) In those days when a spinner was fined a mere pice she felt the loss so keenly that sometimes she burst into tears.
('76', 277, 1, 4, 525431) In the same way, the addition of a copper or two to her expectations brought forth a ray of smile on her face.
('76', 277, 1, 5, 525542) A copper more or less made all the difference in her outlook.
('76', 277, 1, 6, 525604) It appeared so big.
('76', 277, 2, 7, 525624) In 1936, without her asking for it, the spinning wage has been increased
('76', 277, 3, 8, 525697) far beyond her wildest expectations.

('76', 277, 4, 10, 525774) per lb.

('76', 277, 6, 15, 525936) her to spin better, to spin more twisted and even yarn.
('76', 277, 6, 16, 525992) But this has not been the
('76', 277, 7, 17, 526018) The only reaction to our efforts at improving the standard of living of the
('76', 277, 8, 18, 526094) spinner has been that in a vague way she feels that she is being paid more, vastly
('76', 277, 9, 19, 526177) more, than is due to her labour.
('76', 277, 9, 20, 526210) So much so that when she is penalized for

('76', 277, 11, 24, 526386) The spinner feels it is not a

('76', 277, 14, 28, 526573) increase on her own estimate of her labour and there is always a man who is
('76', 277, 15, 29, 526649) willing to purchase it at that price.
('76', 277, 15, 30, 526687) He does not use the rigid tests of the

('76', 277, 16, 33, 526787) It is the uncertified
('76', 277, 17, 34, 526809) dealer, who pays 50 per cent of the wages paid by us and markets the cloth
('76', 277, 18, 35, 526884) produced of that yarn at 75 to 80 per cent of our standard rates.
('76', 277, 18, 36, 526950) Since 1936 we
('76', 277, 19, 37, 526964) have interested ourselves more in the spinner than in the consumer.
('76', 277, 19, 38, 527032) We have
('76', 277, 20, 39, 527040) aimed at getting the maximum out of the consumer and paying it to the spinner.
('76', 277, 21, 40, 527119) And the uncertified dealer (his number is increasing day by day) is given a free
('76', 277, 22, 41, 527200) hand to exploit both the spinner and the consumer.
('76', 277, 22, 42, 527251) The result is that in spite of
('76', 277, 23, 43, 527282) an increase in wages and that without her asking for it, we are not able to show a
('76', 277, 24, 44, 527365) corresponding improvement in the quality.
('76', 277, 25, 45, 527407) The increase in spinning wages has resulted also in more women

('76', 277, 32, 54, 527937) are forced to reject yarn from many who naturally sell their yarn to the

('76', 278, 0, 1, 528082) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 279
('76', 278, 1, 2, 528126) Since 1936 we have always held the view that the producer should be the prime consumer, and that what is produced in excess of the producers’ needs should alone be marketed.
('76', 278, 1, 3, 528300) With this end in view the spinners have been asked to deposit with us a portion of their output for their own use and the balance alone is being purchased.
('76', 278, 1, 4, 528456) This deposit has increased from 13 per cent of the total production in 1936 to 31 per cent in 1938. This percentage can be raised to any limit but for the trouble with the uncertified dealer.
('76', 278, 1, 5, 528648) Perhaps his activities are at its worst in this case.
('76', 278, 1, 6, 528702) He is not above purchasing the cloth thus distributed by us at a low price and selling the same elsewhere at a profit.
('76', 278, 1, 7, 528821) In this instance he is doing more harm than even the vendor of mill cloth.
('76', 278, 2, 8, 528896) The remedy for all this lies perhaps in localizing khadi.
('76', 278, 2, 9, 528954) Khadi must not
('76', 278, 3, 10, 528969) be made a commercial product, produced in villages to be sold in distant towns.
('76', 278, 4, 11, 529049) As at present the spinner thinks she is spinning not so much for her own
('76', 278, 5, 12, 529122) requirements and that of her family as for selling the yarn for an unknown
('76', 278, 6, 13, 529197) destination.

('76', 278, 9, 19, 529442) the requirements of the consumer.
('76', 278, 9, 20, 529476) We have to study what is required and how
('76', 278, 10, 21, 529518) much to produce and in what quality.
('76', 278, 10, 22, 529555) In the case of an organized industry like the
('76', 278, 11, 23, 529601) mill, it is possible to so regulate the production that only what is wanted is
('76', 278, 12, 24, 529680) produced.
('76', 278, 12, 25, 529690) The entire spinning is done in a limited space and the spindles are
('76', 278, 13, 26, 529758) inanimate things working to a definite motion and spinning what is wanted.
('76', 278, 14, 27, 529833) the case of khadi it is not so.
('76', 278, 14, 28, 529865) The spinner and her spindle are different entities.
('76', 278, 15, 29, 529917) She lives and thinks independently of us.

('76', 278, 19, 36, 530239) the village panchayat can be authorized to hold in deposit the surplus yarn

('76', 281, 2, 4, 536315) 360. NOTES
('76', 281, 3, 5, 536326) WILL THEY LEARN ?
('76', 281, 3, 6, 536344) Hirdaynath Baijal was a medical student in Agra.
('76', 281, 3, 7, 536393) Whenever I pass through big stations after a lapse of time there are as a rule wild demonstrations.
('76', 281, 3, 8, 536493) For causes I have not been able to divine, there were wilder demonstrations during my recent journey to the Frontier Province and wilder still on return from there.
('76', 281, 3, 9, 536658) Such a demonstration took place at Agra on the 27th ultimo.
('76', 281, 3, 10, 536718) My ears cannot cope with the noises however affectionate they may be.
('76', 281, 3, 11, 536788) Plugging with cotton wool does not answer.
('76', 281, 3, 12, 536831) I have to plug them with my fingers as hard as I can in order to deaden the noise.
('76', 281, 3, 13, 536914) The demonstrators are themselves so lost in their frenzy that they do not listen to the piteous appeals I and my companions make to them.
('76', 281, 3, 14, 537052) It is not their fault.
('76', 281, 3, 15, 537075) They do not know what is being said to them.
('76', 281, 3, 16, 537120) And they cannot understand why persons in whose honour demonstrations are made should resent them.
('76', 281, 3, 17, 537219) They make no distinction between night and day.
('76', 281, 3, 18, 537267) This Agra demonstration took place at night.
('76', 281, 3, 19, 537312) Among the demonstration was Hirdaynath.
('76', 281, 3, 20, 537352) He boarded the train in order to reach me and get my autograph.
('76', 281, 3, 21, 537416) Before he could come near my compartment he slipped and fell.
('76', 281, 3, 22, 537478) The train moved and ran over him, and he had to lose his legs.
('76', 281, 3, 23, 537541) A correspondent suggests that the railway authorities could have or should have managed the crowd, that the train should have been stopped in time, and that first aid was not provided as it should have been.
('76', 281, 3, 24, 537749) Be that as it may, the fact of the injury to Hirdaynath remains.
('76', 281, 3, 25, 537814) Kind correspondents kept themselves in touch with me after the accident.
('76', 281, 3, 26, 537887) Hirdaynath’s father too wrote to me.
('76', 281, 3, 27, 537924) I was thus able to write a word of cheer to the young man and give such consolation as I could to his father and his friends.
('76', 281, 3, 28, 538050) Unfortunately in spite of the best treatment he breathed his last on the 22nd instant.
('76', 281, 3, 29, 538137) My heart goes out to the deceased’s father and his friends.
('76', 281, 3, 30, 538197) The reason why I pen these lines is to warn the public against these demonstrations in which no order is kept.
('76', 281, 3, 31, 538308) If demonstrations there must be, and I suppose there will be, they must
('76', 282, 0, 1, 538380) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 283
('76', 282, 1, 2, 538424) be regulated either by the demonstrators themselves or the police.
('76', 282, 1, 3, 538491) This is the second accident within the past few months.
('76', 282, 1, 4, 538547) One took place on my return from Brindaban 1. There also the injured party was a student.
('76', 282, 1, 5, 538637) Fortunately he has lived, though without a leg.
('76', 282, 1, 6, 538685) Hirdaynath seems to have been a student of exceptional qualities and a great favourite with the students.
('76', 282, 1, 7, 538791) I suggest to the students that the very best way in which they can treasure the memory of their dear comrade is by organizing a discipline brigade whose mission would be to introduce order in demonstrations, meetings and other crowds.
('76', 282, 1, 8, 539026) With ever increasing mass awakening we need to know the laws governing the conduct and movement of crowds so as to enable vast masses to gather together without fuss, noise or disturbance.

('76', 284, 3, 22, 541948) 365. LETTER TO PYARELAL [After August 28, 1939] 1
('76', 284, 4, 23, 541998) PYARELAL, What you have written about Sushila is not correct.
('76', 284, 4, 24, 542060) If it is not her duty to remain in Delhi on account of Mother, she has to pass her test here.
('76', 284, 4, 25, 542154) In that alone lies her good.
('76', 284, 4, 26, 542183) Devdas says that there is no need to think about him.
('76', 284, 4, 27, 542237) Ba is pining for her.
('76', 284, 4, 28, 542259) That is sufficient for Sushila.
('76', 284, 4, 29, 542291) She is asking me every now and then when Sushila will be coming.
('76', 284, 4, 30, 542356) My saying that you find pleasure in making a person cry is to be understood in terms of popular expression.
('76', 284, 4, 31, 542464) When we make someone cry through our action, it is said, and rightly, that we find pleasure in making them cry.
('76', 284, 4, 32, 542576) Should it not be said that at Abbottabad I derived pleasure from making Sushila cry?
('76', 284, 4, 33, 542661) 2 No matter how much I myself may have cried at heart.

('76', 286, 1, 2, 544792) 368. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('76', 286, 2, 3, 544824) SEGAON, WARDHA, August 29, 1939
('76', 286, 3, 4, 544856) PREMA, I got your letter only today.
('76', 286, 3, 5, 544893) The rakhadi was tied by Amtul Salaam and now I am writing this letter.
('76', 286, 3, 6, 544964) First your question.
('76', 286, 3, 7, 544985) Why don’t you hand over the sum of Rs. 125 to Deo 1?
('76', 286, 3, 8, 545038) There should be no objection to accepting anything which somebody might give for the book 2. You may hand over to Deo whatever you receive or a part of it.
('76', 286, 3, 9, 545194) I fully agree with Deo’s argument, that his expenses should be met by Maharashtra itself.
('76', 286, 3, 10, 545284) If Maharastra does not bear them, it means the province does not want his services.
('76', 286, 3, 11, 545368) Patwardhan 3 may come and stay with me whenever he wants.
('76', 286, 3, 12, 545426) It is always crowded here, of course.
('76', 286, 3, 13, 545464) Come over for a visit whenever you can.
('76', 286, 3, 14, 545504) There is no question of overcrowding in your case.
('76', 286, 3, 15, 545555) Rest assured that if you come over here you will get well.
('76', 286, 3, 16, 545614) Yes, there is one risk, or course, that meanwhile I may have to go out.
('76', 286, 3, 17, 545686) But what even if I have to?
('76', 286, 3, 18, 545714) You will immediately know if that happens.
('76', 286, 3, 19, 545757) Kelkar 4 and I alone know what efforts I have made to win him over.
('76', 286, 3, 20, 545825) It was I who got him appointed on the Working Committee, the sole reason being that he was regarded as Lokamanya’s heir.
('76', 286, 3, 21, 545946) I thought it my duty to accommodate him as much as I could and do my best to win him over.
('76', 286, 3, 22, 546037) I still think so.
('76', 286, 3, 23, 546055) Despite my differences with Lokamanya, I regard myself as his devotee.
('76', 286, 3, 24, 546126) I had the highest regard for his learning, patriotism and courage.
('76', 286, 3, 25, 546193) There is no truth at all in Swami Satyadev’s statement.
('76', 286, 3, 26, 546249) I could never say such a thing.
('76', 286, 3, 27, 546281) If I did, my truth and ahimsa would stand disgraced.
('76', 286, 3, 28, 546334) I do believe, of course, that he would resort to untruth and violence for the sake of the country.
('76', 286, 3, 29, 546433) He himself told me so.
('76', 286, 3, 30, 546456) We had some correspondence too about the matter.
('76', 286, 3, 31, 546505) He had advocated shatham prati shaathvam 5, against which I had asserted shatham prat yapi satyam 6. Didn’t you know this?
('76', 286, 4, 32, 546628) 1 Shankarrao Deo 2 Kama ane Kamini, a novel written by the addressee
