('76', 292, 4, 33, 555622) 378. NOTES
('76', 292, 5, 34, 555633) RURAL v.
('76', 292, 5, 35, 555642) URBAN An educationist writes :
('76', 292, 6, 36, 555673) If you do not take care, you will find that basic education in urban areas will take a different form from the rural areas.
('76', 292, 6, 37, 555797) For instance English will be introduced to the injury of the mother tongue and a kind of superiority complex developed.
('76', 293, 0, 1, 555917) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 293, 1, 2, 555959) I must confess that my scheme was conceived in terms of the villages, and when I was developing it I did say that some variation will be necessary in applying the scheme to the cities.
('76', 293, 1, 3, 556144) This had reference to the industries to be used as media of instruction.
('76', 293, 1, 4, 556217) I never thought that English could ever find place in the primary stage.
('76', 293, 1, 5, 556290) And the scheme has so far concerned itself only with the primary stage.
('76', 293, 1, 6, 556362) No doubt the primary stage is made equivalent to the matriculation, less English.
('76', 293, 1, 7, 556444) To inflict English on children is to stunt their natural growth and perhaps to kill originality in them.
('76', 293, 1, 8, 556549) Learning of a language is primarily a training in developing memory.
('76', 293, 1, 9, 556618) Learning of English from the beginning is an unnecessary tax on a child.
('76', 293, 1, 10, 556691) He can only learn it at the expense of the mother tongue.
('76', 293, 1, 11, 556749) I hold it to be as necessary for the urban child as for the rural to have the foundation of his development laid on the solid rock of the mother tongue.
('76', 293, 1, 12, 556902) It is only in unfortunate India that such an obvious proposition needs to be proved.
('76', 293, 1, 13, 556987) SEGAON, August 31, 1939 Harijan, 9 9 1939
('76', 293, 2, 14, 557029) 379. LIMBDI
('76', 293, 3, 15, 557041) Though I have had protracted correspondence with the Limbdi people, I have refrained for a long time from saying anything about their woes.
('76', 293, 3, 16, 557181) My silence was due to the hope that those who were trying to bring about peace between the Ruler and the people would succeed.
('76', 293, 3, 17, 557308) But it was a vain hope.
('76', 293, 3, 18, 557332) Much has happened since the beginning stages of that struggle.
('76', 293, 3, 19, 557395) Perhaps nowhere has the policy of ruthlessness been pursued with so much precision and persistence as in Limbdi.
('76', 293, 3, 20, 557508) If the reports received by me are to be believed, and I have no reason to disbelieve them, the peasants have been hunted out of their homes.
('76', 293, 3, 21, 557649) The heaviest blow has been aimed at the hated Bania who was at one time the State’s friend, favourite and main supporter.
('76', 293, 3, 22, 557771) But he was to be crushed because he dared to think and talk of responsible govern ment, dared to go amongst the peasantry and tell them what was due to them and how they could get it.
('76', 293, 3, 23, 557955) The shops and houses of these merchants who have performed hijrat 1 are practically looted.
('76', 293, 3, 24, 558047) I cannot use any other term.
('76', 293, 3, 25, 558076) There has not even been, so far as I know, any legal formality observed.
('76', 293, 3, 26, 558149) The will of the administrator of the policy of ruthlessness is the supreme law.The idea is to terrorize the people into
('76', 293, 4, 27, 558269) 1 That is, those who have migrated
('76', 294, 0, 1, 558304) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 295
('76', 294, 1, 2, 558348) subjection.
('76', 294, 1, 3, 558360) No wonder some have weakened.
('76', 294, 1, 4, 558390) I would advise those who are in charge of the movement not to try to keep them from surren dering.
('76', 294, 1, 5, 558489) Of course they should be told what is in store for them.
('76', 294, 1, 6, 558546) But there are people who prize possessions before honour.
('76', 294, 1, 7, 558604) They can only be a burden on a freedom movement.
('76', 294, 1, 8, 558653) Free dom is always won by a few brave self sacrificing souls who will stake everything for the sake of honour.
('76', 294, 1, 9, 558764) Those who understand the value and the necessity of sacri fice, whether they are few or many, should feel glad that their posse ssions in Limbdi have been taken away.
('76', 294, 1, 10, 558931) They should not live in sus pense nor entertain any hope of immediate settlement.
('76', 294, 1, 11, 559013) They should engage in healthy pursuits outside the State, always in the firm faith that a day must come when the people of Limbdi will come into their own.
('76', 294, 1, 12, 559169) When that day comes, as it must, it will have come because of the sacrifice and the bravery of those who will have refused to bend before repression, however severe.
('76', 294, 1, 13, 559335) Let them remember Thoreau’s immortal words that possession is a vice and poverty a virtue in a tyrannical State.
('76', 294, 1, 14, 559448) So much on reliable evidence before me.
('76', 294, 1, 15, 559488) But should Limbdi be a tyrannical State?
('76', 294, 1, 16, 559529) If there is exaggeration in the statements made to me, let the State authorities send me a contradiction.
('76', 294, 1, 17, 559635) I would gladly publish it.
('76', 294, 1, 18, 559662) Better still will be an impartial judicial inquiry into the allegations made, if they are disputed.
('76', 294, 1, 19, 559762) I wish to make a public appeal to the Thakore Saheb of Limbdi.
('76', 294, 1, 20, 559825) I have the privilege of knowing him.
('76', 294, 1, 21, 559862) I have enjoyed his hospitality.
('76', 294, 1, 22, 559894) He has the reputation of being a pious, Godfearing man.
('76', 294, 1, 23, 559950) It is not right that there should be this estrangement between him and his people, some of whom are well known people with a reputation to lose and a stake in Limbdi.
('76', 294, 1, 24, 560117) It would be wrong to regard them all as a discontented lot.
('76', 294, 1, 25, 560177) They have no axes to grind.
('76', 294, 1, 26, 560205) They have not earthly gain to make by ranging themselves against the State.
('76', 294, 1, 27, 560281) They have incurred much material loss by becoming exiles from their own home.
('76', 294, 1, 28, 560359) A wise ruler will think fifty times before facing the discontent of such people.
('76', 294, 1, 29, 560440) He will conclude from it that there must be misrule and injustice on the part of his officials.
('76', 294, 1, 30, 560536) He will summon the discontented people, listen to their complaints and pacify them.
('76', 294, 1, 31, 560620) The Thakore Saheb has not adopted that course.
('76', 294, 1, 32, 560667) It is not too late for him to do so even now.
('76', 294, 1, 33, 560713) SEGAON, August 31, 1939 Harijan, 9 9 1939

('76', 299, 10, 22, 566851) 389. THAT UNBECOMING DEMONSTRATION
('76', 299, 11, 23, 566886) The first I heard of the black flag demonstration against Subhas Babu on his visit to Patna was through a courteous letter received from the Secretary of the Bengali Association of Bankipore.
('76', 299, 11, 24, 567078) 1 I then saw a
('76', 299, 12, 25, 567093) 1 Vide “Letter to A. Gupta”, 29 8 1939.
('76', 300, 0, 1, 567133) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 301
('76', 300, 1, 2, 567177) notice of it in the Press.
('76', 300, 1, 3, 567204) To make myself sure of what had happened I wired to Shri P. R. Das for an authentic and up to date account.
('76', 300, 1, 4, 567312) He replied from Dhanbad saying he was away from the scene and knew nothing.
('76', 300, 1, 5, 567388) The newspapers reported that there was stone throwing and hurling of shoes resulting in injuries to Swami Sahajanand and others.
('76', 300, 1, 6, 567517) Allowing for exaggeration, if any, there seems to be little doubt that there was a hostile demonstration of an unseemly nature which brought no credit to the Congress.
('76', 300, 1, 7, 567685) I have read Rajendra Babu’s eloquent statement on the unhappy incident.
('76', 300, 1, 8, 567757) It is so true and so heart stirring that it admits of no addition or embellishment.
('76', 300, 1, 9, 567841) I endorse every word of that noble pronouncement.
('76', 300, 1, 10, 567891) It is reproduced below this article.
('76', 300, 2, 11, 567928) The demonstrators showed an unworthy intolerance.
('76', 300, 2, 12, 567978) Subhas Babu has a perfect right to agitate against the action 2 of the Working
('76', 300, 3, 13, 568057) Committee and canvass public opinion against it.
('76', 300, 3, 14, 568106) The disciplinary action frees him from any liability for restraint save what every Con gressman, pledged to the credal article of the Constitution, is bound to put on himself.
('76', 300, 3, 15, 568282) That action should save him from any further demonstration of public displeasure.
('76', 300, 3, 16, 568364) And those who disapprove of the action of the Working Committee are certainly entitled to join any demonstration in favour of Subhas Babu.
('76', 300, 3, 17, 568503) Unless this simple rule is observed we shall never evolve democracy.
('76', 300, 3, 18, 568572) In my opinion the black flag demonstrators have rendered a disservice to the cause of freedom.
('76', 300, 3, 19, 568667) It is to be hoped that the Patna demonstration will prove to be the last of such acts by Congressmen.
('76', 300, 3, 20, 568769) The question may be asked, ‘How are those who endorse the action of the Working Committee and dis approve of Subhas Babu’s propaganda to show their disapproval?’ Certainly not through black flags and disturbing of meetings in honour of Subhas Babu.
('76', 300, 3, 21, 569018) They can express their dis approval by holding counter meetings, not at the same time as the others but either before or after them.
('76', 300, 3, 22, 569151) These meetings, both for and against, should be regarded as a means of educating public opinion.
('76', 300, 3, 23, 569248) Such education re quires calm surroundings.
('76', 300, 3, 24, 569292) Black flags, noisy slo gans, and hurling of stones and shoes have no place in educative and instructive propa ganda.
('76', 300, 4, 25, 569409) 1 The statement is not reproduced here 2 Vide “Congress Working Committee Resolution”, 11 8 1939.
('76', 301, 0, 1, 569507) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 301, 1, 2, 569549) Apropos of the ugly demonstration I must refer to a complaint I have received that some Congress Committees have threatened action against those Congressmen who may take part in receptions to Subhas Babu.
('76', 301, 1, 3, 569754) I hope that the complaint has no foundation in fact.
('76', 301, 1, 4, 569807) Such action will betray intolerance and may even be a sign of vindictive ness.
('76', 301, 1, 5, 569886) Congressmen who dislike the Working Committee’s action are bound to take part in receptions to Subhas Babu.
('76', 301, 1, 6, 569994) It is im possible to gag them by threats of disciplinary measures.
('76', 301, 1, 7, 570061) Such action loses its value if it is resorted to on the slightest pretext.
('76', 301, 1, 8, 570136) If it is true, as it is true, that no organization can do without such powers, it is equally true that no organization that makes free use of such powers has any right to exist.
('76', 301, 1, 9, 570314) It cannot.
('76', 301, 1, 10, 570325) It has then obviously lost the public backing.

('76', 302, 5, 9, 571146) 392. NOTES
('76', 302, 6, 10, 571157) TEXT BOOKS The craze for ever changing text books is hardly a healthy sign from the educational standpoint.
('76', 302, 6, 11, 571265) If text books are treated as a vehicle for education, the living word of the teacher has very little value.
('76', 302, 6, 12, 571373) A teacher who teaches from text books does not impart originality to his pupils.
('76', 302, 6, 13, 571454) He himself becomes a slave of text books and has no oppor tunity or occasion to be original.
('76', 302, 6, 14, 571547) It, therefore, seems that, the less text books there are the better it is for the teacher and his pupils.
('76', 302, 6, 15, 571653) Text books seem to have become an article of commerce.
('76', 302, 6, 16, 571708) Authors and publishers who make writing and publishing a means of making money are interested in frequent change of text books.
('76', 302, 6, 17, 571836) In many cases teachers and examiners are themselves authors of text books.
('76', 302, 6, 18, 571911) It is naturally to their interest to have their books sold.
('76', 302, 6, 19, 571971) The selection board is again naturally composed of such people.
('76', 302, 6, 20, 572035) And so the vicious circle becomes complete.
('76', 302, 6, 21, 572079) And it becomes very difficult for parents to find money for new books every year.
('76', 302, 6, 22, 572161) It is a pathetic sight to see boys and girls going to school loaded with books which they are ill able to carry.
('76', 302, 6, 23, 572274) The whole system requires to be thoroughly examined.
('76', 302, 6, 24, 572327) The commercial spirit needs to be entirely eliminated and the question approached solely in the interest of the scholars.
('76', 302, 6, 25, 572449) It will then probably be found that 75 percent of the text books will have to be consigned to the scrap heap.
('76', 302, 6, 26, 572559) If I had my way, I would have books largely as aids to teachers rather than for the scholars.
('76', 302, 6, 27, 572653) Such text books as are found to be absolutely necessary for the scholars should circulate among them for a number of years so that the cost can be easily
('76', 302, 7, 28, 572807) 2 Germany invaded Poland on September 1 and war was consequently declared by England and France on September 3.
('76', 303, 0, 1, 572919) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 303, 1, 2, 572961) borne by middle class families.
('76', 303, 1, 3, 572993) The first step in this direction is perhaps for the State to own and organize the printing and publishing of text books.
('76', 303, 1, 4, 573114) This will act as an automatic check on their unnecessary multiplication.
('76', 303, 1, 5, 573187) DIVIDED LOYALTY?
('76', 303, 1, 6, 573204) Shri Appa Patwardhan writes :
('76', 303, 2, 7, 573234) The Bombay Government spend a large sum in helping weavers.
('76', 303, 2, 8, 573294) They have
('76', 303, 3, 9, 573304) appointed a marketing officer and salesmen.
('76', 303, 3, 10, 573348) They give loans.
('76', 303, 3, 11, 573365) Yet the weavers
('76', 303, 4, 12, 573381) cannot compete with mills and in my opinion the expenses incurred do not
('76', 303, 5, 13, 573454) bear fruit.
('76', 303, 5, 14, 573466) Moreover the weavers use foreign yarn as well.
('76', 303, 5, 15, 573513) Side by side with
('76', 303, 6, 16, 573531) this fruitless help the Government render some help to khadi also.
('76', 303, 6, 17, 573598) I do not
('76', 303, 7, 18, 573607) know how far this divided loyalty is justified.
('76', 303, 7, 19, 573655) I have always held the opinion that help to the weavers who use foreign or Indian mill yarn is a waste of money and effort.
('76', 303, 7, 20, 573779) Expe rience has not changed the view.
('76', 303, 7, 21, 573817) Nor does it change because in certain provinces the Congress rules.
('76', 303, 7, 22, 573885) I hold this view because the disappea rance of the weaver of mill yarn is a question of time only.
('76', 303, 7, 23, 573984) In the nature of things it cannot be otherwise.
('76', 303, 7, 24, 574032) The weavers’ only hope lies in a universal revival of hand spinning.
('76', 303, 7, 25, 574101) Hand spinning and hand weav ing are interde pendent, never hand weaving and mill spinning.
('76', 303, 7, 26, 574192) I have, therefore, suggested that if hand spinning cannot immediately supply the weavers’ requirements, they should be induced to intro duce hand spinning, carding, etc., in their own families if they will not become spinners themselves.
('76', 303, 7, 27, 574430) Now that in several provinces the Con gress rules, the saving of the weaver becomes casier.
('76', 303, 7, 28, 574522) Thus the Govern ment can encourage spinning on a wide scale, guarantee the loss in khadi sales as the State guarantees the foreign railway companies.
('76', 303, 7, 29, 574672) It is the primary duty of the State to guarantee employment of his choice to everyone in need of it.
('76', 303, 7, 30, 574773) This includes the weavers also.
('76', 303, 7, 31, 574805) If during the transition stage it is found impossible to guarantee weaving for every weaver, the State has to find him some other employment, profitable alike to the State and the individual.
('76', 303, 7, 32, 574997) It should be borne in mind that the possibilities of hand spinning have not yet been explored by any Government.
('76', 303, 7, 33, 575110) I am of opinion that such investigation will yield star tlingly encouraging results.
('76', 303, 7, 34, 575195) My argument undoubtedly assumes the elimination of all mills from conside ration.
('76', 303, 7, 35, 575277) No industry, indigenous or foreign, can be allowed to increase un employment and thus harm the true interest of the community as a whole.
('76', 304, 0, 1, 575415) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 305
('76', 304, 1, 2, 575459) WAYS OF FAMINE RELIEF Though the most terrible distress that was feared has been averted by the falling of rains, however belated, some distress is bound to continue for a few months, and it will be unwise for relief agencies to go to sleep.
('76', 304, 1, 3, 575701) What is more, time is now more propitious for devising measures for making permanent provisions for preventing distress caused by scarcity of water.
('76', 304, 1, 4, 575850) I have already made some cardinal suggestions in this direction.
('76', 304, 1, 5, 575915) The Secretary of the Saurashtra Seva Samiti sends me a business like report of the elaborate steps taken by that body for enlisting helpers and providing relief.
('76', 304, 1, 6, 576077) I need not detain the reader over them.
('76', 304, 1, 7, 576117) He also suggests preventive methods.
('76', 304, 1, 8, 576154) As these are still seasonable I give below the substance, the original being in Gujarati: 1. The States should refrain from auctioning their stock of grass but they should store it as a precaution against dry year.
('76', 304, 1, 9, 576369) The store should be replaced when fresh store becomes avai lable.
('76', 304, 1, 10, 576435) There is nowadays danger of the stacks being destroyed by incendiaries.
('76', 304, 1, 11, 576507) The States should have no difficulty in protec ting them.
('76', 304, 1, 12, 576565) They may even allow private collectors to deposit their stores in such areas.
('76', 304, 1, 13, 576643) 2. The existing banks should be renovated and flood water should be banked.
('76', 304, 1, 14, 576719) 3. In the places where cattle are moved during famine times, measures should be taken to ensure proper water supply for the cattle.
('76', 304, 1, 15, 576851) 4. There should be control over the cultivation of money crops to the detriment of food crops.
('76', 304, 1, 16, 576946) Thus people nowadays sow ground nuts in the place of most valuable fodder and food crops, i.e., jawari and bajri.
('76', 304, 1, 17, 577060) 5. Existing forests should be preserved, indiscriminate cutting of trees should be made punishable, and people should be encouraged to plant trees according to plan.
('76', 304, 1, 18, 577226) 6. The management of pinjrapoles should be put on a sound basis and they should become efficient famine insurance agencies for cattle.
('76', 304, 1, 19, 577361) They should become castration depots.
('76', 304, 1, 20, 577399) 7. The State should encourage khadi as a famine insurance measure.
('76', 304, 1, 21, 577466) All these suggestions seem to be sound and deserve the collective consideration of the States and the people of Kathiawar.

('76', 305, 2, 3, 577735) SACRIFICIAL SPINNING IN ANDHRA Shri Shankerlal Banker sends me a letter he has received from the Andhra Branch of the A.I.S.A. I take the following from it :
('76', 305, 3, 4, 577893) On seeing Mahatmaji’s note in Harijan dated July 22, 1939, 1 we concieved the idea of performing sacrificial spinning (sutra yajna) on the lines followed by Sjt.
('76', 305, 3, 5, 578055) Narandas Gandhi of Rajkot Rashtriyashala.
('76', 305, 3, 6, 578097) Accor dingly we sent an appeal on July 29, 1939, to the local Krishna Patrika 2 and the Andhra Patrika 3 for publication, calling for applications from khadi lovers who would participate in the sutra yajna performed under the auspices of the Andhra Branch in connection with the ensuing Gandhi Jayanti.
('76', 305, 3, 7, 578400) All participants are requested to offer 14,000 (70 × 200) yards of self spun yarn or 70 coppers (Rs. 1 1 6) in terms of his present age.
('76', 305, 3, 8, 578537) We find a ready response to our call.
('76', 305, 3, 9, 578575) Till now we have received 500 applications.
('76', 305, 3, 10, 578619) Many applicants offer 14,000 yards of yarn or Rs. 1 1 6 in cash.
('76', 305, 3, 11, 578684) But some poor spinners offer only 7,000 yards of yarn and we accept their offer in consideration of their poverty, though they fall short of the minimum fixed in our appeal.
('76', 305, 3, 12, 578858) Now we are going to issue a special appeal to the spinners in the Andhra Desh to contribute 7,000 yards (nearly one warp) as a birthday gift to Mahatmaji on his 71st birthday.
('76', 305, 3, 13, 579034) In our appeal all A.I.S.A. workers were requested to give yarn contributions only.
('76', 305, 3, 14, 579117) In our central stores and central office sacrificial spinning has been going on for the last 15 days since August 2, 1939. Some have been spinning on the takli and some others on the improved charkha.
('76', 305, 3, 15, 579318) The workers are asked to improve and note the quality and quantity of their yarn.
('76', 305, 3, 16, 579400) We have requested the Andhra Povincial Congress Committee to help us in enlisting volunteers for sutra yajna and see that all members of Congress committees participate in it.
('76', 305, 3, 17, 579576) In compliance with our request they issued a circular to all Congress members to enrol themselves as volunters for sutra yajna and help the khadi movement to the best of their ability.
('76', 305, 3, 18, 579761) We hope to enlist at least 1,000 volunteers before Gandhi Jayanti.
('76', 305, 3, 19, 579828) I have letters from other quarters also showing that Shri Narandas Gandhi’s example has caught on.
('76', 305, 3, 20, 579927) I hope that the organizers are carrying out strictest economy in organizing sacrificial spinning.
('76', 305, 3, 21, 580025) They may not, for instance, move the yarn spun from place to place resulting in the cost of postage being incurred.
('76', 305, 3, 22, 580141) Yarn should be collected by appointed agents so that there can be hand to hand

('76', 310, 1, 2, 587279) 400. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('76', 310, 2, 3, 587309) SIMLA, September 5, 1939 At Delhi, as I was entraining for Kalka, a big crowd sang in perfect good humour, to the worn out refrain of “Mahatma Gandhiki jai” .
('76', 310, 2, 4, 587468) “We do not want any understanding”.
('76', 310, 2, 5, 587504) I had then my weekly silence.
('76', 310, 2, 6, 587534) Therefore I merely smiled.
('76', 310, 2, 7, 587561) And those who were standing on the footboard returned the smile with their smile, whilst they were admonishing me not to have any understanding with the Viceroy.
('76', 310, 2, 8, 587723) I had also a letter from a Congress Committee giving me similar warn ing.
('76', 310, 2, 9, 587797) Neither of these counsellors knew me.
('76', 310, 2, 10, 587835) I did not need the warning to know my limitations.
('76', 310, 2, 11, 587886) Apart from the Delhi demonstration and a Congress Committee’s warning, it is my duty to tell the public what happened at the interview 2 with H. E. the Viceroy.
('76', 310, 2, 12, 588047) I knew that I had no authority to speak for any person except myself.
('76', 310, 2, 13, 588117) 3 I knew that I had no instructions whatsoever from the Work ing Committee in the matter.
('76', 310, 2, 14, 588207) I had answered a telegraphic invitation and taken the first train I could catch.
('76', 310, 2, 15, 588288) And what is more, with my irrepressible and out and out non violence, I knew that I could not represent the national mind and I should cut a sorry figure if I tried to do so.
('76', 310, 2, 16, 588463) I told His Excellency as much.
('76', 310, 2, 17, 588494) Therefore there could be no question of any understanding or negotiation with me.
('76', 310, 2, 18, 588576) Nor, I saw, had he sent for me to negotiate.
('76', 310, 2, 19, 588621) I have returned from the Viceregal Lodge empty handed and without any understanding, open or secret.
('76', 310, 2, 20, 588722) If there is to be any understanding, 4 it would be between the Congress and the Government.
('76', 310, 2, 21, 588814) Having, therefore, made my position vis a vis the Congress quite clear, I told His Excellency that my own sympathies were with Eng land and France from the purely humanitarian standpoint.
('76', 310, 2, 22, 589002) I told him that I could not contemplate without being stirred to the very depth the destruction of London which had hitherto been regarded as impregnable.
('76', 310, 2, 23, 589157) And as I was picturing before him the Houses of Parlia ment and the Westminster Abbey and their possible destruction, I
('76', 310, 3, 24, 589277) 1 This appeared under the title “The Simla Visit”.
('76', 310, 3, 25, 589328) An A.P.I. report of the statement was also published in The Hindu, 5 9 1939, and The Hindustan Times, 6 9 1939, as released by Gandhiji in the “afternoon prior to his departure” from Simla.
('76', 310, 3, 26, 589518) 2 On September 4, 1939 3 This sentence is from The Hindustan Times.
('76', 310, 4, 27, 589586) 4 With reference to the war, which broke out on September 3
('76', 311, 0, 1, 589646) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 311, 1, 2, 589688) broke down.
('76', 311, 1, 3, 589700) I have become disconsolate.
('76', 311, 1, 4, 589728) In the secret of my heart I am in perpetual quarrel with God that He should allow such things to go on.
('76', 311, 1, 5, 589832) My non violence seems almost impotent.
('76', 311, 1, 6, 589871) But the answer comes at the end of the daily quarrel that neither God nor non violence is impotent.
('76', 311, 1, 7, 589971) Impotence is in men.
('76', 311, 1, 8, 589992) I must try on without losing faith even though I may break in the attempt.
('76', 311, 1, 9, 590067) And so, as though in anticipation of the agony that was awaiting me, I sent on the 23rd July from Abbottabad the following letter 1 to Herr Hitler.
('76', 311, 1, 10, 590215) How I wish that even now he would listen to reason and the appeal from almost the whole of thinking mankind, not excluding the German people themselves.
('76', 311, 1, 11, 590368) I must refuse to believe that Germans contemplate with equanimity the evacuation of big cities like London for fear of destruction to be wrought by man’s inhuman ingenuity.
('76', 311, 1, 12, 590541) They cannot contemplate with equanimity such destruction of them selves and their own monuments.
('76', 311, 1, 13, 590638) I am not therefore just now thinking of India’s deliverance.
('76', 311, 1, 14, 590699) It will come, but what will it be worth if Eng land and France fall, or if they come out victorious over Germany ruined and humbled ?
('76', 311, 1, 15, 590833) Yet it almost seems as if Herr Hitler knows no God but brute force and, as Mr. Chamberlain says, he will listen to nothing else.
('76', 311, 1, 16, 590962) It is in the midst of this catastrophe without parallel that Congressmen and all other responsible Indians individually and collectively have to decide what part India is to play in this terrible drama.
('76', 311, 2, 17, 591165) Harijan, 9 9 1939

('76', 313, 2, 3, 592525) SEGAON, September 8, 1939
('76', 313, 3, 4, 592551) OF COURSE MY WHOLE HEART IS WITH THE POLES IN THE UNEQUAL STRUGGLE IN WHICH THEY ARE ENGAGED FOR THE SAKE OF SAVING THEIR FREEDOM.
('76', 313, 3, 5, 592682) BUT I AM PAINFULLY CONSCIOUS OF THE FACT THAT MY WORD CARRIES NO POWER WITH IT.
('76', 313, 3, 6, 592762) I WISH I HAD THE POWER TO STOP THIS MAD DESTRUCTION THAT IS GOING ON IN EUROPE.
('76', 313, 3, 7, 592842) I BELONG TO A COUNTRY THAT HAS LOST ITS INDEPENDENCE AND IS STRUGGLING TO BE FREE FROM THE YOKE OF THE GREATEST IMPERIALIST POWER ON EARTH.
('76', 313, 3, 8, 592982) IT HAS ADOPTED THE UNIQUE METHOD OF NON VIOLENCE TO REGAIN ITS LOST FREEDOM.
('76', 313, 3, 9, 593059) THOUGH THE METHOD HAS PROVED ITS EFFICACY TO AN EXTENT, THE GOAL SEEMS FAR OFF.
('76', 313, 3, 10, 593139) ALL THAT I CAN THEREFORE SEND TO THE BRAVE POLES IS MY HEARTFELT PRAYER FOR THE EARLY TERMINATION OF THEIR FEARFUL TRIAL AND FOR THE GRANT OF THE REQUIRED STRENGTH TO BEAR THE SUFFERING WHOSE VERY CONTEMPLATION MAKES ONE SHUDDER.
('76', 313, 3, 11, 593369) THEIR CAUSE IS JUST AND THEIR VICTORY CERTAIN.
('76', 313, 3, 12, 593416) FOR GOD IS ALWAYS THE UPHOLDER OF JUSTICE..

('76', 316, 3, 11, 598097) 409. NOTES
('76', 316, 4, 12, 598108) SURPLUS KHADI 1
('76', 316, 5, 13, 598124) Under the impulse of the phenomenal rise in the spinners’ wages, voluntarily made by the A. I. S. A., there has been a great output of yarn.
('76', 316, 5, 14, 598265) It has been difficult everywhere to cope with the khadi thus produced.
('76', 316, 5, 15, 598336) In Tamil Nadu alone khadi production shot up to nearly 15 lakhs from about five and a half lakhs and the sales increased to only 11 lakhs from nearly nine lakhs.
('76', 316, 5, 16, 598498) I have already dealt with the difficulty in the U. P. 2 These are only typical instances.
('76', 316, 5, 17, 598588) The difficulty is almost universal.
('76', 316, 5, 18, 598624) I have suggested that khadi experts should study this aspect of it in a scientific manner and discover the remedy.
('76', 316, 5, 19, 598739) This research work, like all other research work, will take time.
('76', 316, 5, 20, 598805) Meanwhile the surplus stock must be cleared.
('76', 316, 5, 21, 598850) It is up to the patriotic public to come to the assistance.
('76', 316, 5, 22, 598910) I have no love for the celebration of my birthday.
('76', 316, 5, 23, 598961) Any other day is as good or as bad as a birthday.
('76', 316, 5, 24, 599011) My parents, so far as I recollect, never celebrated the birthdays of their children.
('76', 316, 5, 25, 599096) I remember the date of my birthday only because I had to take the birth certificate for the London exami nation.
('76', 316, 5, 26, 599209) But I never thought of the date until after the rebirth of khadi.
('76', 316, 5, 27, 599275) Khadi lovers made the date of my birth an occasion for pushing khadi sales.
('76', 316, 5, 28, 599351) I did not mind such exploitation of my birthday but tried with more or less success to give it the name of Rentia Jayanti so far as the Gujarati speaking public was concerned.
('76', 316, 5, 29, 599527) For it was they who first set the vogue for celebrating the date.
('76', 316, 5, 30, 599593) Ever since, the Khadi Week has been celebrated in many parts of India for popularizing khadi and
('76', 316, 6, 31, 599690) 1 In The Hindustan Times, 29 9 1939, this appeared as Gandhiji’s “appeal”, reported by the Assistant Secretary, A. I. S. A., “on the occasion of Gandhiji’s 71st birthday”.
('76', 316, 6, 32, 599862) 2 Vide “Wanted Purchasers”, 21 8 1939.
('76', 317, 0, 1, 599901) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 317, 1, 2, 599943) village products.
('76', 317, 1, 3, 599961) Khadi lovers are setting much store by the forthcoming 2nd October according to the Christian calendar and the 10th October according to the Vikram Samvat.
('76', 317, 1, 4, 600117) U. P., Tamil Nadu and other provinces have issued khadi hundis for which they expect a heavy demand in expectation of the coming celebration.
('76', 317, 1, 5, 600259) Special fuss is being made because I shall have completed seventy years on those dates, assuming of course that I shall survive till then.
('76', 317, 1, 6, 600398) But whether I do or not the dates will come unfailingly.
('76', 317, 1, 7, 600455) And if it is of any value to the public to know it, let them know that my spirit, whether embodied or disembodied, will certainly rejoice to think that there are sufficient men and women in India who will combine always to take up, for the sake of Daridranarayana, all the khadi that can be produced by the semi starved villagers.
('76', 317, 1, 8, 600786) Let no one plead the war as an excuse for not buying khadi.
('76', 317, 1, 9, 600846) War or no war, so long as there is life in us, we shall need to feed and clothe ourselves.
('76', 317, 1, 10, 600937) What can be better than that we cover ourselves with cloth produced through the labours of the needy sisters and brothers of the villages?
('76', 317, 1, 11, 601076) PLEA FOR SELF DENIAL Shri Banker writes to say that the prices of foreign dyes have considerably gone up owing to the war.
('76', 317, 1, 12, 601199) In order to make khadi attractive, the A. I. S. A. have allowed the use of foreign dyes for colouring khadi cloth.
('76', 317, 1, 13, 601314) Now if the use of foreign dyes is continued, there will have to be an increase in the price of khadi.
('76', 317, 1, 14, 601416) The best way of avoiding the increase is for khadi depots to drop the use of foreign dyes and restrict themselves to the use of indigenous dyes and be satisfied with such colours as can be produced therefrom.
('76', 317, 1, 15, 601625) But this can be done only if the public will, by simplifying their taste, encourage the A. I. S. A. in the experiment.
('76', 317, 1, 16, 601744) If they will, it is just possible that necessity will be the mother once more of many inventions in the matter of producing beautiful colours from indigenous dyes.
('76', 317, 2, 17, 601908) NOT AUTHORITATIVE The Secretary of the A. I. S. A. draws my attention to my article “Spinners’ Wages” 1 in Harijan of August 26th regarding the pur chase of underpriced yarn of quality below standard.
('76', 317, 2, 18, 602109) He says in effect: Many people take your word as authoritative, more so in matters of khadi since you are President of the A. I. S. A. Will
('76', 317, 3, 19, 602249) 1 Vide “Spinners Wages”, 20 8 1939.
('76', 318, 0, 1, 602285) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 319
('76', 318, 1, 2, 602329) you not therefore state clearly that your opinion, expressed in Harijan, does not in any way affect or alter the resolutions of the A. I. S. A., and that those who have occasion to take up your advice have to do so subject to the previous permisson of the Secretary in accordance with the recent resolution of the A. I. S. A. on the subject of prices of yarn?
('76', 318, 1, 3, 602689) I need hardly say that I endorse every word of what is said by the Secretary.
('76', 318, 1, 4, 602767) Whatever I write in Harijan has as much authority as any editorial writing has and no more.
('76', 318, 1, 5, 602859) It must be treated as an indivi dual opinion, always subject to the resolutions passed by competent authority on the subject in question.
('76', 318, 2, 6, 602997) INTOXICATING WINES IN JUDAISM When I saw that a claim was registered, and accepted by Dr. Gilder, 1 for the use of spirituous liquors on behalf of Jews, I was much disturbed.
('76', 318, 2, 7, 603172) For my experience of Jews among whom I had many friends in Johannesburg was wholly against the claim made in Bom bay.
('76', 318, 2, 8, 603290) I therefore wrote to my friend Herr H. Kallenbach to send me an authoritative opinion from the Chief Rabbi in Johannesburg.
('76', 318, 2, 9, 603414) Here is Dr. Landau’s opinion :
('76', 318, 3, 10, 603445) I beg to state that the orthodox Jew may use only specially prepared (kasher) wine for the sanctification of the Sabbath or holidays in the Syna gogue after Divine Service and at home before meals, and on the two eves of the Passover Festival.
('76', 318, 4, 11, 603689) The wine need not be fermented.
('76', 318, 5, 12, 603721) I may state that the use of wine is not a law but a tradition which the orthodox Jew cherishes, as it is referred to both in the Talmud and in Jewish Codes of Law.
('76', 318, 5, 13, 603885) If the Jews of Bombay accept this opinion as authoritative, they should withdraw their claim and be satisfied with the juice of fresh grapes which I understand is the original meaning of the word wine.
('76', 318, 5, 14, 604087) It is worthy of note, too, that even this use has the authority, not of the Jewish scriptures but of tradition only.
('76', 318, 5, 15, 604204) SEGAON, September 10, 1939 Harijan, 16 9 1939
('76', 318, 6, 16, 604250) 1 Vide “Telegram to Dr. D. D. Gilder”, 24 7 1939.

('76', 319, 7, 12, 604783) 411. SOURCE OF MY SYMPATHY
('76', 319, 8, 13, 604810) The statement 1 made by me just after my interview with H. E. the Viceroy has had a mixed reception.
('76', 319, 8, 14, 604911) It has been described as sentimental twaddle by one critic and as a statesman like pronounce ment by another.
('76', 319, 8, 15, 605021) There are variations between the two extremes.
('76', 319, 8, 16, 605068) I suppose all the critics are right from their own standpoint and all are wrong from the absolute standpoint which in this instance is that of the author.
('76', 319, 8, 17, 605223) He wrote for no body’s satisfaction but his own.
('76', 319, 8, 18, 605272) I abide by every word I have said in it.
('76', 319, 8, 19, 605313) It has no political value, except what every humanitarian opinion may possess.
('76', 319, 8, 20, 605392) Interrelation of ideas cannot be prevented.
('76', 319, 8, 21, 605436) I have a spirited protest from a correspondent.
('76', 319, 8, 22, 605484) It calls for a reply.
('76', 319, 8, 23, 605506) I do not reproduce the letter as parts of it I do not understand myself.
('76', 319, 8, 24, 605579) But there is no difficulty in catching its drift.
('76', 319, 8, 25, 605629) The main argument is this : If you shed tears over the possible destruction of the English Houses of Parliament and Westminster Abbey, have you no tears for the possible destruction of the monuments of Germany?
('76', 319, 8, 26, 605840) And why do you sympathize with England and France and not with Germany?
('76', 319, 8, 27, 605912) Is not Hitler an answer to the ravishing of Germany by the Allied Powers during the last war?
('76', 319, 8, 28, 606006) If you were
('76', 319, 9, 29, 606018) 1 Vide “statement to the Press”, 5 9 1939.
('76', 320, 0, 1, 606061) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 321
('76', 320, 1, 2, 606105) a German, had the resourcefulness of Hitler and were a believer in the doctrine of retaliation as the whole world is, you would have done what Hitler is doing.
('76', 320, 1, 3, 606265) Nazism may be bad.
('76', 320, 1, 4, 606284) We do not know what it really is.
('76', 320, 1, 5, 606318) The literature we get is one sided.
('76', 320, 1, 6, 606354) But I suggest to you that there is no difference between Chamberlain and Hitler.
('76', 320, 1, 7, 606435) In Hitler’s place Chamberlain would not have acted otherwise.
('76', 320, 1, 8, 606497) You have done an injustice to Hitler by comparing him with Chamberlain, to the former’s disadvantage.
('76', 320, 1, 9, 606599) Is England’s record in India any better than Hitler’s in another part of the world in similar circumstances?
('76', 320, 1, 10, 606708) Hitler is but an infant pupil of the old imperialist England and France.
('76', 320, 1, 11, 606781) I fancy that your emotion at the Viceregal Lodge had the better of your judgment.
('76', 320, 1, 12, 606863) No one perhaps has described English misdeeds more forcibly, subject to truth, than I have.
('76', 320, 1, 13, 606955) No one has resisted England more effec tively, perhaps, than I have.
('76', 320, 1, 14, 607024) And my desire for and power of resistance remain unabated.
('76', 320, 1, 15, 607083) But there are seasons for speech and action, as there are seasons for silence and inaction.
('76', 320, 1, 16, 607175) In the dictionary of satyagraha there is no enemy.
('76', 320, 1, 17, 607226) But as I have no desire to prepare a new dictionary for satyagrahis, I use the old words giving them a new meaning.
('76', 320, 1, 18, 607342) A satyagrahi loves his so called enemy even as his friend.
('76', 320, 1, 19, 607401) He owns no enemy.
('76', 320, 1, 20, 607419) As a satyagrahi, i.e., votary of ahimsa, I must wish well to England.
('76', 320, 1, 21, 607489) My wishes regarding Germany were, and they still are, irrelevant for the moment.
('76', 320, 1, 22, 607570) But I have said in a few words in my statement that I would not care to erect the freedom of my country on the remains of despoiled Germany, I should be as much moved by a contemplation of the possible destruc tion of Germany’s monuments.
('76', 320, 1, 23, 607809) Herr Hitler stands in no need of my sympathy.
('76', 320, 1, 24, 607855) In assessing the present merits, the past misdeeds of England and the good deeds of Germany are irrelevant.
('76', 320, 1, 25, 607963) Rightly or wrongly, and irrespective of what the other Powers have done before under similar circumstances, I have come to the conclusion that Herr Hitler is responsible for the war.
('76', 320, 1, 26, 608146) I do not judge his claim.
('76', 320, 1, 27, 608172) It is highly probable that his right to incorporate Danzig in Germany is beyond question, if the Danzig Germans desire to give up their independent status.
('76', 320, 1, 28, 608328) It may be that his claim to appropriate the Polish Corridor is a just claim.
('76', 320, 1, 29, 608405) My complaint is that he will not let the claim be examined by an independent tribunal.
('76', 320, 1, 30, 608492) It is no answer to the rejection of the appeal for submission to arbitration that it came from interested quar ters.
('76', 320, 1, 31, 608609) Even a thief may conceivably make a correct appeal to his
('76', 321, 0, 1, 608667) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 321, 1, 2, 608709) fellow thief.
('76', 321, 1, 3, 608723) I think I am right in saying that the whole world was anxious that Herr Hitler should allow his demand to be examined by an impartial tribunal.
('76', 321, 1, 4, 608867) If he succeeds in his design, his success will be no proof of the justness of his claim.
('76', 321, 1, 5, 608956) It will be proof that the Law of the Jungle is still a great force in human affairs.
('76', 321, 1, 6, 609041) It will be one more proof that though we humans have changed the form we have not changed the manners of the beast.
('76', 321, 1, 7, 609157) I hope it is now clear to my critics that my sympathy for Eng land and France is not a result of momentary emotion or, in cruder language, of hysteria.
('76', 321, 1, 8, 609309) It is derived from the never drying foun tain of non violence which my breast has nursed for fifty years.
('76', 321, 1, 9, 609415) I claim no infallibility for my judgment.
('76', 321, 1, 10, 609457) All I claim is that my sympathy for England and France is reasoned.
('76', 321, 1, 11, 609525) I invite those who accept the premises on which my sympathy is based to join me.
('76', 321, 1, 12, 609606) What shape it should take is another matter.
('76', 321, 1, 13, 609651) Alone I can but pray.
('76', 321, 1, 14, 609673) And so I told His Excellency that my sympathy had no concrete value in the face of the concrete destruction that is facing those who are directly engaged in the war.

('76', 325, 4, 12, 616333) 419. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS1
('76', 325, 5, 13, 616362) SEGAON, September 15, 1939 The Working Committee’s statement on the world crisis took four days 2 before it received final shape.
('76', 325, 5, 14, 616492) Every member expressed his opinion freely on the draft that was, at the Committee’s invitation, prepared by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru.
('76', 325, 5, 15, 616625) I was sorry to find myself alone in thinking that whatever support was to be given to the British should be given unconditionally.
('76', 325, 5, 16, 616756) This could only be done on a purely non violent basis.
('76', 325, 5, 17, 616811) But the Committee had a tremendous responsibility to discharge.
('76', 325, 5, 18, 616875) It could not take the purely non violent attitude.
('76', 325, 5, 19, 616926) It felt that the nation had not imbibed the non violent spirit requisite for the possession of the strength which disdains to take advantage of the
('76', 325, 6, 20, 617074) 1 This appeared under the title “Gandhiji’s Comment on the Manifesto”.
('76', 325, 6, 21, 617145) The Hindu, 16 9 1939, reported: “When the Hindu representative and other Pressmen approached Gandhiji for his views on the Working Committee’s statement, Gandhiji agreed to make a statement and invited them to Segaon for the purpose.
('76', 325, 6, 22, 617379) Sitting down soon after evening prayers, Gandhiji began drafting his statement.
('76', 325, 6, 23, 617459) .After an hour the statement was ready and as Mr. Mahadev Desai began reading it out, a little party gathered round the hurricane lantern.
('76', 325, 6, 24, 617598) Gandhiji also joined and, as Mr. Desai proceeded, touched up and corrected the language of the statement here and there.
('76', 325, 6, 25, 617719) .When Mr. Desai had finished reading, one of the Pressmen asked, ‘Is that all ?’ ‘Is that not enough?
('76', 325, 6, 26, 617821) replied Gandhiji with a smile and retired.” For the text of the Manifesto, vide Appendix “Working Committee’s Manifesto”, 23 9 1939.
('76', 325, 7, 27, 617954) 2 From September 10 to 14
('76', 326, 0, 1, 617980) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 327
('76', 326, 1, 2, 618024) difficulty of the opponent.
('76', 326, 1, 3, 618052) But in stating the reasons for its conclusion the Committee desired to show the greatest consideration for the English.
('76', 326, 1, 4, 618172) The author of the statement is an artist.
('76', 326, 1, 5, 618214) Though he cannot be surpassed in his implacable opposition to imperialism in any shape or form, he is a friend of the English people.
('76', 326, 1, 6, 618348) Indeed he is more English than Indian in his thoughts and make up.
('76', 326, 1, 7, 618415) He is often more at home with Englishmen than with his own countrymen.
('76', 326, 1, 8, 618486) And he is a humanitarian in the sense that he reacts to every wrong, no matter where perpetrated.
('76', 326, 1, 9, 618584) 1 Though, therefore, he is an ardent nationalist his nationalism is enriched by his fine internationalism.
('76', 326, 1, 10, 618691) Hence the statement is a manifesto addressed not only to his own countrymen, not only to the British Government and the British people, but it is addressed also to the nations of the world including those that are exploited like India.
('76', 326, 1, 11, 618927) He has compelled India, through the Working Committee, to think not merely of her own freedom, but of the freedom of all the exploited nations of the world.
('76', 326, 1, 12, 619084) The same time that the Committee passed the statement, it appointed a Board 2 of his choice with himself as Chairman to deal with the situation as it may develop from time to time.
('76', 326, 1, 13, 619265) I hope that the statement will receive the unanimous support of all the parties among Congressmen.
('76', 326, 1, 14, 619364) The strongest among them will not find any lack of strength in it.
('76', 326, 1, 15, 619431) And at this supreme hour in the history of the nation the Congress should believe that there will be no lack of strength in action, if action becomes necessary.
('76', 326, 1, 16, 619592) It will be a pity if Congressmen engage in petty squabbles and party strife.
('76', 326, 1, 17, 619669) If any thing big or worthy is to come out of the Committee’s action, the undivided and unquestioned loyalty of every Congressman is absolutely necessary.
('76', 326, 1, 18, 619823) I hope too that all other political parties and all communities will join the Committee’s demand for a clear declaration of their policy from the British Government with such corresponding action as is possible amidst martial conditions.
('76', 326, 1, 19, 620061) Recognition of India, and for that matter of all those who are under the British Crown, as free and independent nations seems to me to be the natural corollary of British professions about democracy.
('76', 326, 1, 20, 620261) If the war means anything less, the co operation of dependent nations can never be honestly voluntary, unless it were based on non violence.
('76', 326, 2, 21, 620402) 1 The source, however, has “perpetuated” .
('76', 326, 2, 22, 620445) 2 With Abul Kalam Azad and Vallabhbhai Patel as members
('76', 327, 0, 1, 620501) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 327, 1, 2, 620543) All that is required is a mental revolution on the part of British statesmen.
('76', 327, 1, 3, 620621) To put it still more plainly, all that is required is honest action to implement the declaration of faith in democracy made on the eve of the war, and still being repeated from British platforms.
('76', 327, 1, 4, 620817) Will Great Britain have an unwilling India dragged into the war or a willing ally co operating with her in the prosecution of a defence of true democracy?

('76', 328, 3, 12, 622911) 422. JAIPUR SATYAGRAHA
('76', 328, 4, 13, 622934) Jaipur satyagraha has ended satisfactorily as announced in Sheth Jamnalalji’s public statement.
('76', 328, 4, 14, 623030) He had had several interviews with the Maharaja Saheb.
('76', 328, 4, 15, 623085) The result has been that the regulation regarding public meetings and processions has been withdrawn.
('76', 328, 4, 16, 623187) So has the ban on newspapers.
('76', 328, 4, 17, 623217) Amelioration in several other matters has been assured.
('76', 328, 4, 18, 623273) 1 For this happy result both the Maharaja and Sheth Jamnalalji deserve to be congratulated—the Maharaja for his just mindedness and Shethji for his wisdom and moderation in conducting the nego tiations on behalf of the Jaipur Praja Mandal.
('76', 328, 4, 19, 623513) It is a happy ending to a struggle which was conducted with great restraint and calmness.
('76', 328, 4, 20, 623603) It is a triumph of non violence.
('76', 328, 4, 21, 623636) From the very beginning the demands were restricted to the barest minimum necessary for self expression and political education.
('76', 328, 4, 22, 623765) The goal of responsible govern ment has been always kept in view, but it has never been offensively or aggressively advanced as if the insistence was on an immediate grant of full responsibility.
('76', 328, 4, 23, 623961) The Praja Mandal has wisely recognized its own limi tations and the backward state of the people.
('76', 328, 4, 24, 624059) Practically no political education has been hitherto allowed in many of the Rajputana States.
('76', 328, 4, 25, 624153) It will be solid gain if civil liberty in its real sense is assured to the people of Jaipur.
('76', 328, 4, 26, 624246) For this, as much will depend upon the wisdom with which it is used by the people as upon the restraint of the Jaipur authorities.
('76', 328, 5, 27, 624377) 1 According to The Indian Annual Register, 1939, Vol. II, pp.
('76', 328, 5, 28, 624439) 229 30, the main terms of the settlement were: (1) the release of political prisoners, (2) the lifting of the ban on all newspapers, and (3) satisfactory amendment of the Public Societies Act so as to render unnecessary for a society to get itself registered.
('76', 329, 0, 1, 624699) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 329, 1, 2, 624741) In this connection Sheth Jamnalalji has raised a most important question.
('76', 329, 1, 3, 624815) He insists that no European should be appointed Dewan.
('76', 329, 1, 4, 624870) I have had to perform the painful duty of criticizing the administration of the State by one of its English Dewans 1. I have no doubt that an English Dewan is any day a misfit in an Indian State.
('76', 329, 1, 5, 625066) He has to serve an Indian Chief.
('76', 329, 1, 6, 625099) But retired English officials from whom Dewans are chosen are not by habit used to take orders from Indian Chiefs.
('76', 329, 1, 7, 625214) They cannot understand the caprices of Indian Princes and will not accommodate themselves to them.
('76', 329, 1, 8, 625313) The Chiefs themselves never feel at home with English Dewans.
('76', 329, 1, 9, 625375) Moreover no matter how conscientious they are, Englishmen can never understand the people of the States or have patience with them.
('76', 329, 1, 10, 625507) And the people can never take the same liberty with them that they can and will with men who are drawn from among themselves.
('76', 329, 1, 11, 625633) Thus an English Dewan is a double handicap in an Indian State and robs it of what little scope there is left in it for indigenous development.
('76', 329, 1, 12, 625776) Add to this the fact that the appointment of English Dewans in States is a cruel encroachment upon the very narrow field left for the expression of Indian administrative talent.
('76', 329, 1, 13, 625954) Supposing Dewanships had been a preserve of retired English offi cials, we would have missed Sir T. Madhao Rao or Sir Salar Jung, to mention only two among the well known Dewans of Indian States.
('76', 329, 1, 14, 626150) It is to be hoped, therefore, that if H. H. the Maharaja has really a free choice, he will select an Indian known for his integrity, ability and sympathy for popular aspirations.
('76', 329, 1, 15, 626329) It is to be hoped further that if the choice has to be made by the British Government, they will not impose a European Dewan on the Maharaja.
('76', 329, 1, 16, 626471) SEGAON, September 17, 1939 Harijan, 23 9 1939

('76', 330, 5, 7, 627115) 424. NOTES
('76', 330, 6, 8, 627126) SIROHI Sirohi is a Rajputana State with a population of 1,86,639 and revenue of Rs. 9,70,000. It has figured in the Press for its lathi charge said to be wholly unprovoked.
('76', 330, 6, 9, 627299) I have authentic information of the event from Shri Gokulbhai Bhatt who belongs to Sirohi.
('76', 330, 6, 10, 627390) He has gained a reputation as an efficient teacher and a devoted Congress worker.
('76', 330, 6, 11, 627472) He is saturated with the spirit of non violence.
('76', 330, 6, 12, 627521) He has been recently staying in Sirohi attempting to gain elementary rights for the people.
('76', 330, 6, 13, 627613) He thus writes about the lathi charge to Shri Kishorelal Mashruwala : The events of the 8th instant in Sirohi make it a memorable day for its people.
('76', 330, 6, 14, 627763) The police swooped down upon a meeting all of a sudden, began to pull down the Praja Mandal flag and delivered a lathi charge.
('76', 330, 6, 15, 627890) This was not the national flag.
('76', 330, 6, 16, 627922) When the Hon.
('76', 330, 6, 17, 627936) Resident, Mr. Lothian, was in Sirohi last February he suggested that we could use the Praja Mandal flag in our office, in our processions and at our meetings.
('76', 330, 6, 18, 628095) And we were acting accordingly.
('76', 330, 6, 19, 628127) On the 3rd instant the Dewan Saheb prohibited its use in our processions.
('76', 330, 6, 20, 628201) In order to avoid a breach of the order, we discontinued the procession.
('76', 330, 6, 21, 628274) There was no prohibition against its use at meetings, so we had it at our meeting.
('76', 330, 6, 22, 628357) Suddenly appeared the police in great style and, without warning, without any order, began to pull down the flag.
('76', 330, 6, 23, 628471) Some of the workers held on to it.
('76', 330, 6, 24, 628506) They could not, however, keep their hold for long against the superior police force.
('76', 330, 6, 25, 628591) They were separated.
('76', 330, 7, 26, 628612) co inmate of Chhaganlal Joshi in Thana Jail, has been described as “a satyagrahi of Bombay known as ‘Naye Gandhi”.
('76', 331, 0, 1, 628727) 332 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 331, 1, 2, 628769) somehow retained my hold.
('76', 331, 1, 3, 628795) So they dragged me with the flag.
('76', 331, 1, 4, 628829) They caught me by the neck and beat me.
('76', 331, 1, 5, 628869) Then began an indiscriminate lathi charge on the audience.
('76', 331, 1, 6, 628928) Some notabilities are said to have been inciting the police not to spare the people who said, “You may beat us as much as you like.
('76', 331, 1, 7, 629060) We will not leave the meeting.” Women were also bravely taking part in this struggle.
('76', 331, 1, 8, 629146) The charge must have lasted about seven minutes.
('76', 331, 1, 9, 629195) The meeting continued to the end.
('76', 331, 1, 10, 629229) The event has not demoralized the people.
('76', 331, 1, 11, 629271) It has put heart into them.
('76', 331, 1, 12, 629299) Knowing Shri Gokulbhai as I do, I have no reason to disbelieve his account which is in Gujarati.
('76', 331, 1, 13, 629396) It reflects no credit upon the Sirohi authorities.
('76', 331, 1, 14, 629447) I have before me a long list of the grievances of the people.
('76', 331, 1, 15, 629509) They are trying, in a perfectly constitutional manner, to seek redress.
('76', 331, 1, 16, 629581) But instead of granting redress the authorities are evidently trying to crush their spirit.
('76', 331, 1, 17, 629673) If, however, the people have imbibed the right spirit of non violent resistance, they are bound to gain their end, lathi charges notwithstanding.
('76', 331, 2, 18, 629819) A POLISH SISTER’S 1 AGONY
('76', 331, 3, 19, 629845) In spite of all I am going to try to reach Poland, sailing tonight to Basra in Iraq, then through Turkey and Rumania.
('76', 331, 3, 20, 629963) The inner call is irresistible.
('76', 331, 3, 21, 629995) It may seem madness from the ordinary human point of view.
('76', 331, 3, 22, 630054) Now I am not going for my mother’s sake nor for my dearest friends who are now on the battle fields— ready to die at any moment—it is for Poland itself.
('76', 331, 3, 23, 630207) I believe countries have also souls.
('76', 331, 3, 24, 630244) Souls of nations are a reality, not a theory, for me.
('76', 331, 3, 25, 630298) If I reach the soil of Poland I will feel satisfied, even if I do not find those whom I love.
('76', 331, 3, 26, 630392) It is the soul (and body) of the nation itself that is in its supreme hour of martyrdom.
('76', 331, 3, 27, 630481) I believe Poland bleeds and struggles not only for her own rights but for the right, the just, the true; for the freedom of all nations, India including.
('76', 331, 3, 28, 630635) I feel Hindu to the bottom of my heart; Indian as much as Pole, both Motherlands are to be in my soul to the last day of my life.
('76', 331, 3, 29, 630765) But I could not live if I would not do what is humanly possible to reach the feet of the Mother who is now bleeding in agony of pain.
('76', 331, 3, 30, 630899) I shall write from the way, but not when I reach the war zone; I shall only think often about you and send mental messages as well as I can.
('76', 331, 3, 31, 631040) Bapuji, do pray in all fervour of your great loving heart for those thousands of innocent people who suffer incredible pain and misery in Poland.
('76', 331, 3, 32, 631186) It is these that need most sympathy and blessings and tender thoughts.
('76', 331, 4, 33, 631257) 1 Wanda Dynowska, also known as Uma
('76', 332, 0, 1, 631293) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 333
('76', 332, 1, 2, 631337) This is the letter a Polish sister wrote from Bombay harbour.
('76', 332, 1, 3, 631399) I have known her for some years.
('76', 332, 1, 4, 631432) She has become as much Indian as she is Polish.
('76', 332, 1, 5, 631480) She had decided to work at Maganwadi in the Magan Museum.
('76', 332, 1, 6, 631538) 1 But the rumours of war upset her.
('76', 332, 1, 7, 631574) She has an aged mother in Poland whom she could not bring out owing to passport difficulties.
('76', 332, 1, 8, 631668) When the war actually broke out, she calmed down so far as her mother was concerned.
('76', 332, 1, 9, 631753) But her highly strung nature would not let her rest whilst her nearest and dearest were in peril of their lives for no offence of theirs.
('76', 332, 1, 10, 631891) She is herself a believer through and through in non violence.
('76', 332, 1, 11, 631954) But her very non violence made her restless.
('76', 332, 1, 12, 631999) Her whole soul has rebelled against the wrong, as she thinks, that is being perpetrated against her motherland.
('76', 332, 1, 13, 632111) So she has gone to find the Poland of her imagination fighting to the last ditch, not for merely preserving her own freedom but for the freedom of all those nations who have lost it.
('76', 332, 1, 14, 632294) And in this she naturally includes her second love, India.
('76', 332, 1, 15, 632353) May her dream prove true.
('76', 332, 1, 16, 632379) If Poland has that measure of uttermost bravery and an equal measure of selflessness, history will forget that she defended herself with violence.
('76', 332, 1, 17, 632526) Her violence will be counted almost as non violence.
('76', 332, 1, 18, 632579) SEGAON, September 18, 1939 Harijan, 23 9 1939
('76', 332, 2, 19, 632625) 425. TEMPLE ENTRY
('76', 332, 3, 20, 632643) I had a complaint from a sanatanist in Madura regarding the manner in which the celebrated Meenakshi temple was opened.
('76', 332, 3, 21, 632763) I had forwarded the complaint to Shri Vaidyanatha Aiyar and sent it to another friend too.
('76', 332, 3, 22, 632854) I got a categorical refutation from the latter.
('76', 332, 3, 23, 632902) 2 He added in his letter that Shri Vaidyanatha Aiyar was so persecuted by the sanatanists that his nerves were shattered.
('76', 332, 3, 24, 633024) Thereupon I sent him a long wire urging him not to take to heart what his persecutors may say or do, and that as a religious reformer he had to work with perfect detachment keeping himself unruffled in the midst of persecution and worse.
('76', 332, 3, 25, 633262) To my wire he sent the following consoling reply :
('76', 332, 4, 26, 633313) 1 The Magan Museum of khadi and other village crafts was opened by Gandhiji on December 30, 1938, in memory of Maganlal Gandhi.
('76', 332, 4, 27, 633441) Besides khadi, there were gur making, paper making, soap making, oil pressing and tanning sections in the museum.
('76', 332, 5, 28, 633555) 2 Vide “Letter to V. M. Prasada Rao”, 30 8 1939.
('76', 333, 0, 1, 633604) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 333, 1, 2, 633646) With Shri Meenakshi’s grace and your blessings acquired usual calmness.
('76', 333, 2, 3, 633718) Continuing work.
('76', 333, 2, 4, 633735) Expecting other big temples will follow shortly.
('76', 333, 2, 5, 633784) Your love
('76', 333, 3, 6, 633794) and blessings my strongest support.
('76', 333, 3, 7, 633830) The reply is characteristic of this great reformer.
('76', 333, 3, 8, 633882) He is one of the humblest and the most silent among the workers in the cause of removal of untouchability.
('76', 333, 3, 9, 633989) He is a godfearing man.
('76', 333, 3, 10, 634013) This is what Shri Brijkrishna Chandiwala of Delhi, who had gone on a pilgrimage to the South, writes of his experience in Madura : I stopped seven days in Pondicherry, five in Ramanashram and went as far as Rameshwar.
('76', 333, 3, 11, 634231) I had a great desire to visit the temples of the South.
('76', 333, 3, 12, 634287) But I would not enter those that were closed to Harijans.
('76', 333, 3, 13, 634345) I did, however, see the temples in Madura and Tanjore.
('76', 333, 3, 14, 634400) The others I contemplated from without.
('76', 333, 3, 15, 634440) I tarried awhile in front of many of them—and for the first time I realized what the bar sinister must mean to the tens of thousands of Harijans who, though eager for darshan 1 could never cross the precincts of the great temples.
('76', 333, 4, 16, 634671) who have the right to visit them never think of entering.
('76', 333, 4, 17, 634729) But this time I was overwhelmed.
('76', 333, 4, 18, 634762) I felt a longing to visit them and prayed from the depth of my heart that God might move the sanatanists to open the other temples to Harijans so that I too could visit them.
('76', 333, 4, 19, 634937) I saw, too, at Shri Vaidyanatha Aiyar’s house, what temple entry costs reformers like him.
('76', 333, 4, 20, 635028) Had I not seen with my own eyes what has been happening to Shri Vaidyanatha Aiyar, I could never have believed that human nature could descend so low as I discovered in Madura.
('76', 333, 4, 21, 635205) The conduct of the sanatanists towards him has been most unseemly.
('76', 333, 4, 22, 635272) One of the ways adopted by them is to spread lies about Shri Vaidyanatha Aiyar.
('76', 333, 4, 23, 635352) But both he and his wife are bearing this persecution bravely.
('76', 333, 4, 24, 635415) Only four days ago I had a letter from some ladies of Kumbak onam complaining of the treatment meted out to them by reformers.
('76', 333, 4, 25, 635542) They asked for an appointment.
('76', 333, 4, 26, 635573) In the midst of my work I sent them an early appointment, warning them of my views on untouchability.
('76', 333, 4, 27, 635675) They repented of their wire and said that since I had taken no notice of their complaint, they did not propose to come.
('76', 333, 4, 28, 635795) I have since read the report in The Hindu of the happenings in Shrirangam.
('76', 333, 4, 29, 635870) Dr. Rajan has given a graphic account of the disgraceful behaviour of the so called sanatanists there.
('76', 333, 4, 30, 635973) I have no reason to doubt Dr. Rajan’s account.
('76', 333, 4, 31, 636020) It is a shame that innocent women are being exploited for supporting a wrong.
('76', 333, 4, 32, 636098) I have a vivid recollection of what used to happen to me during my Harijan tour.
('76', 333, 4, 33, 636179) No lie was too bad to be spread about me or
('76', 333, 5, 34, 636223) 1 Sight of a person or thing considered to be holy
('76', 334, 0, 1, 636274) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 335
('76', 334, 1, 2, 636318) my tour.
('76', 334, 1, 3, 636327) So far as I could see, the opposition was confined to a handful only.
('76', 334, 1, 4, 636397) I never opened a temple until I was satisfied that there was no opposition worth the name from the temple goers.
('76', 334, 1, 5, 636510) But the organizers of the opposition resented the very propaganda I was conducting.
('76', 334, 1, 6, 636594) No doubt their opposition proved fruitless.
('76', 334, 1, 7, 636638) My point, however, is that it was unscrupulous and violent.
('76', 334, 1, 8, 636698) If I survived the year’s tour, it was no fault of theirs; it was God’s grace.
('76', 334, 1, 9, 636776) Sixty four charges were recorded against me.
('76', 334, 1, 10, 636821) Not one of them was true.
('76', 334, 1, 11, 636847) I am therefore loath to believe the complaints now made about the cam paign in the South.
('76', 334, 1, 12, 636937) I have not found any of them substantiated.
('76', 334, 1, 13, 636981) Un touchability is itself a lie.
('76', 334, 1, 14, 637014) Lies are not known to have been supported by truth, even as truth cannot be supported by lies.
('76', 334, 1, 15, 637109) If it is, it becomes itself a lie.
('76', 334, 1, 16, 637144) There is no wonder, therefore, that from everywhere evi dence continues to pour in that the sanatanist opposi tion is confined to a few and that the few do not hesitate to resort to any method, however unscrupulous it may be.
('76', 334, 1, 17, 637370) Nevertheless the case against untouchability is not to be sus tained by the weaknesses of opponents.
('76', 334, 1, 18, 637471) It has to be supported by purity of character, industry and strictest honesty of reformers and a limitless capacity for sacrifice.
('76', 334, 1, 19, 637602) For I should not wonder if the wrath of the opponents takes a heavy toll of the lives of reformers.
('76', 334, 1, 20, 637702) No sacrifice, however great, will deter the reformers from pursuing the God given mission of ridding Hinduism of the curse of untouchability.
('76', 334, 1, 21, 637844) For I must repeat for the thousandth time that Hinduism dies, as it will deserve to die, if untouchability lives.
('76', 334, 1, 22, 637958) Only let the reformers know that impatience will be fatal to success.
('76', 334, 1, 23, 638028) They must not open a single temple where a clear majority of temple goers to a particular temple are demonstrably opposed to its opening.
('76', 334, 1, 24, 638166) Untouchability will not be removed by the force even of law.
('76', 334, 1, 25, 638227) It can only be removed when the majority of Hindus realize that it is a crime against God and man and are ashamed of it.
('76', 334, 1, 26, 638348) In other words, it is a process of conversion, i.
('76', 334, 1, 27, 638398) e., purification of the Hindu heart.
('76', 334, 1, 28, 638435) The aid of law has to be invoked when it hinders or interferes with the progress of the reform as when, in spite of the willingness of the trustees and the temple going public, the law prohibits the opening of a particular temple.

('76', 341, 1, 2, 644243) 437. DRAFT RESOLUTION FOR PROVINCIAL LEGISLATURES 1
('76', 341, 2, 3, 644295) [September 20, 1939] 2
('76', 341, 3, 4, 644318) This Assembly regrets that the British Government have
('76', 341, 4, 5, 644373) 1 K. M. Munshi explains: “With the declaration of war, Central encroac hment on Provincial autonomy was inevitable.
('76', 341, 4, 6, 644489) Sardar Patel, therefore, issued a circular letter to all the Congress Prime Ministers advising them on the attitude they should adopt, pending a decision by the A. I. C. C. or the Working Committee.
('76', 341, 4, 7, 644688) The Working Committee met on September 9 and continued their deliberations till September 15. .
('76', 341, 4, 8, 644784) Gandhiji, at first, was for supporting the British unconditionally, but ultimately he yielded to Jawaharlal Nehru.
('76', 341, 4, 9, 644899) The Congress Ministries in the Provinces simply could not continue in office for a long period during which they were bound to accept the direction of a Central Government with which they felt no sense of identity.
('76', 341, 4, 10, 645114) During the time.
('76', 341, 4, 11, 645131) my relations with Sir Roger Lumley, the Governor, had become friendly.
('76', 341, 4, 12, 645202) I tried to prevail upon Sir Roger Lumley to convey to Lord Linlithgow that there should not be any difficulty in meeting the Congress demands, viz., (1) clarification of war aims, (2) assurance as to India’s future, and (3) the immediate steps to ensure Congress participation at the Centre.
('76', 341, 4, 13, 645494) The outlook became gloomy when, on September 18, Kher, like other Congress premiers, received a letter from Sardar Patel intimating that the Working Committee’s statement [Appendix X] should be taken as the background for the time being; that the Ministries should do nothing inconsistent with it and, in particular, should not allow their responsibility as Provincial Governments to be overridden.
('76', 341, 4, 14, 645893) The more important part of the letter was a directive: Provincial legislatures, or, in default of legislatures, Provincial Governments, should as early as possible pass a resolution, a draft of which was appended.
('76', 341, 4, 15, 646107) Sir Roger realized the grave implications of the resolution and told me that a resolution of this character would create the impression that the Congress had given up the intention to co operate in the war.
('76', 341, 4, 16, 646314) He, therefore, strongly urged that I should point out to Sardar the implication of the course advocated in the letter.
('76', 341, 4, 17, 646433) I gave Sir Roger’s message to Sardar Patel.
('76', 341, 4, 18, 646477) He, however, told me that the letter had been drawn up by the Congress War Sub committee and that he could not cancel it without the consent of the other members of the Sub committee, namely, Nehru and Maulana Azad.
('76', 341, 4, 19, 646693) He, therefore, advised me to go at once to Wardha and see Gandhiji and Rajendra Prasad who was still there.
('76', 341, 4, 20, 646801) I left for Wardha the same evening and returned on September 21. Gandhiji gave me a patient hearing, spinning the charkha all the time.
('76', 341, 4, 21, 646937) I remember to have argued the case at length.
('76', 341, 4, 22, 646983) When I finished, he told me: ‘Munshi, you have presented your case well, but the country will not accept the course of action recommended by you’.
('76', 341, 4, 23, 647130) He was, however, prepared to modify the peremptory attitude reflected in the resolution.
('76', 341, 4, 24, 647219) He gave me a statement defining his views on the situation.
('76', 341, 4, 25, 647279) Gandhiji also gave me a draft of the resolution which be passed by the Provincial legislatures if a satisfactory solution on the lines indicated was not acceptable to the British Government.
('76', 341, 4, 26, 647470) .As a result of my inteview with Gandhiji on September 20 .
('76', 341, 4, 27, 647530) instructions were issued to the Congress Ministries postponing action on the proposed resolution for a week.” 2 Ibid
('76', 342, 0, 1, 647647) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 343
('76', 342, 1, 2, 647691) declared India as a participant in the war between Great Britain and Germany, without the consent of the Indian people and without consulting this Assembly.
('76', 342, 1, 3, 647848) The Assembly considers this declaration, made in complete disregard of the opposition from Indian opinion, a contravention of the spirit of Provincial autonomy, as also further measures adopted and laws passed in England and India limiting the powers and activities of Provincial Governments.
('76', 342, 1, 4, 648141) The British Government have stated that the war is for the pre servation of democracy, but their policy in India militates against this profession.
('76', 342, 1, 5, 648289) While this Assembly has the fullest sympathy for the cause of democracy and freedom, and condemns the aggression of the Nazi Government on Poland, it cannot offer co operation in the war, unless the principles of democracy are applied to India and her policy is guided by her people.
('76', 342, 1, 6, 648573) The Assembly invites the British Government to make a clear declaration that they have decided to regard India as an independent nation entitled to frame her own Charter of Freedom, and to accompany this declaration by suitable action, in so far as this is possible, even in the prevailing war condi tions.
('76', 342, 1, 7, 648880) The Assembly is further of opinion that no war measure or other activity should be undertaken in this Province except with the consent and through the medium of the Provincial Government.
('76', 342, 2, 8, 649068) Pilgrimage to Freedom (1902 1950), p.
('76', 342, 3, 9, 649106) 438. A STATEMENT 1
('76', 342, 4, 10, 649125) [September 20, 1939] 2
('76', 342, 5, 11, 649148) 1. I (Gandhi) know that my views in regard to unconditional co operation are not shared by the country.
('76', 342, 5, 12, 649252) The resolution of the Working Committee reflects the Congress opinion properly.
('76', 342, 5, 13, 649332) 2. Since the Congress is unable, owing to past experience, to give unconditional co operation, it can only co operate if it is able to convince the country that it has in substance achieved its purpose and that therefore there is a complete understanding about it between the British Government and the Congress.
('76', 342, 5, 14, 649645) 3. If there is a real understanding between the British Govern ment and the Congress, it follows that there must be corresponding action even during the war.
('76', 342, 5, 15, 649803) Thus Ministries must not be mere regis 
('76', 342, 6, 16, 649843) 1 Foot note no.
('76', 342, 6, 17, 649859) 1 of draft resolution for provincial legislatures, 20 9 1939. 2 Ibid
('76', 343, 0, 1, 649928) 344 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 343, 1, 2, 649970) tering agencies of the measures coming from the Centre.
('76', 343, 1, 3, 650026) Hence there must be some method at the Centre of having a Congress represen tation sufficient to give it a majority.
('76', 343, 1, 4, 650143) 4. The only constitutional way in which the Ministries can declare their position is to obtain the necessary authority of their res pective legislatures by getting them to adopt this resolution 1, unless in the mean time they can convince their legislatures that circumstances in terms of 2 and 3 have come into existence which render such resolution unnecessary.
('76', 343, 1, 5, 650507) 5. If the British Government are serious in their profession that they are fighting for democracy, they cannot marshal the moral opinion of the world in their favour except by declaring that India will be a free and democratic country at the end of the war and that in the mean time it has taken steps to implement the assurances so far as it is practicable under martial conditions.
('76', 343, 1, 6, 650891) 6. If for some reason, the British Government takes a different view, the Ministries will find it impossible to function.
('76', 343, 1, 7, 651013) 7. The resolution may be kept back for a week if the members of the War Sub committee agree.

('76', 345, 5, 20, 653981) In this manner the two ever keep changing places.
('76', 345, 5, 21, 654031) Why then should we rejoice at one and grieve over the other?
('76', 345, 5, 22, 654092) The coming of night is the death of day, but we know that day comes after night and so we are not surprised by the way it goes on.

('76', 345, 5, 24, 654283) But separation is only one member of a pair.

('76', 345, 5, 26, 654388) This is only an intellectual statement.
('76', 345, 5, 27, 654428) But it is worth understanding.
('76', 345, 5, 28, 654459) It will strengthen your faith.

('76', 347, 2, 3, 655742) SEGAON, WARDHA, September 23/24, 1939 How I wish I had the same enthusiasm that fires you.
('76', 347, 2, 4, 655833) Of course I have the experience of listening 2 not merely of trying to listen.
('76', 347, 2, 5, 655912) The more I listen, the more I discover that I am still far away from God.
('76', 347, 2, 6, 655986) While I can lay down rules, the observance of which is essential for proper listening, the reality still escapes me.
('76', 347, 2, 7, 656103) When we say we are listening to God and getting answers, though we say it truthfully, there is every possibility there of self deception.
('76', 347, 2, 8, 656241) I do not know that I am myself altogether free from self deception.
('76', 347, 2, 9, 656309) People sometimes ask me if I may not be mistaken, and I say to them, ‘Yes, very likely, what I say may be just a picture of my elongated self before you.” And then see how one may claim to be God guided in taking a particular course of action, and another may make the same claim in taking an opposite course of action.
('76', 347, 2, 10, 656629) I will give you a good illustration.
('76', 347, 2, 11, 656666) Rajaji, whom you know, at any rate whose name you have heard, is I think unsurpassed in godliness or God mindedness.

('76', 347, 2, 13, 656978) He felt sure that I was deluding myself and that I should probably die and, if I did not, I should certainly be demented.
