('76', 394, 1, 2, 748693) 500. THE UNBRIDGEABLE GULF
('76', 394, 2, 3, 748720) The following letter comes from a friend :
('76', 394, 3, 4, 748763) In the Harijan dated 30 9 1939, on page 1 at the end of your article 1,
('76', 394, 4, 5, 748835) you write: “Speed is not the end of life.
('76', 394, 4, 6, 748877) Man sees more and lives more truly by walking to his duty.”
('76', 394, 5, 7, 748937) And then you subscribe: “On the train to Simla”.
('76', 394, 5, 8, 748986) I am surprised that, with all the fund of humour you possess, you could not see how the words “On the train to Simla” pointed the finger of ridicule to the statement “Man sees more and lives more truly by walking to his duty.” Time was when this friend used to believe in my method and was a valuable supporter.
('76', 394, 5, 9, 749298) Somehow or other I have now fallen from grace.
('76', 394, 5, 10, 749345) He should have had no difficulty in following the rich humour behind the writing which he exposes to ridicule.
('76', 394, 5, 11, 749456) But I must deprive the ridicule of its sting by informing my friend that I was in my senses when I wrote the note referred to.
('76', 394, 5, 12, 749583) I might easily have avoided the exact place where it was penned.
('76', 394, 5, 13, 749648) But I wanted to add point to my remark and to discover to the reader the vast gulf that separates me from my ideal.
('76', 394, 5, 14, 749764) Let the waverers take heart from the fact that though my note containing the flat contradiction of the ideal has provided my friend with mirth, I have got the credit for trying my best to live up to the ideals, I may profess.
('76', 394, 5, 15, 749990) If I am to make an ever increasing approach to my ideal, I must let the world see my weaknesses and failures so that I may be saved from hypocrisy and so that even for very shame I would try my utmost to realize the ideal.
('76', 394, 5, 16, 750213) The contradiction pointed out by the friend also shows that between the ideal and practice there always must be an unbridgeable gulf.
('76', 394, 5, 17, 750347) The ideal will cease to be one if it becomes possible to realize it.
('76', 394, 5, 18, 750416) The pleasure lies in making the effort, not in its fulfilment.
('76', 394, 5, 19, 750479) For, in our progress towards the goal we ever see more and more enchanting scenery.
('76', 394, 5, 20, 750563) Coming, however, to the friend’s gibe let me tell him and the reader that I could pen those lines because it is never a pleasure to me to travel by motor or rail or even a cart.
('76', 394, 5, 21, 750741) It is always a pleasure to walk.
('76', 394, 5, 22, 750774) Nor should I mind in the least if every rail was removed and men, except the sick and the maimed, had to walk to their businesses.
('76', 394, 5, 23, 750905) I can not only imagine but am working for a civilization in which possession of a car will be considered no merit and railways will find no place.
('76', 394, 5, 24, 751052) It would not be for me an unhappy event if the world
('76', 394, 6, 25, 751105) 1 Vide “Is India a Military Country”, 25 9 1939.
('76', 395, 0, 1, 751154) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 395, 1, 2, 751196) became once more as large as it used to be at one time.
('76', 395, 1, 3, 751252) Hind Swaraj was written in 1909 1. Since then it has undergone many editions and has been translated in many languages of the world.
('76', 395, 1, 4, 751385) I was asked last year by Shrimati Sophia Wadia to write a foreword 2 for the edition that she was bringing out.
('76', 395, 1, 5, 751497) I had the pleasure, therefore, of having to re read it carefully.
('76', 395, 1, 6, 751563) The reader may know that I could not revise a single idea.
('76', 395, 1, 7, 751622) I had no desire to revise the language.
('76', 395, 1, 8, 751662) It is a fair translation of the original in Gujarati.
('76', 395, 1, 9, 751716) The key to understand that incredibly simple (so simple as to be regarded foolish) booklet is to realize that it is not an attempt to go back to the so called ignorant, dark ages.
('76', 395, 1, 10, 751896) But it is an attempt to see beauty in voluntary simplicity, poverty and slowness.
('76', 395, 1, 11, 751978) I have pictured that as my ideal.
('76', 395, 1, 12, 752012) I shall never reach it myself and hence cannot expect the nation to do so.
('76', 395, 1, 13, 752087) But the modern rage for variety, for flying through the air, for multiplicity of wants, etc., have no fascination for me.
('76', 395, 1, 14, 752209) They deaden the inner being in us.
('76', 395, 1, 15, 752244) The giddy heights which man’s ingenuity is attempting, take us away from our Maker who is nearer to us than the nails are to the flesh which they cover.
('76', 395, 1, 16, 752397) Therefore even whilst I am travelling at the rate of 40 miles per hour, I am conscious that it is a necessary evil, and that my best work is to be done in little Segaon containing 700 souls, and in the neighbouring villages to which I can walk.
('76', 395, 1, 17, 752642) But being a highly prac tical man I do not avoid railway travelling or motoring for the mere sake of looking foolishly consistent.
('76', 395, 1, 18, 752773) 3 Let the reader know that during the hurricane Harijan tours 4 that Thakkar Bapa had arranged for me I had gently suggested to him that I would like to do the whole of the years’s tour on foot.

('76', 396, 2, 11, 754381) 501. ON TRIAL
('76', 396, 3, 12, 754395) In the course of the conversation with the members of the Working Committee, I discovered that their non violence had never gone beyond fighting the British Government with that weapon.
('76', 396, 3, 13, 754581) I had hugged the belief that Congressmen had appreciated the logical result of the practice of non violence for the past twenty years in fighting the biggest imperialist power in the world.
('76', 396, 3, 14, 754771) But in great experiments like that of non violence, hypothetical questions have hardly any play.
('76', 396, 3, 15, 754868) I myself used to say in answer to questions that when we had actually acquired independence we would know whether we could defend ourselves non violently or not.
('76', 396, 3, 16, 755030) But today the question is no longer hypothetical.
('76', 396, 3, 17, 755080) Whether there is on the part of the British Government a favourable declaration or not, the Congress has to decide upon the course it would adopt in the event of an invasion of India.
('76', 396, 3, 18, 755264) For, though there may be no settlement with the Government, the Congress has to declare its policy and say whether it would fight the invading host violently or non violently.
('76', 396, 3, 19, 755440) So far as I can read the Working Committee’s mind after a fairly full discussion, the members think the Congressmen are un prepared for non violent defence against armed invasion.
('76', 396, 3, 20, 755620) This is tragic.
('76', 396, 3, 21, 755636) Surely the means adopted for driving an enemy from one’s house must, more or less, coincide with those to be adopted for keeping him out of the house.
('76', 396, 3, 22, 755787) If anything, the latter pro cess must be easier.
('76', 396, 3, 23, 755836) The fact, however, is that our fight has not been one of non violent resistance of the strong.
('76', 396, 3, 24, 755931) It has been one of passive resistance of the weak.
('76', 396, 3, 25, 755982) Therefore there is no spontaneous response in
('76', 397, 0, 1, 756028) 398 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 397, 1, 2, 756070) our hearts, at this supreme moment, to an undying faith in the efficacy of non violence.
('76', 397, 1, 3, 756159) The Working Committee, therefore, wisely said that they were not ready for the logical step.
('76', 397, 1, 4, 756252) The tragedy of the situation is that, if the Congress is to throw in its lot with those who believe in the necessity of armed defence of India, the past twenty years will have been years of gross neglect of the primary duty of Congressmen to learn the science of armed warfare.
('76', 397, 1, 5, 756530) And I fear that history will hold me, as the general of the fight, responsible for the tragedy.
('76', 397, 1, 6, 756626) The future historian will say that I should have perceived that the nation was learning not non violence of the strong but merely passivity of the weak and I should have, therefore, provided for Congressmen’s military training.
('76', 397, 1, 7, 756854) Being obsessed with the idea that somehow or other India will learn true non violence, it would not occur to me to invite my co workers to train themselves for armed defence.
('76', 397, 1, 8, 757029) On the contrary, I used to discountenance all sword play and the display of stout lathis.
('76', 397, 1, 9, 757119) Nor am I even now repentant for the past.
('76', 397, 1, 10, 757161) I have the unquenchable faith that, of all the countries in the world, India is the one country which can learn the art of non violence, that if the test were applied even now, there would be found, perhaps, thousands of men and women who would be willing to die without harbouring malice against their persecutors.
('76', 397, 1, 11, 757477) I have harangued crowds and told them repeatedly that they might have to suffer much including death by shooting.
('76', 397, 1, 12, 757591) Did not thousands of men and women brave hardships during the salt cam paign equal to any that soldiers are called upon to bear?
('76', 397, 1, 13, 757720) No different capacity is required from what has been already evinced, if India has to contend against an invader.
('76', 397, 1, 14, 757834) Only it will have to be on a vaster scale.
('76', 397, 1, 15, 757877) One thing ought not to be forgotten.
('76', 397, 1, 16, 757914) India unarmed would not require to be destroyed through poison gas or bombardment.
('76', 397, 1, 17, 757997) It is the Maginot line that has made the Siegfried line necessary, and vice versa.
('76', 397, 1, 18, 758080) Defence of India by the present methods has been necessary because she is an appendage of Britain.
('76', 397, 1, 19, 758179) Free India can have no enemy.
('76', 397, 1, 20, 758209) And if her people have learnt the art of saying resolutely ‘No’ and acting up to it.
('76', 397, 1, 21, 758294) I dare say, no one would want to invade her.
('76', 397, 1, 22, 758339) Our economy would be so modelled as to prove no temptation for the exploiter.
('76', 397, 1, 23, 758417) But some Congressmen will say: ‘Apart from the British, India has so many martial races within her border that they will want to put up a fight for the country which is as much theirs as ours’.
('76', 397, 1, 24, 758611) This is perfectly true.
('76', 397, 1, 25, 758635) I am, therefore, talking for the moment only of
('76', 398, 0, 1, 758683) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 399
('76', 398, 1, 2, 758727) Congressmen.
('76', 398, 1, 3, 758740) How would they act in the event of an invasion?
('76', 398, 1, 4, 758788) We shall never convert the whole of India to our creed unless we are prepared to die for it.
('76', 398, 1, 5, 758881) The opposite course appals me.
('76', 398, 1, 6, 758912) Already the bulk of the army is manned by the Mussalmans of the North, Sikhs and Gurkhas.
('76', 398, 1, 7, 759002) If the masses of the South and the Centre wish to become militarized, the Congress, which is supposed to represent them, will have to enter into competition with them.
('76', 398, 1, 8, 759170) The Congress will then have to be party to an enormous military budget.
('76', 398, 1, 9, 759242) There may be all these things without the Congress consent.
('76', 398, 1, 10, 759302) It will make all the difference in the world whether the Congress is party to them or not.
('76', 398, 1, 11, 759393) The world is looking for something new and unique from India.
('76', 398, 1, 12, 759455) The Congress will be lost in the crowd if it wears the same old outworn armour that the world is wearing today.
('76', 398, 1, 13, 759567) The Congress has a name because it represents non violence as a political weapon par excellence.
('76', 398, 1, 14, 759664) If the Congress helps the Allies as a representative of non violence, it will give to the Allied cause a prestige and a power which will be invaluable in deciding the ultimate fate of the war.
('76', 398, 1, 15, 759857) But the members of the Working Committee have honestly and bravely not made the profession of such non violence.
('76', 398, 1, 16, 759970) My position is, therefore, confined to myself alone.
('76', 398, 1, 17, 760023) I have to find out whether I have any fellow traveller along the lonely path.
('76', 398, 1, 18, 760101) If I am in the minority of one, I must try to make converts.
('76', 398, 1, 19, 760162) Whether one or many, I must declare my faith that it is better for India to discard violence altogether even for defending her borders.
('76', 398, 1, 20, 760298) For India to enter into the race for armaments is to court suicide.
('76', 398, 1, 21, 760366) With the loss of India to non violence that last hope of the world will be gone.
('76', 398, 1, 22, 760447) I must live up to the creed I have professed for the last half a centrury and hope to the last breath that India will make non violence her creed, preserve man’s dignity, and prevent him from reverting to the type from which he is supposed to have raised himself.
('76', 398, 1, 23, 760711) SEGAON, October 10, 1939 Harijan, 14 10 1939

('76', 400, 1, 2, 762349) 505. DISCUSSION WITH A FRIEND 1
('76', 400, 2, 3, 762381) SEGAON, [On or after October 10, 1939] 2
('76', 400, 3, 4, 762422) FRIEND: We have been out and out Gandhji ites for several years and we do not know what we are to do at this juncture.
('76', 400, 3, 5, 762541) The Working Committee’s resolution has puzzled us.
('76', 400, 4, 6, 762592) GANDHIJI: But let me know what you mean by ‘out and out Gandhi ites’.
('76', 400, 5, 7, 762662) Those who are prepared to follow your principles through thick and thin.
('76', 400, 5, 8, 762735) Well, then let me tell you, I am not one myself, for in my practice I am far from what I have conceived as the ideals of truth and non violence.
('76', 400, 6, 9, 762880) I quite see what you mean.
('76', 400, 6, 10, 762907) I simply wanted to say that in our humble way we were trying to do constructive work as shown by you.
('76', 400, 6, 11, 763009) What are we to do if civil disobedience comes?
('76', 400, 6, 12, 763056) We voted for the A.I.C.C. resolution 3 because it was the official resolution sponsored by Rajendra Babu, Sardar and others.
('76', 400, 6, 13, 763181) But when we think of non violence we do not see how we could have voted for it.
('76', 400, 6, 14, 763261) There was nothing against non violence in voting for the resolution.
('76', 400, 6, 15, 763330) What you will do is of consequence.
('76', 400, 6, 16, 763366) And, as you will see from the next Harijan, I am writing 4 for friends like you.
('76', 400, 6, 17, 763447) You will see the position developed from week to week.
('76', 400, 6, 18, 763502) But I can sum it up for you.
('76', 400, 6, 19, 763531) There is no question of civil disobedience for there is no atmos phere for it—at any rate there is no question of civil disobedience in the aggressive sense as we launched in 1930 and 1932. We might have to offer it if all constructive work was made impossible, that is to say, if grave irritation was given by Government.
('76', 400, 6, 20, 763854) I fear no such thing.
('76', 400, 6, 21, 763876) At any rate I will not keep ‘Gandhi ites’ in the dark.
('76', 400, 6, 22, 763931) You should make a point of following carefully what I write every week.
('76', 400, 7, 23, 764003) But my difficulty is this.
('76', 400, 7, 24, 764030) We believe implicitly in developing strength through constructive work which is non violence in action.
('76', 400, 7, 25, 764134) But as we are part and parcel of the Congress, they may come down with a heavy hand on our ashrams and
('76', 400, 8, 26, 764237) 1 The discussion is extracted from “Out and Out Gandhi ite” by Mahadev Desai, who explains: “A friend who is running a rural work centre for some years, and who having come for the A.I.C.C., had come to Segaon to see Gandhiji.” The A.I.C.C. session was held in Wardha on October 9 and 10. 2 Ibid 3 Vide Appendix “A. I.C.C. Resolution”, 18 10 1939. 4 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 13 10 1939.
('76', 401, 0, 1, 764630) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 401, 1, 2, 764672) take possession of them as they did in 1930. It will depend on what the Congress will do.
('76', 401, 1, 3, 764762) Supposing what is unlikely happens and the Congress decides upon a course of aggre ssive civil disobedience, for which as I have said there is no atmos phere, you will have to isolate your ashram from the Congress, that is to say, you may have to secede from the Congress even at the risk of being labelled as ‘cowards’.
('76', 401, 2, 4, 765083) I see, I see.
('76', 401, 2, 5, 765097) There is one thing more about which I wanted to ask you.
('76', 401, 2, 6, 765154) We have
('76', 401, 3, 7, 765162) quarrels in the course of our day to day work in the ashram.
('76', 401, 3, 8, 765223) Therefore, you see, you are far from being ‘out and out Gandhi ites’.
('76', 401, 4, 9, 765293) No, but we have implicit faith in your teachings, and it is only in that sense
('76', 401, 5, 10, 765372) that I used that term.
('76', 401, 5, 11, 765395) But if in spite of that faith they quarrel, then they have not understood even the A.B.C. of ‘Gandhism’.
('76', 401, 5, 12, 765500) What is faith worth if it is not translated into action.
('76', 401, 5, 13, 765557) We may not go about parroting truth and non violence and steering clear of them in daily life.
('76', 401, 5, 14, 765652) Take the law of gravitation.
('76', 401, 5, 15, 765681) The discovery of the law led to numerous other discoveries based on the law.
('76', 401, 5, 16, 765758) Even so unless you go on discovering new applications of the law of non violence you do not profit by it.
('76', 401, 5, 17, 765864) You have to reduce it to a science.
('76', 401, 5, 18, 765900) To say that you have bickerings in the ashram which make smooth work impossible or difficult, is to say that non violence is not being practised.
('76', 401, 5, 19, 766046) Don’t you go away with the impression that we have no bickerings here in Segaon.
('76', 401, 5, 20, 766127) We have them, and that is why I said that I was not an ‘out and out Gandhi ite’.
('76', 401, 5, 21, 766208) But if I seriously thought that these bickerings would make communal life impossible, I might close down the institution.
('76', 401, 5, 22, 766330) It is not an improbability.
('76', 401, 5, 23, 766358) I should not shirk that duty if the idea possessed me.
('76', 401, 5, 24, 766413) Well, that is only to say that the difficulties are enormous everywhere.
('76', 401, 5, 25, 766486) Let God guide you and me and us all.
('76', 401, 6, 26, 766523) Harijan, 28 10 1939

('76', 404, 1, 2, 769692) 510. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('76', 404, 2, 3, 769722) SEGAON, October 13, 1939 I regard the recent resolution 2 of the A.I.C.C. on the situation as moderate and wise.
('76', 404, 2, 4, 769835) It was bound to reiterate the Congress demand for an unequivocal declaration.
('76', 404, 2, 5, 769913) Its merit lies in not fixing any time limit for the declaration.
('76', 404, 2, 6, 769978) It is noteworthy that the resolution was carried by a majority of three to one.
('76', 404, 2, 7, 770058) It is to be hoped that the British Government will appreciate the friendly spirit in which the Congress is approaching the situation.
('76', 404, 2, 8, 770192) It is to be hoped also that the Europeans of India will range themselves alongside of the Congress.
('76', 404, 2, 9, 770292) But the greatest help can only come from Congressmen themselves.
('76', 404, 2, 10, 770357) If they do not act on the square, no external sympathy and even help will be of any avail.
('76', 404, 2, 11, 770448) I see that impatience has seized some Congressmen who want to be doing something to signify their opposition to a war which they believe to be for defending imperialism.
('76', 404, 2, 12, 770618) I suggest to them that they will be defeating the common purpose by acting in opposition to the Congress decision expressed in the only way open to a democratic organization.
('76', 404, 2, 13, 770793) They had their say at the A.I.C.C. meeting.
('76', 404, 2, 14, 770837) They are in honour bound to defer direct action till the Working Committee or the A.I.C.C. decides otherwise.
('76', 404, 2, 15, 770947) No reliance can be placed upon an organization which is not able to exercise effective control over its members.
('76', 404, 2, 16, 771060) Imagine an army whose soldiers, under the false belief that they are advancing the common cause, adopt measures in defiance of those taken by the head quarters.
('76', 404, 2, 17, 771221) Such action may well spell defeat.
('76', 404, 2, 18, 771256) Therefore I beseech Congressmen at this critical juncture to desist from any action that would savour of indiscipline or defiance.
('76', 404, 2, 19, 771387) They should surely see that by such action they undermine Congress prestige and weaken its influence.
('76', 404, 3, 20, 771489) Harijan, 21 10 1939
('76', 404, 4, 21, 771509) 1 This appeared under the title “Notes”, sub title, “The A. I. C. C. Resolution”.
('76', 404, 4, 22, 771591) The statement was also published in The Bombay Chronicle and The Hindu on October 14. 2 Vide Appendix “A.I.C.C. Resolution”, 14 10 1939.

('76', 405, 6, 15, 772316) 512. FALLACY ABOUT SUGAR
('76', 405, 7, 16, 772341) The following article by Shri Gajanan Naik on the superiority of palms over cane and beetroot for the purpose of yielding sugar is presented for the criticism of sugar experts: 1
('76', 405, 8, 17, 772520) Sugar in its pure form is composed of carbon, hydrogen and oxygen (C12 H22 O11).
('76', 405, 8, 18, 772601) As such it does not take anything from the soil, but the crops now mainly
('76', 405, 9, 19, 772675) cultivated for extracting sugar, viz., the beet and the cane, require for their develop ment a number of substances from the soil in which they grow.
('76', 405, 9, 20, 772825) Therefore their culture exhausts the soil.
('76', 405, 9, 21, 772868) What is worse still is that the space now occupied by the beet in Europe and the cane in the tropics, might and ought to serve for the culture of food and fodder crops.
('76', 405, 10, 22, 773037) But people must have sugar.
('76', 405, 10, 23, 773065) Is there a way of getting it without encroaching on the soil fit for superior crops?
('76', 405, 10, 24, 773150) Yes—according to the opinion expressed by Mr. Devry at the Congress of Giessen.
('76', 405, 10, 25, 773230) (Watt’s Dictionary of the Economic Products of India, Vol. I, pp.
('76', 405, 10, 26, 773296) 301 4.) He says that palms can supply the required sugar for they can be grown on inferior soil where even to try to grow cereals would be a vain endeavour.
('76', 405, 11, 27, 773453) The statement throws much light on the place of the palm for the gur
('76', 405, 12, 28, 773522) industry.
('76', 405, 12, 29, 773532) It would be wrong to take it only as a philanthropic proposition for exploring avenues of employment for the toddy tappers who will be rendered idle through prohibition.
('76', 405, 12, 30, 773702) It has immense potentialities in the economics of national agriculture.
('76', 405, 13, 31, 773774) 1 Only extracts from the article by Gajanan Naik, Head of the Gur Department, A.I.V.I.A., are reproduced here.
('76', 406, 0, 1, 773885) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 407
('76', 406, 1, 2, 773929) Sugarcane cannot be grown with profit in the same field year after year.
('76', 406, 2, 3, 774002) to be rotated with some cereal.
('76', 406, 2, 4, 774034) Cane has to be cultivated year after year while palms once planted yield sugar for 20 to 50 years.
('76', 406, 2, 5, 774133) Heavy manuring and regular watering are required for cane while palms require neither.
('76', 406, 2, 6, 774220) Palm plan tations are not affected by wind, flood or shortage of rain.
('76', 406, 2, 7, 774291) Moreover, and this is very important, factory made apparatus, such as crushers are indispensable in cane gur making while the accessories necessary for palm gur manufacture are procurable locally in villages, and their cost is negligible as compared with those used for cane gur.
('76', 406, 3, 8, 774571) Harijan, 14 10 1939
('76', 406, 4, 9, 774591) 513. LETTER TO ABUL KALAM AZAD
('76', 406, 5, 10, 774622) SEGAON, WARDHA, October 14, 1939 DEAR MAULANA SAHEB, We must declare our policy in this matter 1 or do something.
('76', 406, 6, 11, 774736) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('76', 406, 7, 12, 774766) From a copy: Gandhi Nehru Papers, 1939. Courtesy: Nehru Memorial Museum
('76', 406, 8, 13, 774838) and Library
('76', 406, 9, 14, 774850) 1 The reference is to a letter dated October 9 from Mahomed Yunus, leader of the Muslim Independent Party in the Bihar Legislative Assembly who had said: “In continuation of my previous correspondence of the subject of Hindu Muslim unity, may I again draw your attention to what I have been writing and if you settle the following questions, I think, the time is now ripe for us to immediately come to an agreement: (1.) Recognition of the right of every individual to exercise his civil rights unhampered and uninterfered with, provided he does not do anything in a manner which may offend his neighbour.
('76', 406, 9, 15, 775456) (This will include right of every community to take out processions on roads, to kill any animal for sacrificial or other purposes and right of every community to offer prayers in any manner that community likes).

('76', 412, 2, 3, 781738) APPENDIX I LETTER FROM SARAT CHANDRA BOSE 1 May 31, 1939
('76', 412, 3, 4, 781795) MY DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('76', 412, 4, 5, 781814) You have probably learnt from the papers that I and Sjt.
('76', 412, 4, 6, 781871) Lalit Chandra Das,
('76', 412, 5, 7, 781890) M. L. C., my colleague on the Prisoners' Release Advisory Committee, felt compelled to resign from this Committee.
('76', 412, 5, 8, 782005) The reason we gave the Home Minister for doing so was that our approach to the question of release of the convicted prisoners differed fundamentally from that of most of the other members of the Committee.
('76', 412, 5, 9, 782211) This became clear to us during the last few weeks, more particularly in course of the discussions following the interviews with a number of prisoners which took place on May 6, 7, 8 and 9. Those discussions showed that the attitude of the majority of the members of the Committee was very stiff in the case of prisoners convicted in the more serious cases, and that they were not prepared to release them either on the assurance contained in your letter of the 13th April 1938 or on the reiteration by the prisoners of what they had told you when you met them.
('76', 412, 5, 10, 782772) It became apparent to us that the majority of those prisoners stood no chance of being released until they had served or practically served out their term.
('76', 412, 5, 11, 782928) As regards the rest it became apparent that the most that the majority of the members of the Committee were prepared to do was to recommend reduction of sentences in some cases and conditional release or release on giving specific undertakings in some other cases.
('76', 412, 6, 12, 783193) To the Home Minister we gave our reasons for our resignation in general terms only.
('76', 412, 6, 13, 783277) But I feel I ought to give you more details as well as a resume of what we did during the time we served on the Committee.
('76', 412, 7, 14, 783400) You probably remember that when the proposal for an Advisory Committee for the release of political prisoners was put forward and I was requested by Sir Nazimuddin to suggest names from the Congress Party, I was not quite sure in my mind as to what we should do.
('76', 412, 7, 15, 783663) I asked Subhas to seek your advice and he discussed the matter with you when he met you at Delhi towards the end of September or beginning of October last.
('76', 412, 7, 16, 783819) You were of opinion that I should accept membership of the Committee.
('76', 412, 7, 17, 783889) Accordingly, I made the position of the Congress Party in regard to the question of releasing political prisoners perfectly clear to Sir Nazimuddin, and communicated to him our decision to serve on the Committee in the hope that
('76', 412, 8, 18, 784118) 1 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 14 6 1939.
('76', 413, 0, 1, 784162) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 413, 1, 2, 784204) theGovernment would release the prisoners within a short time.
('76', 413, 1, 3, 784267) Copy of my letter to Sir Nazimuddin (dated October 23, 1938) is set forth below :
('76', 413, 2, 4, 784349) Kindly refer to D. O. No.
('76', 413, 2, 5, 784375) 3810 dated the 26th September from Mr. R. H. Hutchings to me, in which he asked me on your behalf to suggest the name of a member of the Bengal Legislative Assembly and also that of a member of the Bengal Legislative Council from the Congress Party who might be invited by Government to serve on the Advisory Committee regarding release of political prisoners.
('76', 413, 3, 6, 784736) You are well aware as a result of the conversations you had with Mahatma Gandhi and with the President of the Congress that the Congress Party cannot identify itself or agree with the Government policy in respect to political prisoners.
('76', 413, 3, 7, 784973) Mahatma Gandhi’s letter 1 of the 13th September to you has also made that clear.
('76', 413, 4, 8, 785054) At the same time, I feel that we should not obstruct any endeavour to bring about the release of these prisoners.
('76', 413, 4, 9, 785168) It is out of this feeling that I am responding to your request for assistance.
('76', 413, 4, 10, 785247) I earnestly hope that Government will see their way to set at liberty all the political prisoners at a very early date.
('76', 413, 5, 11, 785367) I would suggest the name of Sjt.
('76', 413, 5, 12, 785400) Lalit Chandra Das, M. L. C., from the Congress Council Party.
('76', 413, 5, 13, 785462) As regards the Congress Assembly Party, I am prepared to represent it on the Committee.
('76', 413, 5, 14, 785550) You may issue invitations to Sjt.
('76', 413, 5, 15, 785584) Lalit Chandra Das and myself.
('76', 413, 6, 16, 785614) After this the work of the Committee began and we made some progress.
('76', 413, 6, 17, 785684) Naturally, the less difficult cases came up for consideration first, and we were able to bring round our objecting or hesitating colleagues to our point of view, so that recommendation for unconditional release were sent to Government, resulting in the release of 112 prisoners, including all the women prisoners.
('76', 413, 6, 18, 785998) But as we proceeded with our work, a cleavage of opinion made itself distinctly felt.
('76', 413, 6, 19, 786084) It became obvious that the Government were not prepared to follow the recommendations of the Committee in all cases.
('76', 413, 6, 20, 786201) The unanimous recommendation of the Committee, in which the initiative was taken by the Chairman himself (who, I may tell you, had always been over cautious rather than under cautious) was referred back to the Committee.
('76', 413, 6, 21, 786422) It also came to my ears that in some cases the Government were imposing conditions (not recommended by the Committee) when it was perfectly well known that prisoners were not prepared to submit to any conditions or give any assurance except the one they had given to you.
('76', 413, 7, 22, 786694) This attitude of the Government had its reaction on the members of the Committee.
('76', 413, 7, 23, 786776) In the first place, they shrank from making recommendations even when they were satisfied about the attitude of the prisoners.
('76', 413, 7, 24, 786903) Of this, the case of Sjt.
('76', 413, 7, 25, 786929) Purnananda Das Gupta.
('76', 413, 7, 26, 786951) who was convicted in connection with
('76', 413, 8, 27, 786988) 1 Vide “Letter to Khwaja Nazimuddin”, 13 9 1938.
('76', 414, 0, 1, 787037) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 415
('76', 414, 1, 2, 787081) the Inter Provincial Conspiracy Case, is a good example.
('76', 414, 1, 3, 787138) There was a consensus of opinion among the members of the Committee that he had made a perfectly frank statement disavowing faith in terrorism.
('76', 414, 1, 4, 787282) Yet the majority of the Committee did not venture to make the necessary recommendation for his release but accepted the suggestion of the official member on the Committee that a further report be called for from Government about him.
('76', 414, 1, 5, 787516) Secondly, there was insistence on individual declarations which amounted to a specific undertaking for good behaviour.
('76', 414, 1, 6, 787635) While most of the prisoners were prepared to reiterate their declaration to you, and actually did so, they resented fresh individual undertakings and were not prepared to give them.
('76', 414, 1, 7, 787817) I and Lalit Babu considered that the prisoners had said enough in their statements to you and, by reiterating their adherence to those statements, had given convincing indication of a change of heart.
('76', 414, 1, 8, 788018) After the interview I told the Committee that I was perfectly satisfied that the prisoners had abjured violence for good and all of them should be released.
('76', 414, 1, 9, 788175) But my views did not find favour with the majority of the Committee.
('76', 414, 1, 10, 788244) They were not prepared to accept that kind of declaration as satisfactory.
('76', 414, 2, 11, 788319) I also noticed an increasing restiveness among the prisoners in respect of the interviews as well as the assurances required.
('76', 414, 2, 12, 788445) This restiveness and impatience had been present in greater or lesser degree from the very first.
('76', 414, 2, 13, 788543) But we had been able by tactful management to keep it from becoming obtrusive.
('76', 414, 2, 14, 788622) It was, however, impossible to overcome the reluctance of the prisoners when they found that guarantees of a more hard and fast character were required of them.
('76', 414, 2, 15, 788783) In such circumstances, their hostility to the procedure of the Committee came to the surface, and we became convinced that sooner or later its work was bound to come to something like a deadlock.
('76', 414, 3, 16, 788979) This is in short what we saw and thought as members of the Committee.
('76', 414, 3, 17, 789049) Besides this, the general attitude of the Government in regard to the remaining convicted prisoners had also to be taken into account.
('76', 414, 3, 18, 789184) It was clear to us that the Government were not prepared to release all the prisoners, no matter how favourable the atmosphere was.
('76', 414, 3, 19, 789316) In these circumstances I did not think it advisable for us to remain on the Committee any longer.
('76', 414, 4, 20, 789414) After our resignation, the Government issued a communique, copy of which is set out below :
('76', 414, 5, 21, 789506) The Committee appointed by Government to advise on the release of terrorist convicts has considered 183 cases.
('76', 414, 5, 22, 789617) Government have passed orders on the recommendations of the Committee in 112 cases and in 68 the recommendations of the Committee are about to be submitted to Government.
('76', 414, 5, 23, 789788) Three cases are under consideration by Government, and 56 cases remain to be examined by the Committee.
('76', 414, 5, 24, 789892) The Committee have recently interviewed a large number of prisoners individually before disposing of their cases in particular.
('76', 414, 5, 25, 790020) All the female prisoners appeared before the Committee and were recommended
('76', 415, 0, 1, 790096) 416 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 415, 1, 2, 790138) for release after giving satisfactory assurance as to their future conduct.
('76', 415, 1, 3, 790214) They have since been released.
('76', 415, 1, 4, 790245) Government regret to have to announce that two members of the Committee, Mr. Sarat Chandra Bose and Mr. Lalit Chandra Das, have tendered their resignations which have been accepted.
('76', 415, 1, 5, 790427) The two members gave as the reason for their resignation that their approach to the question of release of the convicted prisoners differed fundamentally from that of most of the other members of the Committee.
('76', 415, 2, 6, 790638) The question now is, what should be done to procure the release of the remaining prisoners.
('76', 415, 2, 7, 790730) I would very much like to have your advice as to how we should proceed.
('76', 415, 2, 8, 790802) What I am apprehensive of is that the prisoners may commence a hunger strike.
('76', 415, 2, 9, 790880) If they do so, the situation will become extremely complicated.
('76', 415, 2, 10, 790944) At the same time, I do not know what hopes I can hold out to them.

('76', 416, 5, 8, 792611) APPENDIX III STATEMENT BY SUBHAS CHANDRA BOSE 1
('76', 416, 6, 9, 792659) Prohibition by stages is a feasible scheme.
('76', 416, 6, 10, 792703) It will make both the public as well as the Excise Department experienced in the task of handling problems out of the enforcement of prohibition.
('76', 416, 6, 11, 792849) Moreover, it will be financially a success and it will release for the nation building activities that portion of the revenue derived from extra taxes like property tax, sales tax, etc.
('76', 416, 7, 12, 793035) Speaking generally, I may say that the motives actuating the Bombay Government are quite laudable, but the methods they have been hitherto following or intend following in future in connection with the problems of the property tax and the sales tax are neither scientific nor conducive to the end they have in view.
('76', 416, 8, 13, 793351) The defects in the Prohibition Scheme are more than one .
('76', 416, 8, 14, 793409) Illicit distillation will increase and there will be a rush of men to the wet zone every evening and particularly during every week end.
('76', 416, 9, 15, 793546) Prohibition is a measure of social reform and no social reform can be successfully brought about without winning.
('76', 416, 9, 16, 793660) the goodwill of the people.
('76', 416, 9, 17, 793688) The fact that consistent opposition is being offered by some influential sections of the community shows that the Government have not yet been able to carry with them the approval and goodwill of the people in general.
('76', 416, 10, 18, 793907) Mahatma Gandhi did the right thing when he opined that prohibition should not be forced on Europeans in India because they did not believe in it and it would amount to coercion to force it on them.
('76', 416, 10, 19, 794105) The same principle of non violence should be applied to Asiatics and Indian people as well both in theory and in practice.
('76', 416, 10, 20, 794228) Why should we force prohibition on non Indian Asiatics who do not believe in it, if we do not force it on Europeans?
('76', 416, 10, 21, 794345) It would be wrong to make a distinction between Europeans and Asiatics in this respect either in law or in actual administration.
('76', 416, 11, 22, 794475) Now turning to the economic side of the question, I may say that it is difficult to approve of a method which involves the sudden imposition of an additional tax over a crore of rupees on Bombay alone in order to make good the loss of excise revenue.
('76', 416, 11, 23, 794726) With millions of half filled stomachs, with hundreds of thousands dying every year of preventible diseases and with 92 percent of our people still unable to read or write.
('76', 416, 12, 24, 794898) 1 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 13 7 1939. Only extracts are reproduced here.
('76', 417, 0, 1, 794977) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 417, 1, 2, 795019) consider it no part of statemanship to raise additional money by heavy taxation, not one rupee of which would go towards the better fulfilment of stomachs or saving human lives or making our people more literate.
('76', 417, 1, 3, 795232) I am, therefore, inclined to think that the introduction of prohibition by stages is the more appropriate and scientific method.
('76', 417, 1, 4, 795361) This would not involve heavy taxation for financing prohibition, would save a portion of the taxable capacity of the people for future requirements and would not involve a sudden change in our national economy.
('76', 417, 2, 5, 795572) Nobody who has eyes to see in Bombay can fail to be impressed with one
('76', 417, 3, 6, 795643) important aspect of the Government policy.
('76', 417, 3, 7, 795686) It unfortunately happens that one small
('76', 417, 4, 8, 795726) community in Bombay which for many years past has been extensively engaged in
('76', 417, 5, 9, 795804) the liquor trade is being directly affected by this policy.
('76', 417, 5, 10, 795864) The Parsis are a small but
('76', 417, 6, 11, 795891) influential community.
('76', 417, 6, 12, 795914) Who does not know of the many beneficial institutions and
('76', 417, 7, 13, 795972) activities which have been brought into existence and conducted by them?
('76', 417, 8, 14, 796045) overwhelming majority of the community have been opposing this policy and as a
('76', 417, 9, 15, 796124) minority community the Parsis are entitled to be heard.
('76', 417, 9, 16, 796180) I understand that the Parsis are
('76', 417, 10, 17, 796213) apprehensive that the sudden launching of immediate and total prohibition in
('76', 417, 11, 18, 796290) Bombay will throw into the streets a large number of families and would prejudicially
('76', 417, 12, 19, 796376) affect the income of the charity trusts many of which are for the benefit not of Parsis
('76', 417, 13, 20, 796464) alone but of the Indian community in general.
('76', 417, 14, 21, 796510) Besides the Parsis, the Muslims of Bombay are also affected by the programme.
('76', 417, 15, 22, 796588) While they are not opposed to prohibition on principle, they have objection to the
('76', 417, 16, 23, 796671) 10 percent property tax, which is required for financing prohibition.
('76', 417, 16, 24, 796741) It is urged on
('76', 417, 17, 25, 796756) their behalf that the 10 percent property tax subjects them to exorbitant taxation as
('76', 417, 18, 26, 796842) compared with their population and they resent being taxed in order to force non 
('76', 417, 19, 27, 796924) Muslims to abstain from drink.
('76', 417, 20, 28, 796955) The effect of prohibition on our general economy is of greater consequence than
('76', 417, 21, 29, 797035) even its effect on the Parsis or Muslim community.
('76', 417, 21, 30, 797086) To give a small instance, a large
('76', 417, 22, 31, 797120) number of hotels and restaurants will be badly hit and may have to close down.
('76', 417, 23, 32, 797199) only will their owners suffer loss but the employees will also be thrown out of
('76', 417, 24, 33, 797279) employment.
('76', 417, 24, 34, 797291) It is not impossible that migration from the prohibited area to outside
('76', 417, 25, 35, 797363) places may take place and the importance of the port of Bombay may also be affected.
('76', 417, 26, 36, 797448) The fact is that while piecemeal introduction of partial prohibition is possible,
('76', 417, 27, 37, 797530) piecemeal introduction of total prohibition is next to impossible.
('76', 417, 28, 38, 797597) The Bombay Chronicle, 11 7 1939
('76', 418, 0, 1, 797629) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 419
('76', 418, 1, 2, 797673) APPENDIX IV
('76', 418, 2, 3, 797685) LETTER FROM SIKANDAR HYAT KHAN 1
('76', 418, 3, 4, 797718) SIMLA, July 20, 1939
('76', 418, 4, 5, 797739) MY DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('76', 418, 5, 6, 797758) Many thanks for your letter of the 17th July which I received this morning.
('76', 418, 5, 7, 797834) This has crossed my letter of the 18th July.
('76', 418, 6, 8, 797879) I am sorry I overlooked to answer your query about the representation of Harijans in the proposed Lahore Corporation.
('76', 418, 6, 9, 797997) I have made enquiries from the Minister concerned and am informed that no provision has been made in the bill to provide separate electorates for Harijans.
('76', 418, 6, 10, 798153) The method of election and representation is at present embodied in the rules and it is proposed to leave th is matter to the rules in the new measure also.
('76', 418, 6, 11, 798310) I am almost certain that the question of separate representation for Harjans will be raised in the Assembly when the bill is under consideration as several representations have been received from Harijan organizations.
('76', 418, 6, 12, 798529) So far as Government is concerned, they do not contemplate at the moment to make a departure from the existing practice unless the Harijan representatives in the Assembly press for a revision and, if so, it would largely depend upon what view the Assembly takes regarding this matter.
('76', 418, 6, 13, 798814) Personally, as you are aware, I am not averse to joint electorates; but unfortunately the trend of events during the past few years has made it even more difficult to achieve this ideal in the absence of genuine rapprochement
('76', 418, 7, 14, 799040) between the two major communities.
('76', 418, 8, 15, 799075) I am grateful to you for careful consideration to my alternative scheme of Federation.
('76', 418, 8, 16, 799162) Allow me to remove one or two misapprehensions which seem to have arisen due to the reason that you have not had time to make a comparative study of my scheme with the one embodied in the Government of India Act.
('76', 418, 8, 17, 799375) My proposals do not contemplate a wholesale rejection of the scheme adumbrated in the Government of India Act.
('76', 418, 8, 18, 799486) At the most it would necessitate modification of about half a dozen sections in the Act and the addition of perhaps two or three new sections.
('76', 418, 8, 19, 799629) It would of course involve a revision of the Federal, Provincial and the concurrent lists as you will have noticed from the revised list which I sent with my letter of the 18th July.
('76', 418, 8, 20, 799812) As regards the ‘Zonal’ Legislatures contemplated in my scheme, there again seems to be some misapprehension.
('76', 418, 8, 21, 799921) You must have noticed that I do not contemplate any executive authority for the ‘zones’, and the legislative powers delegated to the Regional Legislatures are meant only to bring the various units in a ‘zone’ closer together in order to bring about mutual confidence and trust between the various units.
('76', 418, 8, 22, 800225) It would
('76', 418, 9, 23, 800234) 1 Vide “Letter to Sikandar Hyat Khan”, 17 7 1939 and 25 7 1939.
('76', 419, 0, 1, 800298) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 419, 1, 2, 800340) not involve any additional expenditure since the members of a Regional Legislature would also be members of the Federal Legislature and will collectively constitute the Federal Legislature.
('76', 419, 1, 3, 800530) No separate building or organization will be required.
('76', 419, 1, 4, 800585) If and when necessary, they will meet together to ratify or pass a measure on which the units in a particular ‘zone’ are agreed.
('76', 419, 1, 5, 800714) As a matter of fact, my scheme would be comparatively less expensive as I have suggested a unicameral instead of a bicameral Federal Legislature.
('76', 419, 2, 6, 800860) As regards the composition of the Army, I have suggested no more than retention of the status quo so far as the peace time strength of the Army is concerned.
('76', 419, 3, 7, 801018) As I explained to you in the course of our conversation, my insistence on this provision is actuated by a desire to create mutual confidence, and in the interests of national harmony and solidarity.
('76', 419, 4, 8, 801217) I appreciate your remarks regarding acceptance of Dominion Status.
('76', 419, 4, 9, 801284) I am aware that all the important political organizations in the country have now adopted ‘complete independence’ as their final goal.
('76', 419, 4, 10, 801419) But I am sure you will agree with me that in the circumstances it would be inadvisable to clutch at a shadow and discard the substance if it happens to be within our grasp.
('76', 419, 4, 11, 801592) After all, what we want is complete control over the administration and affairs of our country and this will be obtained if we get Dominion Status.
('76', 419, 4, 12, 801740) I am fully aware of the fact that some of our fellow countrymen would prefer to chase a will o’ the wisp rather than give up their demand for complete independence; but it would be for an eminent patriot and leader like you to persuade them to accept the substance and leave alone the shadow.
('76', 419, 5, 13, 802033) You mention in your letter that “Yours is the only proposal of a constructive character on behalf of the League.” Let me hasten to make it quite clear that my scheme has got nothing to do with the League.
('76', 419, 5, 14, 802238) It has been formulated by me alone and without consultation with any member of the League or for that matter of any other party in the country.
('76', 419, 5, 15, 802382) It has been conceived with the intention of providing a solution of our communal and political problems and I trust it will be examined and studied by all concerned in the spirit in which it has been conceived.
('76', 419, 6, 16, 802593) As regards your draft solution of the communal problem and my comments
('76', 419, 7, 17, 802664) thereon, I shall be grateful if you would kindly give me some more definite
('76', 419, 8, 18, 802740) indications of your views, if you desire me to 1 proceed with the matter further.
('76', 419, 8, 19, 802822) I quite realize that the draft represents only your views; but that is quite sufficient for my
('76', 419, 9, 20, 802917) purpose provided you approve of my suggestions with reference to the various items
('76', 419, 10, 21, 803000) of the draft.
('76', 419, 10, 22, 803014) I can then proceed to sound important Muslim leaders and the Working
('76', 419, 11, 23, 803083) Committee of the League and let you know their reactions.
('76', 419, 11, 24, 803141) It would be no use my
('76', 419, 12, 25, 803163) trying to bring them round to my point of view unless I am assured of your whole 
('76', 419, 13, 26, 803245) 1 The source, however, has “or”.
('76', 420, 0, 1, 803278) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 421
('76', 420, 1, 2, 803322) hearted approval and support in regard to the points mentioned in my note which I
('76', 420, 2, 3, 803404) handed over to you at Bombay.
('76', 420, 2, 4, 803434) I need hardly assure you that the correspondence
('76', 420, 3, 5, 803483) between us will be treated as strictly confidential.
('76', 420, 3, 6, 803536) Perhaps, you would like to consult
('76', 420, 4, 7, 803571) the Working Committee of the League and other prominent Muslims.
('76', 420, 4, 8, 803636) If there is
('76', 420, 5, 9, 803648) agreement on these points, then we could bring the representatives of the two
('76', 420, 6, 10, 803726) Working Committees together to approve and ratify them informally.
('76', 420, 7, 11, 803793) As regards services, I do not think we need worry about the number of communities which would fall under the category of ‘minorities’.
('76', 420, 7, 12, 803928) The obvious course would be to fix the share of the majority community in each province and leave the balance to be distributed amongst the minorities.
('76', 420, 7, 13, 804080) This is what we have done in the Punjab We have given 50 per cent to the Muslims and 50 per cent to non Muslims.
('76', 420, 7, 14, 804193) The proportion (7 per cent) surrendered by the the majority community was added on to the share of the smaller minorities in the shape of weightage.
('76', 420, 7, 15, 804342) So the problem is not so complex as it appears to be at first sight.
('76', 420, 7, 16, 804411) What we need is a genuine change of heart and once this is achieved there should be no difficulty in adjusting differences.
('76', 420, 7, 17, 804535) I am afraid my letter has become somewhat lengthy; but in view of the issues involved I have taken the liberty of encroaching on your time by answering the points raised in your letter in some detail.
('76', 420, 8, 18, 804736) With best wishes and kind regards,

('76', 420, 11, 21, 804866) HARIJAN SEVAKS’ CONFERENCE RESOLUTIONS 1
('76', 420, 12, 22, 804907) June 4/7, 1939
('76', 420, 13, 23, 804922) 1. This Conference of Harijan sevaks resolves that Harijan sevaks should not visit those temples which Harijans are not allowed to enter.
('76', 420, 13, 24, 805060) It should be clearly understood that Harijan sevaks are not to enter such temples, not only for the purpose of worship but also for sight seeing, provided that this rule is not intended to come in the way of doing service to Harijans.
('76', 420, 13, 25, 805295) Similarly Harijan sevaks are not to attend public meetings which are not open to Harijans.
('76', 420, 14, 26, 805386) 2. The Western and Central India Harijan Sevaks’ Conference held at Poona very much appreciates the organization of Harijan welfare work in Holkar State as explained by Prof.
('76', 420, 14, 27, 805561) R. K. Yardye, Hon.
('76', 420, 14, 28, 805580) Secretary of the Indore H. S. S., but considers that the grant of Rs. 7,000 is too low for the purpose and therefore requests His Highness the Maharaja Holkar and his Government to raise the grant considerably to enable the work to be organized efficiently.
('76', 420, 14, 29, 805838) This Conference is also of the opinion that the object of the State regarding Harijan emancipation will be better served by
('76', 420, 15, 30, 805962) 1Vide “A Harijan Sevaks’ Conference”, 30 7 1939.
('76', 421, 0, 1, 806011) 422 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 421, 1, 2, 806053) the appointment of a special officer, as is done in Bombay, Mysore, Travancore and Cochin, to look after Harijan interests.
('76', 421, 2, 3, 806177) 3. The report of the Harijan Sevak Sangh, Gwalior State, submitted by the Secretary to this Conference, shows that the cause of Harijans suffers on account of the utter lack of practical support by the Government of Gwalior.
('76', 421, 2, 4, 806402) Considering the views of His Highness the Maharaja Saheb as expressed repeatedly in his public speeches, it is most regrettable that such indifference should exist.
('76', 421, 2, 5, 806567) This Conference respectfully draws the attention of the Administration and the Ruler of the Gwalior State to the necessity of taking an active part in the work of the amelioration of the conditions of Harijans, as well as the removal of untouchability.
('76', 421, 2, 6, 806820) For this purpose this conference requests the appointment of a special officer or that of a Committee with an annual grant of a substantial sum of money in the annual budget.
('76', 421, 2, 7, 806995) This Conference is also of opinion that a public declaration of the State policy granting civic rights to Harijans for the use of public wells, tanks, temples, conveyances and schools should be issued forthwith.
('76', 421, 2, 8, 807207) 4. The universal disinclination to do physical work, particularly work involving the handling of dirt, is one of the causes that are responsible for the custom of untouchability.
('76', 421, 2, 9, 807386) For example, scavenging, flaying of dead cattle, tanning, leather work, barber’s work and similar duties are regarded as causing pollution.
('76', 421, 2, 10, 807526) Similarly personal service and hospitality rendered to a member of a so called lower caste is forbidden.
('76', 421, 3, 11, 807631) To achieve total eradication of untouchability, it is necessary to remove as early as possible this false feeling of detestation towards socially beneficial occupations.
('76', 421, 3, 12, 807801) This Conference therefore appeals to all Harijan sevaks and persons interested in the cause of Harijan uplift that they should feel no hesitation in doing with their own hands the aforesaid duties and thereby demonstrate to the world that they involve no indignity or pollution.
('76', 421, 4, 13, 808080) This Conference further appeals to all Hindu sisters and brothers to remain
('76', 421, 5, 14, 808156) absolutely certain that no individual loses his caste by virtue of personal service of
('76', 421, 6, 15, 808243) any description.
('76', 421, 6, 16, 808260) Bearing this religious principle in mind they should extend to guests
('76', 421, 7, 17, 808330) of whatsoever caste coming under their roof the same cordial hospitality that they
('76', 421, 8, 18, 808413) render to their own caste people.
('76', 421, 8, 19, 808447) One need not have a guilty conscience in rendering
('76', 421, 9, 20, 808498) service to such guests.
('76', 421, 10, 21, 808522) A growing tendency is to be noticed among self respecting Harijans to
('76', 421, 11, 22, 808592) abandon their hereditary occupations because these are socially despised.
('76', 421, 11, 23, 808666) Although
('76', 421, 12, 24, 808675) this Conference does not regard any honest occupation as low, it fully appreciates the
('76', 421, 13, 25, 808762) feelings of Harijans and declares that they have every right to give up these
('76', 421, 14, 26, 808840) occupations if they so choose, and that it would be unjust on the part of caste Hindus
('76', 421, 15, 27, 808927) to coerce them into doing such tasks.
('76', 422, 0, 1, 808965) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 423
('76', 422, 1, 2, 809009) 5. With a view to remove untouchability and bring about a speedy uplift of Harijans, this Conference requests all Provincial Boards of the H.S.S. concerned to take necessary steps in order that elementary education is made free and compulsory at least for Harijan children in those places where there are already schools of a District School Board or a Municipal School Board.
('76', 422, 2, 3, 809386) 6. This Conference takes this opportunity to point out to the managers of Harijan students’ hostels of the H.S.S. that segregation is not the object of conducting Harijan hostels, and that therefore an endeavour should be made to secure the admission of Harijan boys and girls of all Harijan sub castes and also of a few caste Hindu boys and girls in the Harijan hostels, provided that no monetary burden is thrown on the resources of the Sangh in respect of caste Hindu pupils.
('76', 422, 3, 4, 809865) 7. This Conference is of opinion that it is necessary to afford legal protection to Harijans who are subjected to social boycott on account of their enjoying a common civic right, and recommends to the Bombay Government, as a measure of partial protection, that the Government should undertake, along with other legislation contemplated by Government, suitable legislation to provide that refusal on the part of a shopkeeper or a regular dealer in articles which are necessaries of life, to sell such articles to a Harijan or his servants or his family dependants as an item of social boycott on the ground of such Harijans trying to enjoy or having enjoyed any common civic rights, should be made a punishable offence.
('76', 422, 4, 5, 810585) 8. It is resolved by this Conference that the various Provincial Boards should request the Municipalities in their jurisdiction to start welfare work for their Harijan employees on the lines of the Bombay Municipal Corporation, and the Municipalities may be requested to use at least the Fine Funds for this purpose.
('76', 422, 5, 6, 810902) The line of work can be suggested on the following fundamental points:
('76', 422, 6, 7, 810973) recreational, educational, social, economical.
('76', 422, 6, 8, 811020) And the welfare work will also include
('76', 422, 7, 9, 811059) the work of a labour officer, i.
('76', 422, 7, 10, 811092) e., to receive complaints about the working conditions
('76', 422, 8, 11, 811147) of the employees and to redress them.
('76', 422, 9, 12, 811185) 9. This Conference urges the Provincial Boards and the Local Committee of
('76', 422, 10, 13, 811259) the H.S.S. to make concerted and special efforts for securing to Harijans the
('76', 422, 11, 14, 811337) enjoyment of civic rights in respect of wells, hotels, etc.
('76', 422, 12, 15, 811397) 10. This Conference is of opinion that the Government of Bombay should take necessary steps to provide for free studentships to all deserving Harijan students in the secondary grant in aid schools in the Bombay Presidency as soon as possible.
('76', 422, 13, 16, 811640) 11. Whereas in various Harijan localities, there are no grocery shops and the Harijans have to purchase corn and other provisions from shops belonging to otherpeople at a very high price, this Conference requests the Harijan Sevak Sanghs to endeavour to open such shops on a co operative basis in those villages where the Harijan population is sufficiently numerous.
('76', 423, 0, 1, 812007) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 423, 1, 2, 812049) 12. This Conference requests all Harijan sevaks that they should try their best to enlist active co operation of women workers in the cause of service to Harijans.
('76', 423, 2, 3, 812213) 13. Whereas it has been found by experience that in multi member constituencies for legislatures and local bodies where seats are reserved for Harijans, votes are not, as a rule, mutually given by caste Hindu voters and Harijan voters, and whereas it is necessary with a view to foster brotherly feelings and to fulfil the real purpose of the Poona Pact 1 that the votes should be mutually given, this Conference calls upon all caste Hindu voters to exercise at least one vote in favour of Harijan candidates, and Harijan voters to exercise at least one vote in favour of caste Hindu candidates.
('76', 423, 2, 4, 812809) This Conference is further of opinion that the distributive system of voting is better suited than the cumulative system to achieve the end in view.
('76', 423, 3, 5, 812958) SEGAON, July 30, 1939

('76', 423, 8, 10, 813085) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('76', 423, 9, 11, 813102) Many thanks for your telegram which I have just received.
('76', 423, 9, 12, 813160) I quite realize your difficulty in getting away at this moment, and I had indeed been a little afraid that it might, as has happened, be impossible for you to do so.
('76', 423, 9, 13, 813326) I should be most reluctant to impose the least strain on you, and I hope that you will never hesitate to let me know if you feel that any suggestion of mine for a meeting is likely to have that effect; and I shall not in the least misunderstand your doing so.
('76', 423, 10, 14, 813586) 2. It is very kind of you to suggest that we might meet later this month.
('76', 423, 10, 15, 813660) I have in fact, as I said, nothing very special to talk about, and my invitation to you to meet me at Delhi was merely in pursuance of my desire to keep in touch with you and maintain contact from time to time.
('76', 423, 10, 16, 813871) Nor do I want to give you the trouble of the tiring journey to Simla.
('76', 423, 10, 17, 813941) I think therefore that we might leave matters as they are for the moment, and I will look forward to seeing you a little later in the year when I am again back from the hills.
('76', 423, 11, 18, 814117) With all good wishes,

('76', 424, 1, 2, 814438) APPENDIX VII KATHIAWAR STATES 1
('76', 424, 2, 3, 814470) The Western India States Agency, comprising all the 284 States in Kathiawar, is, numerically, by far the biggest Agency under the administrative control of the Political Department.
('76', 424, 2, 4, 814652) The Kathiawar States, Between themselves account for just half the number of States in India, the total being computed at 562. These States present the greatest possible variety in size and government.
('76', 424, 2, 5, 814854) At one end of the scale are Cutch with an area of 8,250 square miles and Bhavnagar with an annual income of about Rs. 15 million; at the other end of the scale.
('76', 424, 2, 6, 815015) Vejanoness which has an area of 0.29 square mile, a population of 206 souls and an income of Rs. 500 a year.
('76', 424, 2, 7, 815124) Sir George Macmunn must have had these statelets in mind while writing his famous book The Indian States and Princes.
('76', 424, 2, 8, 815242) In the very first chapter he says:
('76', 424, 3, 9, 815277) The Ruling Princes of India number between five and six hundred, and their principalities vary from that of the Nizam, as large as a third of France, to others no larger than Battersea Park.
('76', 424, 4, 10, 815468) The real demand of the States subjects, it must be presumed, is self government or responsible government and not merely good government.
('76', 424, 4, 11, 815606) Nothing short of extensive democratization of the administrative machinery is likely to satisfy them.
('76', 424, 4, 12, 815708) As democratization must of neccessity involve certain financial commitments, it is neither helpful nor politic to demand it from Rulers of States whose annual income is less than, say, Rs. 50 lakhs.
('76', 424, 4, 13, 815907) Joint administration is, therefore, the only alternative to the existing arrangement for such States.
('76', 424, 5, 14, 816009) Joint administration for small States is no novel or visionary suggestion.
('76', 424, 5, 15, 816084) His Excellency the Viceroy himself, than whom none can claim to be more solicitous for the welfare of the Princes, is responsible for propagating this view.
('76', 424, 5, 16, 816241) The germs of this theory, however, are traceable in the Butler Committee Report, 1928 29. Dealing with the classification of States, the Report says:
('76', 424, 6, 17, 816391) The petty States of Kathiawar and Gujarat, numbering 286 of the total of 327 in the third class, are organized in groups called thanas under officers
('76', 424, 7, 18, 816541) appointed by local representatives of the Paramount Power, who exercise various kinds and degrees of criminal, revenue and civil jurisdiction.
('76', 424, 7, 19, 816684) As the cost of administration rises, the States find it necessary to distribute it over larger areas by appointing officials to work for several States.
('76', 424, 7, 20, 816837) Already there is talk in some of the larger States in Kathiawar of appointing a High Court with powers over a group of such States.
('76', 424, 8, 21, 816969) 1 Vide Letter to R. L. Handa”, 10 8 1939; “Confederation of Small States”, 14 8 1939 and “Kathiawar States”, 11 9 1939. Only extracts are reproduced here.
('76', 425, 0, 1, 817124) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 425, 1, 2, 817166) He Excellency’s views on this question may be gathered from the following extract from his address delivered on the occasion of inaugurating the session of the Chamber of Princes in March last:
('76', 425, 2, 3, 817360) In no case is the need for co operation and combination more patent, more pronounced and more immediate than in the case of the smaller States.
('76', 425, 2, 4, 817504) Those States whose resources are so limited as virtually to preclude them individually from providing for the requirements of their people in accordance with modern standard, have indeed no other practical alternative before them.
('76', 425, 2, 5, 817735) I would take this opportunity to impress upon the Rulers of such States, with all the emphasis at my command, the wisdom of taking the earliest possible steps to combine with their neighbours in the matter of administrative services so far as this is practicable.
('76', 425, 3, 6, 817999) Though the principle of combination enunciated by the Viceroy can apply to smaller States all over India, it is particularly suitable in the case of Kathiawar States.
('76', 425, 3, 7, 818166) One peculiar feature of these States is that, unlike their neighbours, the Gujarat States or the Central India States, they are geographically one compact province.
('76', 425, 3, 8, 818331) The process of combination or grouping or to be a little bolder, of confederation, is immensely facilitated by this continuity.
('76', 425, 3, 9, 818459) The total area of all these States is just over 40,000 square miles and the total population is 42,29,494. The total annual income is estimated at about Rs. six crores.
('76', 425, 4, 10, 818628) During the last three months the Kathiawar Princes have met a number of times and .
('76', 425, 4, 11, 818712) they were reported to have discussed the feasibility of having a combined police force, common Excise, Medical, Public Health, Public Works and Forest Deparments and a common High Court.
('76', 425, 4, 12, 818899) It is so easy to see the futility of combined administration in these important spheres without providing for a combined legislature.
('76', 425, 4, 13, 819033) For, the question arises, to whom will these common administrations be responsible?
('76', 425, 4, 14, 819117) Certainly not to all one score Princes and their Governments.
('76', 425, 4, 15, 819179) You cannot earnestly be responsible to twenty authorities unless confusion is their aim and to bungle your wish.
('76', 425, 5, 16, 819292) Harijan, 30 9 1939
('76', 425, 6, 17, 819311) APPENDIX VIII LETTER FROM SUBHAS CHANDRA BOSE TO CONGRESS PRESIDENT 1
('76', 425, 7, 18, 819381) August 7, 1939
('76', 425, 8, 19, 819396) I am exceedingly sorry for the delay in replying to your letter of the 18th July,
('76', 425, 9, 20, 819478) from Ranchi.
('76', 425, 9, 21, 819491) You have asked me for an explanation of my action in protesting
('76', 425, 10, 22, 819555) against certain resolutions of the All India Congress Committee passed at Bombay.
('76', 425, 11, 23, 819637) 1 Vide “Congress Working Committee Resolution”, 11 8 1939.
('76', 426, 0, 1, 819696) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 427
('76', 426, 1, 2, 819740) In the first place, one has to distinguish between protesting against a certain
('76', 426, 2, 3, 819820) resolution and actually defying it or violating it.
('76', 426, 2, 4, 819872) What has so far happened is that I
('76', 426, 3, 5, 819907) have only protested against two resolutions of the A.I.C C.
('76', 426, 4, 6, 819967) It is my constitutional right to give expression to my opinion regarding any
('76', 426, 5, 7, 820044) resolution passed by the A.I.C.C. You will perhaps admit that it is customary with a
('76', 426, 6, 8, 820129) large number of Congressman to express their views on resolutions passed by the
('76', 426, 7, 9, 820209) A.I.C.C. when a particular session of that body comes to a close.
('76', 426, 7, 10, 820275) If you grant
('76', 426, 8, 11, 820288) Congressmen the right to express their views on resolutions passed by the A.I.C.C.,
('76', 426, 9, 12, 820372) you cannot draw a line and say that only favourable opinions will be allowed
('76', 426, 10, 13, 820449) expression and unfavourable opinions will be banned.
('76', 426, 10, 14, 820502) If we have the contitutional
('76', 426, 11, 15, 820531) right to express our views then it does not matter if those views are favourable or un 
('76', 426, 12, 16, 820619) favourable.
('76', 426, 12, 17, 820631) Your letter seems to suggest that only expression of unfavourable views
('76', 426, 13, 18, 820703) is to be banned.
('76', 426, 14, 19, 820720) We have so long been fighting the British Government among other things
('76', 426, 15, 20, 820792) for our civil liberty.
('76', 426, 15, 21, 820815) Civil liberty, I take it, includes freedom of speech.
('76', 426, 15, 22, 820869) According to
('76', 426, 16, 23, 820882) your point of view we are not to claim freedom of speech when we do not see eye to
('76', 426, 17, 24, 820965) eye with the majority in the A.I.C.C. or in the Congress.
('76', 426, 17, 25, 821023) It would be a strange
('76', 426, 18, 26, 821045) situation if we are to have the right of freedom of speech as against the British
('76', 426, 19, 27, 821127) Government but not as against the Congress or any body subordinate to it.
('76', 426, 19, 28, 821201) If we are
('76', 426, 20, 29, 821211) denied the right to adversely criticize resolutions of the A.I.C.C. which in our view
('76', 426, 21, 30, 821297) are harmful to the country’s cause then it would amount to denial of a democratic
('76', 426, 22, 31, 821379) May I ask you in all seriousness if democratic rights are to be exercised only
('76', 426, 23, 32, 821458) outside the Congress but not inside it ?
('76', 426, 24, 33, 821499) I hope you will agree that when a resolution is once passed by the A.I.C.C., it is open to us to have it reviewed or amended or altered or rescinded at a subsequent meeting of that body.
('76', 426, 24, 34, 821686) I hope you will also agree that it is open to us to appeal against the A.I.C.C. to the higher court of appeal, namely, the open session of the Congress.
('76', 426, 24, 35, 821839) You will agree further, I hope, that it is open to a minority to carry on a propaganda with a view to converting the majority to its point of view.
('76', 426, 24, 36, 821987) Now how can we do this except by appealing to Congressmen through public meetings and through writings in the Press?
('76', 426, 24, 37, 822104) The Congress today is not an organization of a handful of men.
('76', 426, 24, 38, 822167) Its membership has, I believe, reached the neighbourhood of 45 lakhs.
('76', 426, 24, 39, 822237) We can hope to appeal to the rank and file of the Congress and to convert them to our point of view only if we are allowed to write in the Press and also to hold meetings.
('76', 426, 24, 40, 822409) If you maintain that once a resolution is passed in the A.I.C.C. it is sacrosanct and must hold good for ever, then you may have some justification for banning criticism of it.
('76', 426, 24, 41, 822586) But if you
('76', 427, 0, 1, 822597) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 427, 1, 2, 822639) grant us the right to review or amend or alter or rescind a particular resolution of the A.I.C.C. either through that body or through the open session of the Congress, then I do not see how you can gag criticism, as you have been trying to do.
('76', 427, 2, 3, 822883) I am afraid you are giving an interpretation to the word ‘discipline’ which I
('76', 427, 3, 4, 822961) cannot accept.
('76', 427, 3, 5, 822976) I consider myself to be a stern disciplinarian and I am afraid that in the
('76', 427, 4, 6, 823051) name of discipline you are trying to check healthy criticism.
('76', 427, 4, 7, 823113) Discipline does not
('76', 427, 5, 8, 823133) mean denying a person his constitutional and democratic right.
('76', 427, 6, 9, 823196) Apart from the fact that it is our constitutional and democratic right to protest
('76', 427, 7, 10, 823278) against resolutions which in our view are harmful to the country’s cause, a
('76', 427, 8, 11, 823354) consideration of the merits of the two resolutions will show that such protests were
('76', 427, 9, 12, 823439) really called for.
('76', 427, 9, 13, 823458) In our view these two resolutions, if given effect to, will serve to
('76', 427, 10, 14, 823527) accentuate the drift towards constitutionalism, to increase the influence, power and
('76', 427, 11, 15, 823612) authority of the Provincial Ministries at the cost of the Congress organizations, to
('76', 427, 12, 16, 823697) isolate artificially the Congress from the general public as also the A.I.C.C. from the
('76', 427, 13, 17, 823785) rank and file of the Congress.
('76', 427, 13, 18, 823816) Moreover, they will serve to undermine the
('76', 427, 14, 19, 823859) revolutionary spirit of the Congress.
('76', 427, 14, 20, 823897) Consequently, in the best interests of the
('76', 427, 15, 21, 823940) country, these two resolutions should be immediately held in abeyance and ultimately
('76', 427, 16, 22, 824025) altered suitably or withdrawn.
('76', 427, 17, 23, 824056) In this connection I cannot help drawing your attention to certain incidents at the time of the Gaya Congress in 1922 and after.
('76', 427, 17, 24, 824185) Please do not forget what the Swaraj Party did in those days.
('76', 427, 17, 25, 824247) Please do not forget either that when the A.I.C.C. amended the resolution of the Gaya Congress, the Gujarat P.C.C. resolved to defy it.
('76', 427, 17, 26, 824383) Lastly, please do not forget that Mahatma Gandhi wrote 1 in Young India, if my recollection is correct, that the minority has the right to rebel.
('76', 427, 17, 27, 824529) We have not gone so far yet as to actually rebel against the decision of the majority.
('76', 427, 17, 28, 824616) We have simply taken the liberty of criticizing certain resolutions passed by the majority in the teeth of our opposition.
('76', 427, 18, 29, 824739) I am really surprised that you have made so much of what we regard as our inherent right.
('76', 427, 18, 30, 824829) I hope you will accept my explanation as satisfactory.
('76', 427, 18, 31, 824884) But if you do not do so, and if you decide to resort to disciplinary action, I shall gladly face it for the sake of what I regard as a just cause.
('76', 427, 18, 32, 825031) In conclusion, I have to request that if any Congressman is penalized in connection with the events of the 9th July, then you will also take action against me.
('76', 427, 18, 33, 825191) If the observance of an All India Day of the 9th is a crime then I confess, I am the arch criminal.
('76', 427, 19, 34, 825291) With kindest regards,
('76', 427, 20, 35, 825313) The Indian Annual Register, 1939, Vol. II, pp.
('76', 427, 21, 36, 825360) 1 Vide “Notes Congress A Fetish”, 2 3 1922.

('76', 428, 1, 2, 825448) APPENDIX IX CONGRESS PRESIDENT’S DECLARATION 1
('76', 428, 2, 3, 825495) July 6, 1939
('76', 428, 3, 4, 825508) I have been much surprised to read in the papers Shri Subhas Chandra Bose’s statement fixing the 9th July for protesting against resolutions passed by the All India Congress Committee at Bombay.
('76', 428, 3, 5, 825703) It is well known that the resolution was passed after prolonged debate by a very large majority against the opposition of Shri Subhas Chandra Bose.
('76', 428, 3, 6, 825851) If Committees subordinate to the All India Congress Committee and office bearers of such Committees or minorities within the Congress begin to defy such resolution and organize and hold protest meetings against decisions arrived at after full deliberation by the All India Congress Committee or the Congress, there will be an end to all discipline within the Congress and a complete disruption of the organization.
('76', 428, 3, 7, 826266) I therefore desire to impress on all Congress Committees and their office bearers that the policy and practice of the Congress no less than loyalty to the Congress organization require that they should carry out and give effect to the resolutions passed by the All India Congress Committee, and participation in and organizing of protests and condemnation against such resolution will be a breach of discipline.
('76', 428, 3, 8, 826678) I trust the Congress Committees and their office bearers will desist from organizing or participating in such protests and demons trations.
('76', 428, 4, 9, 826818) The Indian Annual Register, 1939, Vol. II, p.
