('76', 429, 3, 8, 828228) APPENDIX XI
('76', 429, 4, 9, 828240) CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE RESOLUTION 1
('76', 429, 5, 10, 828280) The Working Committee have given their earnest consideration to the critical
('76', 429, 6, 11, 828357) international situation and to the danger of war that overhangs the world.
('76', 429, 6, 12, 828432) In this
('76', 429, 7, 13, 828440) world crisis the sympathies of the Working Committee are entirely with the people
('76', 429, 8, 14, 828522) who stand for democracy and freedom, and the Congress has repeatedly condemned
('76', 429, 9, 15, 828601) Fascist aggression in Europe, Africa and the Far East of Asia as well as the betrayal of
('76', 429, 10, 16, 828690) democracy by British imperialism in Czechoslovakia and Spain.
('76', 429, 10, 17, 828752) The Congress has
('76', 429, 11, 18, 828769) further clearly enunciated its policy in the event of war and declared its determination
('76', 429, 12, 19, 828858) to oppose all attempts to impose a war on India.
('76', 429, 12, 20, 828907) The Committee are bound by this
('76', 429, 13, 21, 828939) policy of the Congress and will give effect to it so as to prevent the exploitation of
('76', 429, 14, 22, 829026) Indian resources for imperialist ends.
('76', 429, 14, 23, 829065) The past policy of the British Government as
('76', 429, 15, 24, 829110) well as the recent developments demonstrate abundantly that this Government does
('76', 429, 16, 25, 829191) not stand for freedom and democracy and may at any time betray these ideals.
('76', 429, 17, 26, 829268) cannot associate herself with such a Government or be asked to give her resources for
('76', 429, 18, 27, 829354) democratic freedom which is denied to her and which is likely to be betrayed.
('76', 429, 19, 28, 829432) At its meeting held in Calcutta on May 1, 1939, the All India Congress Committee reiterated this policy of the Congress and expressed its disapproval of the despatch of Indian troops to foreign countries.
('76', 429, 19, 29, 829637) In spite of this clear expression of opinion, the British Government has sent, or is sending Indian troops to Egypt and Singapore against the declared will of the Indian people.
('76', 429, 19, 30, 829815) Even apart from the war situation, the Central Legislative Assembly has previously declared that no Indian troops should be sent abroad without the consent of the Legislature.
('76', 429, 19, 31, 829991) The British Government has thus flouted the declaration of the Congress and the Assembly and
('76', 429, 20, 32, 830084) 1Vide “Statement to the Press”, 23 9 1939; 28 9 1939; 18 10 1939; “A Statement”, 20 9 1939; “Unconditional Support?”, 30 10 1939 and “Congress Working Committee Resolution”, 22 11 1939.
('76', 430, 0, 1, 830270) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 431
('76', 430, 1, 2, 830314) has taken steps which might inevitably lead to India’s entanglement in a war.
('76', 430, 1, 3, 830392) It has further prolonged the life of the Central Assembly by another year.
('76', 430, 1, 4, 830467) The Working Committee cannot accept these decisions of the British Government and must not only dissociate themselves from them but also take such steps as may be necessary to give effect to the Congress members of the Central Legislative Assembly to refrain from attending the next session of the Assembly.
('76', 430, 2, 5, 830775) The Committee further remind Provincial Governments to assist in no way the war preparations of the British Government and to keep in mind the policy laid down by the Congress, to which they must adhere.
('76', 430, 2, 6, 830979) If the carrying out of this policy leads to the resignations or removal of the Congress Ministers they must be prepared for this contingency.
('76', 430, 3, 7, 831121) In the event of a war crisis leading to danger to any part of India from the air or otherwise it may be necessary for protective measures to be taken.
('76', 430, 3, 8, 831272) The Committee will be prepared to encourage such measures if they are within the control of the popular Ministries in the Provinces.
('76', 430, 3, 9, 831405) The Committee are however not agreeable to such protective measures being used as a cloak for war preparations under the control of the Imperial Government.
('76', 430, 4, 10, 831562) The Indian Annual Register, 1939, Vol, II, pp.
('76', 430, 5, 11, 831609) APPENDIX XII LETTER FROM YADAVINDRA SINGH 1
('76', 430, 6, 12, 831653) RANBIR VILLA, CHAIL,
('76', 430, 7, 13, 831674) September 9, 1939 DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('76', 430, 8, 14, 831709) I thank you for your letter dated the 30th ultimo enclosing a copy of the letter reported to have been despatched to me on the 3rd August which, as I intimated you in my telegram dated 28th ultimo, was never received by me.
('76', 430, 8, 15, 831933) I was somewhat surprised to learn of the publication in the vernacular Press of the letter from your correspondent together with your comments and was inclined to think that since you did not consider it worthwhile to await my reply before releasing to the Press your correspondent’s letter, it was unnecessary for me to reply to your letter.
('76', 430, 8, 16, 832276) However, I have since received your message conveyed through my vakil at Simla informing that whereas an intimation had been given in time to the English Press to withhold publication of this matter, owing to rush of work similar instructions could not be conveyed to the vernacular Press.
('76', 430, 8, 17, 832566) I am, indeed, thankful to you for intimating me that the comments that have already appeared in the vernacular Press will be revised or withdrawn in case it was considered necessary on receipt of my reply.
('76', 430, 9, 18, 832772) 1 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 23 9 1939and “Remarks on A Maharaja’s Threat”, 12 9 1939. Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('76', 431, 0, 1, 832898) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 431, 1, 2, 832940) Your correspondent’s letter deals with two issues, namely, (a) the Hidayat of 1988 and (b) the threatening language alleged to have been used by me during the course of an interview I gave to the deputation that waited upon me on the 18th July.
('76', 431, 2, 3, 833185) The main criticism against the Hidayat has been that since it was intended to
('76', 431, 3, 4, 833263) meet a special situation, its retention as a permanent law of the land was not justifiable.
('76', 431, 3, 5, 833355) The communal disturbances, as you will agree, were precisely the kind of special situation to meet which the Government have to keep themselves armed with such special legislation.
('76', 431, 3, 6, 833536) It will appear, therefore, that it is the abuse, by those who were responsible for disturbing intercommunal harmony, of the liberty conferred on them, which was responsible for the subsequent order enjoining the enforcement of the provisions of the Hidayat.
('76', 431, 3, 7, 833794) The fact that this unfortunate occurrence rendered it necessary for me to invoke the provisions of the Hidayat, was appreciated even by
('76', 431, 4, 8, 833930) those who had earlier organized agitation against this enactment, as is evident from their voluntary decision to abide by the order issued by me on the 25th of May.
('76', 431, 4, 9, 834095) The period for which the enforcement of the Hidayat was enjoined is not yet over;
('76', 431, 5, 10, 834177) however, as the communal situation has since eased considerably and I have exercised clemency and withdrawn cases against those involved in this communal clash.
('76', 431, 5, 11, 834338) I would have considered the desirability of revising the provisions of the Hidayat, but
('76', 431, 6, 12, 834426) as you are aware, war has since broken out and while for the successful prosecution thereof emergency measures curtailing civic rights and liberties are being enforced, this emergency legislation has of necessity to be retained on the statute book.
('76', 431, 6, 13, 834675) I have not the least intention of going back over the assurance that was given by the District Nazim, Sunam, but I am obliged to await more favourable circumstances to do the needful.
('76', 431, 7, 14, 834859) As regards the version of what transpired at the interview I gave to the depu tation on the 18th July, I am sorry your correspondent has twisted what I told the deputationists and his letter contains several half truths and mis statements.
('76', 431, 7, 15, 835099) I had assured them that while I was most anxious to redress the genuine grievances of my subjects, I did not approve of their being misled by those who were actuated by motives not wholly impersonal.
('76', 431, 7, 16, 835299) I do not precisely remember the words I used, but I think I told them that I would readily respond to all legitimate wishes of my people but would not be intimidated by any agitation engineered by those not directly interested in the points at issue nor would I accept any dictation from any outside agency.
('76', 431, 7, 17, 835607) In view of what I have stated above, I feel your comments that have appeared in the vernacular Press do not seem to be called for and I trust you will be good enough to withdraw them.
('76', 431, 7, 18, 835791) I thank you for the courtesy you have shown me in inviting my comments on your correspondent’s letter.
('76', 431, 7, 19, 835894) Yours sincerely, YADAVINDRA SINGH Harijan, 16 9 1939
('76', 432, 0, 1, 835947) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 433
('76', 432, 1, 2, 835991) APPENDIX XIII
('76', 432, 2, 3, 836005) WORKING COMMITTEE’S MANIFESTO 1
('76', 432, 3, 4, 836037) 1. The Working Committee have given their earnest consideration to the
('76', 432, 4, 5, 836108) grave crisis that has developed owing to the declaration of war in Europe.
('76', 432, 5, 6, 836183) principles which should guide the nation in the event of war have been repeatedly laid
('76', 432, 6, 7, 836270) down by the Congress, and only a month ago this Committee reiterated them and
('76', 432, 7, 8, 836348) expressed their displeasure at the flouting of Indian opinion by the British Govern 
('76', 432, 8, 9, 836433) ment in India.
('76', 432, 8, 10, 836448) As a first step to dissociate themselves from this policy of the British
('76', 432, 9, 11, 836521) Government, the Committee called upon the congress members of the Central Legis 
('76', 432, 10, 12, 836602) lative Assembly to refrain from attending the next session.
('76', 432, 10, 13, 836662) Since then the British
('76', 432, 11, 14, 836685) Government have declared India as a belligerent country, promulgated ordinances,
('76', 432, 12, 15, 836766) passed the Government of India Act Amending Bill, and taken other far reaching
('76', 432, 13, 16, 836845) measures which affect the Indian people vitally, and circumscribe and limit the
('76', 432, 14, 17, 836925) powers and the activities of the Provincial Governments.
('76', 432, 14, 18, 836982) This has been done without
('76', 432, 15, 19, 837009) the consent of the Indian people whose declared wishes in such matters have been
('76', 432, 16, 20, 837090) deliberately ignored by the British Government.
('76', 432, 16, 21, 837138) The Working Committee must take
('76', 432, 17, 22, 837170) the gravest view of these developments.
('76', 432, 18, 23, 837210) 2. The Congress has repeatedly declared its entire disapproval of the ideology and practice of Fascism and Nazism and their glorification of war and violence and the suppression of the human spirit.
('76', 432, 18, 24, 837409) It has condemned the aggression in which they have repeatedly indulged and their sweeping away of well established principles and recognized standards of civilized behaviour.
('76', 432, 18, 25, 837584) It has seen in Fascism and Nazism the intensification of the principle of imperialism against which the Indian people have struggled for many years.
('76', 432, 18, 26, 837733) The Working Committee must therefore unhesitatingly condemn the latest aggression of the Nazi Government in Germany against Poland and sympathize with those who resist it.
('76', 432, 19, 27, 837905) 3. The Congress has further laid down that the issue of war and peace for India must be decided by the Indian people, and no outside authority can impose this decision upon them nor can the Indian people permit their resources to be exploited for imperialist ends.
('76', 432, 19, 28, 838170) Any imposed decision, or attempt to use Indian resources, for purposes not approved by them, will necessarily have to be opposed by them.
('76', 432, 19, 29, 838308) If co operation is desired in a worthy cause, this cannot be obtained by compulsion and imposition, and the Committee cannot agree to the carrying out by the Indian people of orders issued by external authority.
('76', 432, 19, 30, 838520) Co operation must be between equals by mutual
('76', 432, 20, 31, 838566) 1 Vide“ A Statement”, 20 9 1939; Statement to the Press”, 15 9 1939; 28 9 1939; 18 10 1939; “The Only Way”, 19 11 1939 and “Congress Working Committee Resolution”, 22 11 1939.
('76', 433, 0, 1, 838742) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 433, 1, 2, 838784) consent for a cause which both consider to be worthy.
('76', 433, 1, 3, 838838) The people of India have in the recent past, faced great risks and willingly made great sacrifices to secure their own freedom and establish a free democratic State in India, and their sympathy is entirely on the side of democracy and freedom.
('76', 433, 1, 4, 839082) But India cannot associate herself in a war said to be for democratic freedom when that very freedom is denied to her, and such limited freedom as she possesses taken away from her.
('76', 433, 2, 5, 839264) 4. The Committee are aware that the Governments of Great Britain and France have declared that they are fighting for democracy and freedom and to put an end to aggression.
('76', 433, 2, 6, 839436) But the history of the recent past is full of examples showing the constant divergence between the spoken word, the ideals proclaimed and the real motives and objectives.
('76', 433, 2, 7, 839607) During the war of 1914 18, the declared war aims were the preservation of democracy, self determination and the freedom of small nations, and yet the very Governments which solemnly proclaimed these aims entered into secret treaties embodying imperialist designs for the carving up of the Ottoman Empire.
('76', 433, 2, 8, 839912) While stating that they did not want any acquisition of territory, the victorious Powers added largely to their colonial domains.
('76', 433, 2, 9, 840042) The present European war itself signifies the abject failure of the Treaty of Versailles and of its makers, who broke their pledged word and imposed an imperialist peace on the defeated nations.
('76', 433, 2, 10, 840237) The one hopeful outcome of that Treaty, the League of Nations, was muzzled and strangled at the outset and later killed by its parent States.
('76', 433, 3, 11, 840379) 5. Subsequent history has demonstrated afresh how even a seemingly fervent declaration of faith may be followed by an ignoble desertion.
('76', 433, 3, 12, 840516) In Manchuria the British Government connived at aggression; in Abyssinia they acquiesced in it.
('76', 433, 3, 13, 840612) In Czechoslovakia and Spain democracy was in peril and it was deliberately betrayed, and the whole system of collective security was sabotaged by the very Powers who had previously declared their firm faith in it.
('76', 433, 4, 14, 840826) 6. Again it is asserted that democracy is in danger and must be defended, and with this statement the Committee are in entire agreement.
('76', 433, 4, 15, 840963) The Committee believe that thepeoples of the West are moved by this ideal and objective and for these they are prepared to make sacrifices.
('76', 433, 4, 16, 841103) But again and again the ideals and sentiments of the people and of those who have sacrificed themselves in the struggle have been ignored and faith has not been kept with them.
('76', 433, 5, 17, 841280) 7. If the war is to defend the status quo—imperialist possessions, colonies, vested interests and privileges—then India can have nothing to do with it.
('76', 433, 5, 18, 841432) If, however, the issue is democracy and a world order based on democracy, then India is intensely interested in it.
('76', 433, 5, 19, 841548) The Committee are convinced that the interests of Indian democracy do not conflict with the interests of British democracy or of world democracy.
('76', 433, 5, 20, 841694) But there is an inherent and ineradicable conflict between democracy for India or elsewhere and imperialism and Fascism.
('76', 433, 5, 21, 841815) If Great Britain fights for the maintenance and extension of democracy, then she must necessarily end imperialism in her own possessions, establish full democracy in India, and the Indian people must
('76', 434, 0, 1, 842015) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 435
('76', 434, 1, 2, 842059) have the right of self determination by framing their own constitution through a Constituent Assembly without external interference, and must guide their own policy.
('76', 434, 1, 3, 842225) A free, democratic India will gladly associate herself with other free nations for mutual defence against aggression and for economic co operation.
('76', 434, 1, 4, 842373) She will work for the establishment of a real world order based on freedom and democracy, utilizing the world’s knowledge and resources for the progress and advancement of humanity.
('76', 434, 2, 5, 842555) 8. The crisis that has overtaken Europe is not of Europe only but of humanity
('76', 434, 3, 6, 842633) and will not pass like other crises or wars leaving te essential structure of the present 
('76', 434, 4, 7, 842724) day world intact.
('76', 434, 4, 8, 842742) It is likely to refashion the world for good or ill, politically,
('76', 434, 5, 9, 842808) socially and economically.
('76', 434, 5, 10, 842835) This crisis is the inevitable consequence of the social and
('76', 434, 6, 11, 842895) political conflicts and contradictions which have grown alarmingly since the last
('76', 434, 7, 12, 842977) great war, and it will not be finally resolved till these conflicts and contradictions are
('76', 434, 8, 13, 843068) removed and a new equilibrium established.
('76', 434, 8, 14, 843111) That equilibrium can only be based on the
('76', 434, 9, 15, 843153) ending of the domination and exploitation of one country by another, and on a
('76', 434, 10, 16, 843231) reorganization of economic relations on a juster basis for the common good of all.
('76', 434, 11, 17, 843314) India is the crux of the problem, for India has been the outstanding example of
('76', 434, 12, 18, 843394) modern imperialism, and no refashioning of the world can succeed which ignores this
('76', 434, 13, 19, 843478) vital problem.
('76', 434, 13, 20, 843493) With her vast resources she must play an important part in any scheme
('76', 434, 14, 21, 843563) of world recognization.
('76', 434, 14, 22, 843587) But she can only do so as a free nation whose energies have
('76', 434, 15, 23, 843647) been released to work for this great end.
('76', 434, 15, 24, 843689) Freedom today is indivisible and every
('76', 434, 16, 25, 843728) attempt to retain imperialist domination in any part of the world will lead inevitably
('76', 434, 17, 26, 843815) to fresh disaster.
('76', 434, 18, 27, 843834) 9. The Working Committee have noted that many Rulers of Indian States have offered their services and resources and expressed their desire to support the cause of democracy in Europe.
('76', 434, 18, 28, 844018) If they must make their professions in favour of democracy abroad, the Committee would suggest that their first concern should be the introduction of democracy within their own States in which today undiluted autocracy reigns supreme.
('76', 434, 18, 29, 844253) The British Government in India is more responsible for this autocracy than even the Rulers themselves, as has been made painfully evident during the past year.
('76', 434, 18, 30, 844414) This policy is the very negation of democracy and of the new world order for which Great Britain claims to be fighting in Europe.
('76', 434, 19, 31, 844544) 10. As the Working Committee view past events in Europe, Africa and Asia, and more particularly past and present occurrences in India, they fail to find any attempt to advance the cause of democracy or self determination, or any evidence that the present war declarations of the British Government are being, or are going to be, acted upon.
('76', 434, 19, 32, 844885) The true measure of democracy is the ending of imperialism and Fascism alike and the aggression that has accompanied them in the past and the present.
('76', 434, 19, 33, 845036) Only on that basis can a new order be built up.
('76', 434, 19, 34, 845084) In the struggle for that new world order, the Committee are eager and desirous to help in every way.
('76', 434, 19, 35, 845185) But the Committee cannot associate themselves or offer any co operation in a war which is conducted on
('76', 435, 0, 1, 845288) 436 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('76', 435, 1, 2, 845330) imperialist lines and which is meant to consolidate imperialism in India and elsewhere.
('76', 435, 2, 3, 845418) 11. In view, however, of the gravity of the occasion and the fact that the pace of events during the last few days has often been swifter than the working of men’s minds, the Committee desire to take no final decision at this stage, so as to allow for the full elucidation of the issues at stake, the real objectives aimed at, and the position of India in the present and in the future.
('76', 435, 2, 4, 845805) But the decision cannot long be delayed as India is being committed from day to day to a policy to which she is not a party and of which she disapproves.
('76', 435, 3, 5, 845959) 12. The Working Committee therefore invite the British Government to declare in unequivocal terms what their war aims are in regard to democracy and imperialism and the new order that is envisaged, in particular, how these aims are going to apply to India and to be given effect to in the present.
('76', 435, 3, 6, 846257) Do they include the elimination of imperialism and the treatment of India as a free nation whose policy will be guided in accordance with the wishes of her people?
('76', 435, 3, 7, 846421) A clear declaration about the future, pledging the Government to the ending of imperialism and Fascism alike, will be welcomed by the people of all countries, but it is far more important to give immediate effect to it, to the largest possible extent, for only this will convince the people that the declaration is meant to be honoured.
('76', 435, 3, 8, 846758) The real test of any declaration is its application in the present, for it is the present that will govern action today and give shape to the future.
('76', 435, 4, 9, 846908) 13. War has broken out in Europe and the prospect is terrible to contemplate.
('76', 435, 4, 10, 846986) But war has been taking its heavy toll of human life during the past year in Abyssinia, Spain and China.
('76', 435, 4, 11, 847091) Innumerable innocent men, women and children have been bombed to death from the air in open cities, cold blooded massacres, torture and utmost humiliation have followed each other in quick succession during these years of horror.
('76', 435, 4, 12, 847321) That horror grows, and violence and the threat of violence shadow the world, unless checked and ended, will destroy the precious inheritance of past ages.
('76', 435, 4, 13, 847476) That horror has to be chcked in Europe and China, but it will not end till its root causes of Fascism and imperialism are removed.
('76', 435, 4, 14, 847607) To that end, the Working Committee are prepared to give their co operation.
('76', 435, 4, 15, 847683) But it will be infinite tragedy if even this terrible war is carried on in the spirit of imperialism and for the purpose of retaining this stucture which is itself the cause of war and human degradation.
('76', 435, 5, 16, 847887) 14. The Working Committee wish to declare that the Indian people have no quarrel with the German people or the Japanese people or any other people.
('76', 435, 5, 17, 848035) But they have a deep rooted quarrel with systems which deny freedom and are based on violence and aggression.
('76', 435, 5, 18, 848145) They do not look forward to a victory of one people over another or to a dictated peace, but to a victory of real democracy for all the people of all countries and a world freed from the nightmare of violence and imperialist oppression.
('76', 435, 6, 19, 848382) 15. The Committee earnestly appeal to the Indian people to end all internal conflict and controversy and, in this grave hour of peril, to keep in readiness and hold
('76', 436, 0, 1, 848547) VOL. 76 : 31 MAY, 1939 15 OCTOBER, 1939 437
('76', 436, 1, 2, 848591) together as a united nation, calm of purpose and determined to achieve the freedom of India within the larger freedom of the world.
('76', 436, 2, 3, 848723) WARDHA, September 14, 1939
('76', 436, 3, 4, 848750) Harijan, 23 9 1939
('76', 436, 4, 5, 848769) APPENDIX XIV
('76', 436, 5, 6, 848782) A. I. C. C. RESOLUTION 1
('76', 436, 6, 7, 848807) The declaration of war in Europe has created an international situation of the
('76', 436, 7, 8, 848886) gravest import to the world and to India, and the A. I. C. C., charged with the heavy
('76', 436, 8, 9, 848972) responsibility of guiding the people of India in this moment of world crisis, has
('76', 436, 9, 10, 849054) sought guidance from the principles and declarations of the Congress in considering
('76', 436, 10, 11, 849138) this grave situation.
